fields.headline: The hot Christmas books
fields.standfirst:
The Return of the Naked Chef by Jamie Oliver | How to be a Domestic Goddess by Nigella Lawson | A History of Britain by Simon Schama | The Beatles Anthology | The Truth by Terry Pratchet
Each condensed in the style of the original
fields.trailText: From Simon Schama to Jamie Oliver, those must-have stocking fillers each condensed in the style of the originals
fields.body:
The Return of the Naked Chef by Jamie Oliver (Michael Joseph £20)
Buy it at BOL

Grub. It's what you eat, right? Wrong. It's about ripping up some bread and getting something down ya after a night out with your mates getting tanked up down the boozer. So don't ponce about trying to make it look good. Get stuck in and make it taste good.

Hats off to those diamond geezers at Penguin for giving us a shed load of dosh. Respec. Like, this book is massively different from the first; I'm still naked as in bare essentials, but this time I'm going to be using some new fantastic ingredients you can get from any Sainsbury's.

Grab a dish. Don't bother washing it if it's still got yesterday's slop in. Sling in some coriander, lemon grass and chillies. Put a quid in the meter and turn on the gas. Pull the head off a chicken and dump the rest into the swill. Don't get all arsey about a few feathers. Pass out. Take off the heat when you come round. Phwooar. Smell that. Luvverly jubberly. Bish bosh, give me more dosh.

And if you really are pressed: the digested read, digested Essex boy serves up a second helping of down-to-earth cuisine to be consumed as the last word in designer trustafarian chic.

How to be a Domestic Goddess by Nigella Lawson (Chatto £25)
Buy it at BOL

Take one posh woman and add a soupçon of relaxed classlessness. Remove all signs of the nanny and cleaning staff from the pictures and cut in soundtrack of happy children engaged in creative play and well-heeled groovy friends just "dropping in" for those artlessly casual midweek dinner parties. Install industrial-sized designer kitchen with armoury of stainless-steel utensils.

Plunder recipes found on holiday at delightful out-of-the-way restaurants in Tuscany and Brittany and toss in a few from your fabulous mother-in-law, Carrie, to create that authentic homey feel of a diva trailing nutmeggy fumes of baking pie in her languorous wake.

While it is baking, apply lippy in readiness for an endless succession of lifestyle interviews. Appear graciously bewildered by the attention. Take from the oven and allow to cool to a warm glow of satisfaction at turning base elements into a pure-gold bestseller. That wasn't so very hard, was it?

The digested read, digested Cakes, biccies, pies and puds from the newly crowned queen of kitchen kitsch.

A History of Britain by Simon Schama (BBC £20)
Buy it at BOL

History clings tight, but it also kicks loose. Disruption as much as persistence is its proper subject, so if endurance was the great theme of the 20th century, then alteration must be that of the 21st. Both the Churchillian version of a Britain steeped in Empire, and a socialist one with organised labour at its centre, have fallen deeply out of favour. Instead, view history as flux, where consummation in a unitary whole is but one epoch in our islands' evolution.

Follow me, then, through the remote eddies of Orcadian life 5,000 years ago to the fugitive Alfred - a legend in the bullrush-choked swamps of Athelney; from the apocalypse of William's march north in 1069 to the pestilence of King Death in 1348; feel the ghosts of the martyrs of the Reformation and share in the miracle of the not-so-barren Virgin Queen, who brought forth from her body politic, the greatest fruit of all Magna Britannia: Great Britain.

The digested read, digested Britain's best-known expat historian provides all the answers to those million-pound questions.

The Beatles Anthology (Cassell £35)
Buy it at BOL

Paul: Decca must be kicking themselves for turning us down.

Ringo: I wasn't told about John and Cyn's wedding.

John: We didn't keep it a secret.

George: We had four hits in '63.

Paul: I wanted "McCartney/Lennon".

John: Paul and I saw eye-to-eye musically.

Ringo: I'm still here.

George: The first time we took LSD was an accident. We were the innocent victims of a wicked dentist.

John: I must have had a thousand trips.

Paul: Most people thought we deserved our MBEs.

Ringo: Did I tell you about the time...?

George: Hare Krishna, Hare Krishna...

Paul: John once admitted that one of my songs was better than his.

John: Sex is the only physical thing I can be bothered with.

Ringo: I once...

George: In the big picture, it doesn't matter if we never made a record or sang a song.

Paul: Linda was nicer than Yoko.

All together: All we need is cash.

The digested read, digested The Fab Four plod relentlessly through the anoraks of history.

The Truth: Terry Pratchett (Doubleday £16.99)
Buy it at BOL

"You will work with the dwarves to produce a newsletter," said Lord Vetinari, the Patrician of Ankh-Morpork.

"Er. Is that a proper job?" enquired William de Worde.

"The truth shall make you fret," said Sacharissa, his assistant.

"That's our first misprint."

"Vould you like a votograffer?" asked Otto, the recovering vampire.

"You could print pictures of my curious vegetables," Mr Dibbler added.

"But it's not the truth."

"No. But it sells newspapers."

"We want you to cause problems for the Patrician," said the zombie lawyer.

"It'll cost you," replied Mr Tulip.

"Too ****ing right," agreed Mr Pin.

"Vetinari has been charged with attempted murder," said Vimes, chief of the Watch.

"I suspect foul play," said William to the dwarves. "Why has Wuffles the dog gone missing?"

"I've been in touch with Wuffles," whispered Deep Bone.

"Let me speak to him through a werewolf interpreter," pleaded William.

"Oh no you don't," butted in Mr Tulip and Mr Pin, before they were impaled on the newspaper spike.

"So Vetinari was framed and it was the Times wot got him off," said William.

"Amazing how there's always just enough news to fill the paper," commented Vetinari.

The digested read, digested Ankh-Morpork gets an almost free press and reluctantly lets the truth get in the way of a good story.

webTitle: Holloway looks to get out of jail in Bristol derby

fields.headline: Holloway looks to get out of jail in Bristol derby
fields.standfirst: Rovers go into tonight's game at Ashton Gate as the city's second best
fields.trailText: David Foot reports as Bristol Rovers face tonight's derby clash at Ashton Gate as the city's second best.
fields.body:
For Bristol Rovers it was the worst possible prelude to tonight's tribal clash with City at Ashton Gate. After the club's 3-0 home defeat by Stoke on Saturday, there was an aura of almost funereal gloom about the place.

An initial whisper at the ground that Ian Holloway, still only 37, had offered his resignation as manager took on a crescendo of speculation and rumour. For virtually the first time since he took on the job in 1996 he failed to turn up at the press conference. Instead he sent his coach Garry Thompson to field the questions, castigate the team and diplomatically skirt round the manager's absence.

It was a dreadful day for Holloway. He saw his defence donate a first-half hat-trick to Peter Thorne. He got into a verbal altercation with a spectator near the dugout and the fans barracked him at the end, noisily indicting his tactics, his formations and his team selections.

Up to now it has seemed like sacrilege to imply criticism of him. He watched Rovers as a boy, played his heart out for them for nine seasons and is utterly immersed in the club's homely, deeply ingrained culture.

His early years in charge were tentative with some understandable naivety. But he acknowledged his mistakes and what he said became increasingly reasoned and authoritative.

He bought himself a pin-stripe suit, worked hard at man management and gathered round him a small inner staff, most of whom had Rovers playing links. He was not averse to a touch of the unorthodox and on one occasion read some poetry to his players before kick-off.

His relationship with players also hardened. He said: "The players often looked on me as Olly the joker, ready to join in the banter around the dressing room. But maybe I've got to learn how to stand back." He did that last weekend. Taciturn he may have been, yet he made sure his team, outplayed by Stoke, would report for extra training on Sunday morning.

There has been some tension around the club this week. Holloway hopes that a meeting tonight with the regional enemy will provide its own motivation. Rovers have not won at home this season and are perilously close to the relegation zone. Their plight would be even more marked if City beat them.

Holloway admits he is hurt by the recent taunts but has no intention of resigning from the only job he ever wanted: "I've four years left on my contract and I am prepared to see it out."

The financial constraints, however, imposed by a club who are among the most canny housekeepers in the country, often leaves him frustrated and one suspects there have been words with the directors.

Many of the supporters are still not sure why Rovers' two leading strikers, Jamie Cureton and Jason Roberts, were allowed to leave at the end of last season and why the high-scoring Bobby Zamora, who failed to make his full Rovers debut, slipped away to Brighton.

City start as clear favourites, though it is uncertain how their young players, who have emerged successfully from the Ashton Gate academy, will cope with the derby cauldron.

Their manager Danny Wilson has rapidly become a favourite in the West Country. He wears a saturnine expression, reveals himself as the kind of pragmatist City need and has the advantage of the experienced and wise Frank Barlow as his No2. However, this will be his first experience of raw Bristol rivalry.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

webTitle: Deadly dug his own hole but he is right to hold tight

fields.headline: Deadly dug his own hole but he is right to hold tight
fields.trailText: I get asked a lot why so many people take an instant dislike to Doug Ellis. My answer is that it saves time. But I have to say, he is doing the right thing at the moment.
fields.body:
I get asked a lot why so many people take an instant dislike to Doug Ellis. My answer is that it saves time. But, while there is no love lost between me and my one-time chairman, we do share a great affection for Aston Villa and I must say I back the stance he's taking right now.

Villa fans are calling for vast amounts to be spent on the team but, with the transfer market in a state of flux, I would see it as irresponsible to pay outrageous fees. A few months down the line a signing could have his value slashed. Only Leeds seem to be spending massive money.

That is not to say Villa shouldn't buy, and John Gregory is about to get Colombia's Juan Pablo Angel for around £10m. That's a massive gamble and a lot of money for somebody who doesn't have a recognised international pedigree.

To take this very useful Villa side to the next level Gregory needs the best but who is there? I know that Fabrizio Ravanelli was available on a free transfer a few months ago. Someone like that, over a short period, might have filled the void.

Angel's arrival may well dampen the anti-Ellis feeling at Villa. But what is certain is that the fans who want him to quit haven't got a chance. The only way he'll go is if they carry him out feet first.

There is a perception that Doug Ellis is tight-fisted but in my experience, if you could justify a transfer, he would back you by and large. At times, though, he could be impulsive and beg you to buy players when you didn't need any and at other times he would dither.

I remember him telling me just before I finished the job in 1994: "Go and buy somebody." I told him we didn't need anybody, that the team would pull round and he should save his money to compete for the best players the next summer. I had in mind people like Les Ferdinand, who was top of the range and went to Newcastle.

At the other end of the scale he messed around after I had agreed a deal with Liverpool for Dean Saunders. It was obvious we needed a striker to make us a decent team and I had set everything up with Graeme Souness. But the transfer went through about three weeks later because Doug Ellis was trying to deal and counter-deal. In the end it was virtually the same as we had agreed in the first place.

Even if Angel joins, John Gregory apparently wants a couple more players. It may be that he'll have to use those wheeling and dealing abilities he needed at the lower end of management with Wycombe. John appears to have a team with an awful lot of very good midfield players and may have to trade one or two to get bodies in.

I questioned the signing of David Ginola from the start. That has nothing to do with ability because I'm Ginola's biggest fan. But to utilise him fully I think he has to be played on the wing, providing crosses Dion Dublin can thrive on, as we saw against Manchester City on Saturday.

Villa, though, do not play with wingers, more with wing-backs, and, if you don't put him on the wing, you have to use him in a free role, and Merson already does that job.

It may be that the money there would have been better used elsewhere, although I'm not too sure who bought the player. Rumour has it that what started the ball rolling was Doug Ellis meeting Ginola on holday in Mauritius over the summer.

Not that I ever found him interfering; I never let him. He was very good at getting the stadium organised when I was there. That took up about £6m a summer and restricted buying but I understood that.

I'm sure the flak he has taken will have hurt him. Doug is very sensitive to criticism. He likes to think of himself as Mr Aston Villa, the man of the people, whereas my love of the Villa stems from the fact that they were the team I supported as a boy.

I was watching television and had to smile when all of a sudden he went missing when Villa went 2-1 down to City. Whether he had a cold and had gone to watch from his boardroom, which he can do, I don't know. But I couldn't help thinking that, if they had gone 2-1 up, he wouldn't have disappeared.

For all the criticism, Ellis has done some good. Villa Park is a marvellous stadium. In his eyes it will be a monument to him. The standing joke was that he named one stand The Doug Ellis Stand so that, when he was knighted, it could quickly be altered to Sir Doug Ellis Stand.

Certainly his decision to sack me wasn't just a footballing one. We had a personality clash. I don't think he liked it much that I was popular with the fans, nor that after a game my little bar near the dressing room was packed with football people. He had this massive boardroom and I think he wanted to be part of the magic circle.

The only time we've spoken since was in a television studio about three years ago. He came over in his manner to say something and I told him where to go. It didn't go down too well with him because Gareth Southgate and Andy Townsend were with me. Now if we see one another we stay well away. It's mutual hate. But I'm with him on this one.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

webTitle: Arms and the fan - the Italian culture

fields.headline: Arms and the fan - the Italian culture
fields.standfirst: Gun and bomb are the latest accessories. Paddy Agnew in Rome reports
fields.trailText: Orchestrated instances of violence, racism and unruly behaviour are growing in Italian football. Gun and bomb are the latest accessories, as Paddy Agnew in Rome reports.
fields.body:
Two weeks ago the 19-year-old referee Flavio Nucci was getting ready to handle a match between the Puglia amateur sides San Cassiano and Ruffiano when a masked man entered his dressing room, produced a gun and stuck it up against Nucci's chest. He told him to make sure Ruffiano won.

The young referee subsequently reported the matter to the police and football authorities, resulting in a 19-year-old student called Ivan Pentassuglia being charged with armed aggression.

A week after the San Cassiano incident violence of a different sort emerged when police had to be called in to break up a mass bust-up involving the parents of two Roman under-13 teams, Fiumicino and Arix, who were playing in a tournament ironically labelled "Fair Play". In this case an alleged case of home-team refereeing prompted the sideline altercations.

In such a context no one could really claim to be all that surprised when Internazionale's team bus was the object of a Molotov cocktail attack last week as it arrived at the Meazza stadium in San Siro for an Italian Cup quarter-final second-leg game against Parma. Fortunately for the players the incendiary device bounced off the windows and exploded on the tarmac, injuring nobody.

However, the incident was serious enough for the Internazionale coach Marco Tardelli to liken it to the infamous

Heysel Stadium deaths prior to the 1985 European Cup final between Juventus and Liverpool in Brussels: "I just cannot accept this type of violence bursting into football. For me, after the Heysel disaster, this is the worst that's ever happened to me in football ... Next thing they'll be shooting at us from the grandstand," said Tardelli.

Nor was the Italian Football Players' Association pleased. The start of matches in this weekend's Serie A and B programmes, beginning with Roma v Juventus tonight, will be delayed by a symbolic 15 minutes as the team captains read a message denouncing the "criminal attack" on the Internazionale bus, calling it "the latest of an ever more frequent series of attacks on players ... and an expression of the violence that afflicts all levels of football".

Violence is, of course, nothing new in Italian football but recent months have suggested that isolated and/or orchestrated instances of violence, racism and unruly behaviour are growing.

If the Internazionale attack was potentially the most dangerous incident so far this season, the most recent came last Monday evening when two huge firecrackers were exploded outside the homes of the Serie B players Daniele Gregori and Alessandro Sbrizzo. The "attacks" were prompted by ongoing fan "disgruntlement" with their Pescara team, who are bottom of the league and currently obliged to train with a police presence.

Yet this was merely the latest act in an increasingly violent season. When Roma were eliminated from the Italian Cup by Atalanta in mid-summer it prompted a number of Romafans to attack "team" players as they arrived at the club's Trigoria training ground. Roma have gone on to enjoy their best season in years and are certain to go into the new year as league leaders.

Success, of course, is no guarantee of fan loyalty as Juventus discovered when they flew into Turin airport hours after their Champions League elimination by the Greek side Panathinaikos in November. Their France midfielder Zinedine Zidane was abused by two fans before the Uruguyan reserve Daniel Fonseca intervened so forcefully that the confrontation descended into fisticuffs.

More recently Napoli's poor start to the season prompted one disgruntled fan to throw a hand-bomb into the garden of the club's part-owner Corrado Ferlaino. The Napoli official got off lightly in comparison with the Serie A side Reggina, whose fans caused such disruption in a 3-0 home defeat by Brescia in November that the referee Pierluigi Collina was forced to suspend the game, with the win being awarded to Brescia by an Italian federation ruling.

Even more worrying, though, were findings of the police investigation into the infamous incident at Lazio's home game against Bari last January when a banner reading "Honour to the Tiger Arkan", in reference to indicted war criminal, the recently deceased Serbian warlord Arkan, was displayed.

The complex issue of violence in Italian football may yet prove itself to be much more than a question of local thuggery, over-excited parents and mindless supporters.

webTitle: All eyes on White Hart Lane

fields.headline: All eyes on White Hart Lane
fields.trailText: Tottenham's new owners Enic yesterday warned fans not to expect massive injections of cash to transform the team's prospects.
fields.body:
As George Graham and Terry Venables prepared for what will be a highly charged meeting between Spurs and Middlesbrough tomorrow, the chairman of one of the clubs already backed by Tottenham's new owners Enic yesterday warned fans not to expect massive injections of cash to transform the team's prospects, writes John Cassy.

Cornelius Sierhuis, the chairman of AEK Athens, claimed that the leisure group had starved his club of cash and the recent revival of the team was only due to investment by his own company, NetMed. Enic bought a stake in AEK three years ago.

"The investment of Enic in Tottenham does not bode well for their supporters," Sierhuis said. "The problem of AEK is to a large extent caused by Enic's ownership of AEK. Their investments in football clubs have failed, with the exception of Vicenza thanks to an exceptionally clever manager, and all largely because of an inability or unwillingness to fund in accordance with their stakes."

A spokesman for Enic dismissed Sierhuis's allegations, saying the company has been the longest-term investor in AEK's history.

Tottenham fans hoping to hear the Enic chief executive Daniel Levy outline a grand plan for the club were left frustrated yesterday because Levy was in the middle of completing another big deal. He is seeking to buy the spread-betting firm Sporting Index as part of his scheme to build a global leisure and sports group.

webTitle: A million sporting chances to beat the odds - or not

fields.headline: A million sporting chances to beat the odds - or not
fields.trailText: Jamie Reid offers his guide to the best odds for 2001.
fields.body:
Manchester United remain firm favourites to win the Premiership at a best-priced 2-9 with Coral and others. Arsenal have been shortened a point to 7-2 following Monday night's draw against Spurs. Liverpool can be backed at 22-1 with the Tote and then it is 150-1 and upwards Leeds and the rest.

Bradford lead the Premiership relegation list at 1-7 generally, with Coventry, experts at last-gasp survival, on 5-6 with Stanley. Derby are 10-11 to go down with Sunderlands. Middlesbrough get an 11-8 quote from the Tote and Manchester City have been trimmed to a top-priced 6-4 with Sunderlands.

Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink, with 11 goals to date, is 3-1 with Surrey to be the Premiership's top goalscorer. Mark Viduka, with 12 strikes, is on offer at 7-2 with the Tote. Thierry Henry, with 10, is 4-1 with Ladbrokes. And Emile Heskey, also with 10, is available at 8-1 with Chandler who are paying a quarter the odds a place on the first three.

Fulham are 1-16 with the Tote to win the First Division title but most firms have closed the book on the Cottagers.

In Scotland Celtic's 10-point lead at the top of the Premiership has seen them cut to 1-4 to win the title with Coral. Rangers are now on offer at 7-2 with Surrey.

Arsenal are 5-1 generally to win the FA Cup, which reaches the third-round stage on Janu ary 6 and 7. Manchester United are available at 11-2 with the Tote and Liverpool at 7-1 with Super Soccer. Leeds and Chelsea are on 9-1 with Hill's and Super Soccer, respectively, while other teams to catch the eye are Spurs at 16-1 with Stanley, West Ham and Ipswich at 25-1 with Stanley and Fulham at 100-1 with Coral.

England are 4-1 with Victor Chandler to finish top of the World Cup qualifying group nine. Germany are 2-9 to win the group with VC. England are 7-4 not to qualify with the Tote and 33-1 generally to win the tournament. Brazil are general ante-post favourites at 5-1 with Argentina on 11-2, France 13-2 and Italy 10-1 in places.

webTitle: A splutter that reaped the whirlwind

fields.headline: A splutter that reaped the whirlwind
fields.standfirst: Richard Williams on how the England coach's exit summed up years of official arrogance and neglect
fields.trailText: Kevin Keegan's exit summed up years of official arrogance and neglect and was one of the moments that made 2000 - not to mention the worst day in the history of English football.
fields.body:
When Kevin Keegan went to bed on October 6, on the eve of what was to be his final battle, he could not rest easy. At the end of a difficult week he had just finished watching with mounting dismay as his strategy for the following day's match against Germany had been torn apart by a quartet of television pundits. He had been called a liar and accused of cowardice. And he knew that his players had been watching, too, on the TV sets in the lounges or in their rooms at Burnham Beeches Hotel. The glad, confident morning on which he had taken the role of England's head coach, barely 18 months earlier, had turned into a wintry twilight.

Over the preceding days, as the England players gathered at Burnham and prepared for the match on the training pitch at Bisham Abbey, his staff had noticed the change in him. The death of his mother 12 days before the match had not just saddened but profoundly depressed him. Doris Keegan, aged 76, died in hospital after suffering a suspected stroke at her home in Armthorpe, the South Yorkshire village where her son had been born and where she had remained since the death of her husband 14 years earlier. There was no surprise when the customary press conference to announce the squad was cancelled.

When reporters arrived at the England squad's hotel in Burnham Beeches, near Maidenhead, the following week for the usual run of pre-match interviews, they found the normally bouncy Keegan in an uncharacteristically tense frame of mind as he approached the opening fixture in England's campaign to qualify for the 2002 World Cup. The coach made his first appearance on Tuesday. On Thursday afternoon he stayed away, allowing David Davies, the FA's executive director, to answer routine inquiries about the fitness of individual players.

What the reporters were not told was that during the afternoon Steven Gerrard, the 20-year-old Liverpool midfield player, had been declared unfit. When a tabloid reporter got wind of the story late on Thursday night and published it in the next morning's paper, his rivals were angered by what was seen as a lack of the sort of candour Keegan had promised when he took over the England job. At his Friday press conference David Lacey, this newspaper's football correspondent, was deputed to express the press's dismay at being led up the garden path. Clearly on edge, Keegan rejected the point, saying that it was not his job to reveal every detail of the team's preparation.

Scorn over selection

A few hours later his feelings about the press were to deteriorate further as he watched that night's edition of Hold The Back Page, Sky Sports' weekly round-table discussion, chaired by Brian Woolnough of the Sun. Keegan's selection of Gareth Southgate, the Aston Villa defender, to replace Gerrard had somehow leaked out, which itself annoyed Keegan, and Woolnough and his guests - Henry Winter of the Daily Telegraph, Oliver Holt of the Times and Steve Curry of the Sunday Times - laid into the decision with varying degrees of scorn.

"Defeat will be devastating for Keegan," the coach heard Woolnough pronounce. Holt accused him of lacking the "bottle" to make a decision between Michael Owen and Andy Cole and, apropos of the Gerrard business, of telling "a stupid lie". Curry observed: "I ceased to be amazed by Kevin's selections long ago," while even the comparatively emollient Winter said: "Maybe the stadium goes and the manager goes as well, and we have to have a clean break."

The next day everything felt bad. London's weather seemed to have plunged straight from an unsatisfactory summer to a premature winter. There was drizzle in the air. At the stadium the multi-storey car-park charge had almost doubled overnight, from £8 for Bob Dylan the previous evening to £15 for England, hardly an accurate reflection of their relative significance.

Wembley's stern old twin-towered façade, upon which the nation was supposed to be gazing fondly for the last time, was virtually obliterated by banners advertising the team's chief sponsor, an insurance company. Inside the stadium the resident disc jockey rehearsed his usual inanities. When Russell Watson came on to bellow a Woolworth's version of Nessun Dorma, flanked by a couple of dribbling fountains, we were told that we were listening to "one of the finest voices this country has ever produced" - the sort of hyperbole that, applied to English footballers, has prefaced so many disappointments.

When the two sets of players emerged from the tunnel for the formal pre-match presentation, they were led by Bobby Charlton and Franz Beckenbauer. This seemed a reminder not so much of England's victory in the 1966 World Cup final as of the far more recent humiliation at the hands of the Germans in the bidding to host the 2006 tournament, in which Charlton and Beckenbauer again went head to head. England were wearing red shirts and white shorts, as they had in the 1966 final, another indication of vulnerability since it suggested that they had more faith in the symbolic voodoo attached to a single event than in the integrity of a tradition embodied by the traditional white and blue.

Germany, who had already played one qualifying match, against Greece, and had earned three points from it, were not looking for glory. "We would have settled for a draw," Dietmar Hamann, their Liverpool midfielder, said this week. But once the game started it was immediately apparent that England had little to offer. After 13 minutes Paul Scholes lost the ball to Michael Ballack and reacted by fouling him in the centre of midfield, 30 yards from goal. Sensing England's slowness in getting themselves organised, Hamann took the free-kick quickly and hit a low but not particularly hard shot that bounced once and skidded past the left hand of the diving David Seaman.

A few seconds after the restart Tony Adams, Keegan's captain, was pulling the 20-year-old Sebastian Deisler back by the shirt. Thoroughly dishevelled, the England players were giving the ball away with dismal regularity. "Football is about confidence," Hamann said, "and I think everybody could see what happened to England." Not until the 20th minute did a red-shirted player make a positive contribution to the match, when Cole deftly beat Marko Rehmer, only to be tripped and thereby offer David Beckham the chance to hit a 25-yard free-kick into Oliver Kahn's arms.

By half-time England's plight was obvious - on and off the pitch. All around the ground fans were chanting "Stand up if you won the war!" or turning to the German supporters in the north-west corner, humming the Dam Busters March and making arm-waving gestures intended to evoke air raids. "The chanting upset a lot of people in the royal box," a senior FA official said. "There was a sense that something was going badly wrong."

In the second half England made two chances, missed by Owen and Gareth Barry. "We were able to sit back and let them come at us," Hamann said. "It was a little easier for us." At the final whistle Keegan rose from the bench, shook hands with Rudi Völler, his opposite number, and began the long, lonely walk across the pitch, leaving his staff to bring up the rear. As he neared the tunnel, he could hear the crowd's rancorous chant: "What a load of rubbish!"

Normally he would have spoken to the TV reporters before entering the dressing room. This time he walked straight past them. Once the players had returned, he closed the door and broke the news that he would be resigning immediately. Some of them, led by Adams, tried to persuade him to stay, their arguments reinforced by Peter Beardsley and Arthur Cox, two of the old colleagues whom he had brought on to the coaching staff. But he was immovable.

As the discussion continued, newspaper reporters were waiting for the managers to make their scheduled appearance in the press conference room and were sharpening their questions for the loser. Völler arrived, expressed his pleasure at the performance and the result and left for the airport with his players. But there was no sign of Keegan.

As time went by, the rumour spread that Adam Crozier, the FA's chief executive, and Noel White, the chairman of the international committee, had joined Keegan and the players in the dressing room - an event without precedent, so far as anyone could remember.

In fact they had been accompanied by Geoff Thompson, the FA chairman, after Crozier had received an urgent summons on his mobile phone from Adrian Bevington, an FA press officer, half an hour after the final whistle.

As they entered the dressing room and saw the players' faces, Keegan drew them aside and told them his decision. Quickly recognising his determination to go, they spent 10 minutes trying to talk him into delaying his departure for four more days, so that he could take the squad to Finland for the match on the following Wednesday. But they were no more successful than the players and coaches had been.

Eventually, almost an hour after the end of the match, Crozier took Keegan to face the media, to whom he announced his decision in exactly the terms he had used with the players and officials. "I just came up short," he said, admitting that, when things were going wrong on the pitch, he did not know how to put them right.

When that ordeal was over, he collected his bags from the dressing room and went out to meet his FA car, in which his wife, Jean, and a couple of friends were waiting. Together they drove straight up to their home at Wynyard Hall, outside Newcastle. His 18-month, 18-match reign was over.

The players, too, wandered out to the car park and went off in their various directions, spending the night at their homes before the scheduled return to Burnham Beeches the following evening. Cox, Beardsley, Derek Fazackerley, Ray Clemence, Les Reed and the rest of the coaching staff returned to the team hotel. Inside Wembley, however, Crozier, Thompson and White were trying to work out what to do next.

Faced with the problem of a match in Helsinki on the Wednesday, they swiftly arrived at the only possible short-term solution. Howard Wilkinson, the FA's technical director, was asked to take temporary charge, as he had for one match after the sacking of Glenn Hoddle. No other possibility was seriously discussed. Then they too returned to Burnham, where they had dinner alongside the coaches.

"For a while," one of them said, "people were talking about anything other than football. Everyone was in shock. We'd stood by him when the flak was flying after Euro 2000, because England had endured a lot of changes and we needed some consistency.

"And at that point he felt he had more to give. Then, suddenly, he hadn't. That was quite a change, in such a short period of time."

Call to Eriksson

In Wembley's VIP lounge the news had spread quickly. Athole Still, an agent for footballers and opera singers, dialled a Rome number on his mobile phone and spoke to one of his clients, Sven-Goran Eriksson. A few days later a newspaper claimed that Still had been tipped off by Crozier and invited to contact the Lazio coach about the sudden vacancy.

"That's totally fanciful," Still said this week. "There was no contact with any FA official. Obviously it was big news, and I just rang Sven to tell him what had happened. It was in the days thereafter that I started to wonder if they'd consider him. And until we went to Rome to do the deal, I'd never even met Adam Crozier."

Eriksson's name was already on some minds as the FA officials reconvened at Burnham on the Sunday night and sat down to dinner together, this time to talk about the longer term. The players, too, had regathered, so the hotel was a little noisier than it had been the previous night. And the following morning they all set off for Helsinki.

In terms of awfulness, the weekend's debacle was not to be compared to Bradford or Heysel or Hillsborough, where innocent people died simply because they had chosen to attend a football match. In just about every other sense, however, Saturday, October 7 was the worst day in the history of English football, a moment in time when all the arrogance and neglect of the past came together in one ghastly spluttering anti-climax, with a single small silver-haired figure standing alone at its centre.

It was the day when Kevin Keegan took the blame and ran away and when, after decades of evasion, England finally confronted the truth about the value of heritage and tradition, which is that, although it is nice to have, it cannot be relied upon to provide the present with its meaning or the future with its inspiration.

All around the ground fans were chanting "Stand up if you won the war!" or turning to the German supporters in the north-west corner, humming the Dam Busters March and making arm-waving gestures intended to evoke air raids. "The chanting upset a lot of people in the royal box," a senior FA official said. "There was a sense that something was going badly wrong." In the second half England made two chances, missed by Owen and Gareth Barry. "We were able to sit back and let them come at us," Hamann said. "It was a little easier for us." At the final whistle Keegan rose from the bench, shook hands with Rudi Völler, his opposite number, and began the long, lonely walk across the pitch, leaving his staff to bring up the rear. As he neared the tunnel, he could hear the crowd's rancorous chant: "What a load of rubbish!" Normally he would have spoken to the TV reporters before entering the dressing room. This time he walked straight past them. Once the players had returned, he closed the door and broke the news that he would be resigning immediately. Some of them, led by Adams, tried to persuade him to stay, their arguments reinforced by Peter Beardsley and Arthur Cox, two of the old colleagues whom he had brought on to the coaching staff. But he was immovable. As the discussion continued, newspaper reporters were waiting for the managers to make their scheduled appearance in the press conference room and were sharpening their questions for the loser. Völler arrived, expressed his pleasure at the performance and the result and left for the airport with his players. But there was no sign of Keegan. As time went by, the rumour spread that Adam Crozier, the FA's chief executive, and Noel White, the chairman of the international committee, had joined Keegan and the players in the dressing room - an event without precedent, so far as anyone could remember. In fact they had been accompanied by Geoff Thompson, the FA chairman, after Crozier had received an urgent summons on his mobile phone from Adrian Bevington, an FA press officer, half an hour after the final whistle. As they entered the dressing room and saw the players' faces, Keegan drew them aside and told them his decision. Quickly recognising his determination to go, they spent 10 minutes trying to talk him into delaying his departure for four more days, so that he could take the squad to Finland for the match on the following Wednesday. But they were no more successful than the players and coaches had been. Eventually, almost an hour after the end of the match, Crozier took Keegan to face the media, to whom he announced his decision in exactly the terms he had used with the players and officials. "I just came up short," he said, admitting that, when things were going wrong on the pitch, he did not know how to put them right. When that ordeal was over, he collected his bags from the dressing room and went out to meet his FA car, in which his wife, Jean, and a couple of friends were waiting. Together they drove straight up to their home at Wynyard Hall, outside Newcastle. His 18-month, 18-match reign was over. The players, too, wandered out to the car park and went off in their various directions, spending the night at their homes before the scheduled return to Burnham Beeches the following evening. Cox, Beardsley, Derek Fazackerley, Ray Clemence, Les Reed and the rest of the coaching staff returned to the team hotel. Inside Wembley, however, Crozier, Thompson and White were trying to work out what to do next. Faced with the problem of a match in Helsinki on the Wednesday, they swiftly arrived at the only possible short-term solution. Howard Wilkinson, the FA's technical director, was asked to take temporary charge, as he had for one match after the sacking of Glenn Hoddle. No other possibility was seriously discussed. Then they too returned to Burnham, where they had dinner alongside the coaches. "For a while," one of them said, "people were talking about anything other than football. Everyone was in shock. We'd stood by him when the flak was flying after Euro 2000, because England had endured a lot of changes and we needed some consistency. "And at that point he felt he had more to give. Then, suddenly, he hadn't. That was quite a change, in such a short period of time." Call to Eriksson In Wembley's VIP lounge the news had spread quickly. Athole Still, an agent for footballers and opera singers, dialled a Rome number on his mobile phone and spoke to one of his clients, Sven-Goran Eriksson. A few days later a newspaper claimed that Still had been tipped off by Crozier and invited to contact the Lazio coach about the sudden vacancy. "That's totally fanciful," Still said this week. "There was no contact with any FA official. Obviously it was big news, and I just rang Sven to tell him what had happened. It was in the days thereafter that I started to wonder if they'd consider him. And until we went to Rome to do the deal, I'd never even met Adam Crozier." Eriksson's name was already on some minds as the FA officials reconvened at Burnham on the Sunday night and sat down to dinner together, this time to talk about the longer term. The players, too, had regathered, so the hotel was a little noisier than it had been the previous night. And the following morning they all set off for Helsinki. In terms of awfulness, the weekend's debacle was not to be compared to Bradford or Heysel or Hillsborough, where innocent people died simply because they had chosen to attend a football match. In just about every other sense, however, Saturday, October 7 was the worst day in the history of English football, a moment in time when all the arrogance and neglect of the past came together in one ghastly spluttering anti-climax, with a single small silver-haired figure standing alone at its centre. It was the day when Kevin Keegan took the blame and ran away and when, after decades of evasion, England finally confronted the truth about the value of heritage and tradition, which is that, although it is nice to have, it cannot be relied upon to provide the present with its meaning or the future with its inspiration.  You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: Snow one week, sea and surf the next
fields.standfirst: Milly finds the appeal of Waikiki beach palling after a snowball fight and her first taste of sushi on Vancouver Island, and has a brush with not quite so wonderful strangers on Oahu
fields.trailText: Week 3: Vancouver to Hawaii: Milly finds the appeal of Waikiki beach palling after a snowball fight and her first taste of sushi in Victoria, and has a brush with not quite so wonderful strangers on Oahu
fields.body:
My trusty diary informs me that at the start of this week I arrived on Vancouver Island to overcast skies with a nasty hangover - the social life of Vancouver is incredibly hard to resist. The island, on the other hand, is a lot like England scenically, with rolling meadows, etc.

I'd left myself a bit of time to explore so I headed for downtown Victoria. Feeling uninspired by the thought of shopping, I went to Crystal Gardens, a tropical building which has monkeys and the like. It was nothing fantastic, though the monkeys were very cute.

Deciding to brave the rain - after all, I do come from England - I walked all the way down Douglas Street to the ocean. The sea was really wild and the bright sun in a grey sky made it look incredible, though eventually I was defeated by the extreme weather.

While on the island, I was staying with another gap year student called Julia, who'd contacted me through the website. It was really nice to stay in a real house with a bunch of 18-year-old girls, just watching telly and having a laugh.

However, I'd promised myself to do something the next day, and on the advice of a fellow hosteller, went to Butchart Gardens. By day they were nice - if you appreciate the whole garden thing - but by night they were incredible. The place was covered in lights and came alive like some sort of fantasy land. They also had some traditional carol singers, and for me this definitely felt like my Christmas away from home. If you can make it there (in the evening) I definitely recommend it - if you're full of Christmas spirit!

That evening back at Julia's house we'd just finished watching a video when it started to snow. The five of us ran outside to play in it - I think everybody goes silly in snow. It was definitely one of those moments that will stick in my head, having snowball fights at midnight on Vancouver Island!

I left the next day to enjoy my last few days back on the mainland. I can't really admit to having done anything cultural but you can't tell me that anybody spends all their time visiting their local museum? Well, I was enjoying myself anyhow, which has always been the most important feature of my travels. And I learnt a very good drinking game, which I will happily send the rules of to anyone who's interested!

One point of interest was my very first taste of sushi. Me and a crazy Aussie hosteller, Lill, were shopping when we suddenly got brave and decided to give it a go. I'm not even a big cooked fish fan, so this was quite an achievement for me. I think everyone else in the restaurant thought we were nuts - for a start, their soup didn't come with spoons and it took us 10 minutes of watching everyone else to figure out how to drink it! Still, we passed an entertaining afternoon eating. My verdict: sushi is good, as long as it's the least intimidating variety.

Something strange happened on the plane, heading for Honolulu. I was sat there drinking red wine, listening to Christina Aguilera and anticipating a good(ish) meal, when I had this overwhelming feeling of happiness. I just started thinking, I've had an amazing couple of weeks and now I'm sat on a plane bound for Hawaii. How lucky am I?? I think the people around me were probably a bit concerned, but I guess they just didn't understand!

Unfortunately, things didn't stay good for long. It occurred to me at the airport that I'd made no attempt to book anywhere to stay, and it was now midnight. Eventually I got to a hostel, but the sight of it, and the ugliness of some of Waikiki at night was so different to Vancouver I just wanted to leave. I was woken up in the night by another girl coming into my room. She'd just got in from Rarotonga and said in comparison Honolulu was so big and ugly she wanted to cry. It was slightly comforting to know I wasn't alone in feeling like this.

In the morning, I rejected the idea of sitting on Waikiki beach in favour of exploring the area on foot. Oahu isn't as ugly as I first thought. It has incredibly stunning parts, but there are so many horrible commercial parts that ruin it.

Somehow in my wandering I got drawn into an art shop, and after talking to the owner for a little while he offered to show me round the island later, as I had no car of my own. The second I got into his car that evening, I wondered if I was doing the right thing. It turned out he was a nice guy, but going on tour with a stranger goes against everything I've ever been taught. Generally, my advice would be, "don't".

Anyhow, I had a pretty nice evening, driving round the city and beyond at night. We finished up at the ridiculously rich Hilton Hawaiian Village for a drink. And I was told that I wouldn't be able to drink in America.

The following day my English roommate Alison and I took the bus to the north shore, to the Bonzai Pipeline, which boasts some of the best surf in the world. We met two American guys who seemed pretty nice, so when Alison headed back to catch her flight I stayed. The two guys were staying at a hotel in Waikiki and the idea appealed to me, so I decided to crash there also.

Before I go on, I'd like to offer a great bit of advice. Don't stay with people you don't know, however nice they seem. Get to know them first, and stick to hostels. They may be basic, but at least they're safe.

As the evening went on, it transpired these two were fairly well into drugs of all varieties and I was now stuck with them for the night having not booked anywhere else. Anyhow, this isn't a part of my travels I particularly want to dwell on, so to cut a long story short, nothing bad happened to me, but I was pretty well scared and had got myself well into a situation I could have avoided. It gave me a valuable lesson to be more cautious. There are too many weird people around - and a fairly strong drug presence in Honolulu at night.

I returned to my original hostel as soon as I could the next morning, but it goes some way to explaining why I've not had time to write a report before now. Anyhow, that was the end of my week, and it certainly has felt like a long one. A week ago I was in snow, today I was swimming in the sea - I've experienced more than a little culture shock of late.

Until next week (which I can promise will be better), Milly

webTitle: SNP runs Labour close in byelection

fields.headline: SNP runs Labour close in byelection
fields.trailText:
Labour scraped to victory in the Falkirk West byelection early today in a close run contest which saw its
           majority slashed to just 705 by the Scottish National party.
fields.body:
Labour scraped to victory in the Falkirk West byelection early today in a close run contest which saw its majority slashed to just 705 by the Scottish National party.

In one of the lowest turnouts of recent times in Scotland, the Labour candidate, former army major Eric Joyce, just beat off a challenge from the SNP to secure the seat vacated by the rebel MP Dennis Canavan.

He won 8,492 votes, with the SNP challenger David Kerr on 7,787.

The 16% swing to the SNP surprised political analysts who had predicted a comfortable win for Labour after its victory in last month's Glasgow Anniesland byelections.

When Mr Canavan stood as the official Labour runner in 1997, he won a substantial 13,783 majority.

Mr Joyce said after the count that the result confounded those who thought Labour would get beaten.

He said: "We have disappointed them - those pundits and pollsters who thought that this would be a disastrous by-election. The nationalists have been judged irrelevant in Falkirk West. They have been cast aside by the people of Falkirk in favour of making this country better."

But Mr Kerr said the result showed the SNP was making progress on the road to independence.

He said: "This country needs social justice and that can only be achieved through independence. The key message is that the SNP support is up and New Labour's is down."

It was the first Christmas byelection in Scotland for 50 years and the parties had struggled to get the vote out in the face of apathy, bad weather and seasonal festivities. Turnout was 36.15% and was also thought to have been affected by the electoral register, which is 18 months out of date and was due to be replaced in February. It has been estimated that up to 10,000 of the area's 50,000 electors might not have been on the existing list.

Mr Canavan announced in October that he was standing down as Falkirk West MP. He had been expelled from Labour in 1999 after it excluded him as its candidate for the Scottish parliament elections, and he stood and won as an independent.

Following the death of Donald Dewar, however, moves were made to bring Mr Canavan back into the party fold. But after withdrawing his resignation, he announced last month that he would definitely quit. The SNP dipped in the polls and Labour won the Anniesland byelection.

Mr Canavan had not given his backing to any particular candidate during the contest. He served as Falkirk West's MP for 25 years and will remain its MSP at Holyrood.

John Curtice, professor of politics at Strathclyde University, said the result should concern the Labour leadership in the run-up to an election. "There are worrying signs here for Tony Blair," he said. "It re-raises the doubts about the degree to which Labour is able to reconnect with its heartland voters."

Eric Joyce (Lab) 8,492 (43.54%, -15.81%)

David Kerr ( SNP ) 7,787 (39.93%, +16.50%)

Craig Stevenson (C) 1,621 (8.31%, -3.78%)

Iain Hunter (SSP) 989 (5.07%)

Hugh O'Donnell (Lib Dem ) 615 (3.15%, -1.98%)

Labour majority 705 (3.61%) 16.15% swing Lab to SNP

Electorate 53,953 Turnout 19,504 (36.15%, -36.45%)

1997: Labour majority 13,783 (35.92%)

Turnout 38,370 (72.60%)

fields.headline: Divine waters and devilish driving
fields.standfirst: In Sue's final week in India, she visits the Taj Mahal and Varanasi, has a good experience of Indian trains and a bad one of Indian driving, and wonders whether cows know more than they're letting on
fields.trailText: In Sue's final week in India, she visits the Taj Mahal and Varanasi, has a good experience of Indian trains and a bad one of Indian driving, and wonders whether cows know more than they're letting on
fields.body:
This week it is goodbye India, hello Nepal. I will leave my first impressions of Kathmandu until next time - I want to round off my wonderful but tiring three weeks in India.

On Saturday we had another pre-dawn start to drive to Agra, stopping on the way at the abandoned city of Fatephur Sikri, full of beautiful sandstone buildings. In Agra we had to bid farewell to our driver, Manesh, in his cool shades, and the luxury of our car. That evening we celebrated Clare's birthday (New Zealand Time). Deciding to walk we soon got lost and resorted to the inevitable cycle rickshaws that follow you everywhere. They took us to the wrong restaurant, a gloomy empty place, where they would have been rewarded if we had stayed. This is India!

Somewhat grumpy and footsore we eventually did find a decent restaurant that served 'special tea'. (Bruce was allowed some in honour of the occasion - see picture gallery.)

Dawn the next day saw us at the Taj Mahal. However many pictures you see, the beauty and majesty of it are still truly awesome (see picture gallery). Visitors preserve a sort of quietness as if not to disturb the aloof symmetry of the place. Unforgettable.

That night we took the overnight sleeper train to Varanasi. Thank heavens for being on a tour. The look of anxiety and fear on the face of a young packpacker, wondering how on earth he was going to find his berth, was a reminder that soon I will lose the comfort of being on an organised tour. I asked Carol if she would like to carry on with me to continue to organise all the hard bits, but she declined!

Varanasi, on the Ganges, is a Hindu place of pilgrimage where all Hindus try to visit and bathe. If you die there you skip all the reincarnations and achieve immediate moksha [in Hinduism, the release from the worldly cycle of birth and rebirth]. Dawn again saw us on a boat on the Ganges. The ghats were full of bathers, washing and praying. Cremations were underway, as they are for 24 hours every day. Not at all religious, I was still struck by the atmosphere of reverence and devotion of the place.

Throughout this trip we have learned to take Carol's tendency to underplay with a pinch of salt... 'simple hotel' has often had marble floors, a balcony and hot showers. However her dire warnings about the two-day bus ride to Kathmandu turned out to be spot on. The driver, who was the spit of Omar Sheriff, had a job finding anywhere to put his flip-flopped feet among the tangle of wires under the steering wheel; we had to move off the front seat because the boy needed to sit there to hold the door shut; the windows slid open and closed at will, although miraculously they did stay in their frames. Suspension?- no chance.

Thus we travelled to the border - a nightmare prolonged by the fact that we removed the wheel arch and various other bits of a passing jeep. This led to a couple of hours of shouting and arm waving and a further hour or two having our brakes mended! Poor Clare and Mike were both sick. My day was saved by Sam's 'Epic' tape and Rachel's 'c!hillout'. Thanks kids - two more cracking collections.

The next day's bus was marginally better as it did have some suspension. My very last word on Indian roads concerns cows. Do they know they are sacred? All the other dogs, goats, boars, sheep and even camels that wander the streets move when hooted at. But not the cow - whether it be lying, standing or ambling, it will not budge, and all the traffic has to go round it.

So I leave India. I would not have missed a minute, but it is hard work. We are all tired (it could be all those dawns), and at odd times frayed at the edges. I had a shouting match with a cyber cafe owner who tried to charge me for the half hour wasted trying to load my photos. 'It's your disc,' he bellowed. 'It's your dusty old disc drive,' I yelled back. Carol and Mike fell out over the interpretation of a map. The Rough Guide to India is very large - it is a good job it missed! Happily they have since bought the silk for the wedding dress so all is well. Even Carol lost it once over an omelette.

India is a land full of contrasts; the majesty of the palaces and temples with the abject poverty; the beauty of the land with the dirt; the friendliness and helpfulness of the people with the relentless harassment by rickshaw wallahs and touts; the amazing sunrises that are delayed by 10 minutes to rise above the pollution.

I am looking forward to a few days doing nothing in Nepal. My tour ends Sunday, so I will be spending tomorrow checking out the places to stay and to see you have recommended in emails. Thanks. There was no email access in Agra or Varanasi so I am way behind in reading, answering messages and in sending in the photos. It seems to be good here so I can catch up.

I still do not quite know how I will be spending Christmas - the others will still be here so we will be together - plus Carol's new band of travellers. I will fill you in next week.

May I wish my children, all my family and friends, and my new friends - everyone writing in or reading this, a very Happy Christmas.

The ghats were full of bathers, washing and praying. Cremations were underway, as they are for 24 hours every day. Not at all religious, I was still struck by the atmosphere of reverence and devotion of the place. Throughout this trip we have learned to take Carol's tendency to underplay with a pinch of salt... 'simple hotel' has often had marble floors, a balcony and hot showers. However her dire warnings about the two-day bus ride to Kathmandu turned out to be spot on. The driver, who was the spit of Omar Sheriff, had a job finding anywhere to put his flip-flopped feet among the tangle of wires under the steering wheel; we had to move off the front seat because the boy needed to sit there to hold the door shut; the windows slid open and closed at will, although miraculously they did stay in their frames. Suspension?- no chance. Thus we travelled to the border - a nightmare prolonged by the fact that we removed the wheel arch and various other bits of a passing jeep. This led to a couple of hours of shouting and arm waving and a further hour or two having our brakes mended! Poor Clare and Mike were both sick. My day was saved by Sam's 'Epic' tape and Rachel's 'c!hillout'. Thanks kids - two more cracking collections. The next day's bus was marginally better as it did have some suspension. My very last word on Indian roads concerns cows. Do they know they are sacred? All the other dogs, goats, boars, sheep and even camels that wander the streets move when hooted at. But not the cow - whether it be lying, standing or ambling, it will not budge, and all the traffic has to go round it. So I leave India. I would not have missed a minute, but it is hard work. We are all tired (it could be all those dawns), and at odd times frayed at the edges. I had a shouting match with a cyber cafe owner who tried to charge me for the half hour wasted trying to load my photos. 'It's your disc,' he bellowed. 'It's your dusty old disc drive,' I yelled back. Carol and Mike fell out over the interpretation of a map. The Rough Guide to India is very large - it is a good job it missed! Happily they have since bought the silk for the wedding dress so all is well. Even Carol lost it once over an omelette. India is a land full of contrasts; the majesty of the palaces and temples with the abject poverty; the beauty of the land with the dirt; the friendliness and helpfulness of the people with the relentless harassment by rickshaw wallahs and touts; the amazing sunrises that are delayed by 10 minutes to rise above the pollution. I am looking forward to a few days doing nothing in Nepal. My tour ends Sunday, so I will be spending tomorrow checking out the places to stay and to see you have recommended in emails. Thanks. There was no email access in Agra or Varanasi so I am way behind in reading, answering messages and in sending in the photos. It seems to be good here so I can catch up. I still do not quite know how I will be spending Christmas - the others will still be here so we will be together - plus Carol's new band of travellers. I will fill you in next week. May I wish my children, all my family and friends, and my new friends - everyone writing in or reading this, a very Happy Christmas.

fields.headline: Suicide bomb in West Bank
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: A suicide bomber today walked into a roadside restaurant in a remote Israeli village and blew himself up, also injuring three Israeli soldiers.
fields.body:
A suicide bomber today walked into a roadside restaurant in a remote Israeli village and blew himself up, also injuring three Israeli soldiers.

Israeli police confirmed that the bomber, a Palestinian, had been harnessed with explosives. "The terrorist blew himself up with an explosive charge that he was wearing," said police spokesman Rafi Yaffe.

It was not clear which organisation, if any, was behind the explosion. Israeli troops were combing the area around the village of Mehola, about 50 miles (70km) north-east of Jerusalem, in the Jordan valley at the northern tip of the West Bank.

Yitzhak Miller, a local resident, said the wounded were being flown out by helicopter to the nearest large Israeli town, Afula. "There are body parts lying around, but I can't tell if they are from one, two or three bodies," he told Israeli radio.

Elsewhere, a Palestinian man who worked as a laborer in a Jewish settlement was killed in the Gaza Strip, Israel radio reported. Army officials said Palestinian gunmen had opened fire at army positions in the settlement of Netzarim, killing the man, who was working in a greenhouse.

In Jerusalem, scuffles and stone-throwing also broke out today as Palestinian worshippers were turned away from the walled Old City on the most important prayer day of Ramadan. At least one Palestinian was hurt and another arrested, amid a massive Israeli security drive on the final Friday of the Muslim holy month, employing 3,000 police and soldiers.

Police briefly evacuated the broad plaza fronting the Western Wall after a few stones were thrown at Jewish worshippers from the Al Aqsa mosque compound above.

At the Damascus Gate leading into the Old City's Muslim quarter, scuffles broke out as Israeli troops manning a barricade checked Palestinians' identity cards. One mounted policeman fell off his horse and was stoned by the crowd, but managed to get back in the saddle.

Tight restrictions on access to the Old City have been in effect on most Fridays during the 3-month-long uprising, when the week's main prayers have often boiled over into confrontations between Palestinians and Israeli troops. Only Palestinians over the age of 45 - or over 35, if they live in Jerusalem - were allowed into the Old City.

Other would-be worshippers were turned away at roadblocks outside Jerusalem. Many men spread out rugs and prayer mats just outside the Damascus Gate. "I'll pray at the gate," said Idris Abu-Turki, 21, who traveled from the West Bank town of Hebron. "I passed all the checkpoints today to come and pray this last Friday here."

Meanwhile Palestinian officials maintained their non-committal stance towards Washington peace talks, where US president Bill Clinton presented the two sides with a proposed outline for a treaty.

Palestinian negotiators walked out of talks with their Israeli counterparts amid "deep differences" over key issues.

Palestinian negotiator Saeb Erekat said: "The gaps are wide. Yesterday [Thursday] we walked out of the meeting because of these gaps and we sat after that for long hours with [US Middle East envoy Dennis[ Ross and his team, but we did not solve the problem."

Another Palestinian official that the meeting had almost come to blows when Israeli negotiator Shlomo Ben-Ami began talking about annexing 10% of the Palestinian territories, reneging on an earlier offer of 5%.

Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat told reporters in the Gaza Strip that "no final result has come." Asked if a deal were close, he replied: "We hope so."

fields.headline: Darling, you were divine
fields.standfirst:
Sometimes they are humble scenes of family life. Sometimes they are grand tableaux complete with choirs of angels. But nativity scenes in art are always pure theatre, says Jonathan Jones
Special report: Christmas 2000
fields.trailText: Sometimes they are humble scenes of family life. Sometimes they are grand tableaux complete with choirs of angels. But nativity scenes in art are always pure theatre, says Jonathan Jones
fields.body:
"And every year at Christmas," says the guide on the backstage tour of Radio City Music Hall in New York, "this is the setting for the famous Radio City Music Hall Living Nativity." We are in the wings of the "Biggest Stage in the World", in the fantastic art deco Manhattan venue created by the visionary entertainment mogul Roxy in the early 1930s. One of New York City's most cherished yuletide traditions is Radio City Music Hall's Christmas Show, featuring the world-famous dance troupe The Rockettes in red tunics with white fur trim, and culminating with the Living Nativity, a tableau starring live camels, donkeys and sheep. All the animals live at Radio City Music Hall in the weeks leading up to Christmas, and all of them are here to participate in a pious tribute to the birth of Christ.

For this is no sleazy showbiz festival of kitsch, Radio City publicity explains. This is a sincere continuation of a tradition started by St Francis of Assisi in the small Italian town of Greccio in the 13th century. The saint, "realising Christmas had lost its meaning for many in his day, pondered various ways of bringing the story closer to them. Then he had a wonderful idea - re-enact the nativity scene on Christmas Eve. That night, he had the crib bring Christmas to life for the people of that small town. This year, we hope our enactment of this timeless story will be a moving and memorable experience for you."

The representation of the nativity in European art is closely connected to this popular tradition of creating a crib at home or in the local church. Artists from the 13th century onwards have painted the nativity for the same reason that Saint Francis was supposed to have created a tableau of the crib with a living ox and ass: to make us go all gooey.

It's a long way from Manhattan to the Rode Klooster monastery in the forest of Soigné, outside Brussels, where the painter Hugo van der Goes retreated from the world in the late 15th century. Van der Goes was one of the greatest artists of the northern Renaissance but suffered from suicidal depression that made him the despair of the monks. Van der Goes's late painting The Adoration of the Shepherds (c1480), now in the Gemäldegalerie in Berlin, is the very opposite in spirit to Radio City's Living Nativity. A low, long panel, it represents the stable as a tiny, confined space. The baby in the crib is just off-centre, his flesh glowing, and Mary and Joseph pray to the child in the company of a host of tiny angels while the shepherds squeeze in, too. It is humble. Yet it is also theatre.

This is a stage, a mystery theatre. At the sides are two figures who look directly at us, the audience, as they pull back a pair of curtains on a rail running across the top of the painting to reveal the manger. This picture is derived from the popular reenactments of the nativity: the tableau at Greccio, as well as the Shepherds' Plays that flourished in the lowlands at the time of Hugo van der Goes.

Giotto's painting of the Institution of the Crib at Greccio, part of his fresco cycle of the Life of St Francis in Assisi executed at the end of the 13th century, emphasises the populist nature of the spectacle. St Francis lovingly holds the Christ child; there is a wooden crib, and next to it, a living baby ox and ass, sitting docilely as part of the show. All around, people are singing, the church is full.

The representation of the nativity in art, including the scenes of the adoration of the shepherds and the adoration of the magi, is absolutely inseparable from these traditions of popular theatre. Botticelli's Mystic Nativity (1500) in the National Gallery presents us with a head-on view of the stable, a wood-and-straw loggia added on to the front of a cave, which you can't help comparing to a theatrical stage. Mystery plays were presented on little wooden stages temporarily tacked on to existing buildings in just this way.

Yet, if the nativity in art is intimately connected to popular theatre, some of the most haunting paintings of this mystery turn away from the explicit, universally readable drama of popular art, to touch on more remote emotional resonances, a theatre of the mind. Leonardo da Vinci's sublime, unfinished Adoration of the Magi in the Uffizi, Florence, has a philosopher standing meditatively at the extreme left of the picture. But instead of announcing the nativity as a simple emotive scene, he tugs his chin, implying this is a matter for troubled thought. The ruins in the background are rendered in perfect mathematical perspective yet reduced to fragments, the remnants of a pagan world ruined by Christ's birth. In the background, horses rear. They are manifestations of animal passion and war, the strivings of empire - doomed by this moment when the old must die to make way for the new. The magi, dark-eyed and dumbstruck, know they are part of this old world. As T S Eliot has them say, "this Birth was/Hard and bitter agony for us."

The strangest, most beautiful paintings of the nativity induce this shudder, and if they start as theatre, they end somewhere deep inside our imagination. Piero della Francesca's Nativity (1470-5) in the National Gallery has been rendered all the more mysterious by damage over the years that has simplified its surface. Piero, like Leonardo, was an intellectual - he wrote on perspective - and his painting has a reserve that takes us far from the everyday world represented by Bethlehem to a place outside town, under a humble wooden shelter in a stark countryside, where angels have appeared to hymn this birth. There is a confident reality to the painting, established by Piero's brilliant grasp of perspective. But he uses his understanding of the new Renaissance science of representation to convince us, the learned and the unlearned, the shepherds and the magi, that something magical has happened.

"Paintings are placed in churches so that the illiterate can read on the walls what they cannot read in books," said Pope Gregory the Great. The nativity was especially suited to the Church's need to communicate. In Giotto's painting, St Francis handles the child like a mother. The nativity in Renaissance art makes men feel like mothers, mothers feel like Mary, unites everyone in tenderness for the divine baby.

Yet the sincerity of these paintings has always been in conflict with another desire, to make the tableau that little bit more lavish than the one in the neighbouring village. The populist nature of the nativity and its connection to theatre mean it is always open to competitive, over-ornate types of spectacle; the pure goes hand-in-hand with the vulgar. You only have to look at Veronese's Adoration of the Kings (1573) at the National Gallery to see how elaborate and extravagant nativity scenes could get. Born in a stable? No way, you can hear Veronese's affluent Venetian audience saying. The wooden theatre-like "stable" here is just an afterthought to the classical ruin that dominates the painting. Veronese's Christ is born in a palace, albeit a wrecked one. His mother is dressed in silk every bit as fine as the robes of the kings who have come to pay devotion. She does not sit next to a humble manger but is raised up high, royally, with the crowd bowing down before her. Even the ox looks aristocratic.

The classical ruins in Veronese's painting appear again and again in nativity scenes and are generally interpreted as an allusion to the decline of the classical world. The birth of Christ signifies the death of the Roman empire, the birth of a new age. Although this surely is their emblematic meaning, the ruins in Veronese's painting are also enjoyed for their own sake. It was the Renaissance, after all. In the humblest nativity paintings, the stable is a hut; in the grandest, it is an architectural feast, and the gold vessels presented as gifts by the wise men, and the fine clothes they wear, and their retinue of servants, are flamboyantly tacky. The Living Nativity at Radio City Music Hall really can claim to be in a great tradition.

webTitle: Billy Elliot listed for Golden Globe award

fields.headline: Britons nominated
fields.standfirst: Billy Elliot listed for Golden Globe award
fields.trailText: Billy Elliot listed for Golden Globe award
fields.body:
The film Billy Elliot and actress Brenda Blethyn have staked early British claims for next year's Oscars by securing places on the nominees list for the Golden Globe awards announced yesterday.

Billy Elliot, the story of a working class boy struggling to become a ballet dancer, was nominated for best dramatic picture at a ceremony in Beverly Hills, Los Angeles.

Ms Blethyn was nominated for best actress in a musical or comedy film for her portrayal in Saving Grace of a middle aged woman who branches out into marijuana cultivation.

The best supporting actress category was something of a triumph for British performers, with three nominees.

Julie Walters was named for her role as Billy Elliot's dance teacher, Dame Judi Dench for her role in Chocolat, and Catherine Zeta Jones for her performance in the drug war drama Traffic. Albert Finney received a nomination for best supporting actor in Erin Brokovich.

The awards will be made on January 21.

webTitle: No murder evidence in new Telford inquiry

fields.headline: No murder evidence in new Telford inquiry
fields.standfirst:
Telford inquiry draws blank
Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: Detectives investigating the deaths of two black men found hanged within six months of each other in Telford have concluded that there is no evidence they were murdered, the Guardian has learned.
fields.body:
Detectives investigating the deaths of two black men found hanged within six months of each other in Telford have concluded that there is no evidence they were murdered, the Guardian has learned.

The families of Errol McGowan, 34, and his nephew Jason, 20, had criticised West Mercia police for dismissing both deaths, which followed racial abuse, as suicide. The furore forced a reinvestigation and an apology from the force's chief constable.

In a significant move, West Mercia police say they have sent a file on Errol's death to the coroner and not to the crown prosecution service, where it would be sent if detectives believed there was evidence to support charges.

The decision was made after police found no hard evidence that the two men were hanged by another person or persons.

West Mercia confirmed that their fresh investigation into the death of Errol is no longer "proactive".

The reinvestigation began on February 1, and in an unprecedented move after criticism, hate crime experts from Scotland Yard were called in to give advice.

Police reports will be considered by a coroner who will hold separate inquest next summer which will rule whether the deaths were unlawful, accidental or suicide.

Errol McGowan was found with electrical flex around his neck, hanging from a 5ft-high door knob in a friend's house on July 2 1999. His family was told he was on a far-right death list after clashing with white youths while working as a doorman in the Shropshire town. Jason McGowan was found hanging by his belt from 5ft-high railings by a roadside last New Year's Day.

The family said neither had any reason to commit suicide, and that Jason had been investigating his uncle's death when he died.

West Mercia police insist the investigation is continuing, though the inquiry has been scaled down.

In a statement West Mercia police said: "We do not submit files to the CPS as a matter of course. We would only do so if there was evidence against a specific individual or individuals. This is not the case in relation to the investigation into the deaths of Errol and Jason McGowan. The file in relation to Errol has been completed and presented to the coroner. A further file in rela tion to the investigation into the death of Jason is due to be submitted to the coroner early in the new year.

"A small team of officers is completing work on the investigation into Jason's death and would be available to follow up any new lines of inquiry which may come to light in either case.

"It is a matter for the inquest to decide how Errol and Jason died.
