webTitle: PC sacked for race jibe is reinstated

fields.headline: PC sacked for race jibe is reinstated
fields.standfirst: Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: A policeman sacked for calling a 14-year-old suspected thief a "black bastard" was reinstated by the home secretary yesterday following an appeal which was supported by thousands of his former colleagues.
fields.body:
A policeman sacked for calling a 14-year-old suspected thief a "black bastard" was reinstated by the home secretary yesterday following an appeal which was supported by thousands of his former colleagues.

Jack Straw decided PC Steve Hutt, 38, should be fined 13 days' pay for the racist remark, which was made in the back of a police van as he tried to pacify a youth during an arrest two years ago.

Mr Hutt, who is working as a chauffeur, was "overwhelmed" by the news and said he would definitely return to the ranks.

"I told my girlfriend Karen and we both burst into tears. It is a victory for common sense. I accept what I said was wrong and obviously will pay the 13 days' wages."

Mr Hutt was dismissed in February this year.

Before his suspension, he had 19 years' unblemished service. His duties had included a spell guarding the Prince and Princess of Wales at Balmoral.

Mr Hutt made the remark during the arrest of the youth who was seized in Fulham, west London, on suspicion of trying to break into parking meters.

The youth was crying, shouting and foaming at the mouth when Mr Hutt pushed him into a seat with one hand and shouted "sit down, you black bastard". He was overheard by a sergeant and apologised.

A spokesman for Scotland Yard said: "PC Hutt admitted making a racist remark. He was therefore disciplined because we will not tolerate the use of racist words or behaviour. The disciplinary hearing took the view that such remarks must be dealt with severely and decided that he should be dismissed."

Mr Hutt's appeal was supported by the mother of the youth he abused and several serving black officers.

webTitle: Comment: Met Police Authority chair on Hague and crime

fields.headline: A new beat
fields.standfirst:
Toby Harris, chair of the Metropolitan Police Authority, says William Hague doesn't understand stop and search

Special report: Tories in opposition
Special report: race issues in the UK
Special report: policing crime
fields.trailText: Toby Harris, chair of the Metropolitan Police Authority, says William Hague doesn't understand stop and search.
fields.body:
As chair of the Metropolitan Police Authority (MPA), I was alarmed by William Hague's dramatic u-turn on the Macpherson report into the death of Stephen Lawrence, now claiming it to have damaged police morale and prevented police from effective use of stop and search powers, thus causing a rise in street crime.

It is unhelpful to suggest that a fall in stop and search has been directly responsible for a rise in street crime. Pre-Macpherson, the majority of stop and searches did not lead to an arrest, and many that did were for minor offences. Post-Macpherson, the use of stop and search is being used in a much more sensitive and focused way.

Police are much more concerned with the quality of stop and search, rather than the quantity. Carrying out 100 random stops and searches is pointless. Carrying out 10 that are carefully targeted and result in high-quality arrests is much more meaningful. The use of this power in this way will also find support from the community, as will the abandonment of the disproportionate stopping and searching of black and Asian people. It is criminal intent and not the colour of your skin that should interest the patrolling police officer.

On crime, the biggest concern for Londoners as identified in the Met's public attitude survey is burglary. The Met has worked hard to tackle this deplorable crime with a good deal of success. Burglaries are down more than 9% this year. Figures this low haven't been seen since 1979. Similarly, the Met has had some good results in its big push against crimes involving class A drugs. In the past few weeks, raids across London have produced 323 arrests and large seizures of drugs, guns and stolen property.

In terms of so-called "volume crime", the area which is currently causing most concern is street robbery, particularly the number of robberies involving young people and mobile phones. This is a relatively new phenomenon and shows how the police can face sudden new pressures on time and resources. Tackling street crime is not a matter merely for police. There are many other factors involved which we, as a community, need to think about and work towards solving.

One way of deterring street robberies is to divert youngsters away from crime and into other activities which will help them lead productive lives, achieving their full potential. Truancy, bullying and the connection between school exclusions and crime - all need to be looked at.

But we are still facing huge problems. In fact, the Metropolitan Police is facing its worst crisis in its 170-year history. We need about 3,000 more police officers to police London effectively, in order to ensure that estates like the one in Peckham where Damilola Taylor was so tragically killed are regularly patrolled on foot by police officers who know their beats and know who lives there.

The MPA has just approved a budget recommending an 11.6% increase to enable effective policing of London. The increase would result in a budget of £2,056m, £214m more than last year. If approved by the mayor and the Greater London Assembly, this would allow for the recruitment of an additional 1,050 urgently needed Metropolitan Police officers and a better pay deal for police civilian staff.

By the end of this year we will have vacancies for 1,000 civilian support staff in the Met - that is nearly 7.5% of the total civilian strength. This acute shortage means that about 250 police officers who should be out patrolling our neighbourhoods and our streets, are sitting behind desks carrying out critical support staff functions. We need to recognise the valuable role carried out by civilian staff and reward them accordingly.

The mayor has already declared his desire to pay for these officers and boost civilian pay out of local taxes.

The lack of affordable housing is another area of major concern to potential new police recruits. It was for this reason, to stem the exodus of police officers due to a shortage of reasonably-priced accommodation, that the MPA placed a moratorium on the sale of police houses while we review the policy to dispose of the housing stock.

In the past month or so there has been a slight upturn in recruitment. It is too early to say whether this rise in numbers will be sustained. We as a police authority, the commissioner and the mayor, are doing all we can to ensure it is. If you compare London with New York, a good example because the population sizes, crime, violence and disorder problems are similar, New Yorkers benefit from 40,000 police officers; the Met is down to 25,346.

But the striking difference between policing in New York and London is terrorism. We are once again under very real threat of terrorist violence, this time from dissident Irish republican groups. That is why the commissioner talks of another 3,000 police officers needed to police London. If New York can have a police service of a size to tackle crime and disorder confidently then why can't London?

Dave Eggers being his usual modest self

Zadie Smith on winning the Guardian First Book Award for White Teeth

"He is not properly valued as an objet. If he were in Japan, he'd be valued as some precious, lacquered treasure."
Margaret Atwood on Prince Charles

"I don't miss Smiley."
John Le Carre

"I can do to him whatever I like. I'm allowed to torture him as much as I want. He's mine."
J K Rowling on Harry Potter

"I'm off everything now. I couldn't have written another book if I hadn't cleaned up."
Will Self on his reformed character

fields.headline: Doubts over big signing
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: Former Marks & Spencer boss Sir Richard Greenbury is understood to be considering his long-term future as chairman of crisis-hit sports software firm e-comsport seven months after joining the company.
fields.body:
Former Marks & Spencer boss Sir Richard Greenbury is understood to be considering his long-term future as chairman of crisis-hit sports software firm e-comsport seven months after joining the company.

Sir Richard is thought to be unhappy at the early progress of the firm, which yesterday announced the departure of its third senior director in less than a month. However, he is thought to be determined to stay until recent boardroom turbulence has been resolved.

E-comsport, brainchild of Grant Bovey, the television entrepreneur married to TV presenter Anthea Turner, sells betting software. It said in a statement that chief executive Alan Montgomery was stepping down because he was tired of commuting from his home in Scotland to London.

Mr Montgomery is a former chief executive of Glasgow Rangers and a 6% shareholder in the firm. Two other directors have quit recently amid reports of boardroom bust-ups. Roger Bullen, a non-executive director, stepped down last month, two days after the abrupt exit of operations director Darryl Keys. Mr Keys was in charge of the firm's website development arm, closed after the board decided it was commercially unviable.

Sir Richard, an avid Manchester United fan, was brought in as a high-profile figurehead before e-comsport's AIM flotation in May. His tenure has been a difficult one as the shares have fallen from their flotation price of 61p to close last night at 21.5p.

webTitle: Turkey gets a roasting in EU application bid

fields.headline: Turkey gets a roasting in EU application bid
fields.standfirst: Ankara could one day be the most powerful government in the EU, but not until a thicket of thorny issues are resolved, says Ian Black in Brussels
fields.trailText: Ankara could one day be the most powerful government in the EU, but not until a thicket of thorny issues are resolved, says Ian Black in Brussels.
fields.body:
It was just a year ago, on a freezing day in Helsinki, that the European Union formally adopted Turkey as a candidate for membership, over 30 years after it first applied to join. But since then there have been many painful reminders that relations between Brussels and Ankara are never going to be easy.

Only this week the bloody suppression of rioting in Turkish prisons brought criticism from the European commission, as well as - literally - high-profile protests from Kurdish demonstrators who occupied two pods on the London Eye on the south bank of the Thames. Unrelated to that, EU ministers approved a three-year, £80m grant to help Turkey prepare for eventual membership by promoting economic and social development.

And just a few days earlier, the European court of human rights [ECHR] in Strasbourg formally decided that Abdullah Ocalan, head of the banned Kurdish Workers' Party or PKK, had the right to appeal against his death sentence.

To national delight, Ocalan was kidnapped by Turkish agents in Kenya last year and brought home to stand trial for his role in the country's bloody 16-year separatist war. The ECHR is not part of the EU, but all members of the Council of Europe, including Turkey, are bound by its decisions.

Like the 12 other countries currently seeking to join the union, from Estonia to Malta, and Slovakia to Cyprus, Turkey has to meet a rigorous set of economic, legal and political criteria. But the changes it must make before membership talks can even start under a so-called "accession partnership accord" are in many ways much tougher than for others - because of the sheer scale of its problems.

With a population of 63m people, mostly Muslims (and the unstated, though very real, assumptions of racism or prejudice that go with that), Turkey is by far the largest of all the candidate countries, though not the poorest (in GDP terms it is ahead of Romania, Bulgaria, Lithuania and Latvia). Euro-barometer polls show that more people in the current 15 member states oppose its candidacy than that of any other country.

If it were to join the EU today, it would be second only in influence to Germany, with whom its relations (dominated by issues of gastarbeiter and migrants) have always been surly. If it were to join in 20 years or so, according to current population trends, it would be the biggest and most powerful of 28 member states. Optimistic Turks say they could be in by 2010.

Others think, frankly, that they will never actually make it into this "Christian club". Uniquely, Turkey's candidacy is a problem for an existing EU member - Greece - despite a thaw in relations last year, Athens rarely misses an opportunity to make life difficult for its historic enemy.

Problems over Cyprus and the Aegean loom as large as ever. Insistence by Greece on including references to these issues in the terms for Turkey's accession partnership last month brought a furious response from prime minister Bulent Ecevit, who accused the EU of "deceiving" him over what had been agreed in Helsinki.

If the EU wants a just solution to the Aegean dispute, the way for that is not bowing to Greece's caprices but "...a civilised dialogue with Turkey," he complained. And his foreign minister, Ismail Cem, went undiplomatically further, accusing the EU of behaving like "colonial governors" by setting offensive new conditions for membership.

Matters were not helped by the fact that the European parliament had just approved a resolution formally accusing Turks of genocide against the Armenians 85 years ago - another hardy perennial of this deeply troubled relationship.

The Ocalan case will be in suspension until a ruling on his appeal, probably next summer. But the Turkish elite, at least, already understands well enough that resolving what is euphemistically called the "south-eastern problem" is essential to EU membership. In one encouraging sign recently, a powerful army chief signalled that he could accept Kurdish-language broadcasts - a key demand by Brussels.

Hanging Ocalan would be a severe, perhaps mortal, blow. But as one expert observer put it: "The distinction between EU opposition to the death penalty in principle and EU support for Ocalan is often lost on those forces in Turkey who see the bloc as bent on at best excluding Muslim Turkey and at worst undermining its security and unity."

And Turkey's concern for its security has raised a new difficulty with the EU that also looks like being very hard to resolve. Ankara, where the suspicious and powerful military establishment still plays a central role, has steadfastly refused to drop its opposition to the EU's nascent rapid reaction force - intended to mount limited operations when Nato is not involved.

The problem here is that Turkey, with the second largest army in the Atlantic alliance, does not want to give the green light to a force which it fears, however unrealistically, may one day operate in its own backyard.

EU governments cannot go ahead without Nato's consent, partly to avoid undermining it, and partly because they will need to borrow its weapons and equipment. Despite a personal appeal from Bill Clinton, Ecevit is sticking doggedly to his guns: full decision-making powers for Turkey in EU defence operations or no deal with an alliance where it has always been a valued member.

Legions of harassed diplomats are now working overtime to try to solve this knotty problem. But it is yet another illustration of the well-known - and depressingly familiar - fact that Turkey's march to Europe is always going to be a long and difficult one.

And just a few days earlier, the European court of human rights [ECHR] in Strasbourg formally decided that Abdullah Ocalan, head of the banned Kurdish Workers' Party or PKK, had the right to appeal against his death sentence. To national delight, Ocalan was kidnapped by Turkish agents in Kenya last year and brought home to stand trial for his role in the country's bloody 16-year separatist war. The ECHR is not part of the EU, but all members of the Council of Europe, including Turkey, are bound by its decisions. Like the 12 other countries currently seeking to join the union, from Estonia to Malta, and Slovakia to Cyprus, Turkey has to meet a rigorous set of economic, legal and political criteria. But the changes it must make before membership talks can even start under a so-called "accession partnership accord" are in many ways much tougher than for others - because of the sheer scale of its problems. With a population of 63m people, mostly Muslims (and the unstated, though very real, assumptions of racism or prejudice that go with that), Turkey is by far the largest of all the candidate countries, though not the poorest (in GDP terms it is ahead of Romania, Bulgaria, Lithuania and Latvia). Euro-barometer polls show that more people in the current 15 member states oppose its candidacy than that of any other country. If it were to join the EU today, it would be second only in influence to Germany, with whom its relations (dominated by issues of gastarbeiter and migrants) have always been surly. If it were to join in 20 years or so, according to current population trends, it would be the biggest and most powerful of 28 member states. Optimistic Turks say they could be in by 2010. Others think, frankly, that they will never actually make it into this "Christian club". Uniquely, Turkey's candidacy is a problem for an existing EU member - Greece - despite a thaw in relations last year, Athens rarely misses an opportunity to make life difficult for its historic enemy. Problems over Cyprus and the Aegean loom as large as ever. Insistence by Greece on including references to these issues in the terms for Turkey's accession partnership last month brought a furious response from prime minister Bulent Ecevit, who accused the EU of "deceiving" him over what had been agreed in Helsinki. If the EU wants a just solution to the Aegean dispute, the way for that is not bowing to Greece's caprices but "...a civilised dialogue with Turkey," he complained. And his foreign minister, Ismail Cem, went undiplomatically further, accusing the EU of behaving like "colonial governors" by setting offensive new conditions for membership. Matters were not helped by the fact that the European parliament had just approved a resolution formally accusing Turks of genocide against the Armenians 85 years ago - another hardy perennial of this deeply troubled relationship. The Ocalan case will be in suspension until a ruling on his appeal, probably next summer. But the Turkish elite, at least, already understands well enough that resolving what is euphemistically called the "south-eastern problem" is essential to EU membership. In one encouraging sign recently, a powerful army chief signalled that he could accept Kurdish-language broadcasts - a key demand by Brussels. Hanging Ocalan would be a severe, perhaps mortal, blow. But as one expert observer put it: "The distinction between EU opposition to the death penalty in principle and EU support for Ocalan is often lost on those forces in Turkey who see the bloc as bent on at best excluding Muslim Turkey and at worst undermining its security and unity." And Turkey's concern for its security has raised a new difficulty with the EU that also looks like being very hard to resolve. Ankara, where the suspicious and powerful military establishment still plays a central role, has steadfastly refused to drop its opposition to the EU's nascent rapid reaction force - intended to mount limited operations when Nato is not involved. The problem here is that Turkey, with the second largest army in the Atlantic alliance, does not want to give the green light to a force which it fears, however unrealistically, may one day operate in its own backyard. EU governments cannot go ahead without Nato's consent, partly to avoid undermining it, and partly because they will need to borrow its weapons and equipment. Despite a personal appeal from Bill Clinton, Ecevit is sticking doggedly to his guns: full decision-making powers for Turkey in EU defence operations or no deal with an alliance where it has always been a valued member. Legions of harassed diplomats are now working overtime to try to solve this knotty problem. But it is yet another illustration of the well-known - and depressingly familiar - fact that Turkey's march to Europe is always going to be a long and difficult one.

webTitle: Battle for succession begins at BBC News

fields.headline: Battle for succession begins at BBC News
fields.standfirst: Special report: the BBC
fields.trailText:
11.15am: Richard Sambrook and Roger Mosey are the hot favourites to replace Tony Hall as BBC News director, write Jason Deans and Jessica Hodgson.
Special report: the BBC
fields.body:
Senior BBC News executives Richard Sambrook and Roger Mosey are the hot favourites in the race to replace Tony Hall as BBC News director.

The formal battle to clinch one of the most prestigious positions in the BBC began today with reports that Mr Hall had decided to leave after 30 years.

An announcement had been expected this afternoon following weeks of negotiations about a new job as the Royal Opera House's chief executive.

However, any announcement is likely to be delayed until after Christmas as the two sides are still "haggling over the details", according to sources.

Mr Hall's job as guardian of the corporation's editorial standards and independence is seen as a key role and is likely to go to an insider.

It is not yet clear whether Mr Hall will depart before the general election, which is likely in the spring.

Mr Sambrook is deputy director of BBC News and is highly regarded by journalists.

He has also won the ear of director general Greg Dyke.

A former head of BBC newsgathering, Mr Sambrook was acting director of sport for several months this year before Peter Salmon took the job - a sign that he is seen by Mr Dyke as a trusted lieutenant.

Mr Mosey, as head of TV news, has been heavily involved in the recent move of the BBC1 Nine O'Clock News to 10pm.

He made his name as editor of the Today programme and before taking up his post in television, was former controller of Radio 5 Live, one of the BBC's biggest success stories of recent years.

Other names in the frame include ITV's head of current affairs Steve Anderson, Nigel Dacre, editor of ITV's news programmes at ITN, CNN International boss Chris Cramer - a former BBC executive - and Sky News boss Nick Pollard.

webTitle: Sambrook contends for top BBC News job

fields.headline: Newsgatherer Sambrook has skills for top job
fields.trailText:
2.15pm: Richard Sambrook, contender for the director of BBC News, earned his management spurs as head of newsgathering, writes Jason Deans.
BBC News chief quits
Popescu to edit BBC Ten O'Clock News
fields.body:
Richard Sambrook's rise to be BBC News deputy director and now a leading contender for the top news job may cause raised eyebrows outside the corporation, but insiders are well aware of his management pedigree and capabilities.

As too, apparently, is BBC director general Greg Dyke, who asked Mr Sambrook to baby-sit the director of sport job for six months earlier this year.

Mr Sambrook earned his BBC management spurs during a three-and-a-half year stint as head of newsgathering.

Running newsgathering, which involves managing the BBC's vast network of field producers and reporters and negotiating news supply deals with the agencies and other broadcasters, is not as glamorous or high profile as other management roles within BBC News.

The head of TV or radio news programmes, for instance, can expect to be in the media spotlight every time a controversy blows up around Newsnight or Today.

But the head of newsgathering plays a vital role - and arguably the most powerful within BBC News - in feeding stories to the beast that is the BBC's array of news networks and bulletins.

Mr Sambrook joined the BBC in 1980 as a radio news subeditor, before switching to TV news. He rose through the ranks as a producer and programme editor, before taking over as head of newsgathering in June 1996.

He took up his current job in December last year.

But Mr Sambrook is not the sort of TV executive you find hanging around the Groucho. He is more likely to be swapping war stories with TV news mates over a pint in the local BBC boozer.

Grammar-school educated with an English degree from Reading University, Mr Sambrook is regarded as a no-nonsense, down-to-earth character with a dry, self-deprecating sense of humour.

But those who know him suggest that behind his affable exterior Mr Sambrook is more ambitious than he lets on. The quiet man of BBC News should not be underestimated.

webTitle: Milburn to press on with NHS plan

fields.headline: Milburn to press on with NHS plan
fields.trailText: The government yesterday signalled its determination to press ahead with a shake-up of the NHS and social services in the face of criticism from sections of the medical profession and community health councils. By Michael White
fields.body:
The government yesterday signalled its determination to press ahead with a shake-up of the NHS and social services in the face of criticism from sections of the medical profession and community health councils.

The health secretary, Alan Milburn, published the health and social care bill to implement parts of the NHS plan, which he and Tony Blair unveiled last summer.

The bill proposes granting nurses and pharmacists a wider medical role (notably in prescribing drugs) and tackling hospital "bed blocking" by improving ties with social services departments. Controversially, Mr Milburn also wants to see local community health councils replaced with patients' forums inside every NHS trust.

The bill proposes to empower health authorities to suspend sex abusers in the health service without going through the current protracted procedures. This follows an announcement of an inquiry into the case of a GP who abused patients over eight years.

Locum services will also be more tightly regulated, further examples of what Alan Enthoven, the professor who created the Tories' NHS "internal market" policy, calls a doomed attempt to modernise "a public sector monopoly".

The reforms will be hard fought up to the election. Contrary to some reports ministers have not drawn back from their controversial proposal to prevent hospital doctors from taking on part time private practice until seven years after they qualify. The rule change can be made within the existing legislative framework.

The device is intended to protect the NHS's investment in training doctors at public expense.

The bill represents Labour's foray into the partnership with the private sector in its provision for private funds to be used to help rebuild inner city GP's surgeries.

There are fears that ministers might withdraw from proposals to create primary care trusts. The trusts would allow health authorities to create partnerships with social services departments to improve the situation of elderly people who "block" hospital beds when they need only personal care.

The bill will implement Mr Milburn's controversial plan to give elderly people in homes free nursing care, worth up to £5,000 a year, while making them pay for personal care.

Mr Milburn's bill also provides cash incentives for the more innovative hospital trusts.

In a paper for the Adam Smith think tank Prof Enthoven called this idea "childish, almost embarrassing".

webTitle: Roger Alton scoops best editor award

fields.headline: Roger Alton scoops best editor award
fields.trailText: Observer editor scoops award. By Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
The Observer editor Roger Alton has scooped this year's What the Papers Say Award for the best editor.

The Observer picked up four gongs at the 44th annual awards ceremony set up by newspaper review show What the Papers Say, with the Guardian winning two.

Judges noted that Mr Alton "has turned [the Observer] around. It takes a real effort of will, ingenuity and long-term commitment to stop a long-term decline...In the last year, the paper has recovered its voice and its clout."

In particular, the judges singled out the Observer's revelations about the author Ken Follet's attack on Tony Blair as example of a "big political exclusive".

The Guardian and the Observer shared both the photography awards, news photographer of the year, which went to Murdo MacLeod, and sports photographer, which was awarded to Tom Jenkins.

Andrew Rawnsley, a columnist for the Observer, won the columnist of the year award for the revelations in his book Servants of the People, which were serialised in both the Observer and Daily Mail.

The Sun's Trevor Kavanagh won scoop of the year for his publication of material from the private memo from Tony Blair, indicating that he believed voters had lost confidence in him.

The Times's Janine di Giovanni won the award for foreign correspondent of the year, after being the only British journalist to report from the end of the Siege of Grozny in Chechnya.

Don Hale, the editor of the Matlock Mercury, who investigated an alleged miscarriage of justice in the case of Stephen Leslie Downing, the teenager convicted of the 1973 "Bakewell Cemetery" murder of Mrs Wendy Sewell, was voted Journalist of the Year.

The Daily Mail's Keith Waterhouse won the Gerald Barry award for lifetime achievement.

fields.headline: Bad tidings for new media
fields.trailText: 2.45pm A survey out in the new year reveals that traditional firms plan to cut their new media budgets, reports Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Just when you thought the dot.com world couldn't get any gloomier, a survey out in the new year reveals that traditional firms are planning to cut their new media budgets even further.

The news will send shivers down the spines of new media agencies which rely on retainers and project work from traditional firms for their bread and butter.

New media agencies have already had to tighten their belts, with most the larger global ones - Razorfish, Agency.com and Organic - having already laid off staff.

According to the research, only 6% of UK manufacturing and industrial businesses within the Times Top 1000 Companies have an e-business strategy for next year.

Further damaging findings from other industries - retail, media/publishing and IT/telecoms - are set to be revealed in the new year.

The research was carried out by ICM for e-business consultancy Rubus.

Andrew Yuille, head of marketing at Rubus, said: "The results are surprising when industrial manufacturing businesses are those who could realise the greatest business benefit from investment in B2B internet technology, through areas such as online exchanges and eCollaboration."

The warning follows the recent cost-cutting exercises by the major car manufacturers such as Ford and Vauxhall, as they axe jobs and review their branding and businesses strategies to improve their competitiveness.

While most of them agree that an online presence is necessary, e-commerce has yet to make any impact on the manufacturing industry.

webTitle: Police urge vital Damilola witness to come forward

fields.headline: Police urge vital Damilola witness to come forward
fields.standfirst: Special report: Damilola Taylor
fields.trailText: Detectives investigating the murder of Damilola Taylor have issued an urgent appeal for a potentially key witness to come forward.
fields.body:
Detectives investigating the murder of Damilola Taylor have issued an urgent appeal for a potentially key witness to come forward.

The witness has already contacted police through the confidential Crimestoppers telephone service - but did not leave contact details.

He or she - police are not even certain of the witness's gender - claims to have seen 10-year-old Damilola arguing with a group of youths just minutes before he was killed.

The informant was visiting London at the time and made the new claim in a call to Crimestoppers in Scotland.

Detective Superintendent David Dillnut said the caller claims to have seen Damilola near the Peckham leisure centre.

"The person described seeing him with two black boys who were arguing with Damilola. A third youth was called over by the first two youths," said Det Supt Dillnut.

According to Sky News, police know the identity of Damilola's killer and are attempting to assemble a case, pending new witnesses, before any arrests are made.

Meanwhile, the inquiry team has released a 15-year-old boy on police bail, after arresting him in connection with the November 27 murder. He is the 13th suspect to be questioned.

Police appeals for the anonymous informant and other witnesses to come forward were coupled with assurances that they would receive police protection.

The appeals were echoed by Althea Smith, of the Southwark police and community consultative group. She made a moving plea for local people to remember Damilola's mother, Gloria.

"Just imagine, three days to go to Christmas - how would you feel as a parent to feel you have lost someone who is so close to you?

"Think about on Christmas morning how it will feel for Gloria to look under the Christmas tree at presents for Damilola, but there's no Damilola," she said.

webTitle: Second man arrested before Madonna's big day

fields.headline: Second man arrested before Madonna's big day
fields.trailText: Police have arrested a second man in the Highland town of Dornoch, where Madonna will marry film director Guy Ritchie later today.
fields.body:
Police have arrested a second man in the Highland town of Dornoch, where Madonna will marry film director Guy Ritchie later today.

The arrest was made the early hours of this morning following the christening of the couple's son, Rocco, in Dornoch cathedral.

Northern Constabulary says that a 33-year-old man from the south of England is currently in custody and will appear at Dornoch sheriff court at a later date.

Police would not give any details of the alleged offences, but say they are not linked to the arrest last night of a 51-year-old man.

The elder man did not disturb the christening and was not considered to be a stalker.

Neither men are members of the media, police added.

webTitle: Mosey: the man media hacks warm to

fields.headline: Mosey: the man media hacks warm to
fields.trailText: 2.45pm If contender Roger Mosey gets the top BBC News job, he may prove to be more accessible than his predecessor, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Were Roger Mosey, BBC head of TV news programmes, to bag the BBC News director's job, he would certainly provide more accessible and media-friendly material for the corporation's spin doctors than present incumbent Tony Hall.

Mr Mosey is an assiduous emailer, regularly responding to enquiries and contacting journalists to point out factual errors or make sure the BBC side of an argument gets across while a story about one of his shows is running.

In his current job and previous role, as controller of Radio 5 Live, he also popped up from time to time in authored pieces on the media pages of the nationals, eloquently arguing the BBC's case over issues ranging from the tone of political interviews on Today to News 24.

Nobody likes a media tart. But the reason media hacks warm to the Oxford University-educated Mr Mosey and quote him is because he is genial and approachable - not always qualities found in senior BBC executives.

However, behind the media friendly image, Mr Mosey is also regarded as a canny political operator - an essential attribute for those wishing to prosper in the BBC - who can be ruthless when necessary.

The phrases "obsessive" and "very organised" have been used to describe his management style during three years as Today editor and another three as Radio 5 Live controller.

In his current role as head of TV news, Mr Mosey has been at the heart of one of the most controversial developments in Greg Dyke's first year as director general - the move of the BBC Nine O'Clock News to 10pm.

fields.headline: UPS scraps £30m Olympics sponsorship
fields.trailText: 3pm: UPS has axed its sponsorship of the next Olympics just a year before the next winter games, reports Daniel Rogers.
fields.body:
United Parcel Service has axed its estimated £30m sponsorship of the next Olympics, leaving the International Olympic Committee without a delivery partner just a year before the next winter games in Salt Lake City.

UPS, a backer of the Sydney games in September and a major Olympic sponsor since 1994, said that while it was "proud" to have been a sponsor it could "no longer build a business rationale to continue".

It is the first major sponsor to desert the IOC since the corruption scandal erupted over the Olympic bidding process in Salt Lake City last year.

Recent research from the Chartered Institute of Marketing revealed that the brands that adopted "ambush" marketing strategies in Sydney enjoyed more public recognition than the official Olympic sponsors.

Official sponsors Nike and Visa were less associated with the games in the minds of consumers than their respective rivals Adidas and American Express.

IOC marketing director Michael Payne was unavailable for comment but is understood to have been keen to sign up UPS for further sponsorship.

Last summer IOC president Antonio Samaranch announced: "We need UPS. The IOC and UPS must be friends forever."

The IOC generated over £200m from the sponsorship of the Sydney games. UPS was one of 11 major sponsors, which also included Coca-Cola and IBM.

In a joint statement, UPS and the IOC said they would continue to work together on ways for the parcel carrier to offer its services and expertise.

webTitle: Response: The NHS is not being privatised

fields.headline: Response: The NHS is not being privatised
fields.standfirst: John Appleby and Justin Keen argue that, while the government has a tendency to use private sector solutions to solve public sector problems, there is no danger of the NHS being privatised
fields.trailText: John Appleby and Justin Keen argue that, while the government has a tendency to use private sector solutions to solve public sector problems, there is no danger of the NHS being privatised.
fields.body:
Yesterday ( 21 December) Guardian columnist George Monbiot accused the government of privatising the NHS. He claimed that a combination of new NHS accounting practices, direct charges for services and the use of the private finance initiative, "signals the beginning of the end of public health provision in the United Kingdom. The NHS is being privatised."

This might come as a surprise to anyone who recalls the enormous real terms increases in NHS spending announced in the 2000 Budget. So what is Mr Monbiot on about?

Like many professional campaigners, Mr Monbiot uses the c-word to corral a jumbled collection of disparate policy actions - conspiracy. But where is the conspiracy? Privatisation must mean that we are all about to start paying to see a GP or for a stay in hospital. Wouldn't the government have to tell us about this, so that we could start saving? There are certainly problems with some health policies, but another c-word - cock-up - is nearer the mark in explaining them.

But is it even a cock-up? With regard to Mr Monbiot's privatisation argument, it is worth pointing out that the NHS has always contracted out small volumes of care to the private sector. And in any case, as he says, this will be of benefit to patients. Using the private sector at the margins - the numbers of patients that will be cared for will be a minute proportion of the total NHS workload - is part of a strategy to enable the NHS to respond flexibly to peaks in demand. Privatisation, or just a sensible response to a complex planning problem?

Mr Monbiot cites the government's plan to strike a "concordat" with the private sector. Under the concordat the NHS will, if it feels necessary, increase its capacity by purchasing care from private providers. This agreement is yet to be fully developed, but is predicated on the assumption that care is of a high quality and that it is cost effective. There are some obvious constraints here - the NHS can only buy services at prices it can afford, and can only spend within its budget.

It also helps to get some basic facts straight. For instance the NHS does not, as Mr Monbiot claims, allocate its funds to individual patient "accounts". This suggests that patients have a limited amount of money for their treatment needs. This is wrong. Money is allocated to health authorities and the new primary care groups to fund care for their whole population, and is determined using the most sophisticated needs-based formula in the world.

Further, there were no new charges announced in the NHS Plan. To be sure, the proposal to create Care Trusts will lead to the integration of health and social care. This will involve the NHS taking over some services currently charged for by social services - but the point is that there have always been charges for social services. Labour could and should look at this - but as part of a review of social care charging, not privatisation of the NHS by stealth.

Don't get us wrong. We share some of the concerns expressed in the article. The Private Finance Initiative creates more problems than it solves. We agree that the government has an instinctive tendency to reach for private sector "solutions" to public sector problems. But the response should be to undertake measured assessments of all public-private partnerships, and not just make wild accusations.

Finally, Mr Monbiot fails to ask why the government would want to privatise the NHS. It is possible to devise convoluted, conspiratorial answers to this question. However, unless the entire health policy community has been misled, the answer is straightforward: there is no reason.

 John Appleby and Justin Keen work at the King's Fund, London

webTitle: Popescu to edit BBC Ten O'Clock News

fields.headline: Popescu to edit BBC Ten O'Clock News
fields.standfirst:
Special report: the BBC
TV news: battle of the bulletins
fields.trailText: 12.45pm: A former ITN News at Ten boss is to edit the BBC Ten O'Clock News bulletin after the election, reports Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
A former ITN News at Ten boss is to edit the BBC Ten O'Clock News bulletin after the election.

Mark Popescu, who joined the BBC three years ago from ITN where he was output editor, is to replace Jonathan Baker.

His appointment could signal a new approach for the Ten O'Clock News, which will be plunged into a fierce ratings battle when ITV brings back News at Ten in January.

Mr Baker is moving to be World News editor, where he will manage high-profile BBC correspondents including Kate Adie and John Simpson. Mr Baker replaces Jenny Baxter, who is becoming production editor for newsgathering.

A BBC spokeman said Mr Popescu would not move to his Ten O'Clock News job until after the general election, which is expected in the spring, because it was a tough time for a new editor to take over such a key bulletin.

A BBC spokesman said: "We don't want to rock the boat before the election".

Mr Popescu joined the BBC in 1997 where he worked on News 24 and the relaunch of the Six O'Clock News.

The news comes amid speculation that the BBC is about to announce a replacement for its head of news, Tony Hall, who is thought to be close to accepting a job as head of the Royal Opera House.

fields.headline: Robinson departs Weekend Watchdog
fields.trailText: 2pm: Anne Robinson is quitting as presenter of BBC1 Friday night consumer affairs show Weekend Watchdog, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Anne Robinson is quitting as presenter of BBC1 Friday night consumer affairs show Weekend Watchdog, because of her extra workload with hit BBC2 quiz show The Weakest Link.

But Ms Robinson will continue to front the main Thursday night edition of Watchdog.

She will present her last Weekend Watchdog, a 60-minute live special of the show that she has been with since it launched in 1995, on Friday January 5.

Ms Robinson said: "Having started Weekend Watchdog I'm very sad to be leaving it. But I'm thrilled that in the time it has been running, we've changed the tune of the travel industry, who now recognise that customers have to be taken seriously."

A BBC spokeswoman said Ms Robinson had decided to stop doing Weekend Watchdog because of the extra workload of filming The Weakest Link.

She added that in some weeks Ms Robinson was recording nine editions of hit BBC2 afternoon quiz show, plus The Weakest Link: Champions League for BBC1.

The presenter and journalist has become a cult figure following the success of The Weakest Link, due to her harsh treatment of contestants and catchphrase when they are eliminated, "You are the weakest link, goodbye".

Guest presenters will front the remaining editions of the current run of Weekend Watchdog after January 5.

fields.headline: Successful operation for Holby City
fields.trailText: 2pm TV overnights: ITV's Robson Green vehicle Close and True lost out to the BBC's hospital drama Holby City last night, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Despite the presence of Billy Elliot star Jamie Bell, ITV's Robson Green vehicle Close and True lost out to the BBC's Holby City last night.

The hospital drama racked up 7.3m viewers and a 33% share for its 9pm Christmas special, whilst the ex-Soldier Soldier star's vigilante lawyer series could only muster 6.6m on ITV.

Before that, Who wants to Be a Millionaire? scored 10.8m viewers and 47% share in its 8pm slot.

However, the BBC attacked Chris Tarrant's show with a double header of This Is Your Life and a Vets in Practice Christmas special, which drew a combined 11.3m.

BBC2's gardening night, featuring the gardener of the year final, attracted a fertile 3.6m viewers between 8pm and 10pm.

But the biggest shock came with ITV's car review show Pulling Power, featuring Gail Porter running the rule over a Peugeot Cabriolet.

Its 10.30pm audience of 2.8m drove straight past genius gangster series the Sopranos, which could only draw 1.5m on Channel 4.

Before that, Who wants to Be a Millionaire? scored 10.8m viewers and 47% share in its 8pm slot. However, the BBC attacked Chris Tarrant's show with a double header of This Is Your Life and a Vets in Practice Christmas special, which drew a combined 11.3m. BBC2's gardening night, featuring the gardener of the year final, attracted a fertile 3.6m viewers between 8pm and 10pm. But the biggest shock came with ITV's car review show Pulling Power, featuring Gail Porter running the rule over a Peugeot Cabriolet. Its 10.30pm audience of 2.8m drove straight past genius gangster series the Sopranos, which could only draw 1.5m on Channel 4.

fields.headline: Narrow win for Labour
fields.trailText: Labour has won the by election for the Westminster seat of Falkirk West but with a hugely reduced majority.
fields.body:
Labour has won the by election for the Westminster seat of Falkirk West but with a hugely reduced majority.

A low turnout, at 36.2% the lowest for a Scottish election since the second word war, and a 16% swing to the SNP combined to lose Labour 13,000 votes in the constituency.

New member Eric Joyce won by just 705 votes - a result due in part to the controversy surrounding Falkirk West's former MP, Dennis Canavan.

The Labour rebel vacated the seat after he was expelled from the party for standing as an independent in the constituency at the Scottish parliament elections last year.

The seat, which polled 8,492 votes for the government, is technically a Labour gain from independent.

Mr Joyce said after his win that he would be willing to work with Mr Canavan. The nationalists, whose candidate David Kerr won 7,787 votes, said a similar swing would claim Robin Cook, Alistair Darling and Brian Wilson's seats in a general election.

Result

Eric Joyce (Labour) 8,492 (43.54%)
David Kerr (SNP) 7,787 (39.93%)
Craig Stevenson (Conservative) 1,621 (8.31%)
Iain Hunter (Scottish Socialist Party) 989 (5.07%)
Hugh O'Donnell (Liberal Democrat) 615 (3.15%)

fields.headline: Madonna's wedding
fields.standfirst: Ms Ciccone is about to become Mrs Ritchie. We give you the lowdown on the last uber-celebrity nuptials of 2000
fields.trailText: Ms Ciccone is about to become Mrs Ritchie. We give you the lowdown on the last uber-celebrity nuptials of 2000.
fields.body:
1. Who's that girl?, you may well be asking, getting married in the Scottish Highlands

2. Why it's Madonna and, as usual, she will be causing a commotion as she rounds off a year of celebrity weddings with her own, to British director Guy Ritchie.

3. Just like any other bride she will be hoping the ceremony goes like a prayer and, who knows, maybe a bit of hanky panky on the way to the reception.

4. But what marks Madonna out is her fame, which has never been borderline. Since the mid-1980s the pop star and sometime actress has been one of the most famous women in the world.

5. Not only has she made, and sold, a lot of music but cultural gurus are in awe of her appropriation of practices as diverse as Indian henna painting and vogueing from the New York drag scene.

6. Films include Evita, Dick Tracy and Desperately Seeking Susan.

7. With leading men Warren Beatty and first husband Sean Penn.

8. So when she set eyes on Ritchie, director of Lock, Stock and Two Smoking Barrels, it was hardly a meeting of celebrity equals and, to Madonna's eyes at least, her future husband must just have been a beautiful stranger.

9. Madonna has reinvented herself a number of times - but moving to London, professing her love for stout and complaining about house prices was perhaps one of the least expected.

10. Still, now we know how to get Brad Pitt and Gwyneth Paltrow to fly to Inverness in December. You may even see them get into the groove on this webcam.

fields.headline: Buying, Ruling, and Awarding
fields.trailText: YOU ARE JOHN'S ANGEL
fields.body:
YOU ARE JOHN'S ANGEL

This morning, Aston Villa broke their club transfer record to sign Juan Pablo Angel from River Plate for £9.5m. It's great news for Villa's frustrated fans, who have been calling for their manager to bolster the team. It's great news for John Gregory, who was beginning to look as though he'd never spunk his wad. And it's great news for Massive Attack, who are guaranteed a surge in royalty payments every single bloody time the Villa new-boy is profiled on one of Sky's imaginative football shows.

The deal is subject to Angel passing a medical and Villa securing a work permit and international clearance, but the club see no problems ahead and expect their new man to make his debut in the home game against Leicester on December 30. This inevitably means lengthy legal wrangles with the Department of Employment, River Plate, customs, agents, banks, etc. and so on.

Gregory, however, is too happy at finally buying someone to worry about such trifles. He sees the Colombian international, who in eight World Cup qualifiers has rattled in one goal, as the answer to Villa's scoring problems. "I am delighted to have signed him," grinned a garrulous Greg. "His goalscoring record is excellent, but he is technically also a very talented player. His record year-by-year with River Plate has got better." Let's hope linking him up with Dion Dublin and Julian Joachim helps him to continue that successful trend.

MR POTATO-HEAD FACES THREE YEARS IN JAIL

Flabby bigot Sinisa Mihajlovic faces a three-year jail sentence for racially abusing Patrick Vieira during Lazio's Big Cup match against Arsenal in October. Although Mihajlovic later apologised for calling Vieira a "black bastard" and a "black monkey", the Italian police have decided launch a legal investigation, according to today's Corriere della Sera.

It is the first time that such an action has been taken in Italian football and, if convicted, the big tool faces a maximum sentence of three years in jail.

Corriere della Sera also claimed that Italian police were investigating charges that the misshapen oaf also asked some Lazio fans to unfurl a banner at matches in homage to Serbian warlord Arkan. At an Italian league match on January 30, several days after Arkan's assassination, a banner was seen at the Stadio Olimpico which read "in honour of Arkan the Tiger".

THE FIVER'S INTERACTIVE ADVENT CALENDAR

Dec 22: Click here

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"Nobody tells me how I should present myself in public and I will shit on anybody who doesn't like that" - Bayern Munich captain Stefan Effenberg responds to Bayern Munich coach Ottmar Hitzfeld and Franz Beckenbauer, who criticised him for turning up at their swish Christmas party wearing cowboy boots and leather trousers. At least he didn't mention last year's party, where Beckenbauer fathered a love child, eh?

THE FIVER END-OF-YEAR AWARDS

Moment of the year: Henning Berg meets Redondo and a nation relaxes for another season.

Most hopeless act of buffoonery: Six months on, Phil Neville's comedy cameo against Romania still stands tall - like an uglier and more senseless version of the Millennium Dome - as a monument to searing incompetence. As Phil Babb left the country this summer, nothing else would come close.

Fattest radio phone-in presenter with most obnoxious face: David Mellor.

Best commentary: "It's in! It's Alfonsooooooooooo!" - Only Motty could make Spain's 4-3 injury-time win over Yugoslavia in Euro 2000 sound even more incredible than it was. You'll miss him when he's finally pensioned off and ends up interviewing nobodies on Sky Sports Extra.

Fattest radio phone-in presenter with most obnoxious opinions: Richard Littlejohn.

Most unprovoked attack on an England keeper by a foreign newspaper: "Seaman was static in Portugal's first two goals and slow off his line for the third. England would sometimes do far better if they played with a goalkeeper... rather than that piece of meat with eyes called Seaman" - Spanish daily AS.

Kooganism of the year: "If he's quoting Henry VIII, that's good enough for me" - The man himself, upon hearing Tony Adams was reading Henry V before the start of England's Euro 2000 campaign.

The he-made-the-buses-run-on-time award: "England's humiliation knows no end. We've sold our birthright down the river to a nation of seven millions skiers and hammer throwers who spend half their lives in darkness" - The Daily Mail's sharp-suited, witty, intelligent and urbane Jeff Powell on the appointment of silly old Sven-Goran Erikkson as England manager.

The Liverpool award for end-of-season choke: oh come on.

THE RUMOUR MILL

Glenn Hoddle will be the next manager of Tottenham, according to the Daily Mail. New Spurs owners Enic will relieve George Graham of his duties at the end of the season, paying the last year of his contract off.

Leeds chairman Peter Ridsdale has denied reports claiming that Celtic have bid £3m for Darren Huckerby.

NEWS IN BRIEF

Relatives of Liverpool supporters who died in the Hillsborough disaster have called for a face-to-face meeting with Sports Minister Kate Hoey, after she suggested she would consider a return to "safely designed standing areas" in Premier League grounds. "We challenge Kate Hoey to meet us and look us in the eyes as she attempts to explain why she is fiddling with safety in response to a vociferous minority of fans," said HFSG chairman Trevor Hicks.

Rangers are to unveil a statue of former captain and manager John Greig at a memorial service for those who died in the Ibrox disasters of 1902, 1961 and 1971 on January 2. The bronze statute depicts Greig, who is wearing a black armband, holding a ball and posing reflectively.

Manchester United striker Andy Cole will sign a new four-year contract worth around £78,000-a-week early next year, according to reports.

Coventry are expected to complete the signing of 16-year-old Swedish player Andreas Dahl in a £300,000 deal later today.

West Brom have agreed a fee with Portsmouth for Russell Hoult. The former Derby keeper could make his debut against Nottingham Forest after settling personal terms.

Aberdeen have told Paul Bernard, the only player in Scottish football outside the Old Firm to have cost £1m, that he can leave the Pittodrie club immediately.

St Johnstone defender Darren Dods has signed a new contract that will keep him at the club until 2004.

Manchester City striker Danny Allsopp has joined Notts County for £300,000.

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

Sky Sports 1: Futbol Mundial (5pm)

"When my friend Angus was at University in Leeds he was walking through the park when he overtook a jogging Harry Gration," writes Andrew Powers.

Premier League Preview (12midnight)

"I played cricket against the BBC Leeds mob last year," counters Martin Perry, "and one of their technicians was telling me that despite their seemingly chummy on-screen relationship, Harry Gration and Claire Frisby actually hated each other."

Sky Sports 2: Live Second Division Football - Bristol City v Bristol Rovers (7pm)

"Oh, and that Jake bloke who does the BBC Leeds government stories is a really bad loser as well."

Masters Football (10.15pm)

Keep your stories about regional television presenters, the majority of whom Fiver readers will never have heard of, coming to the.boss@theguardian.com.

British Eurosport: Classic Big Cup Football (10.15pm)

Although we may have forgotten about this brand new feature come the new year.

Radio 5 Live: 5 Live Sport (7.30pm)

Oh, come on, send them in, we're not going to forget about it on purpose.

fields.headline: Home Office ad spend doubles
fields.trailText: 1pm: The government doubled its advertising spend on Home Office initiatives in the last year,, writes Daniel Rogers.
fields.body:
The government doubled its ad spend on Home Office initiatives over the last year to over £11m, the home secretary Jack Straw revealed yesterday.

The news will prompt further criticism from the Conservatives that the government is spending taxpayers' money on attempts to improve its own image.

In answer to a written question in the House of Commons, Mr Straw said the Home Office ad spend for 2000 was £11.08m compared with £5.65m in 1999.

In June the Home Office appointed Rainey Kelly Campbell Roalfe/Y&R to handle its £5m crime prevention campaign as part of Mr Straw's strategy to cut crime dramatically over a five-year period.

It is also spending heavily on a campaign to recruit new police officers.

The news comes at a time when policing is a burning issue following the death of Damilola Taylor on a "lawless" Peckham housing estate earlier this month.

The Conservative party has attacked the government repeatedly over its high advertising spend compared with previous administrations.

Spend by government departments through the Central Office of Information was £105m last year, a 79% increase on the previous year's figure. This year's figures are expected to show a further increase.

webTitle: Court reveals how Hello! took wedding pictures

fields.headline: Court reveals how Hello! took wedding pictures
fields.standfirst:
Dec 22: media lawyers hail Hello! ruling
Key points from the Court of Appeal ruling
fields.trailText:
12.15pm: How Hello! magazine snatched pictures of Catherine Zeta-Jones'wedding has been revealed for the first time, writes Jessica Hodgson.
Dec 22: media lawyers hail Hello! ruling
Key points from the Court of Appeal ruling
fields.body:
The full circumstances of how Hello! magazine managed to snatch pictures of Catherine Zeta-Jones'wedding despite an exclusive deal with rival publication OK! have been revealed for the first time.

The photographer who took unauthorised snaps of the wedding of Michael Douglas and Catherine Zeta-Jones was Phil Ramey, a "well-known Californian paparazzo".

Up to now the source of the photographs remained a mystery with conflicting stories suggesting the footage was either from a video camera or from a hotel worker or guest.

And it is the identity of the photographer that yesterday paved the way for Mr and Mrs Douglas to sue Hello! magazine for breach of privacy under the new European Human Rights Act incorporated into British law in October.

"The Human Rights Act 1998 requires the courts in this country to give appropriate effect to the right to respect for private and family life set out in Article 8 of the European Convention on Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms," said the court yesterday.

It went on to explain that Mr Ramey was not a guest of the bride and groom. This was the key factor in the decision to allow Ms Zeta-Jones and Michael Douglas to sue Hello!.

"The reason why it is material to this case is that on the present evidence it is possible that the photographer was an intruder with whom no relationship of trust has been established," the ruling continued.

"If it was a guest or an employee, the received law of confidence is probably all the claimants needed."

Hello! owner Eduaordo Sanchez told the court said he had not commissioned the photographs, financed them or agreed a price for them in advance.

However, they were bought by the magazine from an agency which was selling the global rights to them.

The full 78-page judgement also states that Hello! offered three times the eventual sum paid by OK! to the couple for worldwide rights.

It also reveals how desperate OK! was to protect its exclusive rights because of plans for an upcoming flotation of Northern & Shell publishing.

The Court of Appeal ruling adds that on the day the injunction was sought "nine low-resolution photos of the wedding had been faxed to OK! from Holland; OK! had been told the photos were by Phil Ramey, a well-known Californian paparazzo; that copies of Hello! were already in the United Kingdom with a photo of the wedding on the front and would be distributed very shortly."

And the ruling details the intense security proceedings organised by Mr Douglas and Ms Zeta-Jones to protect their exclusive contract, suggesting that smuggling video footage out of the wedding must have been impossible.

"Mr Ashford [Paul Ashford, editorial director of OK! and now of Express Newspapers] described a sophisticated large-scale operation, planned with military precision, to try to ensure that no other media reporting took place.

"Security personnel saw someone with a camera on about six occasions during the reception. They immediately confiscated the camera and took the film out of it, thereby exposing the film and destroying any photographs that might have been taken."

It also emerged in yesterday's court ruling that OK! had secured syndication deals worth £750,000 for the wedding pictures.

The appeal judges found that Hello! had caused OK! to be in breach of contract by publishing the unauthorised pictures, which led to the termination of several of these rights deals.

Northern & Shell "received numerous telephone calls and emails from licensees threatening to terminate the licence as a result of those unauthorised photos being published", the ruling noted.

The ruling also contains the appeal judges' ruling on a statement by Martin Ellice, marketing manager for Northern & Shell, claiming that Hello! had brought its print deadlines forward to accommodate the snatched photographs.

fields.body:
Kikujiro
rental and retail Fox Pathé cert 12
****

After the brilliance of Sonatine and Hana-Bi, this light-hearted kids' film is like a holiday for Takeshi Kitano. It's a breather before tacking his American directing debut too, in the light of which, this is the kind of role Hollywood used to give Walter Matthau - a grouch with a kid in tow having to adjust reluctantly to a different sensibility. From referring to him dismissively as "you brat", he gradually remembers how to relate to childhood again. It's simple but inventive fare with much of the enjoyment coming from eccentric characters the couple meet on a long journey to reunite the nine-year-old with his mother. rental High Fliers cert 15
***

One of the year's best video debuts, Cheaters is based on a true story about a deprived Chicago school whose pupils get hold of the exam paper for the "academic decathlon" (a sort of written University Challenge). rental and DVD (£19.99) Columbia Tristar cert PG
***

A Woody Allen period piece, bathed, as usual, in a rosy, nostalgic glow. rental and DVD (£19.99) Columbia Tristar cert 15

Well, the first eight minutes are good fun. webTitle: Key points from the Court of Appeal ruling

fields.headline: Key points from the Court of Appeal ruling
fields.standfirst: Key points from the Court of Appeal ruling on Hello!'s spoiler pictures of Catherine Zeta-Jones and Michael Douglas.
fields.trailText: Paul Ashford, editorial director of Express Newspapers and Northern & Shell, described how the Douglas/Zeta-Jones wedding was "the last important feature before the end of the ABC year" for OK! magazine.
fields.body:
Paul Ashford, editorial director of Express Newspapers and Northern & Shell, described how the Douglas/Zeta-Jones wedding was "the last important feature before the end of the ABC year" for OK! magazine.

Lord Justice Brooke said:

"While OK! complain that Hello! behaved inproperly on the occasion which is at the centre of this appeal, Hello! adduced evidence which purported to show that this was merely a case of the pot calling the kettle black, and that OK! had been no stranger to similar spoiling tactics in the past....

Gloria Hunniford's wedding coverage, given exclusive coverage by Hello! was scooped by unofficial wedding pictures in OK!

"On that occasion OK! published its Issue 128 a few days before Hello! published its wedding photographs. OK! magazine that week bore the banners 'OK! ALWAYS FIRST FOR WEDDINGS' and 'GLORIA HUNNIFORD'S EXCLUSIVE WEDDING DAY' on its cover, which also boasted 'COMPLETE COVERAGE & BEAUTIFUL PICTURES INSIDE'. Six pages of wedding photographs appeared on pages 42-47. Hello! complained that these pictures were obviously not authorised by Hello! or by the married couple, and that they must have been obtained in similar circumstances (ie, surreptitiously) to those of which OK! make complaint in this actions."

OK's response: "OK! contents itself by saying that there had been no international publicity identifying the possessor of the exclusive media rights in advance of the Hunniford wedding. There was no security operation equivalent to the Douglas wedding. The guests at the Hunniford wedding were issued with disposable cameras and encouraged to take photographs by the bride and groom, who had agreed to pose for pictures on public grounds in their wedding attire. OK! also says that it understands that the sums paid for the right of coverage for the Hunniford wedding were much smaller."

"OK! asserted that Hello! offered three times the eventual contract sum for rights to exclusive coverage, but that the couple trusted OK! to project only the images they wanted projected to the public. Hello! does not dispute that it tendered for the rights, although it does dispute that it had offered three times as much as OK! At all events, this evidence shows that Hello! knew that exclusive rights were to be granted for coverage of the wedding, and that it did not secure them themselves."

On the security: "Mr Ashford described a sophisticated large-scale operation, planned with military precision, to try to ensure that no other media reporting took place.

"Security personnel saw someone with a camera on about six occasions during the reception. They immediately confiscated the camera and took the film out of it, thereby exposing the film and destroying any photographs that might have been taken. They then either escorted the person out of the reception, or if a wedding guest was involved, detained the camera until the guest was ready to leave the reception."

On the photographs: "At 7.30pm on Monday evening, 20th November, Ms Zeta-Jones telephoned the third claimants' head of legal affairs in London. She sounded upset and told him that a magazine was about to publish unauthorised photographs taken at their wedding. An interim injunction was obtained by Buckley J, as I have said, on the telephone later for granting the injunction, it appears that he was told that OK! had received information earlier in the day from more than one source that photos were being offered for sale; that nine low-resolution photos of the wedding had been faxed to OK! from Holland; that OK! had been told the photos were by Phil Ramey, a well-known Californian paparazzo; that copies of Hello! were already in the United Kingdom with a photo of the wedding on the front and would be distributed very shortly;"

On the legal right of celebrities to protect their image and livelihood: "Mr Maninder Gill [Northern & Shell's head of legal affairs] said [Zeta-Jones and Douglas] were upset at the possible publication of the unauthorised photographs by Hello!. He said that this was because the portrayal of their image in the film and entertainment industry generally was of 'incredible importance' as it was to most celebrities. This was because of the inevitable spillover of their persona and public image into their livelihoods. He explained that the demand by producers and directors for the service of actors and actresses was dictated to a large extent by what is commonly termed the 'pulling power' of the actor and actresses."

OK! planned to recoup the £1m spent on photos through syndication rights: "[Maninder Gill] added that his company had concluded about £750,000 worth of syndicate deals for the exclusive photographs, and that they had received numerous telephone calls and emails from licensees threatening to terminate the licence as a result of those unauthorised photos being published.

"Ms Cartwright, for her part, said that Hello! had no previous knowledge that these pictures were going to be taken until they were offered on the open market around the world on the Sunday. She explained that Hello! was then able to fit them in the magazine which was by then substantially ready.

"Mr Moore, who is the circulation director of Hello!, said that the print order had been confirmed to the printers in Spain on the Friday, and that the first copies of the magazine traditionally arrived in this country at 7am on the Monday. This issue had been running later than usual. To the best of his knowledge the print run had started on the Sunday, and about a third of the total order had arrived at Stansted on a cargo plane."

Later on that Monday 20th November - the day before OK! won an injunction against Hello! - the photographer Phil Ramey told Mr Anderson, the photos editor of Ok! that he was "pulling" the photos from all the US magazines to which he had distributed them.

webTitle: Christmas is no longer a time of giving

fields.headline: Christmas is no longer a time of giving
fields.standfirst: Christmas is now a festival of materialism, possessions and selfish greed, instead of a time of sharing and helping those in need, writes Bob Holman
fields.trailText: Christmas is now a festival of materialism, possessions and selfish greed, instead of a time of sharing and helping those in need, writes Bob Holman.
fields.body:
The millennium Christmas draws nigh. No doubt, the BBC will again give prominence to the carol service at King's College, Cambridge. Within its ornate surroundings, choristers from a fee-paying school will perform to a congregation of the affluent and privileged. I wonder if its doors would be open to the carpenter from Nazareth whose socially inclusive gospel embraced beggars, lepers, foreigners and the poor.

Christmas at King's can hardly have a greater contrast than with Christmas on the Easterhouse estate, Glasgow. I am not a salvationist - I call myself a Christian socialist - but, on moving to Easterhouse in 1987, I was drawn to the tough, eccentric Salvation Army captain there. At one carol service in the "Sally", the hall was packed. The mobile organ was on its last legs, the nativity scenes were drawn by graffiti-skilled teenagers and the choir was made up of women who knew all about poverty.

The captain was conducting a carol with great gusto when suddenly he walked out. An embarrassed silence followed until my wife initiated "choose your own carol". The captain had spotted a distressed man in great need enter the back of the building. He regarded that one person as more important than carols, so he left. That is the true spirit of Christmas.

Unfortunately, the captain later suffered a stroke - perhaps hastened by his insistence on always being available - and had to retire. But the social needs which he tried to alleviate remain. Living close to the "Sally" is a lone mother whose weekly income is £113.88.Together we poured over her normal payments which amounted to £113.25.How can she afford Christmas presents for her child?

The spin from new Labour suggests that poverty is being tackled. It might seem so to onlookers with incomes of £60,000-plus as they reside in their expensive southern homes. The reality is different for those in the housing schemes who depend upon income support, job seekers allowance and minimum wage.

It was at the "Sally" that I met Gran, her devoted former foster child, Iona, and Iona's son, Pete. Iona was a lone parent in very poor health, and she was pleased when Pete started attending our clubs and camps. Aged 15, he had been drifting, rarely went to school and was then unemployed. Aged 17, he got a job and came home with his wages. In his street, he was mugged and his arm slashed. He was warned not to report it. Pete retreated into the flat and took to drink. I used to call and persuade him to have some games of pitch and putt. Having coffee after one game, he said, "Bob, the happiest days of my life were at camp. Can I go as a helper?"

Sadly, within a fortnight he was dead. He choked on his own vomit. Iona asked me to take a service over his open coffin as it stood in his barely furnished bedroom. It all came back to me recently when I attended Gran's funeral. She had known a life of usefulness but never material comfort. Iona had been a good mother and is now alone. Pete's 17 years were spent in a damp flat in a life marred by violence.

Christmas is now a festival of materialism, possessions and selfish greed. Far better if it was a time when poverty was highlighted. Far better if the values of sharing, the practice of redistributing wealth and the action of joining with the socially excluded were at its heart. For these would contribute to a kind of Christmas society which really would be a cause for rejoicing.

 Bob Holman is the author of Kids at the Door Revisited, Russell House Publishing, 2000.

webTitle: It's quicker by sleigh - travel misery looms

fields.headline: It's quicker by sleigh - travel misery looms
fields.standfirst: If you're thinking of getting away for Christmas, then Derek Brown has a word of warning. Everyone else is thinking the same
fields.trailText: If you're thinking of getting away for Christmas, then Derek Brown has a word of warning. Everyone else is thinking the same.
fields.body:
There is no gentle way of putting this: travelling around Britain this festive weekend is likely to be hellish.

The road organisations are predicting gridlock, while the train companies are warning of delays and overcrowding. Even the airlines, which are running extra services, are stretched to capacity.

Given our modern lust for holiday travel, few motorists or passengers are likely to heed the dire warnings. From this afternoon, as offices and other workplaces close down for the long weekend, a grisly struggle is set to begin.

Holiday travel is always a bit of mess in Britain, with its clapped out, overcrowded infrastructure. This year, the problems have been badly exacerbated by the aftermath of the Hatfield train crash, and the consequent cancellation and slow running of train services.

Even the elements seem against us, with widespread fog in eastern parts, and continued flooding in the south.

The only winners are likely to be the coach operators, who are running more or less to capacity, and regional airlines, which have somehow found the aircraft and crews to carry some 200,000 extra passengers a month.

Road organisations are warning that the scale of delays cannot be gauged until the rush begins. Some of the more predictable bottlenecks are the western section of the M25 - which is always ghastly - the A303 trunk road and all routes to the West Country.

In the Midlands, the M1, M5, and M6 are all likely to be clogged.

On the railways, travel conditions will be at best uncomfortable, especially on the main east and west coast lines from London to Scotland and points in between.

On the west coast route, Virgin services are running at 80% of normal, but on the east coast, GNER is down to a 40% service. And on both lines, the trains are likely to be packed to capacity.

Virgin has introduced an airline-style boarding pass system to prevent gross overcrowding, and GNER staff are manning ticket barriers at the main terminii.

Both companies are pleading with prospective travellers - even those with valid tickets - to confirm their journeys and reserve the few remaining seats.

National Express, which has pressed every available long distance coach into service, says that its passenger load is up by between 15 and 20%, and that many of its weekend services are already fully booked.

Similarly, the airlines have laid on extra flights to the main regional airports - but many are fully booked.

At the main London airports - Heathrow, Gatwick and Stansted, staff are braced for a weekend stampede. They expect to handle 2m passengers.

The only sensible conclusion to draw from this catalogue of misery is to stay at home. But we won't. Family bonds, the pleasure of reunions with friends, and the herd instinct to get away from it all, will draw us into the travel maelstrom.

At least we'll have something to talk about over the turkey...
