fields.headline: Media lawyers hail Hello! ruling as first step to privacy law
fields.standfirst:
Dec 21: Zeta-Jones free to sue Hello!
Nov 23: OK! fails to stop Hello! showing Douglas wedding photos
fields.trailText:
9am: Media lawyers have welcomed yesterday's landmark Hello! court ruling as the first step to a privacy law, reports Jessica Hodgson.
Dec 21: Zeta Jones free to sue Hello!
Nov 23: OK! fails to stop Hello! showing Douglas wedding photos
fields.body:
Media lawyers have hailed yesterday's landmark court ruling on Hello! magazine's illicit pictures of Catherine Zeta Jones' wedding as the first "step in the direction of establishing a privacy law in the UK".

The judgement is the first to uphold a right to privacy under English law since the new Human Rights Act came into force in October.

And legal experts said it could eventually give celebrities recourse to legal action over unwelcome attention from newspapers and magazines.

In a landmark ruling, appeal court judges said celebrities as well as members of the public should have a right to seek damages if their privacy was invaded.

Chris Hutchins, the solicitor acting for Hello! magazine, said the ruling "established that there is a case for celebrities to claim a right to privacy".

Intellectual property specialist lawyer Margaret Briffa said the ruling was "very very important, in that it gives celebrities permission to pursue damages for invasion of privacy".

In the ruling, Lord Justices Brooke, Sedley and Keene noted that Mr Douglas and Ms Zeta-Jones had seized six cameras at the wedding in an attempt to protect their exclusive deal with OK!

Lawyers acting for Hello! had argued that they had practiced similar tactics to those employed by OK! at the wedding of Gloria Hunniford, for which Hello! had paid for exclusive rights.

But the appeal judges ruled that Ms Hunniford had not taken such steps to protect her privacy and the exclusivity of the photographs, noting that guests had been issued with disposable cameras.

The original ruling was made on November 23 when Appeal Court judges lifted a temporary injunction granted to OK! which prevented Hello! from publishing snatched photographs of the wedding of Michael Douglas and Catherine Zeta Jones.

OK! was granted a temporary injunction preventing copies of Hello! being sold.

However the full 78-page statement was only released yesterday.

The Appeal Court judges lifted the injunction because they felt that it was not an appropriate way to stop publication.

Scottish Tourist Board
Dec 22: Madonna stages webcam wedding
fields.trailText:
11.45am: The Scottish Tourist Board is cashing in on Madonna's wedding with an ad campaign featuring her Gaultier cone bra as a Scottish mountain range, reports Claire Cozens.
Scottish Tourist Board
Dec 22: Madonna stages webcam wedding
fields.body:
The Scottish Tourist Board is cashing in on Madonna's wedding with an advertising campaign that transforms her famous Gaultier cone bra into a Scottish mountain range.

With the world's attention focused on the Scottish highland town of Dornoch, where Madonna and Guy Ritchie will marry this afternoon, the Scottish Tourist Board is seizing the opportunity to promote Scotland as the perfect holiday destination.

The tongue-in-cheek advert, which uses the line, "Where does the world's greatest sex symbol go to escape?" has been rushed out on time for the wedding of the year.

"Madonna's wedding is fantastic news for Scotland," said David Reid, creative partner at the Scottish Tourist Board's ad agency, 1576.

"The area around Dornoch has already seen a boost of £2.5m thanks to the wedding, and there will definitely be a knock-on effect with people wanting to get married here.

"There's a feeling that if it's good enough for Madonna it must good enough for me."

The Scottish Tourist Board is also planning to revive a TV ad campaign that ran over the summer. The ads, in which returning holidaymakers reminisce about their experiences in Scotland, will be broadcast on ITV, Channel 5 and Sky over the weekend.

Quick to capitalise on the impending nuptials of the world's most famous pop star, the tourist board has already demonstrated its quick-witted approach to promoting the country to visitors.

Last week they set up a website to promote Scotland as the perfect place to get married. It has already attracted over 10,000 hits from all over the world, and claims to have been visited by someone in every state of America.

And this week two members of staff from its PR department have spent the week in Durnoch, where they have been promoting Scotland to the estimated 500 foreign journalists in the town.

webTitle: The most unfair US election ever

fields.headline: The most unfair US election ever
fields.standfirst:
News that Al Gore has lengthened his lead over Dubya in the popular vote only reiterates the sheer injustice of his defeat, says Martin Kettle in Washington

Special report: US election race
fields.trailText: News that Al Gore has lengthened his lead over Dubya in the popular vote only reiterates the sheer injustice of his defeat, says Martin Kettle in Washington.
fields.body:
Hey, America, maybe you don't want to know this, but Al Gore just increased his majority in the election that George W Bush won.

The latest figures, published yesterday, show that Gore got 50,996,064 votes on November 7. George W got 50,456,167. That gives Gore a majority of 539,897 votes over Bush.

Pretty close election, eh? Sure, but not that close when you actually look at the figures. Don't slip into the mistake of calling it "America's closest ever election", because it wasn't. Kennedy beat Nixon by 114,673 in 1960. That's what you call a close one. And Nixon beat Humphrey by 510,645 in 1968.

So in fact the 2000 contest was America's third closest election of modern times. The big difference was that Kennedy got to be president when he won narrowly, and so did Nixon. Gore's bigger win in the popular vote didn't win him the White House, as we all know.

The possibility of a president winning the popular vote but losing the electoral college is built into the American system. Sometimes, as we know, it happens. Like it did in 1824, when the new president was beaten by 38,149 in the popular vote. Or in 1876 when the president was 254,235 behind his rival. Or in 1888, when the winner lost by 90,956.

To which now add the year 2000, when the winner, Bush, lost the popular vote by 539,897, or by double the number of votes that anyone else has lost by and still become president. Or, to put it another way, lost by more than the total number of people who voted in the state of Idaho. Or all those who voted in Vermont and Wyoming put together. Or the votes in Alaska and the District of Columbia combined.

Or, to put it yet another way, Gore defeated Bush by a majority almost exactly the size of Austin, Texas, a city with 541,000 inhabitants. No, this wasn't the closest American election of all time. It was simply the most unfair.

"There's been a concession speech," someone pointed out this week to people like me. "There's been a declared victor. We even got the United States supreme court to intervene in it, which is a pretty historic thing. The election's over."

That was Jeb Bush speaking. The Florida governor had just certified the 25 electoral college votes from his state which gave the presidency to his brother by 271 to 266 for Gore (one woman from DC refused to vote for Gore in protest at the capital city's lack of voting rights in the US Congress).

Jeb was angry with several newspapers and news organisations from Florida and elsewhere, who are making plans to study some of the 180,000 Florida "undervotes" that never did get counted when the US supreme court conservatives handed the election to brother Dubya.

"Go ahead and do it, but is that going to rewrite history? I don't think so," the Florida governor said. "Should it rewrite history? No. We're a nation of laws and the rule of law prevails.

We're still waiting for word of how the statewide vote check is going to be conducted. But when Chief Justice William ("Christ, he's way to the right of Pat Buchanan" - HR Haldeman, 1971) Rehnquist and his conservative majority stopped the clock on the Florida counting, Bush's lead over Gore there was down to 154.

Since then, though, there have been fresh figures from two counties. An examination of the uncounted votes in Lake County, a heavily republican county in central Florida, has concluded that Gore should have had a further 130 votes there which were never properly counted.

Meanwhile, a separate re-examination exercise in Broward county, sponsored by the Miami Herald, has completed examining 871 out of 6,800 local ballots that were not included in the official Broward hand recount last month. So far, according to the Palm Beach Post, checkers have found 203 potential new Gore votes and 39 potential new Bush votes.

So, after looking at about 1% of the votes which Chief Justice "Way to the right" Rehnquist ordered to be cut from the election, the current overall total in Florida shows Gore 140 votes ahead.

Or, to put it another way, Bush wins again.

webTitle: Mihajlovic faces three years in jail for racist abuse

fields.headline: Mihajlovic faces three years in jail for racist abuse
fields.trailText: Sinisa Mihajlovic faces a three-year jail sentence for the racially abusing Patrick Vieira during Lazio's Champions League match against Arsenal in October. Although Mihajlovic later apologised for calling Vieira a "black bastard" and a "black monkey," the Italian police have decided launch a legal investigation, according to today's Corriere della Sera.
fields.body:
Sinisa Mihajlovic faces a three-year jail sentence for the racially abusing Patrick Vieira during Lazio's Champions League match against Arsenal in October. Although Mihajlovic later apologised for calling Vieira a "black bastard" and a "black monkey," the Italian police have decided launch a legal investigation, according to today's Corriere della Sera.

It is the first time that such an action has been taken in Italian football and if convicted Mihajlovic faces a maximum sentence of three years in jail. Corriere della Sera also claimed that Italian police were investigating charges that the player had asked some Lazio fans to unfurl a banner at matches in homage to Serbian warlord Arkan. At an Italian league match on January 30, several days after his assassination, a banner was seen at the Stadio Olimpico which read "in honour of Arkan the Tiger".

fields.headline: BT loses auction payments action
fields.trailText: BT and One2One failed yesterday in a high court claim that they were treated unfairly in comparison with two rivals as a result of which they lost millions of pounds.
fields.body:
BT and One2One failed yesterday in a high court claim that they were treated unfairly in comparison with two rivals as a result of which they lost millions of pounds.

They alleged that the timetable the government set for payment of sums due from winners of third-generation mobile phone licences gave an unfair advantage - amounting to unlawful state aid - to Vodafone and Orange.

Trade secretary Stephen Byers allowed Vodafone and Orange extra time to pay because, under auction rules, they were forced to break the relationship brought about by Vodafone's takeover of Mannesmann - which included Orange. The split, necessary to ensure that no single operator had more than one licence, was completed in August and the now-separated companies paid on September 1 - Vodafone paying almost £6bn and Orange £4bn.

BT subsidiary BT3G and One2One, which had to settle their £4bn bids in May, complained that the extra time saved their rivals £1m per working day each because their money was still earned interest. They contended that they each effectively lost £80m in interest.

Mr Justice Silber said the benefit to Vodafone and Orange did not amount to state aid. BT3G and One2One were given leave to appeal.

fields.headline: Villa sign Angel for £9.5m
fields.trailText: Aston Villa have signed River Plate's Columbian international striker Juan Pablo Angel for a club record £9.5m, subject to a medical and work permit.
fields.body:
Aston Villa have signed River Plate's Columbian international striker Juan Pablo Angel for a club record £9.5m, subject to a medical and work permit.

Villa clinched the deal in the early hours of Friday morning after protracted negotiations between both clubs and Angel's advisors were finally completed. Angel will fly to Birmingham after Christmas to formally tie up the deal, and could make his Villa debut at home to Leicester City on December 30.

Club spokesman Phil Mepham said: "Aston Villa are delighted to announce the successful conclusion of negotiations for Colombian striker Juan Pablo Angel for a club record fee of £9.5m.

"The deal, subject to a work permit and medical, was concluded in the early hours of this morning after a complicated process involving several parties.

"The club have already applied for a work permit and are now working to ensure Angel can arrive in this country as soon as possible. Subject to the granting of a work permit and international clearance from the Argentine FA, it is hoped that Angel will travel to Birmingham next week to complete formalities."

The signing of Angel, who has scored 17 goals in 17 matches for River Plate this season, smashes Villa's previous transfer record of £7m, which they paid Liverpool for Stan Collymore three and a half years ago.

webTitle: In brief: Arnie and Woody in unlikely partnership

fields.headline: Arnie and Woody in unlikely partnership
fields.standfirst: Plus: Irish singing star screen tests for Blade 2; Madonna and Guy's wedding no big deal for the woman who doesn't know who they are
fields.trailText: Plus: Irish singing star screen tests for Blade 2; Madonna and Guy's wedding no big deal for the woman who doesn't know who they are
fields.body:
 As film pairings go, this must be one of the most unlikely in history. Rumour has it that Arnold Schwarzenegger (pictured) has tired of his tough guy image and, in a bid to make more intellectual movies, is to work with Woody Allen. "In the 1980s men were not very secure and were happy to see a man with muscles," said the former Mr Universe. "Now no-one is interested in that... [Woody Allen and I] are talking about the script at the moment." This will presumably be alongside his commitments to the ultimate tough-guy no-brainer role he is to take in Terminator 3 next year.

 Showbiz Ireland reports that 18-year-old singing star Samantha Mumba has auditioned for a role in the new vampire movie Blade 2. Mumba's manager told the site: "I can confirm that Sam will be in America for nearly all of next year and that she has just done the screen test."

 While the world's press camps outside Dornoch, one person at least is unaware what all the fuss is about. Reverend Susan Brown, who is to marry Madonna and Guy Ritchie later today, admitted she had little idea who either of them were, and no idea that they were so famous. "I haven't got any Madonna records," she told reporters. "I haven't seen any Guy Ritchie films, although Madonna has one named after me, I think, called Desperately Seeking Susan."

webTitle: Roundup: the papers' best of 2000 lists

fields.headline: The best of the best of 2000
fields.standfirst: Almost a quarter of the year's book sales are made over the Christmas season. But, should you find yourself among the ranks of frantic last-minute present-hunters, take heart. Like a crack squad of Santa's literary elves, the nation's pundits and celebs have graciously given their verdicts on the years' best reads...
fields.trailText: We round up the titles that came top in the newspapers' books of the year. Plus: the top 10 most-mentioned books
fields.body:
Biography

Francis Wheen's Karl Marx: A Life found an unlikely fan in Boris Johnson. In the Daily Telegraph, the Spectator editor enjoyed a pleasantly double-edged gush: "I take my hat off to Francis Wheen... He has managed to persuade everybody that his subject was charming, witty and above all, right, whereas he was of course an appalling blot on humanity whose ideas pauperised millions for most of the last century." Meanwhile London: the Biography drew plaudits from Steven Berkoff, who felt that Peter Ackroyd showed London as "a living, breathing creature, greedy, bestial, even demonic" (Observer). Another demonic old beast, Alan Clark, enjoyed a posthumous smirk as the second part of his diaries, Into Politics, was published. Robert Harris called it an "elongated Etonian drawl of selfishness, lechery, snobbishness, hypochondria, self-delusion and melancholy transformed by the razor quality of Clark's prose and his reckless honesty" (Observer).

Debut novels

The first novel from wunderkind Zadie Smith, White Teeth, may have missed the Orange prize but it scooped the Guardian First Book Award. The Independent on Sunday summed up the consensus by stating that while the book is "far from perfect... its range and intelligence are extraordinary".

Another first-timer, Dave Egger, put his head in the noose in calling his debut A Heartbreaking Work of Staggering Genius. But the bluff worked. Zadie Smith offered a succinct explanation of why it was one of her books of the year: "It kicks ass" (Observer).

Harry Potter

William Hague boasted that JK Rowling's fourth wizard adventure, Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire, was one of his books of the year. Labour accused him of bandwagoning and suggested he keep his Harry Potter books next to the Hansard collection he has nurtured since the age of 13.

Something Amis

In the Independent on Sunday, Matthew Sweet declared that the Old Devil's missives, collected in The Letters of Kingsley Amis, turned "tea chests of raw material into an engrossing epistolary novel about a clean-cut young novelist who gradually becomes a stinky Thatcherite tom cat". Martin, meanwhile, shared his reminiscences of everyone from his father to the cousin murdered by Fred West, in Experience. "You may mistrust him," wrote Stella Tillyard, "but you can't help admiring and reading him."

The big guns

London's Evening Standard had no doubt that Muriel Spark's sinister spin on the Lucan affair, Aiding and Abetting, was "the best thing Spark had done for some time". And Philip Roth's latest, The Human Stain, won universal praise. Chris Patten, in the Observer, hailed "a man not afraid to wrestle with ideas, some of them unfashionable but troubling for any liberal conscience".

A family affair

Hey Yeah Right Get A Life, Helen Simpson's tales of London motherhood, found a sympathetic fan in Rachel Cusk (Evening Standard). "Motherhood had long been a subscription-only sort of subject," she sighed in recognition and relief. "Helen Simpson has found a way to tell it, and I hope that people beyond the constituency margins are listening."

Lorna Sage's memoir of a difficult Welsh childhood, Bad Blood, impressed Allison Pearson who labelled it "a beautiful account of [a] hellish, post-war childhood that lifts your spirits, even as [it] hurts your heart" (Daily Telegraph).

The year's most mentioned books:

1 Experience, Martin Amis

2 White Teeth, Zadie Smith

3 London, Peter Ackroyd

4 Hey Yeah Right Get a Life, Helen Simpson

5 The Blind Assassin, Margaret Atwood

6 Aiding and Abetting, Muriel Spark

7 A Heartbreaking Work of Staggering Genius, Dave Egger

8 The Human Stain, Philip Roth

9 Letters, Kingsley Amis

10 Bad Blood, Lorna Sage

"You may mistrust him," wrote Stella Tillyard, "but you can't help admiring and reading him." The big guns London's Evening Standard had no doubt that Muriel Spark's sinister spin on the Lucan affair, Aiding and Abetting, was "the best thing Spark had done for some time". And Philip Roth's latest, The Human Stain, won universal praise. Chris Patten, in the Observer, hailed "a man not afraid to wrestle with ideas, some of them unfashionable but troubling for any liberal conscience". "Motherhood had long been a subscription-only sort of subject," she sighed in recognition and relief. "Helen Simpson has found a way to tell it, and I hope that people beyond the constituency margins are listening." Lorna Sage's memoir of a difficult Welsh childhood, Bad Blood, impressed Allison Pearson who labelled it "a beautiful account of [a] hellish, post-war childhood that lifts your spirits, even as [it] hurts your heart" (Daily Telegraph). fields.headline: E-tailer Gameplay issues upbeat trading statement
fields.trailText: 10.45am: Online games retailer Gameplay has countered a recent stumble in its shares with a bullish trading statement, reports Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Online games retailer Gameplay has countered a recent stumble in its shares with a bullish trading statement.

The company said first-half revenues are set to top £40m, despite a flat computer games market that has been hit by delays in shipping the new PlayStation 2 consoles.

"This represents like-for-like growth for the acquired businesses in each territory at improving margins, despite weak or declining markets," said Mark Strachan, Gameplay chairman.

Although the company admitted market conditions "remain tough", shares in the company climbed 10%, or 11.5p, to 112.5p.

Gameplay's stock has crashed from a year-high of 1102p to under 120p, and has been caught in the turmoil which has savaged technology stocks over the past few weeks.

Aside from the general downturn in technology shares, Gameplay has also been targeted over fears that it will run out of cash in 18 months' time.

However, the company said it was confident it will reach profitability without needing to raise funds from what has become a hostile environment for e-retailers.

Gameplay floated on the small-company AIM market last year, and has been applauded for buying Pixel Broadband Studios, a US company that specialises in putting games on wireless devices.

The £34.1m purchase led to full-year losses of £33.4m.

webTitle: Gladiator wins UK minds, but Toy Story 2 earns most money

fields.headline: Gladiator wins UK minds, but Toy Story 2 earns most money
fields.trailText: Films by British directors take the top three slots in the BBC's best films of 2000 poll, but Walt Disney's Toy Story 2 wins the battle at the nation's box offices
fields.body:
No surprises from the BBC and their best of 2000 film poll. The summer's blockbuster, Gladiator, has been voted top movie of the year. Two out of every five votes that were cast went to the old-fashioned epic, directed by the British Ridley Scott.

The second and third slots also went to British directors - Sam Mendes' American Beauty, and Stephen Daldry's Billy Elliot.

Although Toy Story 2 only came in at number seven on the BBC's list, Screen International has released figures which reveal that it was the UK's top box office attraction of the year. The film's enormous success helped to boost cinema attendance figures to their highest level for more than 25 years.

The Walt Disney sequel to 1995's Toy Story earned £43.5m in cinemas across the UK and Ireland in 2000. Gladiator finished second, with £31m, and Chicken Run took third place on the top-earners list, grossing £29m in ticket sales.

fields.headline: Soderbergh dominates Golden Globe nominations
fields.standfirst: Traffic continues to score strongly in the run up to the Oscars; Billy Elliot, Brenda Blethyn and Catherine Zeta-Jones fly the flag for Britain
fields.trailText: Traffic continues to score strongly in the run up to the Oscars; Billy Elliot, Brenda Blethyn and Catherine Zeta-Jones fly the flag for Britain
fields.body:
Billy Elliot and actress Brenda Blethyn have staked early British claims for next year's Oscars by securing places on the nominees list for the Golden Globe awards, which were announced last night. Billy Elliot was nominated for Best Picture (drama) and Julie Walters is a nominee for Best Supporting Actress, while Blethyn is up for Best Actress in a comedy/musical for Saving Grace.

It's been a good year for director Steven Soderbergh (pictured), who dominates many of the categories, with two Best Director nods, for Traffic and Erin Brockovich, and Best Picture nominations for both movies as well.

Julia Roberts, who has already won two Golden Globes, will be hoping it's third time lucky - she and her push-up bra have been nominated for Erin Brockovich, but faces stiff competition from Bjork, for Dancer in the Dark, and Joan Allen, who has been acclaimed for The Contender.

Spanish actor Javier Bardem, who had to learn to speak English (and with a heavy Cuban accent to boot) for his role as a writer with Aids in Before Night Falls is up for Best Actor alongside Russell Crowe, Geoffrey Rush, Tom Hanks and Michael Douglas.

Not to be outdone by her husband, Catherine Zeta-Jones has also secured a Best Supporting Actress nomination for her role in Traffic.

Announcing the nominations, Kelsey Grammer admitted that he'd only seen one film all year. Not a comment on what most agree is one of Hollywood's worst years, but a comment on the Frasier star's busy schedule. "I can't comment on the films because I haven't gone to the cinema all year," said Grammer. "It's terrible. I've seen nothing, squat, but I intend to."

The winners will be announced in a ceremony on January 21, 2001.

The main nominations:

Best Actor In A Motion Picture (Comedy/Musical)
Jim Carrey (How The Grinch Stole Christmas), George Clooney (O Brother, Where Art Thou), John Cusack (High Fidelity), Robert De Niro (Meet The Parents), Mel Gibson (What Women Want)

Best Actress In A Motion Picture (Comedy/Musical)
Juliette Binoche (Chocolat), Brenda Blethyn (Saving Grace), Sandra Bullock (Miss Congeniality), Tracey Ullman (Small Time Crooks), Renee Zellweger (Nurse Betty)

Best Motion Picture (Comedy/Musical)
Almost Famous, Best In Show, Chicken Run, Chocolat, O Brother, Where Art Thou

Best Director
Ang Lee (Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon), Ridley Scott (Gladiator), Steven Soderbergh (Erin Brockovich) Steven Soderbergh (Traffic), Istvan Szabo (Sunshine)

Actor In A Motion Picture (Drama)
Javier Bardem (Before Night Falls), Russell Crowe (Gladiator), Michael Douglas (Wonder Boys), Tom Hanks (Cast Away), Geoffrey Rush (Quills)

Actress In A Motion Picture (Drama)
Joan Allen (The Contender), Bjork (Dancer In The Dark), Ellen Burstyn (Requiem For A Dream), Laura Linney (You Can Count On Me), Julia Roberts (Erin Brockovich)

Best Motion Picture
Billy Elliot, Erin Brockovich, Gladiator, Sunshine, Traffic, Wonder Boys

Best Screenplay (Film)
Cameron Crowe (Almost Famous), Stephen Gaghan (Traffic), Steve Kloves (Wonder Boys), Kenneth Lonergan (You Can Count On Me), Doug Wright (Quills)

Supporting Actor (Film)
Jeff Bridges (The Contender), Willem Dafoe (Shadow Of The Vampire), Benicio Del Toro (Traffic), Albert Finney (Erin Brockovich), Joaquin Phoenix (Gladiator)

Supporting Actress (Film)
Dame Judi Dench (Chocolat), Kate Hudson (Almost Famous) Frances McDormand (Almost Famous), Julie Walters (Billy Elliot), Catherine Zeta-Jones (Traffic)

Best Non-English Language Film
Amores Perros (Mexico), Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon (Taiwan), The Hundred Steps (Italy), Malena (Italy), The Widow Of St Pierre (France)

 Meanwhile, over in Toronto, Canada's film critics have named Ang Lee's Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon the best film of 2000, and given the film's young co-star Zhang Ziyi the nod as the Best Supporting Female Actor.

Steven Soderbergh took the award for Best Director for his film Traffic, and Benicio Del Toro won the Best Actor Award for his performance in Soderbergh's movie.

webTitle: Arts: Damon Albarn embraces world music

fields.headline: Damon's big adventure
fields.standfirst: Fed up with fame, adulation and Top 10 hits, Damon Albarn is embracing world music.  Caroline Sullivan is not impressed
fields.trailText: Fed up with fame, adulation and Top 10 hits, Damon Albarn is embracing world music. Caroline Sullivan is not impressed.
fields.body:
'It's Africa, innit? Nothing's the same once you've been to Africa," said Damon Albarn during a recent TV appearance. Blur's lead singer was still reeling from a week in Mali, which he visited in August as part of an Oxfam project to explore the cultures of countries along the Greenwich meridian. The experience, which culminated in him recording with Malian musicians, so impressed him that he speaks of it in a sort of hypnotised babble: "I do things, go places as part of the flow of my life, and my life becomes part of me and I become part of it."

Translation: "I'm the latest pop star to discover world music, and now that my musical consciousness has been raised I'm never going back to the Top 10 rat race. Have you seen my ngoni [That's a West AFrican springed instrument, if you were wondering]?"

On Saturday, Albarn will give an "overview of African music" on Radio 4. Only the most cynical could doubt his sincerity, as he has complained for years about feeling constrained by Blur's poppy parameters. He is clearly following his heart (and, wincingly, has adopted black slang to go with it, leading bassist Alex James to call him "the blackest man in west London"), but the thought occurs that there are people better qualified to give overviews of a continent Albarn had never visited until four months ago. Unfortunately, they are mainly broadcasters like Andy Kershaw and Charlie Gillett, who lack Albarn's mass appeal.

He's showing signs of rootsitis, a syndrome suffered by rock stars who've had the fame and the hits, but crave deeper validation, in the way that movie stars such as Nicole Kidman will do a West End play for next to no money because theatre is somehow more "real" than film. Inspired by musical curiosity or (as one suspects with Albarn) a yearning to detach from the past, they take a magical mystery tour in search of authenticity.

Adam Ant was doing it as far back as 1980, using elements of African drumming - which he called "Burundi beat" - and native American chanting. His slogan was, "If that music's lost its taste, then try another flavour." Taking him at his word, Paul Simon risked political censure by recording his Graceland album in South Africa with Ladysmith Black Mambazo. Peter Gabriel introduced Senegalese singer Youssou N'Dour to the British charts and David Byrne (through his Luaka Bop label) and Ry Cooder have been instrumental in taking South American and Cuban music to a global audience.

But who benefits most from these collaborations? The western popsters scoring easy credibility points (because nothing's the same once you've been to Africa)? Or the "world" musicians, who may sell millions of records (the Cooder-produced Buena Vista Social Club album is in 5m homes, while Ladysmith Black Mambazo made a fortune licensing a song to Heinz Beans) but end up pressured into more collaborations by profit-driven record labels?

Ladysmith founder Joseph Shabalala is ambivalent about cross-cultural patronage. "It's a good thing to work with people from other cultures, but it also might be a bad thing. It's wonderful when others respect our beautiful music - it shows us how to love and respect each other - but don't forget your own music. You're my brother, but don't forget your real brothers."

He could be addressing Albarn - who is oddly dubious about the effect of western celebrities visiting third world developing countries on charitable missions: "It doesn't work. It's patronising and inappropriate." He excludes himself on the grounds that his main purpose had been to make music with his Malian hosts, which apparently falls under the heading of breaking down boundaries, instead of patronage.

Veteran broadcaster Andy Kershaw, whose world music show has moved to Radio 3 after being axed by Radio 1, believes Albarn should be encouraged. "Good for Damon! What took him so long?" But Damon may not realise that he picked an unfashionable place to launch this new phase of his career. "I'm not trying to suggest he's 10 years behind the times," says Kershaw, "but I was making documentaries there in 1990, when Salif Keita's album, Soro, was the Buena Vista of its day. Mali's never had the same amount of international attention as it had then." Some critics even claim Mali had its musical heyday in the Middle Ages, when it generated a form of rhythmic story-telling that could be the earliest version of rap.

But the proof of the pudding will be in the listening. An album of Albarn's Malian jam sessions will be released next year, and only then will it be clear whether he can walk it like he talks it.

 Seven Days in Mali will be broadcast on Radio 4 at 10.30am on Saturday.

George Monbiot says the health service's flirtation with the private sector signals "the beginning of the end of public health provision in the UK" and the "privatisation of the NHS".

Below we publish his comment piece together with a response from John Appleby and Justin Keen of the King's Fund.

fields.headline: Rumours Unlimited
fields.standfirst: All today's rumours just want to go home
fields.trailText: Aston Villa have paid a club record £8.4m to River Plate for Juan Pablo Angel, according to Teamtalk. They claim John Gregory has already applied for Angel's work permit so the 25-year-old Colombian striker can play against Manchester United on Boxing Day.
fields.body:
Aston Villa have paid a club record £8.4m to River Plate for Juan Pablo Angel, according to Teamtalk. They claim John Gregory has already applied for Angel's work permit so the 25-year-old Colombian striker can play against Manchester United on Boxing Day.

Glenn Hoddle will be the next manager of Tottenham, according to the Daily Mail. New Spurs owners Enic will relieve George Graham of his duties at the end of the season, paying the last year of his contract off. If that happens, the Mail claim Graham will take over at Chelsea, as Ken Bates is already getting fed up with Claudio Ranieri. They don't, however, bother to suggest what will happen to Southampton should Hoddle leave.

Chelsea will be back in for Robbie Fowler, according to just about everyone. Liverpool have already turned down a £12m bid, but Claudio Ranieri will be back with an improved offer of £13.5m.

Robbie Keane's arrival at Leeds could spell the end of Darren Huckerby's Elland Road career. Celtic are waiting in the wings with a £3m offer.

Two days after publicist Max Clifford insisted Fulham were not interested in Emmanuel Petit, the club have announced on their website that they are being linked with an £8m bid for the former Arsenal man.

Blackburn boss Graeme Souness has blocked Newcastle's loan move for Egil Ostenstad.

Eric Black could replace Ebbe Skovdahl as manager of Aberdeen, according to Planet Football. The former Don has a good coaching record and was assistant manager at Celtic under Jo Venglos and John Barnes.

fields.headline: Top manager in NHS reshuffle
fields.trailText: NHS executive director of personnel Hugh Taylor has been made a deputy to health service chief executive Nigel Crisp, in the latest senior management reshuffle at the Department of Health. Patrick Butler reports.
fields.body:
NHS executive director of personnel Hugh Taylor has been made a deputy to health service chief executive Nigel Crisp, in the latest senior management reshuffle at the Department of Health (DoH).

Mr Taylor has been appointed director of external and corporate affairs. He will be responsible for "modernising" the DoH, and developing relations with other government departments.

He replaces senior mandarin Alice Perkins - the wife of home secretary Jack Straw - who has moved to a post at the cabinet office.

The move will create a vacancy for the top personnel job at a critical time - the NHS is in negotiations with unions over a new pay system - although Mr Taylor has promised to stay on until a successor is found.

In a memo to NHS directors of personnel, Mr Taylor said: "I will be supporting Nigel Crisp in driving through the modernisation of the department and overseeing the development of relationships across government and with other external stakeholders.

"This is an exciting time for human resources in the NHS and it will be a real wrench to move on."

It is the latest in a series of moves at the top of the NHS. In the past few weeks, director of finance Colin Reeves said he was leaving, while NHS modernisation agency director Barbara Stocking announced she is to join aid charity Oxfam. One source said: "I think Mr Taylor is going to sort out the structure of the DoH and NHS executive, because it doesn't work at the moment."

The DoH, which is the policy arm of the health service, and the executive, which is the operational arm, were effectively merged when Mr Crisp took over as chief executive of both bodies in October.

Bob Abberley, head of health at public sector union Unison, said: "Hugh Taylor has been an outstanding director of personnel who has certainly established a positive working relationship between the executive and the unions."

Mr Taylor is a career civil servant. Prior to joining the NHS executive he was director of personnel for the prison service.

"This is an exciting time for human resources in the NHS and it will be a real wrench to move on." It is the latest in a series of moves at the top of the NHS. In the past few weeks, director of finance Colin Reeves said he was leaving, while NHS modernisation agency director Barbara Stocking announced she is to join aid charity Oxfam. One source said: "I think Mr Taylor is going to sort out the structure of the DoH and NHS executive, because it doesn't work at the moment." The DoH, which is the policy arm of the health service, and the executive, which is the operational arm, were effectively merged when Mr Crisp took over as chief executive of both bodies in October. Bob Abberley, head of health at public sector union Unison, said: "Hugh Taylor has been an outstanding director of personnel who has certainly established a positive working relationship between the executive and the unions." Mr Taylor is a career civil servant. Prior to joining the NHS executive he was director of personnel for the prison service.

fields.headline: Obituary: Adrian Henri
fields.standfirst: Prolific painter and poet famed for communicating the delights of popular culture
fields.trailText: Prolific painter and poet famed for communicating the delights of popular culture.
fields.body:
Adrian Henri, who has died aged 68, was perhaps best known as a poet, though he was primarily a painter, as evidenced in a recent retrospective at Liverpool's Walker Art Gallery. But it was as a communicator, in the broadest sense of the word, that he made his greatest impact, both on those around him and on the cultural scene generally.

Born in Birkenhead, Henri grew up through the war years in Rhyl. He was educated at St Asaph grammar school, in north Wales, before studying fine art, from 1951 to 1955, at King's College, Newcastle, where tutors included Lawrence Gowring, Roger de Gray and, later, Richard Hamilton. The influence of the abstract expressionists, and then the newly-emergent pop painters, was evident in his work by the early 1960s, but already it had a personal signature to it, an affection for the urban landscapes and icons of popular culture of his immediate surroundings.

Jasper Johns's American Flag gave way to Omo packets, and Alfred Jarry's Père Ubu was pictured strolling down Lime Street. In a homage to James Ensor, The Entry Of Christ Into Brussels became The Entry Of Christ Into Liverpool - with all of the Henri heroes and friends crowding the foreground, and Jesus on a donkey at the rear. Adrian was a confirmed atheist.

It was at this time that I first met him. To a 16-year-old discovering jazz, modern art and the beat generation writers, his enormous enthusiasm acted as a catalyst in my own development - as it did for many others. It was directly as a result of this meeting - I was working two stalls down from him in a summer vacation job on Rhyl fairground - that I got involved in the increasingly populist bohemia emerging in Liverpool. He helped organise various multi-media events and happenings that, as well as being extensions to his paintings inspired by the New York artist Allan Kaprow, also triggered his performance-driven poetry.

Alongside that of the other so-called Liverpool poets, this resulted in the Liverpool Scene anthology, edited by Edward Lucie-Smith, then (with Roger McGough and Brian Patten) the Penguin Modern Poets' Mersey Sound, which remains one of the best-selling poetry collections of all time.

Adrian's poems were very much those of a painter; he wrote what he saw, as much as what he felt, though what he described was often expressed with such passion that even the most simplistic listings of people or places were lit with an emotional glow. "I want to paint/ Pictures worth their weight in money/ Pictures that tramps can live in/ Pictures that children would find in their stocking on Christmas morning/ Pictures that teenage lovers can send each other/ I want to paint/ pictures."

Despite the media attention spotlighting his poetry activity, and an increasingly hectic working life as a performer - not least as frontman with the touring rock/ poetry band, the Liverpool Scene (with whom I played saxophone) - Adrian never stopped painting throughout the 1960s, a period that culminated in his winning a major prize at the John Moores Liverpool Exhibition of 1972.

The prizewinning work was one of the last of a celebrated series of "Meat Paintings", which marked a turning point in both his art and personal life. After a heart attack, he had adopted a more relaxed lifestyle and an increasingly lyrical approach in his painting, with rural landscapes and hedgerows taking over from the hard edges of pop art and photorealism.

Of course, Adrian's role as communicator had never been restricted to words and canvases; from his post-student days he had taught at schools, colleges of further education and, most notably, at Liverpool College of Art. Through the 1970s and 1980s, he enjoyed lectureships at polytechnics around the country, writers' tours for the Arts Council and a number of writer-in-residence appointments.

Meanwhile, the one-man exhibitions continued, and the poetry books proliferated. His art and poetry became known worldwide, and exhibition openings and reading tours took him across the globe, from America to South Africa, each place becoming a source of inspiration for paint and words, be it Monet's garden at Giverny or the white-walled suburbs of Los Angeles. His energies extended to stage plays, children's books and television plays.

In all this activity, it was Adrian's character that others warmed to. He was eclectic, tolerant and generous of spirit, and happy to mention influences as diverse as James Ensor, Nicholas de Staël, Jasper Johns and Mark Rothko in the same breath - or, in the case of Me, in the same poem. And he could be just as excited about the work of those around him, whose paintings, poetry or whatever he would promote with an enthusiasm sometimes bordering on the evangelical.

Nearly two years ago Adrian suffered a severe stroke from which he would never properly recover, despite a dogged determination to walk, talk and paint again - aided, in no small way, by his partner of the last 15 years, Catherine Marcangeli. He did indeed start drawing again. There was the Walker Gallery retrospective and, only last week, an exhibition of paintings opened in Rhyl. The night before his death, Liverpool city council conferred the freedom of the city on him.

Catherine survives him.

Nell Dunn writes: Adrian Henri was a free spirit in the tradition of Byron and Shelley. He gave himself no limits, and so inspired others towards a greater freedom in their own work and life. I once said to him, "I spend so much time trying to stop things happening to me," and Adrian said, "I want everything to happen."

He told me how, after a gig, he had gone back to a girl's room in some desolate seaside town and lost his wallet. Forced to leave before breakfast in the morning, he walked by the grey waves and, hearing a seagull, looked up - and a piece of bread dropped into his open mouth.

We once did an Arts Council tour together, driving through the west country in a VW beetle. Adrian could neither drive nor map-read, and I got very cross having to do both. But he paid no attention to criticism. The sun shone and he had a huge appetite for pleasure of the sweetest kind ... sitting in the buttercups by the river eating bread and cheese ... discovering the stuffed alligator in the bed and breakfast in Liskeard ... falling asleep, his head on the table in some down-and-out nightclub in Manchester.

Nothing daunted him. He continued to be fascinated by everything, heaped encouragement on other poets and painters, and was absolutely loyal to his friends. Once you were loved by Adrian, you were always loved. The last few years he spent very happily with Catherine. Adrian knew himself to be a lucky man.

 Adrian Henri, painter and poet, born April 10 1932; died December 20 2000

webTitle: Harvesting hatred in the Holy Land

fields.headline: Harvesting hatred in the Holy Land
fields.standfirst: Suzanne Goldenberg in Jerusalem sees religious prejudice seep out of a genteel Jewish neighbourhood as Palestinians commence their yearly olive picking Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Suzanne Goldenberg in Jerusalem sees religious prejudice seep out of a genteel Jewish neighbourhood as Palestinians commence their yearly olive picking
fields.body:
I met the neighbours the other day. One rang the bell with an exacto knife in his hand. Another invited himself into the front garden to tell me I was criminally deluded.

Such pleasantries were this year's innovation on an autumn and winter ritual in the Holy Land, the harvesting of the olives. Although we live in the city, our neighbourhood in Jewish west Jerusalem opens onto a small park with stunning views of the walled city, and a dozen or so gnarled old olive trees. There is one in the front garden of our rented house.

The owner had briefed us on what to expect: At some point in the late autumn, when the olives on the trees were darkening from green to black, the Palestinian women would turn up to strip the trees, returning later in the year with jars of golden oil. It was an experience he cherished, year after year.

September came. And in its final days, the Palestinian uprising against the sluggardly pace of peace talks, and Israel's continuing hold on the West Bank and Gaza erupted. October and November passed, months of conflict and killing, with no sign of the olive pickers.

The Palestinian families who used to picnic in the park disappeared, and so did the furtive couples, young women in headscarves holding hands with their boyfriends , while simultaneously looking over their shoulders for someone they knew.

In the West Bank, the olive harvest, central to the economic life of the Palestinians, and the defining feature of its stony hills, was in trouble. A Palestinian man who tried to bring in his crop was shot dead by a Jewish settler near Nablus, dozens of others were beaten or injured by gunshot throughout the West Bank, terrorising the local Palestinians.

Olive groves were chopped down and razed the length of the West Bank for "security reasons". Some trees were 200 years old; the Palestinians accused Israel of trying to erase their very presence on the land.

I gave up on our tiny harvest. But on a Friday afternoon, the olive pickers finally arrived: grandmother and great aunt, in long embroidered dresses, mother and teenaged daughter in ragged jeans. One of the older women had a cane.

The response in our exceedingly genteel section of West Jerusalem -- think Hampstead -- was electrifying. As the crew spread out, grandmother and mother hoisting themselves into a tree, one man bore down on the daughter, collecting the fallen fruit in a cloth. He was in full-flow by the time I was in earshot. "Behave like a human being," he screamed in Hebrew, shaking a fist. "If you want me to talk to you like a human being, then act like one."

The girl, about 15, was silent. As it turned out later, she barely spoke Hebrew. I asked my neighbour what was wrong. He said he was all for the olive harvest, but this crew were making a terrible mess, dislodging olives and branches on the pavement. With no cleaners over the Jewish sabbath, the neighbourhood would be a mess for days.

I fetched a broom. He grew even more agitated. The women looked afraid; I invited them to pick the tree in my garden, private property. I told them to ring the doorbell if there was any further problem. Three minutes later, they were frantically ringing the bell.

My neighbour was back, having changed his clothes for the Jewish sabbath, and picked up a knife. He told me I did not understand the environmental devastation the women were causing. Proper olive harvesting leaves every branch intact, he said, and he was heartbroken at the destruction.

I told him that it was my tree, and asked him to leave. He told me: "Don't think you are so smart" and raised the knife hand slightly. The women got back to work. I went inside and five minutes later the doorbell rang again. Another neighbour whom I did not know, a kippa-wearing immigrant from New York City, in his 60s.

"Do you know there is an Arab in your tree?" he asked. I told him I did, and that I invited them there. He said: "You let them in to pick your tree, and they stab you in the back. You have got a lot to learn." I asked him to leave too.

He said he would give me ten dollars if I could name a Jew who had ever killed a Palestinian. I named Baruch Goldstein, who shot dead 29 Palestinians in a Hebron mosque six years ago. My neighbour said: "That's different."

We stood outside the gate, and watched the woman shake down the tree. His wife, laden with shopping bags, marched off on a solo mission: blocking the path of another Palestinian woman trying to cross the park and harvest a tree on another side. The two women were beginning to shove one another.

"They come here and pick the fruit off our trees," the woman from New York screamed. "Do you know what happens when we try and go to their places? We come back in body bags." Then she tried reason. "The thing is we like to harvest the olives when they are really black. I like to climb up there myself."

The other neighbour returned, shaking with rage now, to criticise the way the women were cleaning up after the harvest. The grandmother crept off to try to harvest a few trees in the park, and he went to drag her back. The other olive pickers kept their heads down, but they were laughing.

And so it went for nearly three hours, until our tree was plucked bare, and the women straggled back home to their village on the other side of the Mount of Olives. I spoke to two other people living in the quarter. They were sympathetic to the Palestinian women, but did not want to get involved.

The local guardians of the olive trees just thought I was bad. "How could you do this?" they said. "We are your neighbours."

fields.headline: Hollywood stars to sue Hello!
fields.trailText: Catherine Zeta-Jones and Michael Douglas are to sue Hello! magazine for publishing "surreptitious" photographs of their New York wedding, after a landmark appeal court ruling yesterday gave strong backing to their case.
fields.body:
Catherine Zeta-Jones and Michael Douglas are to sue Hello! magazine for publishing "surreptitious" photographs of their New York wedding, after a landmark appeal court ruling yesterday gave strong backing to their case.

Lawyers said it was the first time the appeal court had stated emphatically that a right of privacy exists in English law. In what was seen as a test case, the judges said that the right protects both celebrities and ordinary members of the public.

The couple had signed a £1m deal with OK! magazine for exclusive pictures of their £1.2m wedding last month. But OK!'s rival Hello! hit the streets three days earlier with its own photographs, taken with a hidden camera.

OK! and the couple were too late to stop 15,750 copies already on sale, but won an injunction in the high court banning the rest of the 755,900 print run.

This was overturned on November 23 by the court of appeal, which yesterday gave its reasons for lifting the injunction. But the judges held that the couple were likely to prove at trial that publication of the photographs was a breach of confidence and violated their right to privacy.

Lord Justice Brooke said if they sued and succeeded, "The bill which Hello! will have to pay is likely to be enormous." Maninder Gill, group legal director of Northern & Shell, OK!'s publishers, said the damages claim still had to be worked out, but it might be for all the profits from that issue.

Lord Justice Sedley said the couple had "a powerfully arguable case".

The judges said they had had "misgivings" about lifting the injunction, but the general rule was that an injunction should not stand if damages can afford adequate compensation.

webTitle: Sportal sets out on shopping spree

fields.headline: Sportal sets out on shopping spree
fields.trailText: 9.30am: Sports website Sportal is bucking the current internet trend by going on the acquisition trail, reports Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Sports website Sportal has bucked the trend in the internet market and announced it is going on a shopping spree.

While other websites are cutting their losses or bailing out of the market all together, Sportal shareholders have given their unequivocal stamp of approval for a policy of acquisition.

Sportal is describing the move as a green light to act independently and be a "force for consolidation".

No figures have been given, but shareholders have agreed to meet funds for any acquisitions, within reason, that Sportal wants to make.

"It means we don't have to go to the board every time we need to act quickly and buy other companies or assets," said a spokesman for Sportal.

"The market is entering a period of consolidation now and there's going to more opportunities to pick up assets and domain names of struggling websites

As an indication of what Sportal wants to do with the "war chest" the spokesman suggested a look at its recent acquisition of the Eurofootball.com domain.

Rob Hersov, Sportal CEO and founder, said: "This additional funding will now allow us to accelerate our growth and to bring the Sportal network to profitability at an earlier date. We anticipate reaching this point in quarter one, 2002."

fields.headline: Madonna fever grips Dornoch
fields.standfirst: Scottish town stands still for a christening, a wedding and a glimpse of the first lady of pop
fields.trailText: Scottish town stands still for a christening, a wedding and a glimpse of the first lady of pop.
fields.body:
Even for a star used to the megawatt glare of stage lights, the paparazzi flashes were more than a little disconcerting. As Madonna waved while fiance Guy Ritchie cradled baby Rocco, the biggest star in the world was caught in the brightest lights the town of Dornoch had ever seen.

But the strobe of photographer's flashes as A list stars entered and departed through the doors of the 17th century cathedral for Rocco's christening was just about all the Highland town saw yesterday.

Shortly after 6pm the stars began arriving: Gwyneth Paltrow; Stella McCartney in a frock coat; Sting and his wife Trudi Styler. Then, at around 6.30pm, Madonna and Ritchie sneaked into the cathedral under cover. It was only half an hour later, when the service was over and Madonna waved on the steps, that the waiting crowd of a few hundred were granted a glimpse.

The Rev Susan Brown, who will marry the singer and Mr Ritchie today, baptised the couple's four-month-old son - reportedly in Versace clothes - according to traditional Church of Scotland rites.

webTitle: ITV behind on Christmas ratings target

fields.headline: ITV execs pocket cash bonuses despite missing targets
fields.trailText: 8am: Top ITV managers will get performance-related bonuses despite being set to miss their 38.5% peak-time audience target, reports Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Only a Christmas ratings miracle will ensure ITV meets its 38.5% peak-time share target.

But the channel's top executives will get their performance-related bonuses whether the targets are met or not, it has emerged.

ITV's official peak-time share for the year to date stands at 37.1% and, with two weeks to go before final year-end figures are in, it is unlikely to go much higher.

David Liddiment, ITV director of programmes, and marketing and commercial director John Hardie will still receive performance-related bonuses.

Other department heads including the head of current affairs, arts and religion and the head of factual programming, as well as head of drama Nick Elliott, also stand to get Christmas windfalls.

A spokeswoman said that the ITV incentives package is incrementally linked to a set of performance goals, rather than specifically at the 38.5% target.

While the headline peak-time share target will be missed, ITV is finishing the year with a strong autumn ratings performance.

The station started out with a 37.7% share of peak-time in the first three months of 2000, 36.2% in the second quarter, and just 34.8% over the summer months.

But the extension of Emmerdale into a five-daya-a-week soap and the decision to screen Who Wants to be a Millionaire? three days a week lifted the station's fortunes considerably.

Its average share shot up to 38.7% since Saturday 16 September, when the frequency of the two programmes was increased.

In the four weeks to December 8 - a period that included the Coronation Street 40th anniversary programming, the David Beckham documentary and Fully Monty premiere - ITV's share went up by 39.9% share of peak time viewing.

Last year, a late spurt in the ratings on Christmas Day put Mr Liddiment and the then chief executive Richard Eyre within a whisker of their self-imposed target audience share and bonuses of £75,000.

However, the bonuses were ultimately paid out.

webTitle: Runaway pair win right to keep girls

fields.headline: Runaway pair win right to keep girls
fields.trailText: A couple who went on the run with their foster children rather than return them to local authority care were yesterday given permission to adopt the girls. By Helen Carter
fields.body:
A couple who went on the run with their foster children rather than return them to local authority care were yesterday given permission to adopt the girls.

Jennifer and Jeffrey Bramley fled to Ireland with half sisters Jade and Hannah Bennett in September 1998 after Cambridgeshire social services decided they were unfit to adopt the girls. After four months in hiding, the couple gave themselves up in January 1999 and returned to Ramsey, Cambridgeshire, with Jade, now six, and Hannah, four.

Mrs Justice Hogg, sitting in the high court's family division, made an adoption order that the children should become full and permanent members of the family in which they have lived for three years.

When they returned from Ireland, postal worker Mr Bramley, 36, and his 37-year-old wife were due to face abduction charges. But they were dropped after the couple formally accepted their guilt and agreed to be cautioned.

In June 1999, Mrs Justice Hogg ruled that the girls should remain in the care of the Bramleys for a trial period and the couple would share parental responsibility with social services for two years. This arrangement was due to be reviewed next year.

Mrs Justice Hogg said she had been delighted to meet the girls with their adoptive parents. "I wish the children and their family much happiness together," she said yesterday.

She said all parties involved consented to the adoption application and the agreement "is the best possible foundation for the children's future happiness".

She congratulated the couple for the way in which they had provided a loving and secure home life for Hannah and Jade.

The couple went into hiding with the two girls after being told by social services officials that they would not be allowed to adopt the children.

Their disappearance sparked a nationwide search by police and social services. The family lived in a series of homes in Ireland and wrote a letter to social services asking for a judge to rule on their case, before they gave themselves up.

Mrs Justice Hogg said that everyone agreed that the children were now thriving. "Whatever past doubts about their placement with the Bramleys, Jade and Hannah have made very good progress," she said.

"I am also satisfied that with the support of social services Mr and Mrs Bramley have seriously addressed concerns which I dealt with in my earlier judgment," she added.

It had earlier emerged that Mr Bramley had been a member of a contacts agency and his wife had had an affair. Social workers also discovered that Mrs Bramley had miscarried twins just a month before the couple applied to adopt.

Injunctions remain in place to prohibit the Bramleys, or the children's birth mother or Jade's birth father, from commenting on yesterday's ruling.

A spokesman for Cambridgeshire social services said: "All parties involved in this matter are happy that it has been brought to a successful conclusion and wish the family well for their future."

webTitle: Meet Richard from north London: he's a press baron and he likes to talk dirty

fields.headline: Meet Richard from north London: he's a press baron and he likes to talk dirty
fields.standfirst:
The new Express owner craves respectability, but a close look at his empire reveals porn and sleaze

Mediaguardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: The new Express owner craves respectability, but a close look at his empire reveals porn and sleaze
fields.byline: Steven Morris, Kevin Maguire  and David Teather
fields.body:
'Hello I am Betty. I am 78 and I want to have sex with some young men." In a sequence of photographs Betty, from Southampton, discards her sober black cardigan to strip to her underwear. At one point she wraps a feather boa - that staple prop of the porn model - around her neck. Finally she poses naked.

This outgoing pensioner is hardly the kind of personality readers of the traditionally rightwing Express, which for years has given a home to that rather more staid family favourite Rupert the Bear, might be familiar with.

But the £125m acquisition of Express Newspapers by Richard Desmond means that a somewhat disturbing but irresistible link between Rupert and Betty can be made. For Betty - along with many like her - is to be found on an internet site owned by Desmond through his web of interlinked companies. Desmond, a man who friends say has given £5m to charity over 20 years including huge sums to the Federation of Boys' Clubs, will not be happy at the connection being made so public.

An acquaintance of the Duke of Edinburgh, friend of David and Victoria Beckham and resident of north London's millionaire's row, Bishops' Avenue, Richard Clive Desmond had hoped that his purchase would bestow the kind of respectability he craves. Tea with Tony Blair at Number 10 has already followed.

Whether the prime minister knew the true extent of Desmond's interests when he invited him into Downing Street for a 30-minute chat last week is unclear.

Labour peer Clive Hollick, who sold the papers to the porn baron, left No 10 after making a short introduction.

Desmond said little, Blair said how much he valued the support of the papers as press secretary Alastair Campbell chipped in that they recognised change was necessary. With an election only a few months away, Blair is more interested in keeping that support than challenging the new owner.

When Express editor Rosie Boycott paid her own private visit to Downing Street after Desmond's interest first emerged, Blair made clear he would not interfere. Talking of newspaper proprietors, the prime minister said: "They are all the same."

Relations between Desmond and Blair are better than relations between Desmond and Boycott.

He consults his lawyers before even sending Boycott a memo; she had her office swept for bugs on Tuesday to prevent her conversations being taped.

The Express deal has turned the spotlight on Desmond's questionable business record - few experts believe he has the money to make a success out of the Express titles - and on his group of executives, some of whom have controversial pasts.

Perhaps most annoying for Desmond, it has focused attention on a porn empire which has used Betty from Southampton and countless hundreds of other women to generate the cash to buy the Express, its Sunday stablemate and the Daily Star.

Desmond, on holiday in Thailand with his wife, wants to be known for the celebrity magazine OK! with its pages of glossy colour pictures of the rich and famous trying to look ordinary, rather than as a porn baron. In the "bumper" festive edition of OK! Desmond is pictured dancing with Spice Girl Mel B at her Christmas party - and is described simply as chairman of Express Newspapers and OK!

Sleazy

Desmond has a habit of threatening legal action over descriptions that he is a porn baron - though no such action has come before the courts - and would no doubt ferociously attack the idea that he is involved in the hardcore side of the business. When the Daily Mail, the Express' main competitor, branded him one of the country's "most prolific peddlars of pornography" and "Desmond the degrader", he exploded: "I'm not a degrader, I'm not a degrader. It's adult entertainment not porn, that's what they do in Holland. I don't do Dutch."

But an examination of the companies associated with Northern & Shell and with Desmond's most loyal henchmen reveals the extent of his link to the sleazy side of the entertainment industry.

Open a copy of the British Rates and Data (Brad) directory - a reference work used by the advertising industry of more than 13,000 publications recording the latest advertising prices - and you will find that no fewer than 20 of the 37 titles in the "top shelf" bracket are published by Fantasy Publications.

Martin Ellice and Paul Ashford, now in charge of the day-to-day running of the Express, are directors of the company, which has its registered office at Northern & Shell Tower. Ellice also acts as its secretary and Stan Myerson, back in charge of advertising at the Express after leaving there under a cloud in 1994 amid sensational claims of internal fighting and espionage, is described as "group advertisement director".

Among the stable of magazines listed in Brad are some long-associated with Desmond, such as Asian Babes, Big & Black, Big Ones International and Nude Readers Wives. But there are less well-known ones, pandering to every conceivable taste, including Double Sex Action, Fifty and Over and Mothers In Law.

The entry also refers to a website called www.fantasy121.com which features on its "Welcome Page" two women, one dressed only in a tartan skirt, the other in nothing but a pair of knickers, in extremely intimate pose. The page gives an insight into the sort of services on offer - including "live sex cams", "hot contacts" and "behind the scenes at X Television", the empire's satellite television arm.

Subscribers, says the page, can gain access to "exclusive video" and can "meet horny cock-hungry women on line now!!!". But there is also free access available after just a few clicks of the computer mouse to "1000s of totally free pics" split into categories such as "teen angels", "black and asian" and "big ones". There is also a "fetish" section promising "hard action".

Betty from Southampton is to be found in the "40 plus" section. Lurking in the "fetish" area is a character called "Anal Annie". A photograph of a heavily pregnant woman posing naked is accompanied by the caption: "My name is Kimberley. I am eight months pregnant."

The site also often plays on a model's race. "Big ones" includes a photograph of a young naked woman with the headline: "Pakistani girl shocks parents". "Thanks to Fantasy 21," she apparently says, "I lost my virginity." One "new" photograph yesterday featured "Sikh girl Penkesh from Delhi" who "wanted to try perverted sex".

The website also gives the satellite channel's listings. Typical titles listed this week included Amateur Girls, Butt Monkey and Diggin' The Dirt Hole.

Though it is listed in Brad within entries for Fantasy Publications' titles, the domain name fantasy121.com is registered by Portland Enterprises, again a company which has Ellice and Ashford as directors. Portland Enterprises and Fantasy Publications are wholly owned subsidiaries of Portland Investments - which is wholly owned by Desmond. The intention to expand the web side of the business is clear. According to Network Solutions, a company which keeps a list of names which have been bagged, Portland Enterprises has already reserved fantasygrannies.com and the unalluring hagsandmonsters.com.

Though Desmond is not a director of Portland Enterprises, nor of Fantasy Publications, the link with him is clear. And though the magazines and website steer clear of the label "hardcore", the content is clearly aimed at men and women who are seeking much more than Page Three.

North London-born Desmond left school at 14 with little ambition and his career could have been so different if not for a chance meeting.

Waiting for an interview for a job as a cloakroom assistant at Thomson Newspapers, he bumped into an advertising manager and ended up in classifieds.

Now 49, his first foray into publishing was a musicians' magazine in 1974 and his first flirtation with porn came in 1982 when he won the right to publish a British edition of Penthouse, an agreement that was later terminated.

More magazines followed, plus telephone sex lines in the 1980s, a porn channel in 1995, videos and now websites.

What is almost certainly troubling him at the moment are figures. Does he have the financial clout to make his new venture work?

Empire

In 1999, Northern & Shell reported a loss before tax of £201,020 on sales of £29.8m. Portland Investments, which houses his pornography empire, made a pre-tax profit of £1.8m on sales of £21.7m. It would be almost impossible for the Bentley and Ferrari-driving entrepreneur to be as flush as he is flash but he insisted recently: "The money I have put into this deal is half the money I can afford to lose and still have the same life."

The newspapers are in need of serious investment. The Daily Mail & General Trust, which wanted to buy the Express titles, had promised an annual £50m to get them back on their feet.

The plant which prints the Guardian, the Telegraph and the Express is a joint venture with the Telegraph Group, which has the right to buy Desmond's half because of the change of ownership. Desmond has made 60 support staff redundant and has asked Boycott to draw up plans for heavy cuts in the editorial team. Staff are braced for cuts of between 100 and 200 in the paper's 450 editorial workforce. When it was explained to him that the paper needed a new health editor he asked why the paper couldn't just take material from the internet.

The treatment of Express reader Paul Conway from Widnes may also offer a clue to Desmond's cash-flow difficulties.

The one area where he does appear willing to invest in is unsurprising given his experience: the Sunday Express magazine will soon move on to glossy paper.

Another is a £75,000 new kitchen for his liveried butler who has moved with him from Docklands. Express staff have been bemused by the sight of the manservant wandering the 4th floor and Desmond, who likes his bananas served on a silver tray, sending him out to the fruit and veg stall outside Ludgate House on errands.

"I don't mean to be rude or anything," he is reported to have told him, "but I want you the fuck out of there in two hours," he said. Jonesco has since left the company.

Senior figures, including political editor Tony Bevins and columnist Peter Hitchens, have also resigned and Boycott has been overheard dictating an email to Desmond in which every other word was "fucking". She told the eavesdropper it was the only language he understood.

What is Desmond's vision for the Express? Other than buying him respectability, and improving his still slim prospects of Tony and Cherie posing with baby Leo in OK!, even those who have been closest longest admit they haven't a clue.

Desmond, according to a prominent acquaintance, almost "stumbled" into ownership of the Daily and Sunday Express.

Tired

In October when it emerged Andrew Neil and the Barclay Brothers had bid £75m for the United News & Media titles, Desmond rang the former Sunday Times editor asking if he would sell him the Star. Neil signalled they might, and for a month Desmond rang, pressing Neil to do a deal.

Tired of waiting, Desmond contacted Bernard Gray, United's head of strategy, and asked him to sell the Star. Gray suggested he take the lot. On November 22 Desmond bought the papers.

This year is the 100th anniversary of the creation of the Daily Express. The paper's greatest period was under the tutelage of Lord Beaverbrook either side of the war when sales peaked at 5m.

In a rare interview, Desmond said: "I want to emulate Beaverbrook in making the Express No 1 in the middle market. There is a bust of him outside my new office and I feel he is looking at me and saying: 'Come on, you've got to restore the Express to its rightful position."

The tried and trusted lieutenants

Richard Desmond has brought together an experienced team to run the Express. Here his principal lieutenants are profiled

Stan Myerson, joint managing director Northern & Shell

As deputy advertising director at the Express in the mid-80s, Stan Myerson, 49, appeared the embodiment of the Thatcherite businessman.

According to Andrew Cameron, who was group managing director at the time, Myerson made allegations - unproven - of financial impropriety against his boss Michael Moore, prompting Cameron to have Moore's office bugged.

Cameron says Myerson then hired a firm of private detectives to shadow Moore to the company's summer party at a hotel in Manchester. Their report revealed that Moore had spent the night with a married classified ads manager. Moore resigned, fearing that Myerson would pass the detectives' findings on to his wife.

Attention was then focused on Myerson, who had been moved sideways to become "assistant to the managing director". He had worked for the company for the best part of 20 years. Cameron says Myerson was sacked in 1994 when it was discovered that he was allegedly fiddling expenses and bonuses.

In April 1995 he was appointed group advertising director of Northern & Shell.

Paul Ashford, editorial director of Northern & Shell, and Martin Ellice, joint managing director Northern & Shell

Paul Ashford, 46, and Martin Ellice, 43, are contrasting characters. Ashford is seen by Desmond as the "guiding hand" behind the OK! editorial team. He is said to be able to soak up Desmond's rages.

Martin Ellice has been branded the company's Mr Nasty; others characterise him as Desmond's "rottweiler".

Ian Monk worked on one of the group's titles, the Daily Star, before moving on to the Daily Mail. He was poached by the Express as deputy to editor Richard Addis.

In 1996 Monk's wife, Anita, was arrested by police at a Heathrow airport hotel with a pre-publication copy of Alan Starkie's biography of the Duchess of York. Mrs Monk was never charged but the details of the incident later emerged in the high court. Monk admitted acquiring two copies of the book in the course of his duties as deputy editor. Mrs Monk said she had orally agreed to sell one of the copies to the Sun.

Monk left the Express - "by mutual agreement" and joined the Sun briefly before moving to the MacLaurin PR agency.
