webTitle: Ex-aide tells of attack by mobsters

fields.headline: Ex-aide tells of attack by mobsters
fields.standfirst:
As links went sour, right-hand man was beaten up

Mediaguardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Philip Bailey, Richard Desmond's former right-hand man, has spoken publicly for the first time about how he was tortured by gangsters during a business trip to New York on behalf of the porn baron.
fields.body:
Philip Bailey, Richard Desmond's former right-hand man, has spoken publicly for the first time about how he was tortured by gangsters during a business trip to New York on behalf of the porn baron.

Bailey, at that time Northern & Shell's managing director, was slashed with a blade and pistol-whipped, and suffered electric shocks to his genitals from a cattle prod-type baton.

In the US to fix a new distribution network for Desmond's magazines, he told police that the mobsters yelled "tell your boss Desmond he's a fucking dead man" and "tell Desmond that pond is a short trip across - and we know his address."

Bailey, 46, who has repeatedly refused to talk about the attack, said in an email to the Guardian: "The only reason I am being contacted is because of the knowledge I have concerning my ex-employer. In six years, as I do not merit column inches personally, nobody has ever done me a kindness by asking me how I was physically, mentally or financially following the horrendous assault on my life whilst in New York on business for Richard Desmond."

Desmond's people dismiss Bailey's tale as "no more than fantasy" and the US police were unable to investigate after he left the country. Nor is there any evidence to link any of Desmond's business associates to the assault. But Bailey is believed to have kept an original medical report and copy of the statement he made to officer Ramos of the New York police department's 19th precinct in Manhattan after the attack on October 24 1992.

The porn baron's dismissal of Bailey's claims appears at odds with his reaction at the time. Soon after Bailey returned to Britain, he and Desmond reported the assault and death threats to Golders Green police station in north London.

Porn has always been a murky world and the brush with the New York mob persuaded Desmond to take his own security seriously, hiring bodyguards. One, Jamie Brown, had once been sentenced to seven years in jail after threatening a trial witness with a sawn-off shotgun and became company secretary of Portland Investments before quitting. He now lives in Cornwall and runs pubs.

Northern & Shell had struck a deal during early 1991 with Norman Chanes, president of New York-based Harvest Advertising, to advertise telephone sex lines in its porn magazines on behalf of ATN, a company run by Ricky Martino, who was described by one US police officer as a "soldier" in the notorious Gambino crime family. Chanes and Martino criticised the effectiveness of the adverts as Desmond in turn blamed the way the lines were run.

Chanes flew to London in June 1991 and was placated when Desmond took him to a Variety Club dinner at the Greenwich Naval Club attended by the Duke of Edinburgh, a royal connection Desmond flouted the same month two years later when Prince Philip opened Northern & Shell's head office in Docklands, London.

As the New York links turned sour, rumours circulated of threats and counter- threats. Bailey flew to New York in October 1992 to set up the new Northern & Shell distribution deals and it was on the morning of the 24th that he climbed into a limousine supposedly sent by a business colleague to take him to the airport and his homeward flight. Shortly after it pulled away from the hotel, two men jumped into the car and, in the police report, Bailey told how they assaulted him and issued the threats.

fields.trailText:
8.30am: The boardroom upheaval at French pay-TV channel Canal Plus has claimed at least one victim, reports Dan Milmo.
Dec 21: Canal Plus execs ejected
fields.body:
The boardroom upheaval at French pay-TV channel Canal Plus has claimed at least one victim, following a "significant" revamp of the company.

Michel Thoulouze, head of Canal's Italian operations, has resigned after falling out with boss Pierre Lescure over the new shape of the company.

Canal Plus has been swallowed up by parent company Vivendi's merger with Seagram, owner of Universal Studios, sparking internal wranglings over the company's level of independence.

"Mr Thoulouze disagreed on the way the company was to be organised, so he has left," said a Canal Plus spokeman

However, three other Canal Plus board members have been replaced in a reshuffle which sees the company split into four divisions overseen by two management boards.

Bruno Delecour, head of CanalSatellite, will take on operational responsibilities for the enlarged parent company, called Vivendi Universal.

"He is proud that the first operational manager of Vivendi Universal comes from Canal Plus," added the spokesman.

Laurent Perpere, Canal's development and international activities director, also appears to have no future at the company.

Jean-Marie Messier, head of Vivendi Universal, looms over the reshuffle, with French commentators claiming that he has forced the hand of Mr Lescure.

Rumours of a dispute between the two have been a mainstay of the French business press over the past few months.

"Mr Messier is a shareholder and part of the Canal Plus board, so obviously he had a role. Mr Lescure talks to Mr Messier every day, and that is how it should be, but Mr Lescure was the driving force. It was his job to organise everything," said the spokesman.

Canal Plus will become the film and TV arm of Vivendi Universal, split into distribution, internet, channels and film operations.

The company has called it a "significant move", which will make the company more dynamic following strong criticism of its management structure.

webTitle: Madonna stages webcam wedding of the year

fields.headline: Madonna stages webcam wedding of the year
fields.standfirst: Live webcam pictures
fields.trailText:
8.15am: When Madonna and Guy Ritchie tie the knot today, millions around the world are expected to log onto a webcam and view the action, reports Amy Vickers.
Live webcam pictures
fields.body:
It's being billed as the wedding of the year and another test of whether the internet can cut the mustard as a broadcast medium.

When Madonna and Guy Ritchie tie the knot later today, millions of office workers throughout the world are expected to log onto madonnaweddingcam.com and view the action.

Only, there really isn't that much to see. On Thursday afternoon the site was almost impossible to download, and when MediaGuardian.co.uk managed to get into the site and view the webcam - fixed to a hotel overlooking the cathedral in Dornoch, Scotland - the picture was blurry and static, and impossible to tell one individual from another.

The internet hype was stirred up by Associated New Media's ThisisLondon.com on Thursday afternoon, which sent out a press release bragging that its "exclusive wedding webcam" would make people think that they're actually there.

The experience is far removed from the hype. Camvista.com, the company that set up the webcam to the hotel, was experiencing difficulties all day Thursday.

One can only hope that Camvista.com manages to increase its server capacity today to cope with expected demand.

But don't hold your breath - it's unlikely that anyone will be able to see Madonna's wedding gown through the website.

webTitle: Former Today editor unveils website plans

fields.headline: Former Today editor unveils website plans
fields.trailText: 8.15am: Former tabloid editor Martin Dunn is gearing up to launch his first two internet projects in the new year, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Former tabloid editor Martin Dunn is gearing up to launch his first two internet projects in the new year - including one on slimming.

A former editor-in-chief of Associated New Media and editor of Today, Mr Dunn said he would launch the first, RealSlimmers.com "a daily soap opera following the diets of 15 volunteers" in the second week in January.

His second site, TheAnswerBank.co.uk - a service that provides answers to questions, will launch soon after, followed by a website based loosely on the idea behind Theonion.com, the satirical US news site.

To promote RealSlimmers.com, Mr Dunn said there would be numerous articles placed in national and local newspapers profiling the slimmers who have volunteered 12 weeks of their time, and agreed to have their every dieting whim documented on the site.

"Internet companies are going to have to do one thing to win - be interesting or useful to people. We're looking at ideas that are compelling and that drag people in to the site on a daily basis," said Mr Dunn.

His internet company, Front of Mind, which is bankrolled by the Daily Mail & General Trust, plans to launch seven projects in all.

Mr Dunn said he was able to develop so many websites within DMGT's funding budget because Front of Mind was being incredibly frugal.

"We've outsourced a lot of the work on a contract basis so that we don't have overheads, and we're going to do some direct email and PR.

"We're being sensible and using the internet to keep costs down, and we're never grow bigger than a 10 people strong workforce."

webTitle: Sky One snaps up trio of US dramas

fields.headline: Sky One snaps up trio of US dramas
fields.trailText: 8.15am: Sky One has bought three new US dramas including Dark Angel, Titanic director James Cameron's first foray into TV, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Sky One has acquired three new US dramas, including Titanic director James Cameron's first foray into TV, futuristic action series Dark Angel.

The show, which stars newcomer Jessica Alba as a genetically-enhanced human prototype on the run from her military creators on streets of a post-apocalyptic Seattle, debuts on Sky One on Wednesday January 17.

The two-hour pilot for Dark Angel, which has been scripted by Mr Cameron and Murder One writer Charles Eglee, is reputed to have cost around $10m. The Fox studio show has proved a hit on the Fox network in the US.

Sky One has also bought US dramas Titans and The Street.

Titans, from producer Aaron Spelling - the man behind Dynasty, Melrose Place and Beverly Hills 90210 - is a glossy soap revolving around a super-rich Beverly Hills family.

The drama has a cast drawn from soap heaven, with former Dallas star Victoria Principal, ex-Baywatch babe Yasmine Bleeth and lantern-jawed Starship Troopers hunk Casper Van Dien.

Titans, which goes out on NBC in the US, begins on Sky One on Sunday January 7 and then continues on Tuesday's from January 9.

The Street, another Fox show, is set in the wheeler-dealer world of Wall Street banking.

The drama, from Sex int the City creator Darren Star, will go out on the BSkyB general entertainment channel from Tuesday January 9.

Both Titans and The Street have already been cancelled in the US, so only 13 episodes of each will be available.

webTitle: Time Warner wins rights to Potter sites

fields.headline: Time Warner wins rights to Harry Potter sites
fields.trailText: 8am:Time Warner has won the rights to a host of Harry Potter-related web addresses following a legal battle, reports Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Entertainment giant Time Warner has won the rights to a host of Harry Potter-related web addresses following a legal battle against the organisation that had registered them.

Time Warner, which owns the merchandising rights to Harry Potter, was granted the rights to the addresses in a ruling by the United Nations International Property Organisation.

In a classic case of so-called "cybersquatting", Time Warner claimed that the names had been registered only two days after news of a new Harry Potter film appeared in the media.

The tales of the young apprentice wizard, which have captured the imaginations of children and adults alike, are set to become even more popular with the development of the blockbuster movie.

Time Warner has the rights to produce and market products based on the character.

Time Warner said that it had tried to contact the company that registered the domain names, but had failed to do so. The UN panel ruled that Time Warner should be granted the rights to the addresses.

Anyone can register a domain name for just a few pounds. This has led "cybersquatters" to register famous names in the hope of making large sums of money from companies or individuals who want them.

webTitle: Express owner linked to live sex website

fields.headline: Express owner linked to live sex website
fields.standfirst: Special report: Express takeover
fields.trailText: Fresh evidence of the involvement of Express owner Richard Desmond in the selling of hard pornography emerged last night, report Kevin Maguire, David Teather and Steven Morris.
fields.byline: Kevin Maguire, David Teather  and  Steven Morris
fields.body:
Fresh evidence of the involvement of Richard Desmond, the new owner of the Daily Express and Daily Star, in the selling of hard pornography emerged last night after an investigation of his web of interlinked companies.

Inquiries by the Guardian have revealed that a company wholly owned by Mr Desmond has registered a website which promises live heterosexual sex, live lesbian sex as well as other images portraying women as old as 78, pregnant, and one who calls herself Anal Annie.

A spokesman for Mr Desmond, who was out of the country last night, admitted that the "fantasy" website was part of the businessman's empire which includes a whole stable of top shelf publications, OK! magazine, and now the Daily and Sunday Express and Daily Star, purchased last month for £125m.

The sale of the newspapers, with a combined circulation of 1.6m, has yet to be referred to the trade secretary, Stephen Byers. The Office of Fair Trading has invited comments on the acquisition and has set a deadline of next Wednesday. A report will then be passed to Mr Byers who, if he chooses, can refer the deal to the Competition Commission on public interest grounds.

A precedent was set a decade ago when David Sullivan, publisher of the lurid Daily Sport newspaper, was prevented from taking over the Bristol Evening Post by the then monopolies & mergers commission, now the competition commission.

Although there was no reason to block the takeover on competition grounds, the MMC decided that Mr Sullivan's ownership of the newspaper group "could harm the standing of the papers in their community".

If Mr Sullivan had bought the newspapers he "could be expected to influence editorial policy and the character and content of these papers and this would harm both the accurate presentation of news and the free expression of opinion", it added.

The OFT inquiry is purely on competition grounds, but may also reflect any other public interest comments made by third parties.

Mr Sullivan was referred automatically to the MMC because the combined circulation of his papers and the Bristol Evening Post group breached the rules on newspaper mergers.

The acquisition of Express Newspapers by Mr Desmond has already attracted controversy. An early day motion by Brian Sedgemore and signed by 10 Labour MPs expressed "grave concerns that national newspapers within the Express Group should have fallen under the ownership of a publisher of pornography".

Mr Desmond has set up an advisory board between himself and the newspaper editors to soften criticism that he interferes in the content of the titles, but many staff consider the system to be worthless.

Norman Baker, the Liberal Democrat media spokesman said: "The facts that have been uncovered will cause concern for many longstanding Express readers. If he wants to run sex shows on the sidelines he is happy to do so, but in the public interest, none of that must cross to the newspapers."

Mr Desmond had a 30-minute meeting in Downing Street last week with Tony Blair, who is unlikely to have known the full extent of his involvement in pornography.

On his internet site Mr Desmond charges £9.99 a month to watch "live" sex on web cams, and promotes his magazines.

fields.headline: At this price?  Reuters
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: So far this year Emap, United News & Media and now Reuters have reined in most, if not all, of their ambitious internet related investment programmes, writes Neil Hume.
fields.body:
It is a tale all too familiar to those who have followed the fortunes of the media sector in the past year - a company abandoning an aggressive move into new media that was dreamt up at the height of the dot.com boom.

So far this year Emap, United News & Media and now Reuters have reined in most, if not all, of their ambitious internet related investment programmes.

While the City has welcomed the move in some cases, notably United News and Media, it has reacted badly to Reuters' decision to abandon the launch of a retail version of Instinet - the alternative trading system best known for running one of the world's biggest after hours stock trading systems.

Although the decision is understandable - having tasted a bear market for the first time retail punters are no longer actively trading - Reuters' share price fell 73p to £11.19 yesterday as analysts voiced their disappointment. Investors must be asking themselves why.

Aside from the fact that a retail Instinet was seen as the most valuable of Reuters' new ventures, it also means it will be worth less, when a minority stake, if floated at some point next year.

Retail Instinet was a chance for Instinet - 17% of group turnover last year - to reduce its dependence on the Nasdaq. Until now that has not mattered. Instinet has benefited from the turmoil on the Nasdaq. But things are changing. Trading levels are slowing, and that hurts.

This all highlights Reuters' sensitivity to difficult market conditions and raises doubts as to the viability of some of its other ventures.

In share price terms, the abandonment of the project negates one of the catalysts that could have pushed Reuters out of its recent £10-£12 trading range, which it now looks destined to wallow in. Coupled with its exposure to Nasdaq-listed Tibco, this in effect makes Reuters a geared play on the Nasdaq. A worrying prospect.

At its current level, a hold.

webTitle: Oil group Lasmo falls to £2.7bn Italian bid

fields.headline: Oil group Lasmo falls to £2.7bn Italian bid
fields.standfirst: Special report: the petrol war
fields.trailText: Eni, the Italian national energy company, last night swiftly wrapped up an agreed £2.7bn cash takeover of Lasmo
fields.body:
Eni, the Italian national energy company, last night swiftly wrapped up an agreed £2.7bn cash takeover of Lasmo, the independent British oil and gas group, after swamping an earlier bid from its US rival, Amerada Hess.

Just a few hours after Amerada effectively threw in the towel, saying it did not intend raising its 180p a share cash and stock offer, Eni disclosed that it had bought a further 28.4% of Lasmo's shares on top of the 25% irrevocables it had already acquired from institutions - giving it 53.4% of the 29-year-old British company just a week after approaching its board.

"It's effectively game over," banking sources said, as Vittorio Minchato, chief executive of the world's seventh largest energy group disclosed that he expected the deal to be completed by the end of the first quarter of next year.

The acquisition, worth £3.8bn with the £1.1bn Lasmo debt Eni is taking over, is being financed by a £3bn bridging loan from the Italian group's banking advisers, JP Morgan, which expects it could lead to a further round of consolidation in the global oil and gas industry.

The recent spate of mergers has largely been conducted by and among the so-called oil majors whose shares have soared after the tripling of crude prices. Smaller, independent groups such as Lasmo have been relatively shunned by the market, with the British group's stock rising just 41p in the past 12 months to 141p before Amerada's agreed offer last month.

Paul Murray, Lasmo's finance director, insisted that the independents' business model was not flawed but admitted that such groups were out of market favour and had difficulty attracting capital funds. It effectively put itself up for sale earlier this year by embarking on a fresh round of asset disposals and share buy-backs to boost its value.

Lasmo, which has 62% of its activities in oil exploration and production and 38% in gas, has around 56% of its proven reserves in Indonesia and Venezuela, both tough regions Eni is keen to exploit and where the Italian group believes it can squeeze out greater productivity gains.

Mr Minchato, who paid £788m for British Borneo, another UK oil "minnow", earlier this year, said the Lasmo acquisition would enable Eni to reach its target of 1.5m barrels of oil per day two years early - in 2001.

The agreed deal represents a hefty 42% premium to Lasmo's closing price on November 13, the day before Amerada declared its bid, and is worth 12% more than the US group's offer. It simply reserved the right to make a revised offer "in the event of changed circumstances".

But the market felt the Italian offer represented fair value and was a knock-out blow by a group worth £26.4bn. Eni is promising cost-savings of €80m (£48bn) a year compared with the €130m set out by Amerada.

fields.headline: Actuaries under fire over Equitable
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: The profession that controls Britain's pension companies yesterday agreed to hold a formal inquiry into the crisis at Equitable Life.
fields.body:
The profession that controls Britain's pension companies yesterday agreed to hold a formal inquiry into the crisis at Equitable Life.

There has been widespread criticism that actuaries failed to detect the company's growing financial problems.

The Institute and Faculty of Actuaries said it is to set up a committee of inquiry that will report by spring 2001.

Peter Clark, president of the institute, said: "The closure of Equitable to new business is an unprecedented development, which has led to grave concern felt by thousands of policyholders.

"There has been criticism of the actuarial profession, and we are now acting to ensure that the factors that led to this event are properly assessed to establish whether the existing professional guidance has been adequate or needs to be amended."

The body which represents company pension schemes said that it is to tackle Equitable's decision to impose a 10% penalty on policyholders who want to transfer away from the beleaguered company.

The National Association of Pension Funds has called talks with Equitable and the financial services authority for early January. It said: "In an ideal world we would love to see the penalty removed."

fields.headline: Q+A - Intermediate care
fields.standfirst: The NHS plans to provide permanent services to the elderly to ease the transition from hospital to home. How will it work and where will the funding come from? Steve Brown examines the issue
fields.trailText: The NHS plans to provide permanent services to the elderly to ease the transition from hospital to home. How will it work and where will the funding come from? Steve Brown examines the issue
fields.body:
What's all the fuss about intermediate care?
The population is getting older. Already two out of three hospital patients are 65 or over and intermediate care is seen as an important way of improving services for the elderly.

Is it new?
Despite the seemingly new creation of the "big idea" this year by ministers, intermediate care is nothing new. Also called "step-down" care, it is about providing services to ease the transition from hospital to home and from medical dependence to functional independence. But while the national beds inquiry, launched early in 2000, found some good examples of intermediate care, services were patchy and often set up on a temporary basis to get through winter crises. What ministers want now is to set up a more permanent tier of services that will operate all year round.

Will it end 'bed blocking'?
It is certainly intended to free up hospital beds for more appropriate use. For older people, about 20% of bed days could be termed inappropriate if alternative facilities were in place. As well as representing poor care for patients, keeping patients in hospital beds longer than necessary is also expensive - costing up to £1,200 per bed per week.

How will it work?
A range of ideas are being examined. Medically stable patients could be transferred to community hospitals, special nurse-led care units or residential homes for rehabilitation, before finally being discharged to their own home. Or patients could be discharged home but provided with intensive support including nursing and therapeutic care. But intermediate care is about much more than ensuring faster discharge.

Like what?
For a start, ministers are also keen to avoid inappropriate hospital admissions in the first place. Rapid response teams may be set up that could assess, diagnose and treat patients at home.

What differences will we actually see?
According to last summer's NHS plan there will be an extra 5,000 intermediate care beds. Some will be in community hospitals, others in special wards in acute hospitals and some in purpose-built new facilities or redesigned private nursing homes. The plan also aims to introduce 1,700 extra non-residential intermediate care places.

Where will the money come from?
The NHS plan claims to provide an extra £900m for intermediate care by 2003-04. It is understood that more than £500m of this may have to come from local councils, which run social services.

Has anything been spent already?
Health authorities were expected to spend up to £150m this year from general allocations on intermediate care. And a further one-off sum of £52m was also allocated in the summer to help health bodies prepare for winter. Next year a further £38m is being added, meaning that health authorities and primary care groups will be expected to plough at least £188m into joint investment plans with councils. Guidance on intermediate care due out early in 2001 will unveil further investments for 2002-03 and 2003-04.

What about councils?
This is where the government's pledge to spend an extra £900m may become tougher. For a start, councils are currently seeking clarification from ministers on how much local government is expected to pour into intermediate care. But identifying the amount is just part of the battle. Although councils receive nominal spending assessments for each of their main services, including personal social services, they actually receive a grant covering all services and are largely free to spend this as they see fit, in line with local priorities.

Can't the money be ring-fenced?
To an extent. At the end of November, health secretary Alan Milburn announced an extra £100m for social services departments to spend in 2001-02. To receive the funds to help develop intermediate care, social services departments will have to agree on joint plans with NHS partners. But some authorities say that this increase is matched by a decrease in their spending assessment for services for older people. The government, they say, is giving with one hand and taking away with the other.

Can social services afford to expand intermediate care?
It will be extremely challenging. Social services directors are already predicting overspends this year. And with many spending well over their standard spending assessments as it is, funding new developments for the elderly is likely to be at the expense of other front line services.

webTitle: Blair vows to increase number of adoptions

fields.headline: Blair vows to increase number of adoptions
fields.trailText: Tony Blair yesterday promised to achieve a 40% increase in adoptions by 2004-05.
fields.body:
Tony Blair yesterday promised to achieve a 40% increase in adoptions by 2004-05.

A white paper foreshadowing the biggest shake-up of adoption law for 25 years proposes financial allowances for adoptive parents and a streamlined system to reduce the time children spend in council care.

There would also be a new status of "special guardianship" for children needing a permanent home, but not wanting to sever links with their birth parents.

Ministers said this could be suitable for hundreds of older children who wanted to keep their original family name - and Muslims who have religious and cultural difficulties with full, legal adoption.

Alan Milburn, the health secretary, said: "Children stay in the care system for longer than they should. More than 28,000 children have been in care continuously for more than two years."

He promised national adoption standards setting out what children and parents involved in the adoption process can expect.

Local authorities taking children into care will have to produce a plan for their future within six months. If that involves adoption, a family should be found within a further six months. This would be faster than the average of 16 months before a decision on whether a child should be adopted is made and another seven before the child is placed with an adoptive family.

A task force will tackle poor performance in social services departments and adoption services could be removed from failing authorities.

An adoption register for England and Wales will be drawn up by July to match children with adoptive parents from across the country, in case a local family cannot be found.

People wanting to adopt will gain the right to an independent review if their application is rejected. The government will organise panels to look again at the evidence and tell the relevant adoption agency if it should reconsider.

The white paper said: "No child should be denied loving, adoptive parents solely on the grounds that the child and the parents do not share the same racial or cultural background." Prospective parents "will not be automatically excluded from adoption on grounds of age, health or other factors, except in the case of certain criminal convictions". But there are no plans to change the law which allows only married couples or individuals to adopt. This means that cohabiting couples and homosexual partners will still not be able to adopt together.

After adopting a child, families will have the right to ask for a wide range of support services from the local authority.

They may qualify for a new adoption allowance, including one-off payments for a house extension or larger car, time-limited payments for counselling, or regular payments to cover the cost of visiting birth families.

The government is also proposing 18 weeks of paid adoption leave for one adoptive parent, bringing adoptive parents' rights into line with those of birth mothers with regard to maternity leave.

Mr Milburn promised £66.5m to improve adoption services over the next three years. The money will come from the quality protects programme announced in September. The target is to increase numbers of adoptions from 2,700 this year to at least 3,780 within five years.

Mr Blair, who has given strong personal support to adoption reform, told yesterday how his father, Leo, was fostered when his travelling entertainer parents left him with a couple they met on tour. "In those days there weren't any rules at all. I don't think my grandmother would have passed any tests...But then a framework of rules grew up in a random and ad hoc way. Now is the right time to get back to basics and ask what we want to achieve for children," he said.

Felicity Collier, chief executive of the British Agencies for Adoption and Fostering, said: "We welcome the high profile which is being given to adoption and in particular the personal interest and commitment of the prime minister.

"The biggest problem facing local authorities and adoption agencies is a shortage of families coming forward to adopt. These measures will make a real difference."

Moira Gibb, president of the Association of Directors of Social Services, said its members backed the reforms. The government inquiry "found little evidence of an institutional anti-adoption culture within social work. We have the second highest percentage of children adopted from care in the industrialised world," she said.

Rita Stringfellow, chairman of the Local Government Association's social affairs and health executive, said: "I am delighted that this white paper brings adoption legislation in line with the Children Act and provides a clear duty for health authorities to provide comprehensive post-adoption support services."

Main points

 National target to increase number of adoptions of children in care by 40% over five years;

 councils to decide whether adoption is appropriate within six months and find a family within a further six months;

 a national adoption register to be drawn up by July to match children with parents;

 independent reviews for people rejected as adopters;

 adoption allowances and 18 weeks parental leave for adopters;

 new status of "special guardianship" for children needing a permanent home, but not wanting legal separation from birth parents.

 £66.5m over three years to improve services and support for adoptive families;

 a children's and family court support service to be set up in April to streamline legal procedures.

webTitle: Runaway pair win right to keep girls

fields.headline: Runaway pair win right to keep girls
fields.standfirst: Court allows Bramleys to become an 'official family'
fields.trailText: Court allows Bramleys to become an 'official family'
fields.body:
A couple who went on the run with their foster children rather than return them to local authority care were yesterday given permission to adopt the girls.

Jennifer and Jeffrey Bramley fled to Ireland with half sisters Jade and Hannah Bennett in September 1998 after Cambridgeshire social services decided they were unfit to adopt the girls. After four months in hiding, the couple gave themselves up in January 1999 and returned to Ramsey, Cambridgeshire, with Jade, now six, and Hannah, four.

Mrs Justice Hogg, sitting in the high court's family division, made an adoption order that the children should become full and permanent members of the family in which they have lived for three years.

When they returned from Ireland, postal worker Mr Bramley, 36, and his 37-year-old wife were due to face abduction charges. But they were dropped after the couple formally accepted their guilt and agreed to be cautioned.

In June 1999, Mrs Justice Hogg ruled that the girls should remain in the care of the Bramleys for a trial period and the couple would share parental responsibility with social services for two years. This arrangement was due to be reviewed next year.

Mrs Justice Hogg said she had been delighted to meet the girls with their adoptive parents. "I wish the children and their family much happiness together," she said yesterday.

She said all parties involved consented to the adoption application and the agreement "is the best possible foundation for the children's future happiness".

She congratulated the couple for the way in which they had provided a loving and secure home life for Hannah and Jade.

The couple went into hiding with the two girls after being told by social services officials that they would not be allowed to adopt the children.

Their disappearance sparked a nationwide search by police and social services. The family lived in a series of homes in Ireland and wrote a letter to social services asking for a judge to rule on their case, before they gave themselves up.

Mrs Justice Hogg said that everyone agreed that the children were now thriving. "Whatever past doubts about their placement with the Bramleys, Jade and Hannah have made very good progress," she said.

"I am also satisfied that with the support of social services Mr and Mrs Bramley have seriously addressed concerns which I dealt with in my earlier judgment," she added.

It had earlier emerged that Mr Bramley had been a member of a contacts agency and his wife had had an affair. Social workers also discovered that Mrs Bramley had miscarried twins just a month before the couple applied to adopt.

Injunctions remain in place to prohibit the Bramleys, or the children's birth mother or Jade's birth father, from commenting on yesterday's ruling.

A spokesman for Cambridgeshire social services said: "All parties involved in this matter are happy that it has been brought to a successful conclusion and wish the family well for their future."

fields.headline: The tried and trusted lieutenants
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Richard Desmond has brought together an experienced team to run the Express. Here his principal lieutenants are profiled
fields.body:
Richard Desmond has brought together an experienced team to run the Express. Here his principal lieutenants are profiled

Stan Myerson, joint managing director Northern & Shell

As deputy advertising director at the Express in the mid-80s, Stan Myerson, 49, appeared the embodiment of the Thatcherite businessman.

According to Andrew Cameron, who was group managing director at the time, Myerson made allegations - unproven - of financial impropriety against his boss Michael Moore, prompting Cameron to have Moore's office bugged.

Cameron says Myerson then hired a firm of private detectives to shadow Moore to the company's summer party at a hotel in Manchester. Their report revealed that Moore had spent the night with a married classified ads manager. Moore resigned, fearing that Myerson would pass the detectives' findings on to his wife.

Attention was then focused on Myerson, who had been moved sideways to become "assistant to the managing director". He had worked for the company for the best part of 20 years. Cameron says Myerson was sacked in 1994 when it was discovered that he was allegedly fiddling expenses and bonuses.

In April 1995 he was appointed group advertising director of Northern & Shell.

Paul Ashford, editorial director of Northern & Shell, and Martin Ellice, joint managing director Northern & Shell

Paul Ashford, 46, and Martin Ellice, 43, are contrasting characters. Ashford is seen by Desmond as the "guiding hand" behind the OK! editorial team. He is said to be able to soak up Desmond's rages.

Martin Ellice has been branded the company's Mr Nasty; others characterise him as Desmond's "rottweiler".

Ian Monk, PR man

Ian Monk worked on one of the group's titles, the Daily Star, before moving on to the Daily Mail. He was poached by the Express as deputy to editor Richard Addis.

In 1996 Monk's wife, Anita, was arrested by police at a Heathrow airport hotel with a pre-publication copy of Alan Starkie's biography of the Duchess of York. Mrs Monk was never charged but the details of the incident later emerged in the high court. Monk admitted acquiring two copies of the book in the course of his duties as deputy editor. Mrs Monk said she had orally agreed to sell one of the copies to the Sun.

Monk left the Express - "by mutual agreement" and joined the Sun briefly before moving to the MacLaurin PR agency.

webTitle: Liverpool reject Ranieri's £12m offer for Fowler

fields.headline: Liverpool reject Ranieri's £12m offer for Fowler
fields.trailText: Liverpool yesterday rejected a £12m bid from Chelsea for the unsettled England striker Robbie Fowler.
fields.body:
Liverpool yesterday rejected a £12m bid from Chelsea for the unsettled England striker Robbie Fowler.

Chelsea's manager Claudio Ranieri turned his attentions to the 25-year-old Fowler after being informed that Robbie Keane had decided to leave Internazionale to join Leeds on loan until the end of the season.

Ranieri approached his Liverpool counterpart Gérard Houllier in the belief that he would be willing to offload a player who has been described as the best English-born forward of his generation. Houllier rejected the overtures, insisting that Fowler is still a key member of his squad.

It is possible that Ranieri will test Liverpool's resolve by lodging an improved bid of around £13.5m.

In recent weeks Houllier has used the media to remind the Liverpool captain of his responsibilities both on and off the field. Earlier this month he also appeared to issue a veiled threat when he said that Fowler "is not half the player he was".

Fowler was left out of last Sunday's Premiership game at Manchester United and is now regarded as the club's third-choice striker, behind Emile Heskey and Michael Owen.

Titi Camara, another Liverpool reserve forward, yesterday completed a £2.2m move to West Ham and took a parting shot at Houllier.

"I don't think he ever respected me, so I thought 'What is the point working with him?'" said Camara. "I was training on my own but I always had faith that the situation would change. If you are not getting respect it is useless."

Although Houllier paid Marseille £2.5m for the Guinea international 18 months ago the two fell out during the close season, prompting the manager to suggest that the player was something of a "mercenary".

"If he says today that I am a mercenary or a traitor, that is wrong," said Camara. "Everyone knows Liverpool; they have been the champions of Europe and everyone who goes there wants to make their mark."

Camara added that his decision to move on was motivated by a desire to pick up the threads of his career. "I have come here to play, play, play and to score, score, score. If it was simply a question of money I could have stayed at Liverpool. If I wasn't playing at Liverpool, it wasn't because of sporting or tactical reasons."

Aston Villa's decision to loosen the purse strings to sign Juan Pablo Angel for a club record £10m has left the manager John Gregory optimistic that the rebellious mood which has taken hold at Villa Park recently will be quelled.

Gregory added that he is "confident" that a deal for River Plate's 25-year-old Colombia striker will go through before Saturday although Angel is unlikely to be eligible for the Boxing Day visit of Manchester United. "I think that, if we manage to sign Angel, it will pacify people in and around the club [players and fans] for the time being," he said.

Talks between Villa officials and representatives of Angel, who has scored 17 times in his 17 games this season, have been ongoing this week. "I think we will struggle to get it tied up by the Manchester United game although it would be nice to parade him in front of the fans," Gregory added.

"There is a work permit to get as well and the match with Leicester [tomorrow week] is possibly a more realistic aim."

fields.headline: Watching soccer may shorten life
fields.trailText: Watching football may shorten men's lives, fans have been warned.
fields.body:
Watching football may shorten men's lives, fans have been warned.

Researchers believe they have established that the final score may also be the final straw for those at risk of a fatal heart attack or stroke. They say big sporting events can create enough stress and excitement to kill television spectators too.

The report in the British Medical Journal, by a team from Utrecht medical centre in the Netherlands, follows evidence that death rates from heart attacks and strokes among Dutch men rose by about 50% on the day France knocked their national football team out of the 1996 European championships.

More than 60% of the population watched the game, which the Netherlands lost on penalties after a goalless two hours. The report suggests that the combination of emotion and excitement, perhaps with excess alcohol, over-eating and heavy smoking, took its toll.

Forty-one men died from the two conditions on the day of the match, 14 more than the average for the five days on either side of the game.

On the day after the game there were 21 deaths. "Stress induced by the football match possibly resulted in an acceleration of mortality," said the researchers. "Vulnerable men had their fatal myocardial or stroke a day earlier than they would have otherwise."

There was no corresponding increase in deaths among women.

fields.headline: More qualify for debt relief
fields.standfirst:
Special report: debt relief
Jubilee 2000
fields.trailText: The World Bank and International Monetary Fund are today expected to approve debt relief packages for two more countries from the developing world, taking the total to 22.
fields.body:
The World Bank and International Monetary Fund are today expected to approve debt relief packages for two more countries from the developing world, taking the total to 22 - two more than the end-of-year target set by the Group of Seven industrialised nations.

The target of 20 was achieved in Washington last night when board meetings of the bank and the fund approved the poverty reduction plans of Madagascar, Malawi and Nicaragua.

Those of Guinea and Rwanda are due to be rubber stamped by the board of the bank today. The total amount of debt relief on offer is about $35bn (£25bn).

In a joint statement issued last night the chancellor, Gordon Brown, and international development secretary, Clare Short, said: "We are pleased that the IMF and World Bank have delivered, and look set to exceed, the target of 20 of the world's poorest countries securing debt relief by the end of 2000.

"We pledge that the government's campaign for a virtuous circle of debt reduction, poverty reduction and sustainable development will be stepped up in 2001 as we make debt relief the foundation for meeting the world's 2015 poverty reduction targets."

Jubilee 2000, the global debt relief campaign, said that even after receiving debt relief, 16 of the 22 countries would be spending more each year on debt servicing than health.

Ann Pettifor, Director of Jubilee 2000 Coalition UK, said: "It is a scandal that as the millennium year ends, with the rich richer than ever, the poorest countries still cannot use their own resources to spend on their people."

 The other 17 countries to have qualified for relief are: Benin, Bolivia, Burkina Faso, Cameroon, Gambia, Guyana, Guinea-Bissau, Honduras, Mali, Mauritania, Mozambique, Niger, São Tomé and Príncipe, Senegal, Tanzania, Uganda, Zambia.

webTitle: Peres fails in Israeli poll challenge

fields.headline: Peres fails in Israeli poll challenge
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Shimon Peres, the Nobel peace prize laureate who never managed to win the hearts of his fellow Israelis, was slighted again yesterday when he failed to win support for his candidacy in the prime ministerial election.
fields.byline: Suzanne Goldenberg in Jerusalem and  Martin Kettle in Washington
fields.body:
Shimon Peres, the Nobel peace prize laureate who never managed to win the hearts of his fellow Israelis, was slighted again yesterday when he failed to win support for his candidacy in the prime ministerial election.

With the midnight deadline for nominations drawing near, the contest was shaping up as a battle of the generals, with the Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, squaring off against the hardline Likud leader, Ariel Sharon.

Meanwhile in Washington, amid the faintest of hopes of a breakthrough between Israel and the Palestinians, President Bill Clinton and his secretary of state, Madeleine Albright, offered the two sides what they called a framework agreement for a possible peace deal. But there were conflicting signs about its acceptability.

Israel's foreign minister, Shlomo Ben-Ami, and his aides gave a series of upbeat interviews about progress in the talks, including a suggestion that Mr Clinton had presented new plans for territorial divisions in the West Bank and Jerusalem. "Israel could definitely live with the majority of these parameters," Mr Ben-Ami told Israel radio.

With the election due on February 6 and Mr Clinton set to leave office on January 20, both the Barak government and the outgoing US administration have much to gain politically from a fresh diplomatic effort.

However the senior Palestinian negotiator, Saeb Erekat, said he had informed Mr Clinton that his side wanted the future of Jerusalem and other tough unresolved issues included in any agreement.

"We are having very, very serious discussions," Mr Erekat said. "At the same time, we're facing major difficulties and serious differences."

He said Israel must withdraw to its boundaries before the 1967 war, which would mean it relinquishing east Jerusalem and all the West Bank and Gaza, and accept millions of Palestinians as refugees.

Outlining a hardline peace policy at the start of a six-week-long election campaign, the hawkish Mr Sharon told an academic conference in the Israeli coastal city of Herzliya that the government could not agree to share sovereignty over Jerusalem, the crux of the conflict.

"There is no opportunity to reach a final-status accord today because it is not possible to divide Jerusalem," he said.

The Likud leader's political hopes were boosted by the failure of Mr Peres to win the endorsement of the leftwing Meretz party.

Israeli election law obliges independent candidates for prime minister to win the support of at least 10 parliamentarians of a single party. Though Mr Peres had Meretz grassroots support, the leadership balked at the prospect of splitting the vote of the peace camp.

Meretz's decision is an explosive one, and though it was meant ostensibly to avoid splitting the left, it could do just that. Mr Barak has alienated the peace camp and Israel's 1m Arab citizens, whose support gave him victory 18 months ago.

With only Mr Barak and Mr Sharon in the race, after the on again-off again candidacy of the former prime minister, Binyamin Netanyahu, many fear that leftwing and Arab voters will not bother to go to the polls.

fields.headline: Ethnic trust rises, as rank and file fumes
fields.standfirst: Policing crime
fields.trailText: The issue of police morale refuses to go away. Always eager to seize an opportunity to demand more police numbers, the Police Federation, representing the rank and file, continues to talk of plummeting confidence.
fields.body:
The issue of police morale refuses to go away. Always eager to seize an opportunity to demand more police numbers, the Police Federation, representing the rank and file, continues to talk of plummeting confidence.

A desperate Tory party ignores its anti-union traditions and clings to the outpourings of this relic of the industrial scene. Forget the leaders of the Met, who have embraced the Macpherson report's call to improve their approach to ethnic minorities. Forget thoughtful superintendents, such as Ali Dizaei, who wrote a perceptive column on these pages this week, reminding readers that history shows that "when minorities begin to challenge the rituals and practices which have served a homogenised society for the benefit of the dominant group, that challenge is seen as a threat".

William Hague remains unequivocal: the return of a Labour government would result in more tragedies like the murder of Damilola Taylor - the 10-year-old killed on a south London estate - because of falling police numbers.

Time for some facts. As the audit commission has shown, for every police officer on the beat, there are 18,000 people, 77 miles of road, 7,500 homes, 23 pubs and nine schools. Just supposing the tax-cutting Tories were ready to double police numbers, this would still mean each officer covering 9,000 people, 38.5 miles of road, 3,750 homes, 12.5 pubs and 4.5 schools.

There is no correlation between police numbers and crime. As police chiefs admit, it is communities which control crime, not police officers. And as this week's Met journal shows, the service's response to Macpherson is paying dividends: ethnic trust in the police is growing. The proportion of black people registering trust has risen from 39% in 1998 to 60% this year.

The federation remains unimpressed. Three serving Met officers - out of a force of 24,000 - expressed reluctance yesterday on BBC Radio's Today programme to using stop and search for fear of being accused of racism. The stats do not bear this out.

True there was a drop from 18,000 to 15,000 stops in the 19 months up to October, but arrests of black people declined by a mere 17: from 711 to 694. Police minister Charles Clarke handled the police critics, all of whom said morale was falling, adroitly. He might also have polled BBC staff on his way to the studio. It would not have been difficult to have found three disgruntled members of staff.

fields.headline: Damper on RMC profits
fields.standfirst: Special report: the weather
fields.trailText: RMC, the cement group, yesterday joined the growing list of companies warning shareholders of the adverse impact of the wet weather on profits for the current year.
fields.body:
RMC, the cement group, yesterday joined the growing list of companies warning shareholders of the adverse impact of the wet weather on profits for the current year.

The group said that pre-tax profits, before exceptionals, would be about £205m, slightly below City expectations of about £210m.

In a trading statement, RMC said the "unprecedented wet autumn", coupled with increased energy costs, were to blame. The full-year result is expected to include a £40m profit on property disposals, more than double the previous year's total.

The group, which bought the Rugby ready mixed cement business last year, is in the middle of a strategic review.

Earlier this month it sold its Great Mills retail DIY chain to Focus Do It All for £285m, generating an exceptional profit or £220m. This will be offset, however, by exceptional costs of £60m costs arising from the strategic review and £12m from the restructuring of Rugby.

Finance director Bob Lambourne said the group expected to raise about £200m from the sale of non-core assets in the next year or two.

He said the second half of the year, which usually accounts for the largest chunk of group profits, would produce a profit of about £111m before tax and exceptional items, against £94m in the first half.

RMC said that its British and American markets, which each account for about 25% of group turnover, were still in relatively good shape.

fields.headline: Ashcroft faces wider inquiry
fields.standfirst:
Accountants told to include Tory treasurer's company in Belize report

Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: Accountants told to include Tory treasurer's company in Belize report.
fields.body:
The government yesterday ordered an international firm of accountants to expand an inquiry into the secretive Belize economy to include the company of the Tory party treasurer, Lord Ashcroft.

It is unhappy that the first two drafts of a report from the accountants, KPMG, failed to address the issue.

The move comes after Foreign Office memos leaked to the Guardian revealed a heated row between Lord Ashcroft and the British high commissioner in Belize, Tim David, at a Christmas drinks party in the former British colony earlier this month.

The role of Lord Ashcroft in Belize has been the source of much unwanted publicity for the Tories since the 1997 general election.

A spokesman for Lord Ashcroft said last night that the peer would "make a formal statement in due course". The spokesman disputed that the main issue in the row between the two men had been the KPMG report. He added that there had been another point of contention that Mr David had apparently failed to disclose to the Foreign Office. "There is no reference in the memo, as described, to what was the primary cause of the debate. It was not an argument about the KPMG exercise."

In memos to the Foreign Office, Mr David said Lord Ashcroft had "accosted" him at the party, which was hosted by the Belize Bank, in which Lord Ashcroft has substantial interests. "I think he had been waiting for me," Mr David said. According to the diplomat, Lord Ashcroft had raised an attempt by Labour to block his peerage and mentioned the KPMG study, going on to raise two contentious points about the KPMG investigation.

KPMG was given a remit in the summer to look at reforming Belize's financial institutions. The British government is withholding debt relief because it is concerned about the present economic set-up in Belize, in particular generous tax breaks for companies such as Lord Ashcroft's.

Clare Short, the international development minister, said in a Commons written answer yesterday to the Labour MP Lindsay Hoyle: "In assessing Belize's eligibility for debt relief, the UK and Belize governments have jointly commissioned a study from KPMG to review the regulation of off-shore financial services and the effect of tax exemptions on pro-poor programmes."

She disclosed that the two governments had written to KPMG "to confirm that the study should cover the issue of public investment companies". There are only two companies in Belize that this will apply to: Carlisle Holdings, in which Lord Ashcroft has a substantial interest, and Sonisa, the Central American holding of the Atlantic Bank. Carlisle Holdings includes the Belize Bank, Belize Telecom and other interests.

Ms Short said: "When the study has been completed, and discussed with the government of Belize, a decision will be made on Belize's eligibility for debt relief."

Tim Roberts, director of corporate media relations for KPMG, said last night that he had not yet seen the parliamentary written answer but if the remit had been changed, "we will respond".

Ms Short said the debt relief announced in 1997 by the chancellor, Gordon Brown, applied only to countries "committed to international development targets, are actively pursuing sound economic policies that benefit the poor, are promoting responsive and accountable government which encourages transparency and are bearing down on corruption".

The Foreign Office yesterday said its policy was not to comment on leaks. A spokesman for Tony Blair also declined to comment on the affair, apart from saying that he had no idea how the memos had been leaked.

webTitle: Hamilton protests as he loses the last battle

fields.headline: Hamilton protests as he loses the last battle
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Hamilton v Al Fayed libel trial
fields.trailText: The disgraced former Tory MP Neil Hamilton's six-year battle to clear his name in an English court ended in defeat yesterday when three appeal court judges refused to overturn a libel jury's verdict against him.
fields.body:
The disgraced former Tory MP Neil Hamilton's six-year battle to clear his name in an English court ended in defeat yesterday when three appeal court judges refused to overturn a libel jury's verdict against him.

Mr Hamilton's only option now is to take his battle to the European court of justice, a move which he said he would consider after calling the latest finding against him "justice in Wonderland".

The former MP for Tatton has now been branded corrupt in the course of two high court cases since the Guardian first reported the cash-for-questions scandal in 1994. He has also been hauled before the Commons committee on members' interests and been heavily criticised in a report by the standards and privileges committee.

Yesterday - a year to the day after losing a desperate libel battle against Mohammed Al Fayed - his attempt to have the verdict set aside was turned down by three appeal court judges, including Lord Phillips, master of the rolls.

Mr Hamilton claimed the trial was unfair because crucial court documents taken from bins outside his barrister's chambers had been bought by Mr Fayed.

The court accepted that the Harrods owner probably had been involved in the plot but decided that it would not have made any difference to the outcome of the case.

Crucially for Mr Hamilton and his wife Christine, the court also lifted "stays" which had been put on costs orders relating to the trial and on the naming of the backers who have bankrolled Mr Hamilton's fight. It is estimated that he could face costs of £2m and the prospect of losing his Cheshire home.

The couple showed little emotion as the judgment was handed down in court. Outside, however, Mr Hamilton said: "This is the most bizarre and unexpected of results.

"For six and a quarter years I have been fighting a billionaire crook. I cannot believe that this is English justice. Outside this court it says 'high court of justice' but I am thinking of going out to buy the letters I and N to add to that."

Mr Hamilton said he would be consulting his lawyers before deciding whether to fight on. Asked if he was bankrupt, he said: "Not as we speak." Mrs Hamilton added quickly: "That is a technical term."

Asked how he would pay his costs, he said: "You can't have less than nothing. I can't pay Fayed anything. I already owe more money to my lawyers than I have."

Mr Hamilton had sued over claims made by Mr Fayed in a Channel 4 Dispatches programme in January 1997 that he corruptly demanded and accepted cash payments, gift vouchers and a free holiday at the Paris Ritz in return for asking parliamentary questions.

Yesterday's judgment recalled how the trial judge, Mr Justice Morland, had crystallised the case in a single question put to the jury: "Are you satisfied on the balance of probabilities that Mr Fayed has established on highly convincing evidence that Mr Hamilton was corrupt in his capacity as a member of parliament?"

Lord Phillips said: "The jury answered 'yes' and found accordingly for Mr Al Fayed...The single question put to the jury represented the single issue in this case."

The judges did not agree with the claim during this appeal that Mr Hamilton had lost because of separate allegations which surfaced just before the trial that he had corruptly taken money from Mobil for parliamentary services.

Lord Phillips said: "We do not agree...On the material before the court and in the light of [Judge Morland's] summing-up, the jury may have found against Mr Hamilton on the cash-for-questions issue, the Mobil issue or both."

The judge said that on the balance of probabilities the court believed Mr Hamilton's claims that a character called Benjamin Pell - nicknamed Benji the Binman - did supply documents to the freelance journalist Mark Hollingsworth, who passed them on to Mr Fayed's head of security, John Macnamara, for £10,000.

Furthermore, the court believed that in making the payment Mr Macnamara was acting on behalf of Mr Fayed. Lord Phillips said Mr Fayed, who testified in court that he knew nothing of the documents, was "not an impressive witness". But the judges decided that there was "no reason to believe that they [the documents] will have given any significant procedural advantage to Mr Al Fayed."

Lord Phillips said: "The judge gave the jury as strong a warning against giving credence to Mr Al Fayed's uncorroborated evidence as it is possible to imagine. We do not believe that evidence that he had been party to the purchase of the stolen documents would have done any harm to his credit. He had no credit."

webTitle: Simon Hoggart: Gongs for gaffes, chutzpah and a great escape

fields.headline: Gongs for gaffes, chutzpah and a great escape
fields.standfirst: Special report: Parliament
fields.trailText: Once again it's time for my annual parliamentary awards. The awards cast a glow over the festive season for so many MPs, not because they want to win, but because they long to see their friends humiliated. That is how democracy works.
fields.body:
Once again it's time for my annual parliamentary awards. The awards cast a glow over the festive season for so many MPs, not because they want to win, but because they long to see their friends humiliated. That is how democracy works.

Gaffe of the year: defence minister John Spellar tried to say, "We recognised that these cuts in the defence medical services had gone too far," but he inserted an unwanted letter "n" in the word "cuts". It still made perfect sense.

Last-minute escape of the year: the new probation service was to be called community rehabilitation and probation, until ministers spotted the acronym.

Turncoat of the year (thanks to Tom Utley): in 1999, Shaun Woodward wrote to a constituent about Tony Blair and a ban on fox-hunting, "It just shows how out of touch he is with people in the country." This year he attacked the Tory leader for opposing the ban. "Frankly it shows yet again just how out of touch William Hague has become with the people of Britain, whether they live in the town or the country."

Erksine May award for improbable forbidden parliamentary expressions: Martin O'Neill was mysteriously obliged to retract his description of Angela Browning as "a second-rate Miss Marple".

Chutzpah of the year lifetime achievement award: to Jeffrey Archer for returning to the House of Lords after being expelled from the Conservative party, sitting first on the steps to the throne, then amid the Tory peers, and later writing an account in the Spectator of a dinner with Margaret Thatcher which had not yet taken place.

Most dreary press release: Anne McIntosh MP, who alerted the nation to the fact that she planned to eat a hamburger: "Little Mac to meet Big Mac for Millennium Mac."

Heckle of the year: the day Tony Blair bombed at the Women's Institute, Labour MPs diverted attention by chirping like chickens throughout a speech by David Amess, the Tory MP who took the "chicken run" to a safe seat.

Most upsetting remark to a party leader by a member of the public: the man in the Royal Bournemouth hospital who told Charles Kennedy, "I'm a great admirer of yours. I voted for you, and I've just had major brain surgery."

Best assault by Mr Hague on the prime minister: the devastating attack on the government's "annual report" which included the opening of the "world class" UK Sports Institute - for which not a brick had been laid, and which had been re-sited to London anyway.

Best assault by Mr Blair on the Tory leader: Mr Hague had nagged him to read out the results of his focus groups. The prime minister replied with the focus groups' views on Mr Hague, "boring, false, irritates me greatly, pathetic drip, nonentity, no substance, no personality, a waste of time".

Worst prime ministerial meltdown: Mr Blair defending Welsh first secretary Alun Michael even after Tories had learned of his resignation on their bleepers.

Second worst: Mr Blair praised our "American" allies in the last war, when he meant to say "Australian". It would not have mattered, except that five former Australian premiers were in the gallery to watch him mark their nation's anniversary.

Most bizarre John Prescott speech: too many and too lengthy to choose from, but his repeated shout of "citizens make cities, and cities make citizens" ranked highly. Also his claim that the Labour government rather than God had made hosepipe bans unnecessary.

Greatest failed speech: Ann Widdecombe's proposal for £100 spot fines and criminal records for cannabis users, which made half the Tory party fear for their teenage children, and half of the shadow cabinet admit to smoking pot themselves.

Greasiest question: another crowded field, though the winner must be Miss Widdecombe interviewing her own leader on ITV. "We are sticking up for the British people. You go round sticking up for the British people yourself," was one of many agonising confessions she wrung out.

Worst failed sycophancy: Caroline Flint, the most egregiously greasy Labour backbencher, had been told what question to ask but someone got there first: "My question has already been asked, so I'll sit down," she said limply.

webTitle: EU tries to figure out what it decided at Nice

fields.headline: EU tries to figure out what it decided at Nice
fields.standfirst: Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: EU ambassadors were closeted in emergency session last night to try to thrash out what was agreed in last week's Nice treaty.
fields.body:
EU ambassadors were closeted in emergency session last night to try to thrash out what was agreed in last week's Nice treaty. There was confusion about what the exhausted leaders decided in the small hours of the morning about how many votes each EU state will get in decisions by the council of ministers.

Meeting for a second consecutive day, the permanent representatives of the 15 member states struggled to resolve conflicting figures in different parts of the summit text - an embarrassing outcome for the summit organiser, France, which is days away from ending its six-month stint in the union's rotating presidency.

Nice, the longest summit in EU history, was supposed to be a defining treaty, ushering in long-overdue institutional reforms needed to allow the union to go ahead with enlargement to the east.

Several key problems remain, but diplomats in Brussels said last night that the biggest was still the glaring inconsistency between two different figures for "re-weighting" the votes of member states in the decision-making council of ministers.

In one place the Nice treaty refers to the figure of 91 votes as the threshold needed for a so-called "blocking minority". But elsewhere it refers to a majority of 73.4% of votes being enough to override the minority, which would imply 93 votes as the blocking figure.

The problem arose because of last-minute haggling that added three votes to the total because of small countries' outrage at what was seen as a coup d'etat by bigger states.

In the final tense half-hour of the summit, close to 4am, the Belgian prime minister, Guy Verhofstadt, won two more future votes for Lithuania and one extra for Romania, arguing that these candidate countries had been discriminated against relative to others of a similar population size.

Critics say that whether or not this problem is ironed out, decision-making is now so complicated that it will not be possible without the aid of pocket calculators.

Every delegation, including Britain's, took special software to Nice to work out majorities, blocking threshholds and fairness ratios. But these were apparently not used during the final, crucial round.

Questions are also being asked about the future seat allocations in the European parliament and a decision to hold all EU summits in Brussels, and, who will pay.

"The final deal was the tawdriest in EU history" and would store up trouble, said one expert. The result had been unprecedented soul-searching about how to make reforms.

webTitle: Gang guilty of £2.5m rotten poultry scam

fields.headline: Gang guilty of £2.5m rotten poultry scam
fields.standfirst:
Loophole in food regulations allowed condemned carcasses intended as petfood to be cleaned up for human consumption

Special report: what's wrong with our food?
fields.trailText: Loophole in food regulations allowed condemned carcasses intended as petfood to be cleaned up for human consumption.
fields.body:
The food standards agency yesterday admitted there was an "anomaly" in Britain's regulation of contaminated poultry after three executives were found guilty of selling more than 1,000 tonnes of rotten petfood meat for human consumption.

Andrew Boid, 33, Darren Bibby, 39 and Peter Tantram, 47, wholesale meat suppliers from the East Midlands, made £2.5m from hosing down condemned chicken and turkey destined for tins of Spillers and Pedigree petfood and selling it to butchers, market traders, restaurants and supermarkets across England, Scotland and Wales.

The three had denied charges of conspiracy to supply unfit meat into the human food chain.

In a three-month trial at Hull crown court, Ben Nolan QC, prosecuting, told the jury that over a three-year period, the men had caused an "incalculable risk to human health" by acquiring condemned poultry fit only for petfood, slicing through mould and green slime to find scraps of remaining pink meat, washing it in salt and repackaging it as fit for humans.

The three men will be sentenced today alongside John McGinty, a meat broker from Rotherham and Arnold Smith, a meat dealer from Sheffield, who earlier pleaded guilty to their part in the conspiracy.

Three other food brokers - Timothy Powell, Louise Tantram and Kevin Wilson - were found not guilty of conspiracy. Another defendant died within hours of his first court appearance and Clive Boid, a former director of Prosper De Mulder, Britain's biggest meat rendering firm, was acquitted of conspiracy but found guilty of a charge of fraudulently selling petfood meat as quality human food.

Rotherham council's environmental health department, which investigated the scam at its own cost of £500,000, warned yesterday that it had found what was potentially the tip of an iceberg of contaminated poultry laundering in Britain.

Lewis Coates, team leader, said: "This investigation was potentially only part of a much wider problem. As it proceeded, officers became aware that similar scams were operating throughout the country."

He said there was a loophole in the law whereby poultry is exempt from stringent rules which require condemned meat to be stained with indelible dye to prevent resale for human consumption.

The food standards agency said it had had one meeting with Rotherham council this month and so far no evidence had been provided of an illicit trade in condemned poultry outside the court case.

An FSA spokeswoman said of the law which allowed contaminated poultry to go unstained: "It is an anomaly which we have picked up and are looking at."

Rotherham council began its investigation in 1995 after an anonymous letter from a local butcher.

It found the gang had set up a secret boning shed operation at Wells By-Products factory at Darlton, near Newark. There, Boid and Tantram employed 12 workers in a 20-hour a day operation to remove feathers, mould and green bits of flesh from petfood grade meat. Raids revealed hundreds of tons of bruised poultry, covered in faeces. Meat like this had been hosed down and left to steep in salt baths. Then it was packed and relabelled as fit for humans.

Police discovered a nationwide distribution network, using unmarked lorries, false names and paperwork to sell meat, heavily disguised to look white, which moved through a series of middle men on to supermarkets including Kwiksave and Netto.

Money changed hands in car parks, pubs and through private bank accounts. The conspirators made a profit of £1 per pound of chicken and 60p per pound of turkey.

webTitle: The detective work that exposed foul meat trail

fields.headline: From van floor to table top
fields.standfirst:
The detective work that exposed foul meat trail

Special report: what's wrong with our food?
fields.trailText: The detective work that exposed foul meat trail.
fields.body:
The vans came in the middle of the night but the darkness could not hide the smell of poultry meat which was starting to turn green and drip slime.

It wasn't long before tip-offs reached Rotherham's environmental health department, who were already puzzling over local butchers' complaints about suspiciously cheap chicken and turkey supplies.

So began three years of detective work by Lewis Coates, Claire Cheetham and Lesley Alder, whose daily bread had previously been scams in the town's market or infestations in South Yorkshire takeaways. Ten arrests, a dozen raids and half a million documents later, they had uncovered a national scandal of contaminated petfood repackaged for family dinner tables.

More than 1,300 tonnes of chicken and turkey were laundered in the scam exposed by the Rotherham team, netting at least £3m for bent executives in Britain's meat trade. But the operation also exposed legal loopholes, the virtual certainty of similar rackets across the country and the past feeble response of government food safety agencies.

As five of the gang awaited sentencing last night, Rotherham began a rueful audit of the effect on its local environmental health service. Virtually unaided by other agencies, apart from the police, three staff spent two years full-time on the inquiry and, for three months in 1997, every member of the department was put on the case.

"So much time and resource went into this," says one of Coates, Cheetham and Alder's colleagues, "that we've been unable to provide our basic day-to-day service for almost three years. It's ridiculous that investigations like this have been left to local authorities. The food standards agency should appoint a special investigative team to break the illicit trade in unfit poultry and other meat."

Rotherham was even criticised by central government for failing to reach adequate standards in its local environmental health performance, as well as having to foot the inquiry's £250,000 bill.

"It makes you wonder who's being punished," says another long-time council officer. "Especially when endless requests to the Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food brought very little help with the raids and no real follow-up."

Change is promised, following the spectacular success of the operation and the setting-up of the new food standards agency, which distanced itself yesterday from Maff's work in the past. And others will learn from the quality of Rotherham's work which began with the stinking midnight vans.

Watched by covert environmental health teams, drivers with names like "Nick the Belgian" unloaded poultry carcasses at four units on Barbot Hall industrial estate in Rotherham, where follow-up raids found rotting poultry meat smeared with faeces, brine units for cleaning the meat and invoice books which showed a list of customers at butcher's shops and supermarkets. Two walk-in fridges at one warehouse had stacks of meat beyond its sell-by date alongside boxes of poultry labelled for retail sale as human food.

The trail led to Britain's biggest poultry rendering firm, Wells By-Products of Newark, which took 85% of condemned poultry from slaughterhouses and food manufacturers, theoretically for petfood. But a raid by the inquiry team discovered a secret boning shed where chicken and turkey meat was prepared for sending on to Clifftop petfoods, a Lincolnshire firm and the link to the chain's main link, John McGinty, a 48-year-old meat broker in Sheffield.

"Mr McGinty's position in the fraud was pivotal," said prosecutor Brian Nolan QC in the Hull trial. "It was through his energies and activities that the product changed its identity from petfood to food which was ostensibly wholesome and marketable to the human food chain."

Using regularly changed vans and drivers, and altering invoice books, McGinty took the meat to at least three different brokers in Brighton, Cleethorpes and on Rotherham's Barbot Hall estate. More altered paperwork and mixing with good-quality meat made final, undetected sale to retail outlets a cinch.

The length of the chain was key to the success of the scheme, which the Rotherham team traced back, in part, to rumours in the town about sub-standard meat as long ago as 1974. The racketeers also relied on tight security which meant that even a succession of Newark meat-boners, who worked in the secret shed and gave evidence in Hull, genuinely believed they were preparing petfood.

Finally, despite all the obstacles they uncovered in the path to reliable meat hygiene regulations, the Rotherham environmental health team could eventually celebrate yesterday - two of them in particular. After all the close cooperation with Lewis Coates over the meat racket, Claire Cheetham recently became Mrs Claire Coates.
