"So much time and resource went into this," says one of Coates, Cheetham and Alder's colleagues, "that we've been unable to provide our basic day-to-day service for almost three years. It's ridiculous that investigations like this have been left to local authorities. The food standards agency should appoint a special investigative team to break the illicit trade in unfit poultry and other meat." Rotherham was even criticised by central government for failing to reach adequate standards in its local environmental health performance, as well as having to foot the inquiry's £250,000 bill. "It makes you wonder who's being punished," says another long-time council officer. "Especially when endless requests to the Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food brought very little help with the raids and no real follow-up." Change is promised, following the spectacular success of the operation and the setting-up of the new food standards agency, which distanced itself yesterday from Maff's work in the past. And others will learn from the quality of Rotherham's work which began with the stinking midnight vans. Watched by covert environmental health teams, drivers with names like "Nick the Belgian" unloaded poultry carcasses at four units on Barbot Hall industrial estate in Rotherham, where follow-up raids found rotting poultry meat smeared with faeces, brine units for cleaning the meat and invoice books which showed a list of customers at butcher's shops and supermarkets. Two walk-in fridges at one warehouse had stacks of meat beyond its sell-by date alongside boxes of poultry labelled for retail sale as human food. The trail led to Britain's biggest poultry rendering firm, Wells By-Products of Newark, which took 85% of condemned poultry from slaughterhouses and food manufacturers, theoretically for petfood. But a raid by the inquiry team discovered a secret boning shed where chicken and turkey meat was prepared for sending on to Clifftop petfoods, a Lincolnshire firm and the link to the chain's main link, John McGinty, a 48-year-old meat broker in Sheffield. "Mr McGinty's position in the fraud was pivotal," said prosecutor Brian Nolan QC in the Hull trial. "It was through his energies and activities that the product changed its identity from petfood to food which was ostensibly wholesome and marketable to the human food chain." Using regularly changed vans and drivers, and altering invoice books, McGinty took the meat to at least three different brokers in Brighton, Cleethorpes and on Rotherham's Barbot Hall estate. More altered paperwork and mixing with good-quality meat made final, undetected sale to retail outlets a cinch. The length of the chain was key to the success of the scheme, which the Rotherham team traced back, in part, to rumours in the town about sub-standard meat as long ago as 1974. The racketeers also relied on tight security which meant that even a succession of Newark meat-boners, who worked in the secret shed and gave evidence in Hull, genuinely believed they were preparing petfood. Finally, despite all the obstacles they uncovered in the path to reliable meat hygiene regulations, the Rotherham environmental health team could eventually celebrate yesterday - two of them in particular. After all the close cooperation with Lewis Coates over the meat racket, Claire Cheetham recently became Mrs Claire Coates.

webTitle: Savings ratio is lowest for a decade

fields.headline: Savings ratio is lowest for a decade
fields.trailText: Consumers saved less of their incomes between July and September than at any time in the past 12 years, cooling speculation about an early cut in British interest rates to boost demand.
fields.body:
Consumers saved less of their incomes between July and September than at any time in the past 12 years, cooling speculation about an early cut in British interest rates to boost demand.

Official figures published yesterday showed that the household savings ratio fell to 3.0% in the third quarter, the lowest since the height of the Lawson boom in the third quarter of 1988.

City analysts said the data suggested consumers remained confident about spending despite fears of a global economic slowdown.

"Base rates are unlikely to rise any time soon - given the backdrop of below-target inflation and slowing world trade," said Michael Saunders, economist at Schroder Salomon SmithBarney.

"But, with the stimulus coming through the loosening of fiscal policy plus the lower pound, we doubt that UK base rates will fall in coming months unless the global slowdown is very severe."

The Office for National Statistics confirmed that GDP grew by 0.7% in the third quarter, down from 1% in the second. However, the annual growth rate was revised up to 3% from 2.9%.

The ONS also said the current account deficit narrowed to £3.2bn in the third quarter from £3.4bn in the second.

The smaller current account deficit was mainly due to a higher surplus on investment income, which increased to £2.7bn from £1.4bn, partially offset by higher deficits on trade in goods and current transfers.

Trade minister Richard Caborn said: "These figures reveal continuing international confidence in UK business environment. Recent closure announcements, although very disappointing, reflect specific industry trends and are not representative of overall investment picture."

webTitle: Market forces: Little information goes a long way

fields.headline: Little information goes a long way
fields.trailText: It is probably fair to say there is not much independent research in the Square Mile. In fact the situation has become so dire that "hold" recommendations are now interpreted by fund managers as "sell" advice.
fields.body:
It is probably fair to say there is not much independent research in the Square Mile. In fact the situation has become so dire that "hold" recommendations are now interpreted by fund managers as "sell" advice.

The root of the problem is the pressure exerted by corporate finance departments. Such is the need to secure the position of adviser on the next corporate takeover or flotation that analysts are uncomfortable writing something negative on a company which is, or could become, a client.

The recent case of Orange, the mobile phone company, trying to vet independent analysis produced before its listing has taken the debate to another, and more worrying, level.

Investors, therefore, are always keen to get their hands on some raw data and luckily enough there was some floating around yesterday. Market research firm Taylor Nelson Sofres has just released the latest data on the respective market share of the nation's food retailers, and it does not make pleasant reading for Sainsbury, unchanged at 405p.

According to Taylor Nelson, in the four weeks to December 10 Sainsbury's market share dropped noticeably, from 18% to 17.6%. Analysts reckon this is Sainsbury's lowest market share in living memory and puts its position as the nation's second biggest grocer in jeopardy. Wal-Mart-owned Asda was yesterday claiming it is the second biggest, something Sainsbury angrily denied.

Whatever the truth, market professionals believe the data could be a signal to sell Sainsbury. Since appointing Sir Peter Davis to run the group in March, Sainsbury's price has risen almost 200p but profitability has not improved.

In the wider market it was another tough day with more gloomy corporate news rolling in from the other side of the Atlantic - warnings from telecom company AT&T and equipment maker Lucent. With traders still trying to figure out why the Federal Reserve had warned about an impending recession in North America this week and then decided to do nothing about it, the FTSE 100 ended 61.2 points lower at 6,115.5.

This was off the lowest levels of the day thanks to a late Nasdaq surge but still left the blue chip index at its lowest closing level for seven months and on course to record its worst annual performance since its creation at the end of 1983.

In the wake of the AT&T warning, telecom stocks were under pressure. BT fell 32p to 590p and Cable & Wireless eased 3p to 919. But it was market heavyweight Vodafone, off 11p to 234, that did the real damage, as dealers fretted about the impact of 220m freshly minted Vodafone shares hitting the market in the near future.

Vodafone yesterday acquired the mobile operations of Irish telecoms group Eircom for $4.01bn (£2.6bn). One un fortunate effect of the deal is that Dutch telecoms group KPN, which owns a 21% stake in Eircom, has ended up with 220m Vodafone shares that it is free to sell 30 days after the deal is completed. Given KPN's financial position, traders think it will sell at the first possible opportunity.

The tech sector was also weak with the FTSE Techmark 100 falling 45.07 points to 2,499.05. Autonomy, down 191 to £19.45, and Dimension Data, 33p lower at 462p, were the worst casualties.

Things were a little brighter in the mid cap world as a couple of takeovers - a counter offer for oil company Lasmo, up 21.5p to 199p from Italy's ENI and a £692m offer for heating products concern Hepworth, 26.5p stronger at 279.5 - spiced things up. Turnover in Lasmo almost reached 700m shares. Apparently ENI's brokers moved into the market and bought 10% of Lasmo shares.

But the FTSE Mid 250 ended 14.7 points adrift at 6,423.1. Handheld computer specialist Psion was the worst performer, down 47p to 243.5p, unsettled by disappointing second quarter figures from US rival Palm.

fields.headline: Hepworth succumbs to German bid
fields.trailText: Hepworth, the heating equipment and building materials group, which put itself up for sale earlier this year, has agreed to a £692m cash offer from Vaillant, a privately owned German company.
fields.body:
Hepworth, the heating equipment and building materials group, which put itself up for sale earlier this year, has agreed to a £692m cash offer from Vaillant, a privately owned German company.

Vaillant, which is offering 285p a share, is expected to sell Hepworth's building materials side and retain the more profitable heating division, which includes Glow-worm boilers.

Hepworth, which has net cash reserves of £190m, had been hoping to expand by acquisition itself, but promised shareholders it would look at other options, including takeover, if it failed to find a suitable target.

Its own takeover ambitions were frustrated because all the appropriate targets were private companies which were not for sale.

Hepworth's shares, which have fallen steadily over the past seven years, perked up when the board confirmed at the beginning of November that it was in talks that could lead to a bid.

Jeremy Lancaster, the company's chairman, said: "Whilst it is sad to see Hepworth lose its independence, the board could not ignore the price that Vaillant has offered and the strong commercial fit between the two businesses."

A Vaillant spokesman refused to comment on the possible sale of Hepworth's building materials business, beyond saying it was speculation.

He said that the takeover of Hepworth would increase Vaillant's heating business by 50%, taking its sales to more than DM2bn (£645m). About 45% of Vaillant's sales are in Germany, with other European countries accounting for the bulk of the rest.

The chief executive of the enlarged Vaillant group is to be Jean-Francois Chene. Vaillant, founded in 1874 by Johann Vaillant, is based in Remscheid, near Cologne. It is still 100% owned by members of the Vaillant family.

In recent years it has been overhauling its operations to become a leaner and fitter company, better able to participate in the consolidation of the fragmented heating equipment industry. It recently acquired a small Italian company.

fields.headline: JCB hit by £22m competiton fine
fields.trailText: Bulldozer group JCB was yesterday fined £22m after the European Commission ruled that the company had seriously violated EU competition law.
fields.body:
Bulldozer group JCB was yesterday fined £22m after the European Commission ruled that the company had seriously violated EU competition law.

Competition commissioner Mario Monti, who set the fine, one of the 10 largest ever imposed, said: "The punishment is justified by the gravity and duration of the infringement. JCB engaged in restrictive distribution practices."

Mr Monti said the company had created artificial barriers within the single market and, at times, fixed retail prices.

The commission found that JCB had placed restrictions on distributors to limit sales outside their territories. The restrictions then prevented buyers of the distinctive yellow diggers and earthmovers from shopping around to take advantage of price variations in different member states.

The commission said JCB, the world's fifth-largest maker of heavy plant machinery, had "illegal agreements" with its network of independent authorised distributors in "at least" Great Britain and Ireland, France and Italy.

It said JCB also interfered with the freedom to set resale prices and discounts across different territories and had bonus and fee systems which disadvantaged out-of-territory sales

The commission said JCB had been engaging in the illegal practices for 10 years, affecting the £4.7bn market for earthmoving machinery. JCB has 13% of the market but 45% of the smaller backhoe loader market.

"The fight against cartels will remain one of our top priorities," said Mr Monti.

Staffordshire-based JCB, which remains a private family company, said it intended to appeal against the ruling and the fine. Chairman Sir Anthony Bamford, the eldest son of founder Joseph Cyril Bamford, described the decision as "disappointing and wrong".

The company exports more than 70% of its products to 140 countries and last year made £91m profit from sales of £833m.

webTitle: After 209 years, a profit for map of Britain

fields.headline: After 209 years, a profit
fields.trailText: The Ordnance Survey and the National Audit Office are at loggerheads over the value of the national mapping agency's map of Britain.
fields.body:
The Ordnance Survey and the National Audit Office are at loggerheads over the value of the national mapping agency's map of Britain.

Sir John Bourn, the head of the NAO, said in a report published yesterday that the OS's national topographic database was worth "not less than £50m".

The OS, which reported its first profit in its 209-year history, however, claimed that the database was a constantly changing intangible asset which could not be valued.

The issue is a critical one for the OS in its first year as a "trading fund" within the civil service. It has to achieve a return on capital of at least 9% under Treasury rules.

Including the NAO valuation of its database would double its capital base and force it to achieve at least doubled profits. The OS argues that its database is always changing, with more than 5,000 revisions made to it every night as new information flows in from its surveyors. "This makes it an intangible asset similar to in tellectual property, rather than a tangible asset such as a building," a spokesman said.

The NAO argues that most features, such as roads and buildings, rarely change, giving the data a useful economic life well beyond a year, thus supporting the treatment of it as a capital asset.

The OS's decision not to value the database in its 1999-2000 accounts, published yesterday, has been approved by its advisers, accountants Deloitte & Touche. But the NAO qualification has been included in the report and accounts.

An OS spokesman said the present treatment would continue until either the Treasury or the public accounts committee intervened.

The OS made a £12.7m trading surplus last year on a record turnover of £99.6m. As a trading fund, it can now keep the money for reinvestment in the business rather than have to hand it back to the Treasury.

Paper maps now account for only a quarter of sales. The rest comes from the sale of digital information to public and private bodies, including companies which use the geographic information as part of internet services or in-car navigation systems.

fields.headline: Laughter in the dark
fields.trailText: Sopranos
fields.body:
There's no doubting what we're expected to think of the opening image of last night's Sopranos (Channel 4). A giant garbage truck dumps a festering mound in front of a deli, whose owner has complained about the "service" he has been receiving from Barone, the waste management business Tony Soprano uses as a front. It's the company motto, say the heavies: "Double your garbage back if you're not happy."

So the shit continues to hit the fan - tons and tons of it, as Tony's business comes under scrutiny from every angle: practically, morally and metaphorically. But if the imagery gives it to us on a plate, the script - agile, sharp, brutal and comic - still offers us no easy way out, even as the series pulls in to the final lap. It still manages to walk a dazzling tightrope over the chasm between good and bad, denying us the irresistible life or death punch at the end of a scene that lets us know, in more straightforward terms, what to think.

What blurs the moral boundaries further is the way in which, as the key players' inner problems come more aggressively to the surface (literally in Tony's case, to form a nasty rash) people are starting to look more and more like each other.

As Dr Melfi, Tony's shrink, dines her son in a restaurant, she picks a fight with a woman at the table next to theirs, bothered by her smoking. It takes just seconds for her calm, reasonable manner to give way and - hey presto - she's become Tony, seeing red and spouting obscenities. Elsewhere she is seen to be gently losing her grip. She's cracking up, obsessive, bargaining with her own therapist and drinking the hard stuff between sessions. The waste, everywhere we look, is floating to the surface.

As Tony's chest tightens, and his vision starts to blur once again, it is almost as if we feel the same claustrophobic symptoms in a desire for some resolution of all these festering problems. "You poor bastard," Tony growls, as he watches his future brother-in-law. But it is left ambiguous as to whether Tony is referring to himself, or Richie April.

It was an episode that again showed an ER-like ability with sparkling dialogue, with every scene pushing to a climax line by line, but the crucial difference is that Sopranos hardly seems to even break into a sweat. People just sit opposite each other and talk. "The pursuit of happiness is guaranteed in writing," Tony tells his psychiatrist. "Where's my happiness?" "It's the pursuit that's guaranteed," she tells him.

We were also presented with a touching subplot in the form of Junior, Tony's ailing elderly uncle, finding what may well be love, or at least someone to adjust his new anti-snoring mask. This occurred while Junior took his increasingly cantankerous carcass to hospital. ("I'm not a cat," he says, after being asked why he won't use a bedpan. "I don't shit in a box.").

While leaving hospital, he runs into Catherine, a woman he used to know. "You break your ankle?" he said, as he was being wheeled out, pointing at her bandaged foot. "No," she replied. "Bunions." Again, the plot was impossible to second guess. Just as a touching story about old people in love seemed on its way, Catherine calls round at Junior's house with some homemade cooking. But Junior blows her out. Why? "Bunions," he tells his burly home help. "You know how I feel about feet."

Scene to scene, the episode shows off how the script mines yet more ambiguity in butting the comic moments up against the severe and the violent - just as the smiling gangster face is always the one with a gun to your belly. When the doctor tells Tony he needs to get rid of some stress, after he has angrily balled her out, he is then seen bonking a secretary from the comfort of an office chair, which bobs up and down ridiculously as he grunts and she yelps. Badaboom!

In the final scene, the lads are all back together at the cafe when a car crash outside brings these ruthless gangsters rushing out on to the street, appalled at the thought of drivers speeding in their neighbourhood. But as the camera spirals up, past a sign for "suckling pigs" it's clear that everyone is going down the pan.

It's just a question of who's going to float.

Scene to scene, the episode shows off how the script mines yet more ambiguity in butting the comic moments up against the severe and the violent - just as the smiling gangster face is always the one with a gun to your belly. When the doctor tells Tony he needs to get rid of some stress, after he has angrily balled her out, he is then seen bonking a secretary from the comfort of an office chair, which bobs up and down ridiculously as he grunts and she yelps. Badaboom! In the final scene, the lads are all back together at the cafe when a car crash outside brings these ruthless gangsters rushing out on to the street, appalled at the thought of drivers speeding in their neighbourhood. But as the camera spirals up, past a sign for "suckling pigs" it's clear that everyone is going down the pan. It's just a question of who's going to float.

fields.headline: Who are you?
fields.standfirst: What the Famous Grouse ads say about you
fields.trailText: What the Famous Grouse ads say about you
fields.body:
The ad:
Christmas wouldn't be Christmas without the Famous Grouse ads. This year there are a selection of four 20-seconders and 10-seconders centring on the animatronic bird doing various tricks. The first features a grouse nonchalantly sauntering across the screen, as the endline comes up: "Mellow". In the next he is tap dancing and the line reads "Something a bit special", while the third shows a blank white screen to reflect the "Extremely rare" quality of the whisky. The last one simply features the grouse zooming across the screen with the endline, "A swift one".

The jargon:
The grouse appears once a year, at Christmas, because of the key "gifting opportunities" then, and he is a campaign icon that is aimed at representing the brand. The witty ads use the construct of the grouse doing something funny followed by a punning endline to differentiate them from other more serious rival whisky ads.

Personality:
You are male, probably over 25 (whisky is not a young bloke's tipple), located anywhere in the UK or indeed abroad (the ads are running all over the world, from China to Greece). You might drink whisky, but not always Famous Grouse, hence you need reminding of its special qualities...

Financial status:
Famous Grouse is claimed to be the best of the blended whiskies. As such it is slightly cheaper than the top-notch single malts, and is priced head to head with rival blends such as Bell's and Teachers at an affordable £16-ish.

Telling lifestyle detail:
You like to kick off your shoes (slippers?), relax and take it easy. Life for you is preferable at a gentle pace.

Other relevant data:
The "famous grouse" campaign is now four years old. Each year a few more ads are made, but a pool of over 17 commercials now exists that is drawn on each Christmas. The most popular to date has been the "On ice" execution featuring the grouse ice-skating.

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Duel In The Sun | Don't Look Now | Teaserama
fields.body:
Duel In The Sun

(King Vidor, 1946)

7pm, Carlton Cinema

Or Lust In The Dust as it was known, since Vidor had the temerity to suggest the wild west could be sexy. Jennifer Jones smoulders as mixed-race woman caught between two brothers - sensible, upright Joseph Cotten and wild Gregory Peck (pictured). Her gunfight with the latter caps a lurid drama, full of colourful action and shot through with ambiguities.

Don't Look Now

(Nicolas Roeg, 1973)

10pm, Sci-Fi

Grief, guilt and something nasty inhabit chilly out-of-season Venice in Roeg's masterly supernatural thriller based on the Du Maurier story. Donald Sutherland and Julie Christie are the couple recuperating after the accidental drowning of their daughter, and meeting two old ladies (Hilary Mason, Clelia Matania), one a blind medium who foresees danger: towards which the sceptical Sutherland runs, through inky, echoing streets. Fragmented visual clues - glimpses of red, a funeral procession, breaking glass, a cry in the night - meld into an awful sense of impending doom: a chronicle of a death foretold.

Teaserama

(Irving Klaw, 1955)

4.25am, FilmFour

A good old-fashioned striptease extravaganza with Betty Page stealing the show. America's sweet 'n' saucy pin-up introduces a number of fantastically named burlesque queens, including Cherry Knight, Honey Baer and Tempest Storm (whose rather large rack Betty helps squeeze into a tight bodice back in the boudoir), as well as performing a couple of naughty numbers herself. Corny comedy from Dave Starr and Joe Ross and a few scenes of flamenco dancing and contortionist moves complete this crazy combo of humorous, freakish and, frankly, fetishistic entertainment that could have only really been thrown together in the 50s.

fields.headline: Atlantic flyer
fields.trailText: Atlantic Telecom, the broadband telecom specialist, has not been one of this year's star performers. In fact, it has been one of the biggest victims of the great technology slump.
fields.body:
Atlantic Telecom, the broadband telecom specialist, has not been one of this year's star performers. In fact, it has been one of the biggest victims of the great technology slump.

At last night's closing price of 98p, its shares were 92% off their 52-week high, and yesterday it emerged that one of its largest shareholders was to liquidate his holding.

Marcus Citron, who acquired a 4.34% stake in Atlantic when it purchased First Telecom, a company he helped form, sold his entire holding, 9.25m shares, earlier this week.

According to market sources this was Mr Citron's first chance to sell. After the completion of the First Telecom deal in June, he was not able to sell his shares for six months.

While the clearance of such a stock overhang is positive, Mr Citron's move is hardly good news.

After all, if he thought the shares were going up, he would not have sold.

fields.headline: A country diary
fields.standfirst: Northumberland
fields.trailText: Northumberland
fields.body:
High seas and strong winds mean rich pickings for fuel gatherers on our beaches. After a stormy week I went to Lynemouth to join the few sea-coal men who still forage on the shore here. They are gleaners, gathering the leftovers from an industry which once extended seven miles out under the North Sea.

My friend was knee deep in water, swathed in yellow oilskins and rubber thigh boots raking the sea bed and the shingle with a wire net. Known as coalies, the men use flat carts hitched to ponies to carry their bags, because sand and salt water spell disaster to motorised vehicles. Sea coal is packed into sacks, sells at a pound a bag and gives off a wonderful heat for those, like us, who still have an open fire.

With collieries and pits almost all closed now, this minor industry has suffered. But there are still men scratching a living from what the tide leaves behind. I admired my friend's piebald pony. He ran his hand down the strong equine limbs and lifted a hoof to prod the inside with his thumb. "Hard as nails," he remarked.

The ponies' work entails being constantly in salt water, which is beneficial to limbs and hooves. They graze the dune grass at Lynemouth, Druridge and Cresswell tethered on long ropes to neck straps. The best time for coaling is one hour after the tide has turned. "You look at the ground and you can tell from the horse's hoofprints when there is coal underneath", said my friend. The families take care of their ponies and, in hard weather, feed quality oats. "Its hay that's the problem," sighed my friend. "A few farmers still make it but it's a ridiculous price."

webTitle: Leader: Is Dirty Desmond really owner of the Express?

fields.headline: Is he really a proper owner of the Express?
fields.standfirst: Mediaguardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: The more one learns about Richard Desmond, the new owner of the Daily Express, the less appetising he seems.
fields.body:
The more one learns about Richard Desmond, the new owner of the Daily Express, the less appetising he seems. He is customarily described as someone who has built his fortune on "soft" porn, as if he went no further than page three of the Sun, or saucy late-night titillation on Channel Five. In fact, as our special report demonstrates today, he has made much of his money out of what - in any sensible use of the English language - can only be described as hard porn. His magazines and websites are explicit and frequently repellent in their depiction - in both words and pictures - of women.

With six months to go before an expected election, Mr Desmond is already a welcome visitor at Number 10. But it is worth asking whether the sale of the titles satisfies all the requirements of the Department of Trade and Industry and the competition commission. It is true that there appear to be no competition issues involved. But the commission specifically acknowledges that the transfer of newspapers raises such important issues that they are treated differently from other company mergers.

In 1990 another porn magnate, David Sullivan, was stopped from buying two papers in the Bristol area, not because there were competition issues, but because the competition commission thought: "Mr Sullivan could be expected to influence editorial policy and the character and content of these papers and this would harm both the accurate presentation of news and the free expression of opinion.

"We also consider that the acquisition could harm the standing of the papers in their community and that there could be some adverse effects on circulation."

In other words, porn bosses should not be allowed to get their hands on decent newspapers. What is good enough for local Bristol papers is surely good enough for the Daily Express? Stephen Byers can still refer this sale to the competition commission. We think he should.

fields.headline: Lucent piles on tech woes
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: Telecommunications equipment maker Lucent Technologies delivered another blow to fragile sentiment regarding technology stocks yesterday when it warned that it was on course to run up bigger than expected losses in the last three months of the year.
fields.body:
Telecommunications equipment maker Lucent Technologies delivered another blow to fragile sentiment regarding technology stocks yesterday when it warned that it was on course to run up bigger than expected losses in the last three months of the year.

The announcement followed hard on the heels of AT&T, the long distance telecoms group, to cut its fourth quarter dividend - the first time the company had ever reduced its pay-out to shareholders.

But while the news from AT&T sparked a sharp sell-off on Wednesday, Lucent's revelation that it would lose between $800m and $1bn in the first three months of next year had a less dramatic impact.

Although its share price fell 18% to its lowest level for almost three years, heavy trading on Nasdaq - which was down 7% on Wednesday - made up part of the lost ground.

"The market is oversold," said Richard Cripps, chief market strategist at Legg Mason Wood Walker. "We are going to have these very significant rallies, but the question is, does it hold?."

Nasdaq was also helped by a statement from telephone and data provider Qwest Communications, which said both its fourth quarter and full-year earnings would be above Wall Street estimates.

The company put out the statement in response to what it described as "recent market turmoil and extraordinary speculation about the likely results of major companies in the sector".

One reason why Lucent - which was spun off from AT&T - had less impact on other stocks than might have been expected was the view that many of its problems were specific to the company.

Lucent has fallen behind in the optical networking market while sales of its office equipment products have fallen more rapidly than expected. It has also had to increase its reserves against bad debts on its vendor financing programme.

"It is unclear how quickly Lucent will be able to implement and track a more conservative set of policies," said Merrill Lynch analyst Michael Ching.

Lucent said it was seeking to cut costs by up to $1bn a year as it tries to restore profitability, with some observers suggesting that could lead to the loss of up to 12,000 jobs.

Its chairman, Henry Schacht, said the company was anticipating improved performance on a quarter by quarter basis over the remainder of the fiscal year 2001, adding he expected the company's performance in 2002 to be at or above market rates.

Adding to Lucent's woes, credit rating agency Standard and Poor's cut its rating, and it remains on credit watch.

webTitle: Leader: Clinton aiming to go out with a bang

fields.headline: Clinton is aiming to go out with a bang
fields.trailText: US President Bill Clinton seems determined to put his remaining 30 days in office to good use. Far from sitting back and waiting for George W Bush to pick up the baton, Mr Clinton is intensifying his personal involvement in efforts to resolve a range of international issues.
fields.body:
US President Bill Clinton seems determined to put his remaining 30 days in office to good use. Far from sitting back and waiting for George W Bush to pick up the baton, Mr Clinton is intensifying his personal involvement in efforts to resolve a range of international issues.

His motivation is partly a desire to tie up loose ends, partly his ambition to stamp his mark on history. An outgoing American president may feel a certain freedom of action once the die is cast: witness George Bush Snr's departing 1993 Somalia intervention. This might be dismissed as mere legacy politics. But such thinking ignores the desirability of much that Mr Clinton is hurriedly seeking to achieve. It also overlooks another key motivating factor. Competitive as always, the president can see some opportunities to "do the right thing" - and snooker poor Dubya and all those smirking Republicans at the same time.

The immediate focus of Mr Clinton's attention is the Israeli-Palestinian dispute. Having exacerbated the problem by raising hopes before last July's ultimately unsuccessful Camp David summit, and then been forced to look on impotently as rage overwhelmed dialogue, Mr Clinton dragged the two sides back to the negotiating table this week. On Wednesday he personally presented them with the outlines of a revised deal on sharing Jerusalem, on land and refugees. Today he will step into the fray once again.

The reaction of both parties has been remarkably positive. "Concerning sovereignty over Arab Jerusalem, including the holy shrines ... we are very close," says the Palestinians' chief negotiator, Yasser Abed Rabbo. Israel's Shlomo Ben-Ami is similarly and strikingly upbeat. Mr Clinton says he will not travel to the Middle East again. But he is prepared to host one more last-gasp summit. For this he has set a cliffhanger deadline of January 10, just 10 days before he leaves office.

If Mr Clinton pulls this off, after so many setbacks, it would be an extraordinary coup. It could bring the bloodshed to a halt, clear the way for an independent Palestine, finally furnish the state of Israel with some secure, recognised borders, reboot stalled negotiations with Syria over the Golan Heights, defuse oil price-destabilising, anti-western agitation in the Arab world and rescue Israel's prime minister, Ehud Barak, from possible defeat at the polls next February.

What a way to leave the Oval Office! And what fun, he might think, what an added bonus to be able to stiff de facto president-in-waiting Dick Cheney and the other Bushmen who have been busily rubbishing his peacemaking efforts.

If that does not work, Mr Clinton has several other tricks up his sleeve. Still on the cards is a visit to North Korea, the so-called rogue state whose rusting missiles cause so much concern in Washington. Such a trip would undoubtedly be presented as enhancing the prospects for detente on the Korean peninsula and bolstering regional security. But as the Republicans know well, any agreement with Pyongyang on missile curbs would also kick into touch the major single justification for spending $60bn on that pet Bush project, national missile defence.

Mr Clinton's end-of-term activities in other trouble spots also bear close watching. He remains deeply engaged in Ireland. He may yet punish Afghanistan militarily for its support of terrorism. And if the Socialists are finally routed in tomorrow's Serbian elections, he would dearly like to close another chapter by seeing Slobodan Milosevic delivered up to The Hague war crimes tribunal. Nothing may yet become Mr Clinton in office so much as his leaving of it.

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Jazz Legends | The Cave Of Harmony
fields.body:
In 1939 Nat King Cole established his first trio in Los Angeles, and broke with tradition by dispensing with the drummer. It sounds a small change but his piano, bass, and guitar group was an instant success and set the trend for Art Tatum and Oscar Peterson. In Jazz Legends (4.0pm, Radio 3) Julian Joseph recalls Cole's three decades at the top of the charts, first as a superb jazz pianist and later as one of the world's most popular vocalists.

Charles Dickens and William Makepeace Thackeray were both members of a convivial song-and-supper club known as The Cave Of Harmony (9.0pm, Radio 4). These clubs, initially regarded as pretty low dives, were common in the 1850s. Gradually they became respectable enough to evolve into the Victorian music hall. Michael Eaton's play is an imaginative reconstruction of the relationship between the two eminent writers, set against reconstructions of the sentimental and bawdy songs they jointly enjoyed.

webTitle: Letters: Questions of ethnic identity are not black and white

fields.headline: Questions of ethnic identity are not black and white
fields.trailText: Professor Richard Berthoud warns against drawing "simplistic ethnocentric conclusions" from his study on marriage and ethnic diversity (Asians fly the flag for traditional family life, December 18).
fields.body:
Professor Richard Berthoud warns against drawing "simplistic ethnocentric conclusions" from his study on marriage and ethnic diversity (Asians fly the flag for traditional family life, December 18).

It's a pity his survey of differences between Asians, Caribbeans and "whites" did not observe the disproportionately high number of homicides of women in the Asian community. Nor did it observe that among Asians, more than among any other group, the chief suspect in homicides of women is a family member. Nor did it refer to the increased number of suicides among young Asian women.

Is it ethnocentric to point out that many Asian women are forced into marriage and confined within traditional family structures against their will and that they are murdered if they rebel against cultural pressures? Is it simplistic to suggest we stop sacrificing the human rights of Asian women living in Britain at the altar of cultural relativism? Or is it preferable to let them continue to die in their homes in greater numbers than their white and Caribbean counterparts for the sake of cultural tolerance?
Olenka Frenkiel
Reporter, Murder In Purdah and Licence To Kill (BBC2)
Olenka3@aol.com

 As the "white British" half of a "mixed" couple, I have, unlike your correspondent Louisa Young (Letters, December 20) no problem with my son's "ethnic identity". Nor, I believe will he, nor will most black people I know, nor, sadly, will most white racists. Like Bob Marley (Gary Younge, December 18) he is a black person with a white parent (British or Caribbean according to his own later choice). Ethnic monitoring is designed to identify people likely to have less-than-equal opportunities due to their ethnic origin or physical appearance. By this criterion - and the history of Caribbean people - my son is black. I am - and he, I hope, will be - content and proud to proclaim him as such.
Richard Kirkwood
University of North London
r.kirkwood@unl.ac.uk

 Louisa Young sure is confused about ethnicity. At the last census my wife put White British, I put Greek Cypriot (despite having been born in England). Our children, then 11 and 15, enjoyed working out quite happily that they should for census purposes describe themselves as: other - Anglo-Cypriot. They were not dispirited by the experience and if anything it reinforced their appreciation of being part of two cultures.

Our children clearly do not fit in the same box as either my wife or myself when describing ethnic origins for census purposes, but so what! Nobody is ashamed or upset by that, and the government have accurate descriptions for profiling the population. Maybe Louisa Young should relax and allow her daughter to describe herself as whatever her daughter is most comfortable with, and to celebrate whatever that happens to be.
AG Krokou
London

fields.headline: Middle East war continues
fields.trailText: Ahdaf Soueif rightly asks "how can people, people with souls, tolerate this" (Living under Israeli occupation, December 18). Her companion Judy Blanc's reply "they're not aware" is charitable, but inaccurate.
fields.body:
Ahdaf Soueif rightly asks "how can people, people with souls, tolerate this" (Living under Israeli occupation, December 18). Her companion Judy Blanc's reply "they're not aware" is charitable, but inaccurate.

A wealth of data has been published in the Israeli popular press and shown on Israeli TV. Many Israelis are aware of the facts but prefer inaction, because Israeli routine has hardly been affected by the shattering of Palestinian lives.

On the other hand, publicly criticising Israeli aggression would disturb their comfort and make them targets of verbal terrorism. My father, who escaped Nazi Germany and lost relatives in concentration camps, was attacked in Tel Aviv because he dared to protest against the Israeli repression of Palestinians.

Many complacent Israelis will speak up when the western media no longer accepts Israeli official spin. Ahdaf Soueif eloquently describes the conditions and aspirations of the Palestinian people under occupation. It is a timely reminder that being implicated in Israeli aggression against mostly unarmed Palestinians is worse than being branded a self-hater.
Yael Oren Kahn
Kenilworth, Warwickshire. yael_oren_kahn@yahoo.co.uk

 I have just finished the second instalment of Palestinian journey (December 19) and was appalled to see to what depths you have sunk to influence the minds of the uninformed about the conflict. Ahdaf Soueif's entire article was hearsay: supposed tales of Israeli injustice and a poetic David and Goliath scenario without evidence. She presented an extreme left position as the only rational voice of Israel, while implying that all the rest were racist and presented the Israeli rightwinger as a religion-crazed fanatic.

I am a leftwing Jew - I believe in the establishment of a Palestinian state on all of the West Bank and Gaza. But the writing of your newspaper and its incipient anti-semitism makes all of the Jewish community scared and defensive and has helped move the consensus of Jewish opinion rightwards.
James Taylor
London

 Ahdaf Soueif depicts Israel as if the peace movement is dead. I can understand her disappointment. Since the war started there has been a systematic "disinterest" in reporting the many protests. The media were searching for "disappointed peace activists", hardly ever allowing others to speak. But Gush Shalom (Peace Bloc) immediately started to break the silence with an advertising campaign in all the papers. Soon many others followed, denouncing government policy and pointing out that peace is possible only by withdrawal from the occupied territories and dismantling of the settlements.

Of course we tell ourselves it is never enough what we can do. But we are progressing and becoming stronger. Pressure from within the Labour party forced a return to the negotiations and prevented an alliance with Sharon; and food transports by Israeli peace activists to the besieged Palestinians continue. As a peace activist I feel obliged to counter the too pessimistic picture.
Beate Zilversmidt
Holon, Israel beate@gush-shalom.org

 As a member of the London Society of Jews and Christians and of British Friends of Peace Now, I wish to remind you that the Jewish community is on red alert. Ms Soueif's one-sided and inflammatory diatribe, with alarming references to "Jews" reminiscent of the days of Joseph Goebbels, can only inflame the already violence-prone Arab community (50 UK synagogues attacked since October) and can only further damage the work we in the church-synagogue-mosque community are trying to achieve by restoring calm and understanding.

I went on a Christian trip through Israel in 1997 and have never seen such glory as that the Jewish people have restored to the Holy Land. Israel is a beautiful, crime-free democracy brimming with theatres, concert halls, opera houses and magnificent hospitals and universities - surrounded by Arab neighbours who expend endless energy on just hating Jews.
Carol Gould
London

 While it is gratifying to see the Guardian devote 10 pages to Ahdaf Soueif's visit to Palestine and Israel, it is surprising that she was so surprised by what she found. "I am angrier than before I went," she writes, although the facts about Israel's grip on Palestine are not difficult to discover. Analysts such as Edward Said have provided a wealth of horrifying detail.

The heartbreaking tales from a people who have been ignored by the rest of the world, particularly America, were salutary but the articles might have been better still if we had more expressions of Ms Soueif's anger and less straight reportage. There is a political dimension which is often missing from the reporting of western journalists, but might have been expected from an Arab writer and would have given more depth to the message.
Karl Sabbagh
Newbold on Stour, Warks

 There is an almost complete news blackout in the US media. I know from Palestinian friends that the situation Ms Soueif describes is not exaggerated. Thank you for allowing a voice to be heard.
Julie Cambridge
Chico, California

fields.headline: Indignities in the air
fields.trailText: I hope that consideration will be given in the design of the massive A3XX for seating of passengers who use wheelchairs (Clinton warns of A3XX battle, December 19).
fields.body:
I hope that consideration will be given in the design of the massive A3XX for seating of passengers who use wheelchairs (Clinton warns of A3XX battle, December 19).

The current jets now in use humiliatingly force wheelchair users to be lifted onto narrow and often filthy chairlifts, often by ill-trained staff, to be carried down cramped aisles to their assigned seats. Once in their seats most non-ambulatory passengers are not able to use the washroom facilities during the entire flight.

I would hope that the consortium building the A3XX will incorporate features in these much larger planes to will allow the mobility-impaired to travel with dignity.
John M Poirier
San Diego, USA

 So, the US doesn't want the EC to subsidise the development of the Airbus jumbo. So they threaten the EC with trade sanctions. I wonder what financial advantage the US gives its home manufacturing industry by refusing to tax fuel at a similar rate as the rest of the civilised world; it must be colossal. To make it worse, they choose to ignore the effect their "subsidised" industries have on climate change with their enormous and wasteful use of energy.

The EC should play the same card and threaten sanctions against the wealthiest, most polluting country in the world. The president-elect should start to clean up the US's act by bringing its fuel taxation levels up to EC levels.
Bernard Hull
Maidstone, Kent

fields.headline: Lost world
fields.trailText: It was a shock to get to page seven of my paper (December 21) and see a photograph of my grandmother's house and apple tree in Imber.
fields.body:
It was a shock to get to page seven of my paper (December 21) and see a photograph of my grandmother's house and apple tree in Imber. Both she and my grandfather were heartbroken when they had to leave the village where they had lived all their lives.

Imber was the boyhood home of my father, who was away in the Royal Marines fighting the war at the time of the evacuation. Unlike most of us, he has returned to Imber: his ashes are scattered in the churchyard. Like Lionel Daniels, with whom I attended the village school, I too believe, that if the village were to be reopened, it would be peopled with yuppies. Thank you Audrey Gillan for your article.
William Meaden
Kings Lynn, Norfolk w.meaden@talk21.com

fields.headline: Sandy Johnstone
fields.standfirst: Ace Battle of Britain fighter pilot whose commands stretched from Nato to Borneo
fields.trailText: Ace Battle of Britain fighter pilot whose commands stretched from Nato to Borneo.
fields.body:
During the Battle of Britain, Air Vice-Marshal Sandy Johnstone, who has died aged 84, was an acting squadron leader, commanding 602 (City of Glasgow) Auxiliary Air Force Squadron and flying Spitfires from West Hampnett airfield in west Sussex. Then only 24, he had already shot down three German bombers, the first of them at night, near Dunbar, before the squadron moved south. His eventual score was at least eight confirmed, with four "probables".

Despite this, Johnstone counted himself a notoriously bad shot, claiming that "if I had downed all the German aircraft I shot at, I'd have ended up with a very big score". Good shot or not, the citation for his DFC, gazetted on October 1 1940, described him as conspicuously successful and "a leader of ability and determination".

Johnstone was born in Glasgow and educated at Kelvinside Academy. At the age of 18, while working for an Edinburgh shoe company, he joined 602 squadron and spent his weekends learning to fly. During the next four years, he worked as a civilian navigation instructor, first at Scottish Aviation and later at the Civil Air Navigation School, Prestwick. In August 1939, he was called up for fulltime service with 602 squadron.

Following a spell as operations controller at Royal Air Force Turnhouse, Johnstone went to Haifa in April 1942 as sector commander, from where he moved to become station commander at Luqa, in Malta, before taking command of a Spitfire wing there.

At the beginning of 1943, with air attacks on Malta lessening, the RAF was able to return to the offensive and, on January 16, Johnstone escorted 12 Spitfires, acting in the unlikely role of bombers, with a 500lb payload beneath each wing, in a spectacular low-level attack on a chemical factory at Panchino, Sicily. He later wrote a lively account of this raid, admitting that so overwhelming was the feeling of excitement that "your mouth ran dry with the taste of it". For his service in Malta, Johnstone received a mention in dispatches.

Later that year he returned to Britain to attend staff college, following this with a stint in command of a Hurricane conversion unit and a period as officer commanding Fairwood Common. In May 1944, promoted acting group captain, he joined the Allied Expeditionary Air Force operations staff in preparation for D-Day. After the landings in Aule, he went to Normandy with HQ AEAF.

A short attachment to the RAF delegation in Washington followed, after which Johnstone joined the staff at HQ Fighter Command's 12 Group. Having been granted a permanent commission, he served as air attaché in Dublin from 1946-48, and held a number of Air Ministry posts before an enjoyable two years as officer commanding RAF Ballykelly. In 1953, he commanded the air-sea warfare development unit at RAF St Mawgan and the next year returned to 12 Group as senior air staff officer.

In 1956, with the Malayan emergency continuing, Johnstone went to the far east as deputy air defence commander in Malaya, following this with a secondment to help set up what became the Royal Malaysian Air Force. Back in Britain, he held various appointments, including director of personnel at the Air Ministry. Having enjoyed the far east, he jumped at the chance to return, this time to Borneo as Air Commodore, Commonwealth Air Forces.

Promoted air vice-marshal in 1965, his last appointments included command of Coastal Command's 18 Group, air officer Scotland and Northern Ireland and maritime air commander, Nato. He was appointed CB in 1966 and, reflecting his years as an Auxiliary Air Force officer, also held the much-prized air efficiency award.

For 10 years following his retirement in 1968, Johnstone was vice-chairman of the Territorial Auxiliary and Volunteer Reserve. He was a deputy lieutenant of Glasgow from 1971-94. For a number of years, he worked for National Car Parks, heading their Scottish operations and, later, as London director.

He enjoyed sailing, golf and writing. His first book, One Man's War (1964), was followed by Where No Angels Dwell (1969), Enemy In The Sky (1976), Adventure In The Sky (1978), Spitfire Into War (1986), and Diary Of An Aviator (1993).

Looking back on 1940, Johnstone admitted that the most worrying part was waiting for the telephone to ring with the order to scramble. "For years afterwards," he wrote, "the sound of a phone ringing two houses away would have me out of bed. I still hate the ringing of a telephone."

He is survived by his wife, whom he married in 1940, a son, who is a serving army officer, and two daughters.

fields.headline: Iris Loveridge
fields.trailText: Iris Loveridge, who has died aged 83, was a concert pianist of great distinction with an unusually enterprising repertory; her performing career lasted for 50 years.
fields.body:
Iris Loveridge, who has died aged 83, was a concert pianist of great distinction with an unusually enterprising repertory; her performing career lasted for 50 years.

At the height of her powers, from the 1940s to the 1960s, she was one of the most sought-after and popular players in Britain, participating at the highest professional levels, and, equally brilliantly, with amateur orchestras. She was always eager to establish a rapport with her audiences, and many will remember her friendly words of wisdom before performing each item.

Born in London, Iris went to the Lady Eleanor Holles school, Hampton. Winning the Ada Lewis scholarship to the Royal Academy of Music enabled her to continue studying with her existing teacher, Welton Hickin, as he was also a professor at the RAM. She won numerous awards and prizes there, and was chosen by Sir Henry Wood to perform a concerto under his direction, in the old Queen's Hall, London.

As her career blossomed, she appeared at several Promenade concerts. Her programmes extended from the recognised classics to such relative rarities as works by the Spanish composers Falla, Albeniz and Turina, not often heard in Britain at that time. She also toured in Europe and Australasia, and a 1955 concert in Lerwick, in the Shetland Islands, is remembered in a 1996 history of the Lerwick Orchestra.

Iris's broadcasting career began in 1936. fields.headline: Liverpool poet Adrian Henri dies
fields.trailText: Writers, friends and critics yesterday paid tribute to the Liverpool poet and painter Adrian Henri who helped find a huge new audience for English poetry in the 60s.
fields.body:
Writers, friends and critics yesterday paid tribute to the Liverpool poet and painter Adrian Henri who helped find a huge new audience for English poetry in the 60s.

Henri, 68, died at home in Liverpool on Wednesday night as the freedom of the city was being conferred on him. He had been too ill to attend the ceremony following complications after a stroke two years ago and was also unable to collect an honorary degree awarded by Liverpool University on Monday.

"He was a shining example of the heart and soul of British poetry at its best," said the poet Carol Ann Duffy, who acknowledged his influence on her work.

Henri was born in Birkenhead but made a significant crossing of the Mersey in 1965 as the Beatles and the Mersey beat were resonating through the country. He studied fine art at King's College, Newcastle, but began writing seriously when he returned to Merseyside and was encouraged by the Liverpool poets Roger McGough and Brian Patten.

Remembering his first public reading, he told an interviewer: "It was a basement club and I was lousy. Pedantic, boring basically. I was looking at all these uninterested people with a drink in their hands and it was a revelation to me.

"Every poem from then on had to have a surface meaning. Maybe you could get to another level by reading it but it had to mean something immediately."

He teamed up with Patten and McGough and their collection The Mersey Sound, published in the Penguin modern poets series, sold more than 1m copies. He later led the poetry and rock band The Liverpool Scene.

His last performance was at a tribute event at Liverpool's Philharmonic Hall last year.

fields.headline: Jacques Goddet
fields.standfirst: Sports father figure who guided the Tour de France for 50 years
fields.trailText: Sports father figure who guided the Tour de France for 50 years.
fields.body:
When the cyclists of the Tour de France pedal over the 6,400ft summit of the Col du Tourmalet, in the Pyrenees, next July, they will pass a newly-erected monument to one of the fathers of the world's biggest annual sporting event, Jacques Goddet, who has died in Paris, aged 95.

Goddet ran the tour from 1936 to 1987 and, as founder of the French sports newspaper l'Equipe, and a prime mover in the foundation of the European football clubs' cup (a precursor of the Champions League), athletics' European Nations' Cup and skiing's world cup, he was a definitive figure of French sport in the 20th century.

There was little chance of his ever moving in a direction other than sport or journalism, given that his father, Victor, founded the newspaper l'Auto and, with its co-owner Henri Desgrange, was behind the birth of the Tour de France in 1903. Educated partly near Oxford, where he broke his leg playing rugby - his other love, for which he covered more than 40 Five Nations tournaments - Goddet began writing about the tour for the paper in 1928.

Eight years later, when Desgrange was taken ill, Goddet inherited the race organisation, together with the direction of the newspaper, and, like the man he referred to as "my master", continued writing editorials in the sonorous, quasi-classical style which is the language of cycling in l'Equipe, after each day's stage was over.

Even before he took over the race, Goddet had pressed Desgrange "to bring coherence to this monumental event, which is threatened by the fact that it lasts a month and moves through a human corridor 5,000km long with no limits". The tour was shortened, national teams were introduced (including a British Empire squad in 1936) and the format made more media-friendly.

Goddet's organisational style, in conjunction with his sidekick Felix Levitan, of the Parisien Libéré newspaper, was imperious, and he was a distinctive figure in his Indian army garb - khaki shorts and a pith helmet, which, he said, "I put on by chance as the tour went south one year. It proved popular, so I kept wearing it. It was cool and added colour to the race."

He used the sprawling event as a testbed for radio and television, finishing the race high on mountain-tops in the Alps and Pyrenees. He took it outside France - including an incursion to Plymouth in 1974 - and never ceased to encourage the internationalisation of the field. He created the philosophy that, as well as holding on to its traditions, the tour must be of its time, a keystone of its enduring success.

As recently as two months ago, Goddet was urging that the race be shortened; at the turn of the year, he called for the creation of a sports equivalent of the United Nations to wipe out doping, and for cycling to look for new talent among the endurance athletes of sub-Saharan Africa. Some things could not be overcome; after Greg LeMond became the first American winner in 1986, he wanted to start the tour in New York, but the logistics proved too complex.

During the occupation, l'Auto continued to appear, although its print works produced posters, speeches and material for the resistance. The Tour de France, however, stopped. Goddet told me last year of his pride at this stand. "The occupying authorities and the Vichy regime wanted the tour to take place at any price to make the world believe that France was a normal, happy place. I refused, in spite of the fact that, in a time of shortages, any resources we needed - food, petrol, vehicles - would be made available. I saved the tour from being sullied, and that was important for its postwar future."

Two years after l'Auto closed in August 1944, Goddet founded l'Equipe; he remained a director until his death and ran the paper with the same imperiousness he brought to the tour. Even after retirement, his influence remained; the current Tour de France organiser, Jean-Marie Leblanc, would visit him before presenting the route, and in 1998, during the race's gravest crisis - over the expulsion of a team for systematic drug use - Leblanc waited nervously for Goddet's reaction.

The tribute that would have meant the most came from the five-times tour winner Bernard Hinault: "Above all else, he loved sport and those who practise it."

Goddet is survived by his wife, Rosine.

webTitle: Redress for slavery could follow law

fields.headline: Redress for slavery could follow law
fields.standfirst: California legislation focuses on insurers of 'human property'
fields.trailText: California legislation focuses on insurers of 'human property'
fields.body:
A law about to come into effect in California could bolster the growing movement to compensate the descendants of slaves.

From January 1 every insurance company operating in the state will have to declare any "slave insurance" policies it offered in the 19th century.

The law will require companies to state which policies they offered to slave-owners for the death, loss, or injury of slaves the policy-holders had bought.

It began life as a bill sponsored by the radical California senator Tom Hayden, and does not require the insurance company to pay recompense; rather, it seeks to act as an educational reminder of the history of slavery.

In 1705, a slavery act was passed in Virginia requiring that "Negro, mulatto and Indian slaves" be considered as "real estate". Since slavery was abolished in 1865 at the end of the civil war, there has been no payment made in restitution to the descendants of slaves.

There is, however, a growing movement of activists seeking reparation, and they regard the new law as a step towards their goal.

Two Democrats, Jesse Jackson and John Conyers, have proposed legislation that would establish a federal commission to explore how reparation might be made. In declaring his support for the new law, Mr Jackson said: "The nation must come to grips with the truth and consequences of its history."

The largest insurance company in the US, Aetna Inc, has apologised for selling slave insurance policies in the 1850s, but so far no other company has declared such practices.

Yesterday, Fred Laberge of Aetna said his company fully intended to comply with the law. As to whether the law could lead to moves for financial reparation, Mr Laberge said: "It's hard for us to speculate."

He did speculate, however, that it would be wrong to judge a company with a good record for diversity by the "very different moral and ethical standards" of a bygone era.

Opponents of the law say that insurance companies are being unfairly singled out when almost all commercial enterprises at the time of slavery benefited directly or indirectly from the trade and the unpaid labour. Its supporters argue that it will remind Americans about a key part of their history.

The issue of reparations has been raised before. In 1866 a "black tax refund", apparently based on the estimated value of 40 acres (16 hectares) and a mule, was laid out by Congress but vetoed by President Andrew Johnson.

In 1963 in his book, Why We Can't Wait, the late civil rights leader Martin Luther King proposed a "bill of rights for the disadvantaged", in which he called for reparations.

"Not all the wealth of this affluent society could meet the bill. Yet a price can be placed on the unpaid wages," he said. "The ancient common law has always provided a remedy for the appropriation of the labour of one human." He proposed a massive programme of compensation.

The US government has in the past acted to compensate ethnic groups that have been exploited or mistreated; in 1988, it apologised and gave $20,000 (£13,500) each to around 60,000 Japanese-Americans who were held in internment camps during the second world war.

Reparation today remains a hot issue and one that is unlikely to subside. Only this month an elaborate fraud persuaded around 30,000 gullible Americans that the government owed them $5,000 (£3,400) each as payment for the legacy of slavery.

Con artists told elderly African-Americans that they were entitled to tax breaks as a result of a "slave reparation act" and offered - for a fee - to obtain tax refunds on their behalf.

fields.headline: Pupils sit examination in murder
fields.trailText: Japanese parents are up in arms over an end-of-term examination paper that asked teenage children how they would go about bumping off their future spouses.
fields.body:
Japanese parents are up in arms over an end-of-term examination paper that asked teenage children how they would go about bumping off their future spouses.

The question was meant to spice up a dull test for a physical education class, but although the black humour was a hit with students, it has gone down like a lead balloon among education authorities, who fear it could worsen a wave of youth violence.

The exam was set for 135 third-year students at Nara Ikuei junior high school in the western region of Kansai, which is famed for its over-the-top sense of humour.

After four dull-as-ditchwater questions about health and the environment, the final section of the test asked students "to list two methods of killing your future husband or wife without violating the law".

One male student said he would get his wife drunk and then encourage her to drive home alone. Another wrote that he would do the job slowly by pressing large quantities of alcohol and tobacco on his partner over several years. A third answered that a daily diet of fatty food would have the desired result.

Such responses were exactly what the 51-year-old teacher who set the test wanted.

In classes this term, the teacher, who is described by colleagues as joke-loving, diligent and popular with pupils, had told students to note down ways "not to live a long life" as an offbeat way of explaining the dangers of smoking, drinking and a poor diet.

"I was only trying to grab their attention," the teacher explained amid a growing outcry as details of the question filtered out.

"It was extremely inappropriate," said Otozo Koda, the headmaster, in a written apology to parents. "We are sorry for what happened and we will not allow it to occur again."

He said that special classes had been given to the students who took the test so that they would not believe it was right to consider killing somebody.

webTitle: Serbian voters prepare to heap more humiliation on Milosevic

fields.headline: Serbian voters prepare to heap more humiliation on Milosevic
fields.standfirst: Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: The last bastions of parliamentary power held by ex-president Slobodan Milosevic's Socialist party are expected to fall to reformist candidates in Serbia's elections tomorrow.
fields.body:
The last bastions of parliamentary power held by ex-president Slobodan Milosevic's Socialist party are expected to fall to reformist candidates in Serbia's elections tomorrow.

Supporters of President Vojislav Kostunica are forecast to win a landslide victory and secure control of Serbia's government, the most important power centre in Yugoslavia.

The election should give Serbia its first government for more than 50 years not led by the Socialists or their communist predecessors. It will be a fresh humiliation for Slobodan Milosevic who was removed from power following a popular uprising.

He remains controversially protected by a special army unit and police guard in Beli Dvor (White Palace), which was once the home of Marshal Tito, in the Belgrade suburb of Dedinje.

The man who ought to live in the palace, the new federal president Mr Kostunica, is busy travelling around the world re-establishing ties that Mr Milosevic severed.

In just two months since the 5 October uprising, when Serbia overthrew Mr Milosevic, Mr Kostunica has brought Yugoslavia back into the world community, rejoining the United Nations and the Organisation for Security and Cooperation in Europe and raising its long term aim of joining the European Union.

During this time his popularity has soared to an unprecedented 91% approval rating.

According to many opinion polls, members of the anti-Milosevic coalition, DOS (the Democratic Opposition of Serbia), will gain more than 70% of the vote.

The latest survey showed DOS with 63% - which would translate into a larger majority in parliament, because some parties will not clear the 5% threshold.

The Socialists, with a projected 13% of the vote, look set to win a few seats in parliament, but not to have any serious power. Two splinter parties will further divide the leftwing vote and the Yugoslav Left party of Mr Milosevic's wife Mira Markovic is not expected to gain a single seat.

Rebeka Srbinovic, vice-president of the DOS party New Democracy, said it was important that in the elections, DOS wins more than two thirds of the seats in parliament. This would give them the mandate to change the Serbian constitution and jettison the one that Mr Milosevic tailor-made for himself.

On Serbia's streets, people see the elections as being their chance to stamp out Mr Milosevic. Car mechanic Vladimir Dacevic, 62, hurrying home from work on 27 March Street in central Belgrade, said: "These elections are very important. We need to finish the changes that we started on 5 October and to get rid of the Reds [Socialists], to put normal, young people into jobs - and not old thieves."

The DOS coalition has already announced that the Democratic party leader, Zoran Djindjic, will be prime minister and parties in DOS have agreed a share-out of seats in the parliament and in the cabinet.

Mr Djindjic has named the key cabinet positions and the only top post still in question is that of minister for police.

The new police chief will take over from an ally of Milosevic, Rade Markovic, whom Mr Kostunica controversially kept in power.

The minister will be responsible for overseeing the secret police and so will control access to the files that Mr Milosevic's secret service gathered on his political enemies - many of whom are now DOS leaders.

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: • There's nothing nicer than watching an old favourite get on, so congrats to Marcia Saunders. We first met Marcia in February during the mayoral fiasco when, as constituency chairman of my friend Barbara Roche's Hornsey and Wood Green seat, she naughtily tried to deny that a woman who wrote to the paper rubbishing Ken Livingstone was Barbara's constituency secretary.
fields.body:
 There's nothing nicer than watching an old favourite get on, so congrats to Marcia Saunders. We first met Marcia in February during the mayoral fiasco when, as constituency chairman of my friend Barbara Roche's Hornsey and Wood Green seat, she naughtily tried to deny that a woman who wrote to the paper rubbishing Ken Livingstone was Barbara's constituency secretary.

At the time there were rumours that Marcia's "pro-active" way of running meetings was causing umbrage to some Hornsey members. Now news reaches us that she is moving on. And given New Labour's promise not to fill quangos with political affiliates, who better to become the new chairman of Barnet, Enfield and Haringey health authority, on an "honorarium" of almost £20,000 a year? "These are exciting times," says the outgoing Hornsey chair. "I am deeply impressed by the work that has already been done ..." Splendid. Patients in north London can relax knowing that this rampantly independent, non-partisan free thinker is fighting their corner.

 Bouncing back from the lottery disaster, Richard Branson has recorded Jingle Bells for his Virgin email Christmas card. Thanks for alerting us to this go to a reader in Bootle who was particularly thrilled with his animated Santa Branson, having just received £7 compensation after the Virgin train for which he spent £64 buying a ticket was delayed by precisely one calendar day.

 Lovable old halibut Baronness Young has been doing some research on her website (www.ageofconsent.co.uk). Concerned that "there has been no true test of public opinion over this important irreversible Act of Parliament", she sets out to provide one by inviting visitors into her natty virtual polling booth. The vote, she writes, "will allow public opinion to be heard and will truly reflect how the nation feels about the age of consent." Indeed. As things stand, 67% wish to lower the age of consent, a fact she will certainly wish to trumpet the next time she treats the Lords to a squirt of her poison.

 Tribune is being evicted from its offices near Kings Cross in January, but it seems the landlord is worried that Mark Seddon and co may be unwilling to move. So to give them a nudge, the janitor has been told to enter the office each morning to turn off all lights and remove all loo rolls. Mark did consider appealing for help to the National Union of Journalists, but decided against on remembering that the NUJ is the landlord.

 Thanks to Gill Spaul for supplying a strong peg for an ancient story about a smashed Richard Littlejohn's making an ass of himself with a Tory cabinet minister and his wife. Gill cites the purchase of a controlling interest in Spurs, the club Richard tried to buy, and for this a bottle of champagne is hers (don't hold your breath). However, I'm a bit fragile myself today after an outing to Westminster on Wednesday night culminating, I think, in my embracing Helen Brinton while she queued for a taxi. In this case, it would be too hypocritical to tease Richard for wine-induced imbecility today, so we will hold it back for a New Year treat.

 The meaning of Christmas may have been buried under an avalanche of commercialism, but in Downing Street at least the anti-materialist message of a baby born into poverty is well understood. So well, in fact, that all papers which ran the Christmas card picture of Mr T and Cherie with Leo have unexpectedly been invoiced for £500. The usual defence (it's going to charideee) applies, but even so what a pair of cheeky bleeders they are.

 The Diary returns next Wednesday, when we begin the embarrassing annual attempt to stretch what might laughably be called the "highlights" of the year over as many columns as possible.
