fields.headline: Missing Manchester values
fields.standfirst:
The fact of the matter is: we all need to reread our Scott

MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: The fact of the matter is: we all need to reread our Scott.
fields.body:
"Comment is free, but facts are sacred." When CP Scott, one of this newspaper's greatest editors, wrote his famous lines, he could count on general agreement - confident that intelligent readers were responsive to well-documented evidence and honoured a boundary between truth and interpretation, facts and their evaluation.

Eighty years on, journalists no longer share that confidence: they're as puzzled as anyone at the apparent immunity to evidence of people's convictions. GM crops remain, for the general public, a sinister threat however patiently leading biologists and government scientific advisers present evidence to the contrary.

Journalists are right to have lost Scott's confidence. But why? What's going on? There's nothing new in people sticking to their guns despite the evidence. We don't live by reason alone. But contemporary resilience to "the facts" is especially impressive. They bounce off people, leaving armour-plated convictions unscathed. Among the reasons are ones for which the media bear some responsibility - in particular, their promotion of images, stereotypes, that easily trump the actual evidence. In a debate dominated by the Frankenstein imagery of power crazy scientists violating life itself, and by a bucolic stereotype of organic farmers, their muddy boots planted firmly in our country's soil, the facts hardly get a look in. Between graphic imagery and sober commentary, there's no contest.

But it's not simply that facts bounce off people: there are powerful currents in contemporary culture that erode the very distinction between fact and comment which Scott relied on his readers to respect. For a start, there's the postmodernist fashion - let loose from the confines of university literature departments - expressly to deny, "deconstruct", that distinction. Facts are what you can persuade your friends to accept, says one leader of that fashion. The Gulf war never took place, declaims another: his point being that actual events cannot be sifted from the virtual reality - the product of spin and presentation - on our TV screens.

Spin, of course, has its own corrosive influence. When papers are keener to report the spin behind a story than the story itself, it's unsurprising that readers swallow any story only with a spoonful of salt. "Who's peddling what?" they ask cynically.

Erosion of respect for "the facts" is further encouraged by our culture's celebration of variety, of difference - something children are programmed for in schools which teach that any opinion is as valid as another. The fairness towards conflicting views on which Scott insisted becomes an uncritical welcome to just about everything, lest anyone's sensibilities are offended. The effect on the arts, morality and religion is palpable: "Never mind the quality, feel the breadth!" might have been the slogan for the millennium extravaganza. In the moral arena, it seems, the only sin is to think that there's such a thing as sin.

In religion, people often welcome this ecumenism, but the mania for kaleidoscopic variety has spread even to the scientific arena. Every voice is to be heard: think of those TV investigations into unexplained phenomena - corn circles, say - where the same solemn respect is extended to the crackpot as to the astronomer royal. Viewers are invited to choose their favourite explanation, as if they were buying a T-shirt. Facts are out: only preferences, points of view, remain.

Should we try to repair the situation, to rebuild Scott's temple of sacred facts? People in my trade - philosophy - often argue that even the most objective facts are, at some deep level, dependent on human perspective. Maybe they're right: but it's only when that view escapes from the olive grove or the ivory tower - simplified and coarsened - that it gets virulent and threatens our familiar, everyday distinction between facts and interpretation.

Postmodernists like to cite Kurosawa's film, Rashomon, in which the same murder is shown from the different perspectives of the people involved. The message, it's said, is that the truth can't be separated from the perspective, the interpretation. Well, we should reread our Scott. He himself warned against citing bare facts out of their context. But, equally, he would remind us that however differently the murder was interpreted, one man did stick a sword into another. That was fact, not comment.

 David Cooper is professor of philosophy at Durham University. This piece was written for BBC Radio 4's The Message, which broadcasts a discussion on the subject at 4:30pm today before an invited audience at the Guardian's northern offices in Manchester.

webTitle: Colombia puts the brakes on smugglers' gravy train

fields.headline: Colombia puts the brakes on smugglers' gravy train
fields.standfirst: Livelihoods in peril on bootleg peninsula
fields.trailText: Livelihoods in peril on bootleg peninsula
fields.body:
In the wheelhouse of Richard V, a Panamanian freighter anchored just off Colombia's desolate Caribbean coast, Captain Javier Penagas sighs deeply as he stares out at the isolated bay where he has been stranded for over a week.

The harbour is little more than a rough wooden platform jutting out from a dirty spit of sand, but for years this grubby beach has been the hub of a smuggling network worth hundreds of millions of pounds every year.

Now the port has been paralysed by a government effort to crack down on the trafficking. But the contraband is not cocaine or heroin on its way to markets in the US and Europe. In this case the merchandise is smuggled into Colombia.

Until recently, ships would anchor nearly every day at Puerto Nuevo and a handful of other deep bays along the north coast of the Guajira peninsula. Teams of Wayuu tribesmen unloaded thousands of tonnes of merchandise every week - mostly electrical goods, textiles, cigarettes and alcohol bought cheaply in the tax-free ports of Panama and the Dutch Antilles.

The government is trying to stop the illegal imports, which officials say are undercutting legitimate industries, ruining the Colombian economy and enabling the mafia to launder its narco-dollars.

On the deck of Richard V, 500 tonnes of fridges and washing machines have baked in the fierce Caribbean sun for eight days, while Capt Penagas waits for permission to unload.

Technically the cargo is not yet contraband. In an attempt to boost the region's economy, the Guajira was declared a tax-free zone in 1992, and taxes were eliminated on merchandise imported for local use.

But few of the goods stay in the Guajira. Most of the imports are loaded on to armed convoys which disappear into a maze of desert trails. Fifty miles south of Puerto Nuevo, the trucks cross an invisible line in the sand and the merchandise becomes contraband for sale on the black market throughout Colombia.

So far, government efforts to police the region have been ineffective, and officials say that multinational tobacco and electronics companies prefer to turn a blind eye to a situation which, though illegal, was always good for business.

"For them the important thing was to sell. It didn't matter who to," said a senior customs official, Mauricio Molano.

The government's current anti-smuggling campaign includes actions against both the suppliers and the smugglers.

Earlier this year Colombian officials brought lawsuits against cigarette companies Philip Morris and British American Tobacco, accusing them of tax fraud for allowing illegal imports. The government has also signed a series of pacts with multinationals which have agreed to sell their goods only to legal importers.

Armed police have raided black market stores throughout the country, but in the Guajira, actions against contraband have provoked riots. In one incident a police station was burnt down by an angry mob.

According to a local anthropologist, Weildler Guerra, the government's campaign ignores the region's particular history. "For the government it's smuggling. For the Guajiros it's just business," he said.

Most imports pass through Maicao, a desert trading post three hours south of Puerto Nuevo. Every street is lined with shops touting cut-rate contraband goods: Korean CD players, French perfume, American washing machines and bales of Indian textiles.

Security guards armed with shotguns and revolvers lounge in the shade, but now there are few customers in any of the stores, and shopkeepers say that business is a fraction of what it used to be. Drifts of rubbish scud down deserted streets that once thronged with shoppers, and untreated sewage trickles over the broken pavements.

"We used to drink champagne, but we have no clean water and no paved roads," said Mara Ortega, a member of the Wayuu community and president of the local trade association. She says the government's anti-smuggling drive is attacking Maicao's only source of employment.

Local business leaders say that they do not oppose stricter controls on trade in the Guajira, which could help legitimise the region's shadow economy. But they say that the reforms must be sensitive to the region's traditions.

Business is practically at a standstill, says Gazi Issa, a Lebanese shopkeeper dozing in the corner of his empty electronics store. He hasn't seen a customer all day. Six months ago he would sell £2,000 worth of goods every day - now he's lucky to sell more than £200 worth. "This town is dying. In two years' time Maicao won't exist," he said.

webTitle: LBS order book fails to convince

fields.headline: LBS order book fails to convince
fields.trailText: Several analysts yesterday dismissed an upbeat trading statement from retail banking IT specialists London Bridge Software as over-reliant on "highly debatable" accountancy methods.
fields.body:
Several analysts yesterday dismissed an upbeat trading statement from retail banking IT specialists London Bridge Software as over-reliant on "highly debatable" accountancy methods.

The statement is thought to have been issued after founder and chairman Gordon Crawford received notes from fund managers and analysts concerned about rumours of an imminent profit warning.

"This month will be the best month for trading and new licence sales in the company's history," Mr Crawford said. "The order book is at an all-time high against which we are recruiting as quickly as possible in many areas of the company.

"Whilst we can not guarantee the performance for this year at this stage, this augurs well for the future," he said.

Attempts to scotch talk of a drop in profits did little to convince analysts. Shares in LBS closed down 32.5p at 317.5p.

Jeff Hargreaves, from stockbroker Peel Hunt, said there were several licensing contracts which had to be signed in the next few working days if LBS was to meet his pre-tax profits forecast of £13.8m for the year to December 31.

He said that the way the company recognised revenue meant it was very dependent on signing licensing sales at the end of every quarter, and particularly at the end of its financial year. This uncertainty was bound to affect share price.

Given the continuing slow down in the US market, where LBS has had a difficult six months, Mr Hargreaves said a number of licensing contracts may not be signed until next year. A worst case scenario over the next few days would shave 20% off his profit forecast for the current year.

Neither Mr Crawford nor anyone at LBS was available for comment yesterday.

The LBS trading statement said that the firm's 2001 budget would not be affected if the company failed to meet targets this year.

fields.headline: Ultra-faithful kill with impunity
fields.standfirst: Sect faces legalised persecution in Pakistan for its beliefs
fields.trailText: Sect faces legalised persecution in Pakistan for its beliefs
fields.body:
Even before you enter the village at the end of the rutted road in the dusty plains of the Punjab you sense the hatred that has overtaken Takht Hazara.

"If you befriend a Qadiani then you are opposing Islam," reads the red and black Urdu script on a wooden sign hanging over the first shop. Three bored policemen slouch idly at the roadside nearby.

"Qadiani" refers to the Ahmadis, a minority religious sect which was officially declared un-Islamic in 1974 and has since suffered intense persecution in Pakistan.

Five Ahmadis, including two 15-year-old boys, were hacked to death in Takht Hazara last month by a mob led by a local cleric. Two of the bodies were thrown from the roof of their mosque. Days earlier, five other Ahmadis in another Punjab village were shot dead by four gunmen at a prayer meeting.

Pakistan's 3.5m Ahmadis belong to the only religion in the country which it is legal to discriminate against; it is illegal for them to call themselves Muslims, to describe their places of worship as mosques or for the muezzin to call the faithful to prayer five times a day.

Although, like all Muslims, they believe in the prophet Mohammed, Ahmadis also believe the messiah was a man named Mirza Ghulam Ahmad, who lived in Qadian, India, in the last century. It is this belief that is considered blasphemous by hardline Islamists.

In Pakistan, many Ahmadis are well educated and relatively wealthy, which, particularly in Takht Hazara, where they are in the minority, has caused years of jealousy.

Ahmadi gravestones in the Takht Hazara cemetery have been smashed. Many in the community, including one of the men killed in last month's attack, had complained to the police about harassment, without result.

Athar Shah, the local hardline Sunni Muslim mullah who led the mob that night and was injured in the attack, ran an anti-Ahmadi organisation from a small, wooden office in the village.

"The death of an apostate is better than the deaths of all the non-Muslims in the world," read a sign on his locked office door. Mr Shah, who is under arrest in Faisalabad, had tried to begin proceedings to have the Ahmadi mosque knocked down.

On the night of the attack, the mob broke down two walls of the Ahmadi mosque and forced their way in.

"The crowd used axes on Nasir Ahmad," said Waseem Ahmad, a 22-year-old student who watched two of his cousins die. "They cut his throat and then they threw him down on to the road."

As he spoke, Nasir Ahmad's mother sat crouching in the mosque's burned out prayer hall rocking backwards and forwards as she sobbed into the bloody shawl her son had been wearing that night. The ceiling fans above her were bent crooked by the fire.

Many of the Ahmadis in the village say they no longer notice the inflammatory signs. But their resentment is not hidden far below the surface.

"I am thinking I should kill half of this village," said Afzal Mehmood, 38, whose father and brother died in the attack. "But our supreme head doesn't allow this."

"My family emigrated from India to Pakistan at the time of partition for protection because it was a Muslim state. It was supposed to be our beloved country," he said. "Now India is a better place to be."

Little is said in Pakistan's wordy newspapers about the Ahmadis or the country's other persecuted religious minority, the 2m Christians. Pakistan's Christians often live in city slums and, passed over for most jobs, they do the work no others will do.

Both Ahmadis and Christians are regularly arrested under the sinister and arbitrary blasphemy law introduced by General Zia ul-Haq in 1985, which laid down the death penalty for anyone insulting the prophet Mohammed.

"There is a small lobby of mullahs who are pushing forward a campaign against minorities," said Kamila Hyat, joint director of the Human Rights Commission of Pakistan. "The government should be clamping down, but it seems there is a tacit support for this."

Pakistan's military leader, General Pervez Musharraf, proposed a slight amendment of the blasphemy law earlier this year which would have made prosecutions harder. But within days he backed down in the wake of furious criticism from Sunni Muslim leaders.

"The government is responsible for stopping not only the killings," said Ms Hyat, "but also the preaching of hatred, which is against the law, and which keeps instigating the violence."

Five Ahmadis, including two 15-year-old boys, were hacked to death in Takht Hazara last month by a mob led by a local cleric. Two of the bodies were thrown from the roof of their mosque. Days earlier, five other Ahmadis in another Punjab village were shot dead by four gunmen at a prayer meeting. Pakistan's 3.5m Ahmadis belong to the only religion in the country which it is legal to discriminate against; it is illegal for them to call themselves Muslims, to describe their places of worship as mosques or for the muezzin to call the faithful to prayer five times a day. Although, like all Muslims, they believe in the prophet Mohammed, Ahmadis also believe the messiah was a man named Mirza Ghulam Ahmad, who lived in Qadian, India, in the last century. It is this belief that is considered blasphemous by hardline Islamists. In Pakistan, many Ahmadis are well educated and relatively wealthy, which, particularly in Takht Hazara, where they are in the minority, has caused years of jealousy. Ahmadi gravestones in the Takht Hazara cemetery have been smashed. Many in the community, including one of the men killed in last month's attack, had complained to the police about harassment, without result. Athar Shah, the local hardline Sunni Muslim mullah who led the mob that night and was injured in the attack, ran an anti-Ahmadi organisation from a small, wooden office in the village. "The death of an apostate is better than the deaths of all the non-Muslims in the world," read a sign on his locked office door. Mr Shah, who is under arrest in Faisalabad, had tried to begin proceedings to have the Ahmadi mosque knocked down. On the night of the attack, the mob broke down two walls of the Ahmadi mosque and forced their way in. "The crowd used axes on Nasir Ahmad," said Waseem Ahmad, a 22-year-old student who watched two of his cousins die. "They cut his throat and then they threw him down on to the road." As he spoke, Nasir Ahmad's mother sat crouching in the mosque's burned out prayer hall rocking backwards and forwards as she sobbed into the bloody shawl her son had been wearing that night. The ceiling fans above her were bent crooked by the fire. Many of the Ahmadis in the village say they no longer notice the inflammatory signs. But their resentment is not hidden far below the surface. "I am thinking I should kill half of this village," said Afzal Mehmood, 38, whose father and brother died in the attack. "But our supreme head doesn't allow this." "My family emigrated from India to Pakistan at the time of partition for protection because it was a Muslim state. It was supposed to be our beloved country," he said. "Now India is a better place to be." Little is said in Pakistan's wordy newspapers about the Ahmadis or the country's other persecuted religious minority, the 2m Christians. Pakistan's Christians often live in city slums and, passed over for most jobs, they do the work no others will do. Both Ahmadis and Christians are regularly arrested under the sinister and arbitrary blasphemy law introduced by General Zia ul-Haq in 1985, which laid down the death penalty for anyone insulting the prophet Mohammed. "There is a small lobby of mullahs who are pushing forward a campaign against minorities," said Kamila Hyat, joint director of the Human Rights Commission of Pakistan. "The government should be clamping down, but it seems there is a tacit support for this." Pakistan's military leader, General Pervez Musharraf, proposed a slight amendment of the blasphemy law earlier this year which would have made prosecutions harder. But within days he backed down in the wake of furious criticism from Sunni Muslim leaders. "The government is responsible for stopping not only the killings," said Ms Hyat, "but also the preaching of hatred, which is against the law, and which keeps instigating the violence."

webTitle: Britain fought to block UN sanctions against Taliban

fields.headline: Britain fought to block UN sanctions against Taliban
fields.trailText: Britain privately opposed the fresh round of United Nations sanctions imposed against Afghanistan this week, according to a security council source yesterday.
fields.body:
Britain privately opposed the fresh round of United Nations sanctions imposed against Afghanistan this week, according to a security council source yesterday.

Although Britain voted for the sanctions, in private British diplomats in New York worked up until the last minute to try to block them.

The security council source said that the only outcome of the sanctions would be to make the already appalling humanitarian situation in Afghanistan even worse.

The ruling Taliban reacted to the sanctions by pulling out of UN peace talks aimed at ending the civil war, and ordering a boycott of US and Russian goods - a largely meaningless gesture as few can afford such items.

America and Russia, which formerly occupied Afghanistan, unusually joined forces in the security council to push through the sanctions, aimed at the Taliban government in Kabul. UN staff were pulled out on the orders of the New York headquarters fearful of Taliban retaliation.

The security council source said: "This was all predictable. The Taliban reaction was predictable. Whether it is the fault of the Taliban or our action, the people who are going to be hurt on the ground are the people of Afghanistan."

UN sanctions were imposed against the Taliban government last year. The latest round includes a ban on arms to the Taliban and more flight restrictions.

The sanctions are largely symbolic: the Afghan economy is in such disrepair that they will have little impact.

The US is keen to keep up pressure on Afghanistan to hand over Osama bin Laden, the terrorist accused of bombing US embassies in east Africa in 1998 and suspected of involvement in the recent attack on USS Cole in Yemen.

The sanctions will come into force if Bin Laden is not handed over by next month, but the Taliban government claims there is insufficient evidence against him.

Britain was joined in its scepticism about the value of the sanctions by Canada and the Netherlands. "If it had not been put on the table, we would not have dreamt it up," one of the diplomats involved said.

The security council source said that, in addition to worries about the humanitarian impact, the big question was: "How can we possibly implement these sanctions? "

The UN secretary general, Kofi Annan, took the unusual step on Tuesday, the day the resolution was passed, of warning that it would harm the UN's humanitarian work and do little to help the peace process.

The World Food Programme said yesterday that it had begun to ship food aid through Iran to Afghanistan to fight a potential famine brought on by the worst drought in 30 years. It said up to 12m Afghans were affected by the four-month-old drought, 3-4m of them severely, with thousands forced to migrate to urban centres.

The office of the UN High Commissioner for Refugees expressed disappointment yesterday that its staff had had to leave. Yusuf Hassan, the senior regional external relations officer for the south-west and central Asian region, said the presence of UN staff was a must: "I think we need to have presence inside [Afghanistan] to monitor the condition and to continue to support the refugees coming back."

He quoted the high commissioner, Sadako Ogata, as saying: "The vast majority of Afghans face a constant struggle to survive the effects of armed conflict, grinding poverty, displacement and the worst drought in living memory."

The International Committee of the Red Cross said it would keep its staff in Afghanistan.

fields.headline: On message
fields.trailText: BT is to launch a wholesale unmetered internet access service for internet service providers and other licensed telecommunications operators.
fields.body:
No clock watching

BT is to launch a wholesale unmetered internet access service for internet service providers and other licensed telecommunications operators.

BT's Ignite unit said the service, called BTnet SurfPort 24, will be available to order from January 18 and provide unlimited access 24 hours a day for a simple quarterly port-based fee.

Program for business

Software group Microsoft has agreed to acquire Great Plains Software, a supplier of mid-market business programs, for $1.1bn (£700m). Microsoft said the acquisition will accelerate its offerings for small and medium-sized businesses with global business interests.

fields.headline: 3G infatuation threatens heartbreak
fields.standfirst: Central banks and credit rating agencies are warning lenders their exposure to broadband telecoms providers may be too high
fields.trailText: Central banks and credit rating agencies are warning lenders their exposure to broadband telecoms providers may be too high.
fields.body:
It is a $300bn gamble. The stakes are so high even hardened financial regulators who have watched countries go to the brink and beyond are starting to feel twitchy. The big rating agencies have added their voices to a chorus of caution. Indeed there are now so many people saying, "there is no need to panic but ...", it is hard not to feel worried.

The cause of this angst? The extent to which the banks have backed the European telecommunications industry's rush into the world of third generation mobile telephone networks.

These promise to provide "always on", high speed internet connections enabling mobile phones to transmit video images and run computer games across the web.

Between the cost of government auctions for the digital wireless licence and the price of setting up a new network, the bill will top $300bn (£204bn).

Little wonder, then, that there are those who wonder if 3G threatens to become a black hole into which even the most solid balance sheets might disappear.

Regulators are worried about the banks' exposure. Investors who dream of a wireless world generating a quality stream of earnings may find it turning into a nightmare of overspending and underperformance. So far only taxpayers in countries such as the UK and Germany - which milked every penny and pfennig from the auctioning of licences - are laughing.

In theory 3G looks like a steal. Traditional wireless technologies are circuit switched, 3G is built so it can handle packet switched data. The difference is enormous - in terms of traffic it is rather like driving from a country road onto a 10, even a 20 lane highway.

While the old networks are fine for voice traffic, the new generation will be able to do much more. If the networks work the same way as roads, where the more capacity you build the more traffic is attracted, then nobody in the industry will worry about that.

Nor are the numbers as scary as they look. On the basis of by no means unrealistic projections for the numbers of Europeans who will have a mobile phone over the next few years, some analysts think those firms which have splashed out on 3G need only generate around €2 per subscriber a month over the period of the licence to get their money back.

But not everybody agrees. At the beginning of the year telecoms was the place to be. Investors were clamouring to fill their portfolios with stock. Vodafone's daring bid for Mannesmann of Germany showed what could be achieved - although the deal meant Vodafone had to sell on Mannesmann's Orange business, there was never going to be a shortage of takers.

Then the world changed. Britain's 3G auction - which raised $35bn - showed how much might have to be spent. Germany managed even more - $46bn. Even with the love affair with technology ending, governments have wrung $120bn out of mobile phone companies.

Suddenly investors began to worry about what the cost would do to balance sheets. The gloom enveloped those who missed out in the auctions. This week shares in Telia, the Swedish state-owned company, plunged because it did not win a 3G licence at home.

Pekka Sivonen, chairman of leading Finnish wireless software firm Digia, says that makes Telia a target for hostile takeovers. "I think it could now be an acquisition target for somebody since they are not even on strong ground on their own territory," Mr Sivonen told the Guardian. "I really believe the decision is not beneficial for the mobile industry in Scandinavia. I've always been a strong supporter of a free market economy and old companies being challenged by new ones, but this is not good."

At the same time many experts wonder what a successful 3G launch would do to revenues from the fixed line business owned by former state-owned monopolies such as BT, France Telecom, Deutsche Telekom and Telefonica. Speculation that the industry will not be able to support all the current players is growing.

Events in the wider world have conspired to add to the woes. Investors have taken fright at the glut of bad news coming from the hi-tech sector. This week AT&T announced an 80% cut in its fourth quarter dividend. Lucent yesterday announced larger than expected losses in the current quarter.

There are those who suggest that rolling out the networks could prove more expensive than the operators may have imagined. As demand on a network base station grows, the area it can serve shrinks - so operators who reckon they can use the same number of base stations for 3G as for existing networks could find holes in their coverage.

Nor can the operators simply pull back the old and roll out the new. Many customers will want to stay with their existing phones, however outmoded, so operators will have to maintain existing coverage alongside the 3G networks. New entrants face no such hazards - but they do not have the existing customer base.

But the advice is not to panic - equipment providers reckon they can lick the technical problems. New equipment can be installed alongside the old.

Existing operators may choose to hedge their bets by opening their networks to new entrants. BT Cellnet is already considering that option, and while those who live in rural areas may have to wait for the brave new world of 3G technology, subscribers in urban areas will find themselves at the front of the queue once the roll-out is under way.

Lloyd Carney is a man with a lot riding on the way the 3G business develops. He is president of Nortel Networks' wireless internet solutions business. Nortel is a leading player in the 3G network market. It has won more than $2bn of infrastructure business in Europe with contracts from BT Cellnet, Xfera and Airtel in Spain and T-Mobile in Germany. Yet despite the doubters, Mr Carney is relaxed, even bullish about the outlook - not least about Europe where, unlike the US, the industry has addopted a single standard.

Even so he admits that some things will have to change. The future will belong to those who provide "value added" services, companies with a multimedia focus. "Voice [calls]," he says, slightly dismissively, "is the cost of entry. You have to be doing more to succeed".

The higher margins, say Nortel, will be found in the additional services third generation nets can provide. Although Mr Carney points to the business market as an important area, he reckons the retail market will provide lots of opportunities.

Think of the music business, of consumers being able to download the latest from their favourite artists from the internet. Music companies are spared the expense of making and distributing the physical product while consumers are much more likely to buy on impulse.

The far east has been a test bed for 3G services. In Japan, the phenomenal success of "i-mode" has driven the growth of web-style mobile phone services.

With more than 9m users, i-mode provides teenage must-haves such as horoscopes, ticket booking and chart news, with new downloadable melodies.

The service is so popular that its operator, NTT DoCoMo, had to halt sales and advertising temporarily last month because demand kept crashing its system.

The way in which services are delivered and billed will have to change, too. Mr Carney thinks the idea of billing by the minute will have to go. Consumers will have to be offered different levels of service depending on functions offered.

The equipment to which such services will be delivered will also have to change. Mr Carney believes future devices will look more like consumer electronic devices than today's conventional handsets.

If Mr Carney is correct, that could have serious implications for mobile phone makers lacking the experience of consumer electronics that is second nature to some Asian equipment makers.

"This whole 3G thing is different - different services, different business model."

 Additional reporting by Andrew Osborn

webTitle: Vodafone stands out among the crowd

fields.headline: Vodafone stands out among the crowd
fields.standfirst: Global player Purity pays for British firm on takeover trail
fields.trailText: Global player Purity pays for British firm on takeover trail.
fields.body:
Few in the global telecommunications industry will look back on 2000 with pleasure. Despite a flying start it has been, largely, a year of mounting debts and increasingly anxious shareholders. The management at Vodafone will, however, count itself among the few.

The group began the year with 35m subscribers in 24 countries. By the end of third quarter, thanks to a series of takeovers and alliances, the total had soared to almost 60m. Nor has the company shown any inclination to rest on its laurels. This week alone it has bought a 15% stake in Japan Telecom, expanding its presence in an important mobile telephone market and underlining its credentials as a truly global player.

Even before the ink was dry on that deal, the Vodafone negotiators were burning Wednesday's midnight oil to clinch a €4.5bn (£2.7bn) deal to acquire Eircell, Ireland's biggest mobile phone company with more than 1m subscribers.

The hectic pre-Christmas spree ensures that Vodafone is ending the year on a similar note to the way in which it saw in the millennium. The group kicked off 2000 embroiled in one of the year's toughest takeover battles. Its hostile bid - which eventually toppped $190bn (£135bn) - for Germany's Mannesmann not only raised eyebrows in the industry, it turned corporate Germany upside down. In a sense, Mannesmann sealed its own fate when it bought Orange in 1999, throwing down a gauntlet Vodafone could hardly fail to pick up.

Despite a degree of anguish from many in the German establishment - Germany had traditionally been a place where hostile takeovers were just not done - Vodafone got the bid through, not least because some shareholders were keen to shake-up the previously cosy world of Rhineland capitalism. Time magazine rated it hostile bid of the year.

Vodafone kept up a hectic schedule of deals. It took control of Spanish mobile telecoms operator Airtel. It struck alliances in the US and Europe to form internet companies Verizon and Vizzavi respectively. And like any self respecting mobile phone group, it joined in the complex series of auctions via which Europe's governments (with mixed success) parcelled out third-generation mobile phone licences.

Along the way it dropped Airtouch - legacy of yet another, but earlier alliance - from the name, demonstrating clearly the location of the corporate centre of gravity. The group also ran into a row over special bonuses to executives which the company justified on the basis of Vodafone's transformation from a corporate shed in Newbury to global powerhouse

The financial performance has not been bad either. In the year to the end of March, turnover on a pro-forma basis was up by more than a third at £12.56bn. Profits, on the same basis, had risen from just under £1bn to more than £2.5bn. Yet by the halfway stage in the current financial year, Vodafone had all but matched the previous full-year's profits figure.

Vodafone's relative ability to ride out the storm - and it is relative not absolute, the share price is down from a February peak of 401p to just below 250p - has been boosted by its status as a "pure" mobile phone company.

Not for Vodafone the endless wrestling with regulators and/or Brussels over opening various bits of a fixed-line business, such as the local loop, which generate valuable revenues to new entrants.

Even so, Vodafone will still have its work cut out in the current year, reassuring investors that it can turn its geographic reach and technical capability into services and market shares capable of generating the level of earning investors were expecting when they pushed the shares up to that early-year peak. For Vodafone 2000 has been the year of the deal. Now it has to make sure it can deliver.

fields.headline: Homeless workers lose drug case plea
fields.standfirst: More about the Cambridge Two
fields.trailText: Two managers of a refuge for the homeless who were jailed in the first case of its kind for "knowingly permitting" drugs to be peddled at the hostel lost their attempt to have their convictions quashed yesterday.
fields.body:
Two managers of a refuge for the homeless who were jailed in the first case of its kind for "knowingly permitting" drugs to be peddled at the hostel lost their attempt to have their convictions quashed yesterday.

Homelessness charities said the appeal court's dismissal of appeals by Ruth Wyner and John Brock would make it harder to tackle drug addiction among street sleepers.

Wyner was the director and Brock the manager of the Bus Project, a daytime drop-in centre run by the charity Winter Comforts for the Homeless in Cambridge. Wyner was given a five-year prison sentence and Brock four years after being convicted last December of permitting the centre to be used for supplying heroin.

The so-called Cambridge Two, both 50, admitted they knew dealing was going on and tried to tackle the problem. They were released from prison last July pending their appeal, after serving 207 days.

Yesterday three judges ruled that their sentences were "very significantly too high" and reduced them to 14 months or, "if necessary, such a lesser term as ensures their immediate release". But the judges warned that those found guilty in similar circumstances in the future could expect stiffer sentences of 18 months or more.

The charity had operated a policy of confidentiality under which information about the people who attended the centre would not generally be passed on to outside agencies, including the police. After Wyner and Brock were convicted, some charities began turning away drug addicts and suffered staff shortages because people were unwilling to run the risk of imprisonment for failing to inform on those seeking shelter.

Lord Justice Rose said it was "not open to the defendants to shelter behind the existence of the confidentiality policy". He added: "Refuges for the homeless are vital at a time when homelessness is, sadly, a prevalent feature of the society in which we live. If such refuges become, as this refuge did, a focal point for the distribution of illegal drugs, local authorities, charitable foundations and others may well be reluctant or unwilling to provide the financial support without which such refuges are unlikely to exist."

Wyner and Brock were both of "hitherto impeccable character", he said. But the case "must serve as a warning that no one, however well intentioned, can with impunity permit their premises to be used for the supply of class A drugs".

Afterwards, Wyner said she and Brock would take the case to the European court of human rights in Strasbourg. "We feel very much for people working in projects with drug addicts as this makes their work much more difficult ... The judges are almost, in a sense, putting a threat of imprisonment over them unless they change their practices."

Rachel O'Brien, of the homelessness charity Shelter, said the ruling conflicted with the government's strategy to cut the numbers of rough sleepers. Those using drugs, a high proportion of the homeless, needed to have their lives stabilised, including having somewhere to live, before they could be weaned off drugs.

"There is a real danger that the people responsible for providing that accommodation are going to leave those people out in the cold for fear of prosecution," she said.

The chief crown prosecutor for Cambridgeshire, Richard Crowley, said: "Charities, their staff and workers who remain within the law have nothing to fear from this decision."

fields.headline: Rail chaos victims get £20m more
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Rail passengers are to get a further £20m in compensation for delays following the Hatfield crash, train companies announced yesterday.
fields.body:
Rail passengers are to get a further £20m in compensation for delays following the Hatfield crash, train companies announced yesterday.

It covers the period November 12 to December 9, and follows £50m previously announced for the four weeks immediately after the derailment in October.

The latest package includes up to 24 days of free travel for monthly or annual season ticketholders on Virgin's west coast and GNER's east coast main lines. Virgin CrossCountry season ticketholders will also get 24 days' free travel. Silverlink is offering up to 20 days' free travel on its Northampton line, which was affected by a derailment.

About 300,000 passengers will receive either five days' free travel or a discount when renewing their season.

"We want to demonstrate our recognition of the difficulties [passengers] have been experiencing," said George Muir, director general of the Association of Train Operating Companies.

Passengers with weekly or daily tickets must apply for refunds under each company's passenger's charter. The rail passengers council said that yesterday's package, while "generally fair", did nothing for the weekly holders, who had suffered exactly as had monthly holders.

 An ICM poll for BBC's Newsnight found three-to-one support for re-nationalising the railways, with 86% saying the service was unsatisfactory. Almost three times as many blamed the Tories as Labour.

webTitle: Scientists pinpoint risk of inherited Alzheimer's

fields.headline: Scientists pinpoint risk of inherited Alzheimer's
fields.trailText: A breakthrough in understanding how the risk of getting Alzheimer's disease can be inherited was announced by researchers yesterday.
fields.body:
A breakthrough in understanding how the risk of getting Alzheimer's disease can be inherited was announced by researchers yesterday.

They have identified an area on a chromosome - the 10th - linked to an increased risk of contracting Alzheimer's. The findings, in the journal Science, come hard on the heels of news in the journal Nature of a vaccine.

Richard Hodes, director of the US National Institute of Ageing, said: "With the ageing of the baby boomers, the urgency to understand the disease increases every day."

It was known that a form of one gene on chromosome 19 made people more susceptible to the disease. But only 50% of sufferers have that gene, so other factors are at work.

Pinning down a new chromosomal hotspot will spark a race to find and patent the gene or genes involved.

If a commercial firm were to get the patent it would be able to command princely licence fees from anyone else seeking to develop gene-based tests or treatments.

The researchers were from the University of Wales college of medicine, the Institute of Psychiatry in London, a number of US institutions and the Institute of Biomedicine in Valencia, Spain.

fields.headline: Kidnap Britons describe jungle ordeal
fields.trailText: Two kidnapped Britons yesterday relived the "rollercoaster of emotion" they had experienced during nine months in the Colombian rain forest, as they arrived home in time for Christmas.
fields.body:
Two kidnapped Britons yesterday relived the "rollercoaster of emotion" they had experienced during nine months in the Colombian rain forest, as they arrived home in time for Christmas.

Paul Winder, 29, a merchant banker, and Tom Hart Dyke, 24, a horticulturist, vanished in March while hunting for rare orchids in the Darien Gap, one of Colombia's most dangerous regions. For many months their parents assumed they had been shot by bandits or fallen prey to the natural dangers of the area.

But the two men had been abducted by guerrillas, who on December 10 suddenly released them.

After getting hopelessly lost in the dense jungle, they were forced to return to the guerrillas six days later to ask for a map, before finally stumbling across an astounded park ranger on December 19. After a night's rest at the British embassy in Bogota, and a medical checkup and debriefing with the Colombian authorities, they were put on to a British Airways flight home

The pair seemed elated but dazed as they were greeted by relatives at Gatwick yesterday afternoon. "Forty-eight hours ago we were in the jungle and then we were whisked from motorboat to plane to house and suddenly here we are back on British soil. Amazing," said Mr Winder.

Weals were visible on the feet of Mr Hart Dyke, who was wearing flip flops, but like his companion he seemed otherwise unscathed. He said they had shared extraordinary camaraderie with the guerrillas - even stopping for a drink and a cigarette when they returned to ask for the map - but had been terrified when first captured.

He recalled: "Initially they used their guns to get us on to the ground, they tied us up for half an hour and said 'Are you going to run?' After that it never happened again."

Their captors treated them well, built them a bed and gave Mr Winder antibiotics for a foot infection. They showed Mr Hart Dyke the rare orchids he had been looking for and he joked that he had even put on weight thanks to their diet of beef and bananas.

But inevitably the Britons struggled to cope with the harsh terrain as the rebels kept them moving to avoid discovery.

"We're not used to living in that environment. They [the guerrillas] are very strong people and we couldn't always keep up with them, but we always did our best. It was a team effort," said Mr Winder.

"We tried to live off each other. There were low times, high times, terrifying times and fantastic times.

"It was a huge roller-coaster of emotion." He added: "We always had confidence that we would get back to England and see our families."

The two Englishmen met in Puerto Rico. Mr Winder had travelled extensively in Africa and south-east Asia, and Mr Hart Dyke had spent the past two years travelling the world in search of rare orchids. But the Darien Gap is pristine tropical rainforest, with no marked paths or bridges, and its natural predators include alligators, panthers and venomous snakes.

Bandits, drugs and arms-smugglers are rife and the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia are active in the area. Farc is responsible for most abductions in Colombia, which number 3,000 this year.

However the guerrillas in question did not identify themselves to their captives or explained the purpose of the kidnapping, and although at one point they did tell Mr Winder that they would demand a ransom of $5m (about £3.3m) for each man, they never did.

During the months that the pair's fate remained unknown, Mr Winder's father, Brian, and Mr Hart Dyke's mother, Sarah, flew out to search for their sons. Yesterday, Mr Hart Dyke's father, Guy, told reporters: "This is the best Christmas present I have ever had" - before driving the family home to Lullingstone castle, in Kent. Mr Winder's mother, Anne, said the family was looking forward to a champagne celebration at their home in Chelmsford.

Hear Martin Hodgson report on the kidnapping at: www.guardianunlimited.co.uk/audio

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText:
Police cleared on drug charges
Pothole survey
Rail lock-in
Email warning
Body armour
Pig ban lifted
fields.body:
Police cleared on drug charges

Two former Flying Squad detectives were yesterday cleared at the Old Bailey of a plot to steal and supply ecstasy tablets worth £500,000. The tablets had been impounded following a police raid, but disappeared. A jailed former detective accused Detective Sergeant Leonard Guerard, 52, Detective Constable Christopher Carter, 47, and DC David Evans, 51, all based at Heathrow. Evans was cleared on Tuesday.

Pothole survey

The government is to count the holes in roads around England. Utility and cable companies will meet ministers in the new year to coordinate and "rationalise" repairs.

Rail lock-in

Twenty concert-goers had to be rescued from Rochdale railway station, in Greater Manchester, by fire crews early yesterday after staff locked up without checking all the trains had arrived.

Email warning

Five workers at the London law firm Norton Rose have been disciplined but have kept their jobs, after about 10m people read an intimate message sent to one of them by a woman.

Body armour

Council workers in Walsall, West Midlands, are to be issued with body armour following a series of violent attacks, including battery acid thrown at a man investigating a noisy party.

Pig ban lifted

A ban on East Anglian pig breeders exporting to other European Union countries has been lifted, it was announced yesterday. More than 40,000 pigs have been slaughtered following an outbreak of swine fever.

webTitle: Milburn to press on with NHS plan

fields.headline: Milburn to press on with NHS plan
fields.trailText: The government yesterday signalled its determination to press ahead with a shake-up of the NHS and social services in the face of criticism from sections of the medical profession and community health councils.
fields.body:
The government yesterday signalled its determination to press ahead with a shake-up of the NHS and social services in the face of criticism from sections of the medical profession and community health councils.

The health secretary, Alan Milburn, published the health and social care bill to implement parts of the NHS plan, which he and Tony Blair unveiled last summer.

The bill proposes granting nurses and pharmacists a wider medical role (notably in prescribing drugs) and tackling hospital "bed blocking" by improving ties with social services departments. Controversially, Mr Milburn also wants to see local community health councils replaced with patients' forums inside every NHS trust.

The bill proposes to empower health authorities to suspend sex abusers in the health service without going through the current protracted procedures. This follows an announcement of an inquiry into the case of a GP who abused patients over eight years.

Locum services will also be more tightly regulated, further examples of what Alan Enthoven, the professor who created the Tories' NHS "internal market" policy, calls a doomed attempt to modernise "a public sector monopoly".

The reforms will be hard fought up to the election. Contrary to some reports ministers have not drawn back from their controversial proposal to prevent hospital doctors from taking on part time private practice until seven years after they qualify. The rule change can be made within the existing legislative framework.

The device is intended to protect the NHS's investment in training doctors at public expense.

The bill represents Labour's foray into the partnership with the private sector in its provision for private funds to be used to help rebuild inner city GP's surgeries.

There are fears that ministers might withdraw from proposals to create primary care trusts. The trusts would allow health authorities to create partnerships with social services departments to improve the situation of elderly people who "block" hospital beds when they need only personal care.

The bill will implement Mr Milburn's controversial plan to give elderly people in homes free nursing care, worth up to £5,000 a year, while making them pay for personal care.

Mr Milburn's bill also provides cash incentives for the more innovative hospital trusts.

In a paper for the Adam Smith think tank Prof Enthoven called this idea "childish, almost embarrassing".

webTitle: Britons under arrest in Saudi Arabia

fields.headline: Britons under arrest in Saudi Arabia
fields.trailText: Three Britons are under arrest in Saudi Arabia on suspicion of producing or smuggling alcohol, the British embassy in Riyadh said last night.
fields.body:
Three Britons are under arrest in Saudi Arabia on suspicion of producing or smuggling alcohol, the British embassy in Riyadh said last night.

The arrests follow bomb attacks against British citizens living in Saudi Arabia.

The Britons, who have not been named, were arrested more than a week ago. A Belgian and a Lebanese are also believed to have been detained.

Alcohol is illegal in the kingdom. The penalties for importing, manufacturing or possessing it include jail sentences or public flogging.

Unofficial sources said that during the bomb investigations the Saudi authorities uncovered what they suspected was an illicit alcohol ring.

Christopher Rodway, 47, an engineer from Gloucestershire who worked at a military hospital in Riyadh, died when a bomb exploded in his car on November 17, also injuring his wife. Six days later, three Britons and an Irish woman were injured by a similar car bomb in the capital.

Last Friday, David Brown, 32, a Briton working for Coca Cola International, lost an eye and suffered injuries to his hand when a juice carton placed near the windscreen of his car exploded in the eastern town of al-Khobar.

No group has claimed responsibility for the attacks, and Saudi officials have suggested the first two attacks might have been carried out for personal rather than political motives.

A Saudi newspaper said last week they could be linked to "illegal activity such as distribution of liquor".

Yesterday, the Saudi-owned al-Hayat newspaper reported that a Belgian and a Lebanese had been arrested within the "framework" of the bomb investigation on suspicion of involvement in smuggling and selling "forbidden things" - a term which includes alcohol.

Sa'ad Fagih, of the opposition Movement for Islamic Reform in Arabia, told the Guardian he had received information that 50 people had been arrested: up to 10 Europeans and about 40 Saudis.

Dr Fagih said he believed the attacks had been carried out by jihad groups and that the Saudi authorities, reluctant to admit any threat to the kingdom's stability, were using the alcohol investigation "to divert attention from the real cause".

fields.headline: 20 minutes to 'save the dome'
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Millennium Dome
fields.trailText: David James was given just 20 minutes to save the Millennium Dome from closure in September by agreeing to take control, he has revealed.
fields.body:
David James was given just 20 minutes to save the Millennium Dome from closure in September by agreeing to take control, he has revealed.

The dome was facing bankruptcy when Mr James was negotiating with the operators, the New Millennium Experience Company. Experts had warned that the gates would simply have to shut that night if the millennium commission did not promise more cash by the time the board met at 2.30pm.

At 2.10pm the commission said yes, they were prepared to put up the £47m - but only if Mr James, accepted the job of NMEC chairman, he reveals in a BBC2 documentary Death of the Dome to be screened tonight at 9pm.

"I had 20 minutes to digest that and get to the board of NMEC, which was waiting in a different place," said Mr James.

webTitle: Armed forces fall foul of work decibel limits

fields.headline: Battle noise falls foul of work decibel limits
fields.trailText: A team of scientists, academics and musicians is considering whether military bands play too loudly and whether officers giving orders to soldiers under fire should quieten down.
fields.body:
A team of scientists, academics and musicians is considering whether military bands play too loudly and whether officers giving orders to soldiers under fire should quieten down.

The study follows a report by Ministry of Defence officials, who identified two areas where the armed forces are failing to comply with noise at work regulations, part of the raft of health and safety laws that General Sir Charles Guthrie, chief of the defence staff, warned this week could threaten combat effectiveness.

The two areas are "operational training situations where it is essential for soldiers to hear orders or the sound made by any potential enemy", and "military bands, especially the percussion and brass sections".

Noise has affected the hearing of soldiers who have been through real battles where decibel levels were higher than recommended by the health and safety executive. Damaged hearing did not help military effectiveness, it said yesterday.

The regulations say people should not generally be exposed to more than 90 decibels, with a "peak active level" of no more than 140.

"Industrial deafness isn't a joke," said John Spellar, the armed forces minister. However, "if there are common sense solutions we will take them up".

There is little prospect of sergeant-majors whispering orders, soldiers wearing ear defenders, or military bands muffling their trumpets and drums.

If there was, there would be an outcry, not least from Sir Charles. "There is a culture of risk aversion developing in society which is anathema to servicemen," he said this week.

"We are not foolhardy, but our profession requires a degree of decisiveness, flair and courage which sits badly with some of the more restrictive practices of employment legislation."

webTitle: Minister hits at landfill tax relief 'scam'

fields.headline: Minister hits at landfill tax relief 'scam'
fields.trailText: A government minister said yesterday that the £100m landfill tax credit scheme should be changed because it could be seen as a public expenditure scam.
fields.body:
A government minister said yesterday that the £100m landfill tax credit scheme, which gives waste operators tax relief to donate to environmental projects, should be changed because it could be seen as a public expenditure scam.

Waste operators have to pay £12 a tonne tax on rubbish dumped on tips, but they can get a rebate of up to 20% if they donate the money to environmental groups approved by a private regulator, Entrust.

Michael Meacher, the environment minister, told the Commons environment committee: "There is a basic conflict of interest between waste companies and environmentalists under the scheme, since landfill operators will be putting themselves out of business by donating money to recycling groups."

He told MPs the scheme did not favour the development of recycling or a huge cut in landfill dumping, and agreed with Crispin Blunt, Conservative MP for Reigate and Banstead, that it was a "public expenditure scam" as it was a way of raising cash for the environment without saying it was public money.

Mr Meacher said guidelines to direct more money towards recycling under the scheme were being introduced and ministers were examining turning it into public expenditure programme. The scheme was investigated by the Guardian and Channel 4 Dispatches programme earlier this year following criticism from environmentalists.

fields.headline: Head's return is thwarted
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Marjorie Evans, the head teacher cleared of slapping a 10-year-old pupil, was last night warned by school governors that she would be suspended if she returned to work today.
fields.body:
Marjorie Evans, the head teacher cleared of slapping a 10-year-old pupil, was last night warned by school governors that she would be suspended if she returned to work today.

The National Union of Teachers had earlier said that Mrs Evans, 56, would be back at St Mary's Junior School in Caldicot, Monmouthshire, for the last day of term after a 15-month absence. But then it was revealed last night that Mrs Evans had decided not to return after receiving a letter from the chair of the school governors "instructing" her not to go back.

An NUT spokswoman said it would immediately begin legal proceedings to prevent the governors from going ahead with a suspension following their further "irrational" behaviour in their treatment of Mrs Evans.

She was suspended in September last year for allegedly slapping a pupil and was found guilty of assault, but was cleared on appeal this September.

Police continued to investigate claims against her, but in October the crown prosecution service said it would not take any further action. However, the dossier of allegations was handed to the local education authority and school governors, who decided Mrs Evans should face a disciplinary hearing.

Doug McAvoy, the general secretary of the National Union of Teachers, said earlier that it was "in the best interests of the school, its community and Marjorie Evans herself" that she return.

"The governing body has failed to identify its complaints and insists that it is under no obligation to do so until seven days before a disciplinary hearing. The union regards that refusal as wholly unreasonable."

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Gore won vote by half a million | UN warns of African famine | 5 charged over embassy blasts
fields.body:
Gore won vote by half a million

Revised figures for the US election give Al Gore a majority of more than half a million votes over George W Bush, the president-elect. Mr Gore took 50,996,064 votes (48.4%) against Mr Bush's 50,456,167 (47.9%).

Mr Gore's majority exceeds the popular vote majorities won by John Kennedy and Richard Nixon when they won the presidency in 1960 and 1968 respectively.
Martin Kettle, Washington

UN warns of African famine

About 28m people in sub-Saharan Africa face severe food shortages because of prolonged drought and civil strife, the UN Food and Agriculture Organisation warned yesterday. Most at risk are Eritrea, Ethiopia and Kenya, which will need food aid next year to avoid starvation.
AP, Rome

5 charged over embassy blasts

US prosecutors have indicted five more suspects - taking the total to 20 - over the bombings of US embassies in Kenya and Tanzania. The twin blasts on August 7, 1998 killed more than 220 people and injured thousands.
Reuters, Nairobi

webTitle: Rape victim's son brings France to book

fields.headline: Rape victim's son brings France to book
fields.trailText: He was born in April 1960 in the Algerian internment camp of Theniet el-Had, the son of a 16-year-old local girl and an unknown French officer, one of 30 or 40 who raped her, repeatedly and brutally, during a period of months.
fields.body:
He was born in April 1960 in the Algerian internment camp of Theniet el-Had, the son of a 16-year-old local girl and an unknown French officer, one of 30 or 40 who raped her, repeatedly and brutally, during a period of months.

It took him 12 years and three court actions in Algeria to establish those facts. Yesterday, after another two years of legal wrangling in France, a French court agreed to look further into Mohammed Garne's claim that the simple fact of his birth made him a "victim of war".

Mr Garne's case, the first of its kind in French legal history, comes as a divided France embarks on a renewed and bitter bout of soul-searching for the conduct of its soldiers during Algeria's savage 1954-1962 war of independence - in particular their use of torture.

A military pensions tribunal in March threw out his claim for compensation on the grounds that, although he was "born of a rape perpetrated on his mother by French officers", he was not "the direct victim of this act of violence", and it could not be proved that his subsequent psychological problems were uniquely due to it.

The Paris appeal court verdict represented a victory of sorts. The court said it would give an expert six months to investigate and report back to it on all aspects of Mr Garne's claim. "Of course I'm pleased," he said. "It is a step towards achieving the one thing I want: recognition of the crime of which I have been a victim."

Mr Garne, a caretaker in a Paris department store, said he did not want to find his father, nor to seek his punishment. "Recognition is all I seek," he said. "There are many of us in Algeria, children born of French army rapes. It is necessary that this is said and recognised in France. Otherwise it will be forever a stain on its history."

Whether France should officially recognise the atrocities committed by its troops in Algeria has become the subject of a heated and at times venomous debate this year, launched in the summer when Le Monde published a shocking interview with an Algerian woman, Louisette Ighilahriz.

In horrific detail, Ms Inghilahriz described how as a young pro-independence fighter in the late 1950s she was tortured three times a day for more than three months, left handcuffed to a steel bed, and lying in her own excrement between sessions.

Such allegations were not, of course, new. During the conflict, demonstrators protested at length about the use of la gégène, a torture technique involving electrodes clamped to the genitals, ears and tongue.

For years since, rumours have circulated and old soldiers have hinted that the bloody savagery of the pro-independence guerrillas - the slit throats, bayonetted stomachs and sliced ears - was more than matched by the barbarity of French troops. The army, while refusing to comment on specific allegations, always insisted that whatever happened was militarily justified since it saved lives.

After Ms Inghilahriz's account of her torture, however, a senior army figure, General Jacques Massu, 92, admitted for the first time to Le Monde that torture was "institutional" in the French army at the time, and that it served no military purpose.

"Morally, torture is dismal," he said. "I think it would be a positive thing to recognise and condemn what happened."

Gen Massu added that the blame should be placed not on the army, but on politicians who gave the order to break up rebel cells at any cost.

Newspapers rapidly began to fill with letters from two camps: embittered former officers fearful that their records would be sullied, and some of the estimated 2m conscripts who served in Algeria, witnessed or took part in atrocities, and felt shame for having stayed silent.

Another retired general, Paul Aussaresses, said he personally had killed 24 suspected guerrilla chiefs during the 1957 battle of Algiers, and that some 3,000 other suspects had been killed, their bodies "made to disappear".

He had, he confessed, "used methods that are not approved by the laws of warfare".

When Amnesty International called on France to put both generals on trial, the prime minister, Lionel Jospin, intervened. He said the issue was "not one for which France can accuse itself and blame itself globally".

Mr Garne's story, however, has finally been told.

When the French troops who were holding his mother discovered she was pregnant, she was savagely beaten in an attempt to make her lose the child. He was born with physical and mental infirmities, was immediately given up to an orphanage and later to a foster family, who also abused him.

"It seems to me I have always been unbalanced, somehow," he said. "In any event, I have never been happy. But what tortured me more than anything was not knowing who my father was. There was my biological mother's name on my birth certificate, but for the name of my father there was just a big black line."

In 1988, he finally traced his mother to the decrepit shack she was living in, between the tombs in a cemetery in central Algiers. She carried an axe, and neighbours viewed her as a madwoman.

There was an emotional reunion, but Mr Garne had to take her to court before she would finally reveal the circumstances of his conception.

"It's like I'm up against an iceberg that won't melt," he said. "My friends say to me: stop it, forget it all. Stop? Forget? Never. I can't. I want to be recognised."

webTitle: French school in a row over kissing

fields.headline: School in a pet over kisses
fields.trailText: A secondary school in Alsace has just given a one-day suspension to Céline and Sébastien, 17, for holding hands and kissing in the back of a bus on a school outing.
fields.body:
Le baiser, as the likes of Rodin and photographer Robert Doisneau would have readily told you - and as the briefest of strolls round Paris will confirm - is French. And France, in general, celebrates the kiss.

Shame, then, on Ribeauvillé secondary school in Alsace, which has just given a one-day suspension to Céline and Sébastien, 17, for holding hands and kissing in the back of a bus on a school outing.

"It is profoundly shocking," Sébastien's father, a former teacher, wrote in an outraged letter to the education minister, Jack Lang, "that such sanctions can be envisaged at a time when schools guarantee access to the morning-after pill."

Is it, he wondered out loud in phone calls to journalists on most of the nation's dailies, the kiss of these two love-struck teenagers that French society should find troubling - or the extraordinary response to it of certain perverted adults?

At the headmaster's office, they were polite but firm. "We get teased a lot in schools, you know, but one has to set certain limits," they said. "We took the action we had to take. Both these pupils had been warned, long and loud. They were clearly undermining our authority."

Céline and Sébastien, they said, had first been spotted in a tender embrace near the canteen back in September. A few weeks later, a senior teacher - and what exactly was he doing there? - said he spied them holding hands most heinously on a path near the lycée.

"You like a good party, minister," the father wrote to Mr Lang. "Why don't you organise, please, a national kissing day in all our secondary schools. It would be a huge success: hundreds of thousands of pupils are rehearsing for it already."

webTitle: Mitterrand son a suspect in illicit African arms deals

fields.headline: Mitterrand son a suspect in illicit African arms deals
fields.trailText: Jean-Christophe, the elder son and close adviser of the late French president, François Mitterrand, was arrested yesterday and detained for questioning on suspicion of involvement in alleged illegal arms sales to Angola.
fields.body:
Jean-Christophe, the elder son and close adviser of the late French president, François Mitterrand, was arrested yesterday and detained for questioning on suspicion of involvement in alleged illegal arms sales to Angola.

Mr Mitterrand, who was his father's African strategy analyst from 1986 to 1992, was being held in the headquarters of the Paris financial crime squad with a noted writer, Paul-Loup Sulitzer, judicial sources said.

The two men were arrested after police seized computer discs that linked them to Pierre Falcone, a businessman currently under investigation for tax fraud involving tens of millions of dollars of allegedly unauthorised arms sales to Angola in 1993.

The scandal has also dragged in Jacques Attali, another former Mitterrand adviser and head of the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, who was recently questioned by police, and a former interior minister, Charles Pasqua, whose offices were searched.

Mr Mitterrand, now a businessman and consultant, and Mr Sulitzer have admitted receiving large sums of cash from Mr Falcone's company, Brenco International, but have denied the money was ever linked to any fraudulent dealings. A former director of the state arms export company Sofremi, Bernard Poussier, is also under investigation.

All are suspected of playing a role in Brenco's sale, in the early 1990s, of well over $500m (£315m at the time) of arms, helicopters and MiG jet fighters to the Angolan government, then fighting a vicious war with Unita rebels. Police believe several other arms sales, particularly to the Congo, may have taken place. Under French law, such a private sale has to be approved by parliament.

François Mitterrand served two presidential terms from 1981 until 1995, before dying of cancer in 1996. Jean-Christophe, 54, started as an Africa correspondent for the French news agency AFP, but moved to the Elysée palace in 1982 and headed its secretive and controversial "Africa cell" from 1986 to 1992.

Dubbed by his opponents "Papa-m'a-dit" (Daddy told me), he was criticised for mixing business and politics, travelling frequently to Africa and maintaining privileged relations with African heads of state such as Omar Bongo, the president of Gabon, where he was at one stage involved with a large mining company.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Shipbuilder Vosper Thornycroft is to make 650 staff redundant because of the way the government has awarded a contract to build new warships.
fields.body:
Vosper to cut 650 staff

Shipbuilder Vosper Thornycroft is to make 650 staff redundant because of the way the government has awarded a contract to build new warships.

The company said it was making the announcement because of delays for the design and construction of a Type 45 destroyer for the Royal Navy. The Ministry of Defence on Wednesday placed a "prime contract" with BAE Systems to supervise construction.

"This contract has been awarded without there being in place any associated agreements with the shipyards," said Vosper. "It will be September 2001 at the earliest before the prime contractor places shipbuilding sub-contracts." The job cuts will take place at the Woolston yard in Southampton.

Darlows estate agency fails

About 280 jobs are in the balance after west country estate agency chain Darlows went into receivership. KPMG Corporate Recovery is seeking buyers for 39 offices, which were yesterday closed after the residential and commercial agency collapsed.

A further 45 offices have already been sold to the Spicerhaart Group, which will deal with customer queries from the other offices for the time being.

Richard Hill, of KPMG, said: "We are seeking buyers for the remaining branches."

Fairview sold in £307m deal

Builder Fairview Holdings was yesterday bought out with an agreed £307m offer from a group backed by private equity firm 3i.

The vehicle, General London Constructors, is offering 180p per share. Fairview had turned down a 170p per share offer from the same buyer in November. The shares closed last night up 8.5p at 179.5p.

The price is at a 41% premium over Fairview's share price of 125p on April 26, the day before it announced it had been approached for a possible offer. The deal comes within a week of two other builders, Beazer and Bryant agreeing to merge.

Ofgem sets Grid targets

The energy regulator, Ofgem, yesterday set the National Grid, the monopoly power transmission company, "fair but tough" targets for operating the system under the new wholesale electricity trading arrangements (Neta) due to take effect next spring.

National Grid had proposed a target of £542m as the cost of operating the so far much-troubled new system but Ofgem has scaled this back by 13% or £71m to £471m. Neta, originally due last month, is now set to go live on March 22 and is supposed to deliver cuts in power bills of around 10%.

Byers helps Cammell bid

The chances of a cruise ship being built in Britain for the first time in more than 20 years were given a boost yesterday when the government announced an offer of a loan guarantee to help win a £344m contract.

Trade and Industry Secretary Stephen Byers made the offer of assistance in support of a bid by the Cammell Laird yard on Merseyside to build two new vessels for US firm Luxus.

Fairview sold in £307m deal Builder Fairview Holdings was yesterday bought out with an agreed £307m offer from a group backed by private equity firm 3i. The vehicle, General London Constructors, is offering 180p per share. Fairview had turned down a 170p per share offer from the same buyer in November. The shares closed last night up 8.5p at 179.5p. The price is at a 41% premium over Fairview's share price of 125p on April 26, the day before it announced it had been approached for a possible offer. The deal comes within a week of two other builders, Beazer and Bryant agreeing to merge. Ofgem sets Grid targets The energy regulator, Ofgem, yesterday set the National Grid, the monopoly power transmission company, "fair but tough" targets for operating the system under the new wholesale electricity trading arrangements (Neta) due to take effect next spring. National Grid had proposed a target of £542m as the cost of operating the so far much-troubled new system but Ofgem has scaled this back by 13% or £71m to £471m. Neta, originally due last month, is now set to go live on March 22 and is supposed to deliver cuts in power bills of around 10%. Byers helps Cammell bid The chances of a cruise ship being built in Britain for the first time in more than 20 years were given a boost yesterday when the government announced an offer of a loan guarantee to help win a £344m contract. Trade and Industry Secretary Stephen Byers made the offer of assistance in support of a bid by the Cammell Laird yard on Merseyside to build two new vessels for US firm Luxus.

webTitle: It's been a record year, LSE declares

fields.headline: It's been a record year, LSE declares
fields.trailText: The London Stock Exchange rounded off a turbulent year yesterday by declaring 2000 a record for international and domestic shares trading.
fields.body:
The London Stock Exchange rounded off a turbulent year yesterday by declaring 2000 a record for international and domestic shares trading.

Domestic business was up by a third while international business increased by 40%, the LSE said, claiming the results confirmed its status as number one in Europe.

"London has enjoyed extremely buoyant levels of trading and new issues in 2000.

"The continued growth of our international and domestic business, coming on top of last year's outstanding results, provides a positive reminder of the exchange's strong competitive position, both in the UK and internationally," said Martin Wheatley, LSE director of business development.

However, Angela Knight, the chief executive of APCIMS, which represents private client stockbrokers and fund managers, commented: "Whether you are a corner shop, a supermarket, a steel producer or an exchange, the fact that you have a good year is excellent, but what you need to do is ensure the years ahead encompass the changes and developments that your markets require."

The total value of UK equities rose to £1,900bn while the number of bargains reached a record 29m.

International equity trading soared to £3.4bn, with the number of trades at 11m. The number of companies listed on the exchange has increased by 6% to almost 3,000.

Markets have been tricky, too, with the FTSE 100 share index starting the year at close to 7,000 points but then tumbling to a low of less than 6000 in April.

Yesterday the London market was still in sombre mood, still suffering the effects of the earlier shake-out on Wall Street. The FTSE 100 share index was down 61.2 points at 6115.5.

Paradoxically, New York's markets were showing signs of a tentative recovery as bargain hunters moved into hard hit sectors. The Dow Jones industrial average was 133.5 points higher at 10452.41 by noon.
