webTitle: 400 inmates make last stand in Turkey

fields.headline: 400 inmates make last stand in Turkey
fields.standfirst: Government approves amnesty to cut overcrowding in jails as protests at all but one prison are crushed
fields.trailText: Government approves amnesty to cut overcrowding in jails as protests at all but one prison are crushed.
fields.body:
Soldiers pressed defiant inmates to end their standoff in the last Turkish prison holding out against authorities, after more than 150 left-wing inmates in another jail surrendered.

Prisoners across the country had embarked on a two-month hunger strike to protest at plans to move them from huge, packed prison wards to small cells.

After three days of raids on more than 20 prisons, 400 inmates remained barricaded in Istanbul's Umraniye prison. The standoff at Canakkale prison in western Turkey ended earlier yesterday, with the interior ministry saying that two more prisoners had been found dead, taking the official death toll in the raids to 19 inmates and two soldiers.

NTV television showed some of the Canakkale inmates jumping out of a hole soldiers had smashed in a prison wall and crawling towards the heavily armed security forces.

Earlier, soldiers shouted "Life is beautiful" and "If you are not thinking of yourselves, think of your parents waiting in front of the prison" through megaphones, the daily Milliyet reported.

Parliament yesterday approved an amnesty that will nearly halve the country's prison population of 72,000 and help end overcrowding. Parliament passed the amnesty bill for the second time after President Ahmet Necdet Sezer had previously vetoed it. Turkish presidents cannot veto a bill twice.

Officials have said it is vital for Turkey to reduce jail numbers as it struggles to regain control of prisons where inmates often live in wards that house up to 100 people.

Political groups frequently run wards like indoctrination centres and bar warders from entering. Poorly paid guards are bribed and threatened and telephones and weapons smuggled in.

Convicted murderers and thieves will benefit from the amnesty, but rapists, corrupt state officials, drug traffickers and those accused of crimes against the state, such as Kurdish guerrillas and leftwing and Islamic militants, will not.

Although hundreds have demonstrated in the streets in support of the prisoners, the police raids appear to have been popular. The prisoners are mostly from fringe groups that have little support and many Turks have been critical of the government for not reining in the prisoners earlier.

"It is ... a great shame that the state has allowed the current mess in the prisons to prevail for so long without taking effective steps," wrote Ilnur Cevik, editor-in-chief of the Turkish Daily News.

The newspaper Radikal quoted the interior minister, Sadettin Tantan, as saying that the government had chosen to take the "slow road" and use psychological warfare to end the siege.

At Umraniye prison shots were heard throughout the day, the independent Human Rights Association said. Security forces, throwing tear gas from holes drilled in the prison, were closing in on the prisoners who had barricaded themselves in, the news agency Anatolia said.

The protesters

 The Revolutionary People's Liberation Army-Front, DHKP-C, which organised uprising, aims to replace government in Ankara with revolutionary republic

 Up to 1,000 DHKP-C inmates said to be involved

 Its gunmen have targeted generals, police officers, government officials and US military missions

 Several senior members said by the Turkish press to live in Britain and Belgium

fields.headline: Ex Tomkins chief presses £2m claim
fields.trailText: Greg Hutchings, chief executive of industrial group Tomkins who was ousted two months ago amid allegations of corporate excess, has gone on the offensive to win a big pay-off.
fields.body:
Greg Hutchings, chief executive of industrial group Tomkins who was ousted two months ago amid allegations of corporate excess, has gone on the offensive to win a big pay-off.

He is claiming the independent report into the lavish perks he enjoyed at company expense - including four company planes, a helicopter and two central London apartments, one in Eaton Place, Belgravia - will exonerate him.

Mr Hutchings is demanding about £2m in compensation plus 3m shares and a lump sum pension payment. He has signed a confidentiality agreement while negotiations continue. A statement on his behalf yesterday said the investigation was complete and showed "all remuneration and benefits which he received were within his contractual arrangements and entitlements and had the necessary authorisations and approvals".

He enjoyed a jetset lifestyle at Tomkins's expense - including putting his wife and housekeeper on the company payroll - but Mr Hutchings says it was all approved by the former chairman Michael Moore in the mid-1980s. Mr Hutchings had not adjusted the package as views on corporate excess changed.

A source close to Mr Hutchings said: "He is not out to hit the jackpot here. He just wants the compensation he is entitled to, to restore his reputation and get on with his business career".

Mr Hutchings's move came as Tomkins chairman David Newlands - who forced Mr Hutchings to quit - sent a letter to shareholders saying the company had not yet reached a financial settlement with Mr Hutchings, who headed the company for 17 years. Mr Newlands is under pressure from shareholders to scale back any payment and yesterday he made it clear the excesses discovered "will be a factor in any discussions with Mr Hutchings". The letter added that the company's fleet of aircraft and the luxury apartments have now been put on the market and are likely to net more than £20m.

The company had made donations to the London Forum, run by Mr Hutchings's friend Lord Archer. Mr Newlands said full board approval would now be required for charitable and political donations.

webTitle: Notebook: Vodafone now has to till land

fields.headline: Time for Gent to look over his shoulder
fields.standfirst: Vodafone now has to till land
fields.trailText: Vodafone now has to till land.
fields.body:
Another day, another deal for Vodafone. Yesterday it was Ireland's turn for a taste of inward investment Voda-style, from a company which can claim to have created bigger cross border capital flows than perhaps any individual company before.

The target this time was Eircell, Ireland's leading mobile phone business, which has been snapped up from Eircom, the former state-owned telecoms group, for £2.8bn in Voda-shares. A day earlier Vodafone paid £1.6bn cash for 15% of Japan Telecom. And there is still one more market day to go before Christmas.

The 1m existing Irish subscribers (in a market reckoned to be Europe's third-fastest growing) who come with Eircom mean Vodafone has all but doubled its subscriber base in the past year to about 60m users around the world. What is more, the move opens up a new competitive front with British Telecom, which has a 51% stake in Ireland's only other mobile operator, Esat Digifone.

In the Far East, Vodafone's stake in Japan Telecom matches that of BT, and with other big tranches of stock in the Japanese mobile firm due to come loose, it is seen as only a matter of time before Vodafone wins control there. BT is paying a serious price for allowing its balance sheet to weaken at the worst possible time.

Of course, this acquisition binge by Britain's biggest company has nothing to do with the traditional demonised motivations behind so many takeovers - namely consolidating to cut costs and maximise cash flow. Vodafone and its ever-so-slick chief executive, Chris Gent, are being driven by a rampant commercial desire to grab new consumer markets before someone else does.

Having whet his whistle with the takeover of America's Airtouch, Mr Gent learned the real need for haste last year from Klaus Esser, erstwhile boss of Mannesmann, who was cheeky enough to buy its rival, Orange.

Vodafone turned round and bought Mannesmann, and Mr Gent has not looked back. He cannot have had time to.

Maybe his new year's resolution should be to make some. Corporate history is littered with examples of companies which bungled their competitive position by making too many acquisitions too quickly. Every deal, big or small, brings cumulative risks - a black hole in the accounts here, an integration problem there.

The land grab in the world of mobile telephony could not have been more exciting (or remunerative for the likes of Mr Gent), but the time has arrived to show that the acreage won can be effectively mined.

Face value

At first glance it looked like a classic piece of pork-barrel politics. On Wednesday, after months of acrimonious negotiations, the Department of Trade forged an outline deal with the main high street banks to provide funding for the planned universal bank, hopefully saving a good portion of the post office network in the process.

Yesterday, after months of silence, the Treasury responded to a main recommendation in the Cruickshank review of the banks - namely that a new regulator be established to ensure the fair operation of money payment systems - and decided that a beefed-up Office of Fair Trading was adequate for the job.

The banks, in response, issued a collective sigh of relief. They were concerned that a new regulator would be tempted to meddle in their affairs to justify its existence. They have escaped this threatening scenario and we must assume that the banking industry's cave-in over the universal bank was simply coincidental.

The flaw in all this is that the author of the banking review, Don Cruickshank, took time off yesterday from trying to find a new chief executive to help him run the London Stock Exchange (where he is chairman), to issue a statement congratulating the Treasury on seemingly ignoring his advice.

The media had been wrong to focus on his "paycom" suggestion, he said, ar guing that arming the director general of fair trading with the necessary powers to tackle competition problems in bank payment systems was just as good. "I'm afraid that the days of clear, simple, competition-based, consumer protection from sectoral regulation have gone," Mr Cruickshank added.

"This is not a rejection of the Cruickshank proposals. Giving the role to the OFT was an option considered in his report, and he thoroughly supports the decision to give this new role to the OFT," chimed the Treasury.

We should probably take this at face value - applaud it, even. The continuous replication of regulatory bodies to monitor each and every aspect of economic life is a curse of the times.

Adding clarity and firepower to an existing body, such as the OFT, is a more sensible way forward. Just so long as the clarity and firepower are actually provided.

fields.headline: Gérard Depardieu  was unwell
fields.standfirst: How the great French actor rode into hospital on a motorbike, had a multiple heart bypass, then went off to shoot three films
fields.trailText: How the great French actor rode into hospital on a motorbike, had a multiple heart bypass, then went off to shoot three films
fields.body:
Five months ago, Gérard Depardieu went into hospital for a check up. He had been feeling below par, a bit tired, and suspected something was wrong. He drove himself to the clinic on his motorbike, went in for some tests and only emerged after undergoing emergency open-heart surgery, which saved his life.

When we meet in a sedate little Chelsea hotel, Depardieu does not look in the least bit chastened by the experience. I was expecting a thinner, fitter, healthier post-operative Depardieu, but he is none of these. He is huge - not especially tall, perhaps 5ft 11ins, but his torso, which seems to be fixed to his head without the benefit of a neck, is the size of two men rolled into one.

Like a circus acrobat at the bottom of a human pyramid, his legs are spread wide to carry the load and his face - dominated by that extraordinary phallic nose - is carnation pink with the effort.

For most of us, dramatic medical intervention is life-changing. It's a chance to reflect; a brush with mortality, a warning; you give up the cigarettes, cut down on alcohol, promise yourself a saner, healthier lifestyle. But, at 51, Depardieu has had more brushes with mortality than most.

Two years ago he survived a high-speed motorbike accident when he was five times over the limit; in 1996 he escaped unhurt when a small plane he was in collided with a Boeing 727 on the ground at Madrid airport; and his violent childhood, spent among prostitutes and petty criminals, is the stuff of legend. What's so exciting about open heart surgery?

Today, Depardieu is grumpy. He is in Britain on a flying visit to publicise his television series, The Count of Monte Cristo. It's all very last minute and Depardieu clearly has not enjoyed his 45 minutes with another interviewer, who emerges looking shaken.

He snaps miserably at the French woman who has kindly volunteered to help me out as an interpreter when she is unable to translate something he has said - his subsequent apology reduces her to tears - and the BBC PR and hotel staff tiptoe around him.

Usually, when you interview celebrities in their hotel suite, the rooms are untouched, unlived in. Depardieu's room looks as though it has been ravished. The bed is dented and crumpled, a dressing gown is tossed across it; towelling mule slippers are scrunched up next to the bed and the door to the garden is flung wide open, letting in the winter chill.

"When you have heart disease you start to be tired of everything," he says. "It's like getting older. You become more white and after that grey. You have no feeling for anything." Not trusting my amateur interpreter, Depardieu speaks in a mixture of French and imperfect English, but his mood shifts quickly from irritated to charming.

"I thought maybe it's time to have a check up. I thought, deep down, I'm sure I have something, but I won't mention it to anybody. I will see." He finished the film he was doing and made a hospital appointment. "I arrived on my motorbike and I thought I would be leaving. But the doctor said, 'No, Gérard. No, I don't think so. I don't think you can go out." They did a test and showed me my heart on the screen and I could see what was wrong. I said, 'Yes! I can see! You want to do a real operation. Yes!' "

An hour later he called the director of his next film and explained he had to have a multiple bypass. They prepared him for theatre; he asked the medical team to put on some music (it was, he remembers, She, the theme tune from the film Notting Hill); he told his doctors he had the utmost confidence in them and went to sleep. And that was that. Four weeks later he was back at work and in the three months after his operation he made three movies - more than some leading actors do in a decade.

Which is part of the problem with Depardieu - his excessiveness in all things. He is fantastically hard working, in movie terms at least. John Updike once poetically complained "I think that I shall never view/ A French film without Depardieu." He does a minimum of three films a year, notching up more than 100 in total (plus television projects), and because of the sheer quantity (and dubious quality of some), you forget just how many brilliant performances he has pulled off.

Look at his filmography: there's Cyrano de Bergerac, Trop Belle Pour Toi, Jean de Florette, Police, Danton, The Return of Martin Guerre; Colonel Chabert, Tous Les Matins du Monde, Camille Claudel, 1900. It's an extraordinary achievement for someone who, by his own admission, has done some "grosse merde" in his time.

Depardieu is an actor who follows his instincts, both in his choice of work and his approach to a role. Yves Angelo, who directed him in Le Colonel Chabert, describes him thus: "An animal, but warm and generous; you can tame him. He has to like the person who takes him in hand. He acts purely on instinct, but if he likes you, he has this astonishing instinct for the part." If it is not instinctive, then he becomes "a very commonplace, even a bad actor".

But what on earth makes him do films like Bimboland (1998); Asterix and Obelix Take on Caesar (1999), and 102 Dalmatians? "I follow friends, I follow the energy, I still have the instinct to go." He tries to explain that he is not so much interested in the film itself, but in the people he works with. "Look, life is short - that motorbike accident, open heart surgery. La vie est fragile. Cigarettes, wine, love..." I think he's trying to say there are better things in life to worry about than movies, rather than making me an offer.

Depardieu's extraordinary acting talent grew out of an extraordinary early life that has been mythologised over the years, but the bare bones are these: he was born the third of six children of an illiterate father in Chteauroux, 160 miles south of Paris. His father was a sheet metal worker and a drunk. His mother once told him that she considered aborting him with a knitting needle.

At the age of 12, Depardieu ran away from home to live with two prostitutes called Michelle and Irène; he got involved in petty theft, the black market and brawling, and ended up briefly in prison. But after years of delinquency, at 16 he arrived in Paris, auditioned for the Thétre Nationale Populaire and, once he had overcome a stammer which severely damaged his self-esteem, became a star pupil, making his big break with Bertrand Blier's Les Valseuses (1974) in which he plays a feckless thug.

"Twenty years ago he was extremely dangerous," Blier says, recalling the young Depardieu. "We literally had to follow him at night to stop him getting into punch-ups. He would deliberately go into the most dangerous areas, looking for trouble. Even now when he arrives at the door, I think, Christ, where are the valuables?"

Depardieu has never quite translated his talent to Hollywood - there was Green Card (1990), which was successful, but not Depardieu at his best. He was on the brink of achieving mass popularity in the US with Cyrano de Bergerac (1990) - which he cites as the one film of which he is most proud and for which he was Oscar-nominated - when his fortunes took a dramatic dive.

Just before the Academy Awards ceremony, Time magazine ran a profile that mistakenly suggested that the actor might have "participated" in a rape at the age of nine. The claim was based on an interview carried out 13 years earlier and was the result of an incorrect translation - Depardieu, though the clear favourite, did not win the Oscar.

Today he is careful about translators and dismissive of Hollywood. "I don't care about Hollywood films. I'm not against Hollywood films, you know? Hollywood films were very good before, in the 1950s. Now you see the English film-makers are the best. Ridley Scott who did Gladiator... American Beauty, the Oscar winner, came from London."

And in any case he prefers working with Europeans - he loves Kenneth Branagh and Timothy Spall and Ridley Scott. "They don't have ego like you find in the American industry," he says. "Hollywood exists only for the B-movies. The best things are coming from Europe. We have all the talent here, and we need American money. Ha ha ha!" And he laughs a huge laugh, which starts deep in that barrelled chest then turns high and giggly. He says he is excited by the future of television and he wants to do more work for the BBC. "I'm knocking on the door of the BBC," he says, bashing the table, making the coffee pot jump. "Because we have to do interesting work together."

Today, Depardieu has two grown-up children by his long marriage to Elisabeth Guignot, from whom he is separated. There are also two children by other women and he has had a long relationship with the actress Carole Bouquet. Beyond acting, he has a strange and eclectic mix of business interests - a vineyard in the Loire, Cuban oil wells and telecoms and textiles businesses in Romania - and has made unlikely political appearances in Slovakia and Romania.

As Depardieu talks, I notice the top couple of buttons of his electric blue shirt are undone and in the crack behind the material I can see a thin white line streaking up towards his throat. It's the scar left after surgery. He catches me looking at it and I tell him it looks as though it has healed well. Yes, he says with pride, very well.

Then he undoes the rest of his shirt buttons down to his waist, and pushes out his enormous chest and stomach towards me. He wants me to admire it, so I do. That's amazing, I say. And it is. To be so close to Gérard Depardieu's nipples is amazing. "So they had to open up your chest," I say, feebly. "Yes," he says, and gestures with his giant hands to show how his ribs were parted to enable the surgeons to replumb his arteries. It's a huge scar. There must be a big heart beating under there.

I ask him if the operation has changed his attitude to work. "Non." Has it changed his attitude to life? "Non." What about lifestyle - the Gitanes, the booze, the excessive food?

"I don't smoke any more. That's very well. Because I don't like to smoke and now I have a good reason to stop smoking. I drink less - a little bit. I try to eat less. I try. But it is very hard. I promised myself to change, but I think I forgot the promise now." He laughs that uproarious laugh, then sobers up.

"Just before the operation, I was full of admiration - the surgery, the progress, the good fortune I had. I thought of my children, and all those people who love me, and I said - I promise to listen to them more. And now I'm listening, I'm listening."

fields.bodyText: Five months ago, Gérard Depardieu went into hospital for a check up. He had been feeling below par, a bit tired, and suspected something was wrong. He drove himself to the clinic on his motorbike, went in for some tests and only emerged after undergoing emergency open-heart surgery, which saved his life. When we meet in a sedate little Chelsea hotel, Depardieu does not look in the least bit chastened by the experience. I was expecting a thinner, fitter, healthier post-operative Depardieu, but he is none of these. He is huge - not especially tall, perhaps 5ft 11ins, but his torso, which seems to be fixed to his head without the benefit of a neck, is the size of two men rolled into one. Like a circus acrobat at the bottom of a human pyramid, his legs are spread wide to carry the load and his face - dominated by that extraordinary phallic nose - is carnation pink with the effort. For most of us, dramatic medical intervention is life-changing. It's a chance to reflect; a brush with mortality, a warning; you give up the cigarettes, cut down on alcohol, promise yourself a saner, healthier lifestyle. But, at 51, Depardieu has had more brushes with mortality than most. Two years ago he survived a high-speed motorbike accident when he was five times over the limit; in 1996 he escaped unhurt when a small plane he was in collided with a Boeing 727 on the ground at Madrid airport; and his violent childhood, spent among prostitutes and petty criminals, is the stuff of legend. What's so exciting about open heart surgery? Today, Depardieu is grumpy. He is in Britain on a flying visit to publicise his television series, The Count of Monte Cristo. It's all very last minute and Depardieu clearly has not enjoyed his 45 minutes with another interviewer, who emerges looking shaken. He snaps miserably at the French woman who has kindly volunteered to help me out as an interpreter when she is unable to translate something he has said - his subsequent apology reduces her to tears - and the BBC PR and hotel staff tiptoe around him. Usually, when you interview celebrities in their hotel suite, the rooms are untouched, unlived in. Depardieu's room looks as though it has been ravished. The bed is dented and crumpled, a dressing gown is tossed across it; towelling mule slippers are scrunched up next to the bed and the door to the garden is flung wide open, letting in the winter chill. "When you have heart disease you start to be tired of everything," he says. "It's like getting older. You become more white and after that grey. You have no feeling for anything." Not trusting my amateur interpreter, Depardieu speaks in a mixture of French and imperfect English, but his mood shifts quickly from irritated to charming. "I thought maybe it's time to have a check up. I thought, deep down, I'm sure I have something, but I won't mention it to anybody. I will see." He finished the film he was doing and made a hospital appointment. "I arrived on my motorbike and I thought I would be leaving. But the doctor said, 'No, Gérard. No, I don't think so. I don't think you can go out." They did a test and showed me my heart on the screen and I could see what was wrong. I said, 'Yes! I can see! You want to do a real operation. Yes!' " An hour later he called the director of his next film and explained he had to have a multiple bypass. They prepared him for theatre; he asked the medical team to put on some music (it was, he remembers, She, the theme tune from the film Notting Hill); he told his doctors he had the utmost confidence in them and went to sleep. And that was that. Four weeks later he was back at work and in the three months after his operation he made three movies - more than some leading actors do in a decade. Which is part of the problem with Depardieu - his excessiveness in all things. He is fantastically hard working, in movie terms at least. John Updike once poetically complained "I think that I shall never view/ A French film without Depardieu." He does a minimum of three films a year, notching up more than 100 in total (plus television projects), and because of the sheer quantity (and dubious quality of some), you forget just how many brilliant performances he has pulled off. Look at his filmography: there's Cyrano de Bergerac, Trop Belle Pour Toi, Jean de Florette, Police, Danton, The Return of Martin Guerre; Colonel Chabert, Tous Les Matins du Monde, Camille Claudel, 1900. It's an extraordinary achievement for someone who, by his own admission, has done some "grosse merde" in his time. Depardieu is an actor who follows his instincts, both in his choice of work and his approach to a role. Yves Angelo, who directed him in Le Colonel Chabert, describes him thus: "An animal, but warm and generous; you can tame him. He has to like the person who takes him in hand. He acts purely on instinct, but if he likes you, he has this astonishing instinct for the part." If it is not instinctive, then he becomes "a very commonplace, even a bad actor". But what on earth makes him do films like Bimboland (1998); Asterix and Obelix Take on Caesar (1999), and 102 Dalmatians? "I follow friends, I follow the energy, I still have the instinct to go." He tries to explain that he is not so much interested in the film itself, but in the people he works with. "Look, life is short - that motorbike accident, open heart surgery. La vie est fragile. Cigarettes, wine, love..." I think he's trying to say there are better things in life to worry about than movies, rather than making me an offer. Depardieu's extraordinary acting talent grew out of an extraordinary early life that has been mythologised over the years, but the bare bones are these: he was born the third of six children of an illiterate father in Chteauroux, 160 miles south of Paris. His father was a sheet metal worker and a drunk. His mother once told him that she considered aborting him with a knitting needle. At the age of 12, Depardieu ran away from home to live with two prostitutes called Michelle and Irène; he got involved in petty theft, the black market and brawling, and ended up briefly in prison. But after years of delinquency, at 16 he arrived in Paris, auditioned for the Thétre Nationale Populaire and, once he had overcome a stammer which severely damaged his self-esteem, became a star pupil, making his big break with Bertrand Blier's Les Valseuses (1974) in which he plays a feckless thug. "Twenty years ago he was extremely dangerous," Blier says, recalling the young Depardieu. "We literally had to follow him at night to stop him getting into punch-ups. He would deliberately go into the most dangerous areas, looking for trouble. Even now when he arrives at the door, I think, Christ, where are the valuables?" fields.headline: The best Christmas morning scene
fields.standfirst: The family man
fields.trailText: The family man
fields.body:
Christmas Eve. Following a visit from a mysterious stranger (Don Cheadle) warning him that "you brought this on yourself", the avowedly single, career-minded Jack Campbell (Nicolas Cage) falls asleep alone in his opulent Manhattan apartment. On Christmas morning, he wakes up to find an equally unfamiliar woman (Tea Leoni) asleep on top of him.

"Ten more minutes, Jack," she says drowsily. "It's Christmas."

Jack peers at her in utter disbelief. A small girl rushes into the room, carrying what appears to be her baby brother. Laughing, she breaks into song.

"Jingle Bells, Santa smells, Rudolf laid an egg..."

The woman groggily sits up in bed. Jack is still aghast as the little girl begins maniacally jumping up and down on the bed.

A dog runs in, barking loudly. The little girl stares at Jack.

"Don't you think we should open some presents?"

He stares back at her, his mouth open.

"Come on Dad, get up."

He staggers to his feet, clamping his hands against his ears. As he stumbles across the room, the woman grabs his arm.

"Jack...strong coffee... Now."

See also:
A Christmas Carol, Citizen Kane, Miracle On 34th Street, Gremlins

Don't see also:
Kramer vs Kramer

Pointless trivia:
Nicolas Cage owns a Lamborghini formerly owned by the last Shah of Iran.

fields.headline: Pokemon 2000: The Movie
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: So utterly without the usual attractions of script, characterisation and storyline that it's close to pure gibberish.
fields.body:
Here we are again. Another Pokémon film. Another one. Film two. They're back. We can wait until the cows come home for a Simpsons film. But the Pokémon franchise just trundles on. Like the first one, this film will astonish and insult you with its staggeringly poor animation. Not deliberately and mischievously crude like South Park - just... well just rubbish. Flat and bland like a Saturday morning cartoon on ITV. Like the first time, it is prefaced by a weirder-than-weird short feature noticeably without the main event's attempt at a conventionally developed narrative - perhaps to appeal to the younger siblings (three years old? four?) of its target audience (eight? nine? 10?).

This has the drearily pedantic title of Pikachu's Rescue Adventure and is a sort of pseudo-Alice tale of Ash's Pokémon pal Pikachu and his Pokémon buddies wandering away from their human keepers one sleepy summer's day, falling down a hole and having an adventure. Then there is the main film, The Power Of One, about Ash saving the entire world by foiling an attempt by an English-accented villain to capture the Pokémon birds Moltres, Zapdos and Articuno who represent the vital earthly forces of fire, lightning and ice.

I can't tell you how boring and bad the whole thing is. It takes place in a fictional world without oxygen or atmosphere and at times is so utterly without the usual attractions of script, characterisation and storyline that it's close to pure gibberish, like watching a kind of continuous kaleidoscope of random, meaningless colour, shape and sound. Only, unfortunately, it is always just cogent enough to be dull.

Apart from the first pocket-monster extravaganza, only one other thing can induce the same boredom and irritation: and that is the dire cod-mythological saga that takes place every day in the centre stage at the soon-to-be-put-out-of-its-misery Millennium Dome. The adventures of Skyboy and his attempts to put our dysfunctional cosmology to rights. Only that in its pointless grandiose silliness can hold a candle to Pikachu and the all the unlovely cartoon creatures. Surely nothing can be as rubbish as Pokémon this Christmas...

fields.headline: Merlin: The Return
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw Any parent caught taking their unfortunate child to see this film should be reported to the social services immediately.
fields.body:
....sorry, did I just say nothing could be as rubbish as Pokémon this Christmas? Compared to this, that is a work of genius. Merlin: The Return is the same sort of film as those we saw recently with the ropey Little Vampire or the frankly dire Tom's Midnight Garden.

Co-productions or UK productions which appear to be headed straight for the twilight netherworld of cable TV in the United States starring tousle-haired American kids in cutesy English country settings that only exist within the heads of raddled US movie executives, populated by British actors behind whose eyes you can see the flash of dismay and panic as they mouth the lines allotted to them and lumbering Americans who are not merely restricted to having English as a second language, but appear to have learned to move and behave in a homo sapiens-like manner the day before yesterday.

Rik Mayall is Merlin, defending "King Arthur Pendragon" (Patrick Bergin - managing, just, to keep his dignity) against the depredations of the wicked Mordred (Craig Sheffer) and his crazed mother who shouts things like: "Move your arse and pass that wine!" Or is that Arthur's mother? Either way, it isn't a line that appears in Malory. For some reason, Mordred has made telepathic contact fifteen hundred years into the future with Joan Maxwell, an evil scientist played by Tia Carrere, whose appalling researches will enable Mordred to advance his unspeakable plans.

Or something. Anyway, it in this modern-day era that American kid Ritchie Gould (Byron Taylor) living in England will do battle with Maxwell - and all the Arthurian knights are incongruously transported into modern Britain for the big showdown. The oddest thing is that people keep shouting: "Look! There's Maxwell!" And you expect Captain Bob himself to blunder into shot.

The most uproarious thing about this quite dreadful film is Lancelot, played by hunky, long-haired Adrian Paul, an alumnus of the Colbys and Dynasty. Adrian attempts an English accent that makes him sound like a stroke victim. Poor Rik Mayall does his best, but keeps flinching and sneering in a very Alan B'Stard-like way.

Any parent caught taking their unfortunate child to see this film should be reported to the social services immediately.

fields.headline: Not such a wonderful life
fields.standfirst: Never has Peter Bradshaw seen a film in which each plot twist is so clearly flagged in advance
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: Derivative, humourless and unbelievably icky sentimental comedy for Christmas. Never before has a Yuletide film's celebration of family been so self-centred.
fields.body:
This film has the distinction of getting the biggest laugh I have heard this year in any screening theatre or cinema. Nicolas Cage plays Jack Campbell, a horse-faced young would-be merchant banker about to take fateful leave of his girlfriend Kate (Téa Leoni) at the airport. Poor Kate tearfully thinks this might split them up forever - but Jack says it's only temporary and they can't pass up these career opportunities. "You've got a place at one of the best law schools in the country," he says earnestly, "and I've got this internship at Barclays bank."

Er, hello? Jack is supposed to be on his way to being a Manhattan Master of the Universe, not a Student Loans Officer at Keele. Did producer Marc Abraham, co-writers David Diamond and David Weissman or director Brett Ratner have some vague tourist memory of classy Berkeley Square in London, England, with its toney luxury car dealer Jack Barclay? Or, given that Jack forgets about poor Kate and becomes a heartless mammon-worshipper, is it an allusion to Barclays' sinister "big" commercials starring Tony Hopkins? Derogatory cockney rhyming slang maybe? Either way, it's a false note which is typical of this derivative, humourless and unbelievably icky sentimental comedy for Christmas.

Anyway. Flash forward 13 years and it turns out Kate's worst fears have been realised. Jack is a mega-wealthy swinging bachelor in New York, laying hot babes and nailing big deals all over the place. We join him just as he has bullied all his modern-day Cratchits into coming into the office for a meeting on December 25. On Christmas Eve, Jack drops into a Korean corner-store to encounter a young gun-wielding punk called Cash (Don Cheadle), who looks deep into Jack's eyes and tells him to expect a "glimpse" of how his life might have been. And next morning, he wakes up married to Kate, with two kids and a low-paying job in New Jersey. He panics, of course, at this suburban hell, tries to get back into his office and spiffy apartment and is repulsed by various baffled doormen. But then, he looks around at the comforts of home and family (his little girl is actually called Annie ) and... guess what?

It's an outrageous rip-off, or rather genetic modification, of a handful of films. It's a Wonderful Life has been mixed with a dash of Trading Places, a dollop of Regarding Henry - the movie where hotshot Harrison Ford learns to appreciate family life after being shot in the head in a convenience-store - and maybe a spoonful of Disney's The Kid. Never have I seen a film where the pitch meeting was so clear, and in which each plot modulation was so clearly flagged in advance.

That visionary punk-cum-angel, for example, the man who shows Jack his alternate life. What race does he absolutely have to be? Correct. And there are no other black people in this tale of American city and the provinces, except the doorman. When we see Cash again, he is actually working in a convenience store, sadly testing the honesty of customers by giving them change for a $10 bill, when only $1 has been tendered. Is that his "glimpse"?

Then there's Kate. She's still supposed to be a lawyer, of course, while Jack has stayed in Smallsville to help her father in his tyre shop after he had a heart attack. There's many a reference to her low-paying "pro bono" work - and Cage's face is never more equine than when he reverently repeats this Latinism - but we never get to see her working in any breadwinning capacity. To all intents and purposes she is the Stepford Wife, but a thousand times more creepy and dull than the robots because she is supposed to be the perfect mom, living for nothing more than the inexcusably cute things Jack does every year to celebrate their anniversary. After an adorable scene where they smear chocolate cake over each other's faces (an unwatchable sequence in itself), sweet Kate smoochingly whispers to Jack to say what she loves to hear. This presumably was "I Lurve You" but, baffled, Jack tries: "Ooh baby you are such a bad girl, you make me so hot." She runs away upset - Doris Day creature that she is.

It isn't a matter of political correctness so much as the sheer predictability. There was only one moment where the obvious plot development failed to materialise. Jack is always furtively trying to find stuff out about himself by poring over photos and videos - I expected him to find pictures of a mysterious third child who had tragically died of something. And the resulting heartache would bring Jack and Kate together as never before. It didn't happen, but I'm prepared to bet it was there in an earlier draft.

Never before has a Yuletide film's celebration of family been so self-centred. It's a Wonderful Life was about the difference one man had made to an entire community - through sacrifice. Here, Jack yearns for happiness and redemption within his tight little family unit. When he wakes up back in his old life, consumed with a Scrooge-like zeal for amendment, he seeks out Kate, herself naturally coarsened by non-non-profit legal work.

And the movie concludes by appearing to suggest that they can have the lovely family life and yet keep pulling down the big Manhattan bucks at the same time. An appropriate dénouement for this smug movie.

And there are no other black people in this tale of American city and the provinces, except the doorman. When we see Cash again, he is actually working in a convenience store, sadly testing the honesty of customers by giving them change for a $10 bill, when only $1 has been tendered. Is that his "glimpse"? Then there's Kate. She's still supposed to be a lawyer, of course, while Jack has stayed in Smallsville to help her father in his tyre shop after he had a heart attack. There's many a reference to her low-paying "pro bono" work - and Cage's face is never more equine than when he reverently repeats this Latinism - but we never get to see her working in any breadwinning capacity. To all intents and purposes she is the Stepford Wife, but a thousand times more creepy and dull than the robots because she is supposed to be the perfect mom, living for nothing more than the inexcusably cute things Jack does every year to celebrate their anniversary. After an adorable scene where they smear chocolate cake over each other's faces (an unwatchable sequence in itself), sweet Kate smoochingly whispers to Jack to say what she loves to hear. This presumably was "I Lurve You" but, baffled, Jack tries: "Ooh baby you are such a bad girl, you make me so hot." She runs away upset - Doris Day creature that she is. It isn't a matter of political correctness so much as the sheer predictability. There was only one moment where the obvious plot development failed to materialise. Jack is always furtively trying to find stuff out about himself by poring over photos and videos - I expected him to find pictures of a mysterious third child who had tragically died of something. And the resulting heartache would bring Jack and Kate together as never before. It didn't happen, but I'm prepared to bet it was there in an earlier draft. Never before has a Yuletide film's celebration of family been so self-centred. It's a Wonderful Life was about the difference one man had made to an entire community - through sacrifice. Here, Jack yearns for happiness and redemption within his tight little family unit. When he wakes up back in his old life, consumed with a Scrooge-like zeal for amendment, he seeks out Kate, herself naturally coarsened by non-non-profit legal work. And the movie concludes by appearing to suggest that they can have the lovely family life and yet keep pulling down the big Manhattan bucks at the same time. An appropriate dénouement for this smug movie.

fields.headline: MPs demand Axa inquiry
fields.standfirst:
High court verdict gives policyholders only a small share of £1.7bn surplus

Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: High court verdict gives policyholders only a small share of £1.7bn surplus
fields.body:
MPs and consumer groups demanded an urgent inquiry into the life insurance sector after a court verdict yesterday allowing insurer Axa to retain control of the bulk of its £1.7bn surplus cash pile and hand over only a small proportion to policyholders.

At the high court, Mr Justice Evans-Lombe said he had reached the "clear conclusion" that he should approve the French insurer's scheme for dividing up the money. It involves cash payments being made to up to 660,000 policyholders in return for them surrendering any future claims to the bulk of the orphan assets.

Vincent Cable MP, the Liberal Democrat trade and industry spokesman, claimed the planned distribution of Axa's "orphan assets", money which has been built up over decades from surpluses and unclaimed policies, was "little better than legalised theft", while the Consumers' Association denounced the ruling as a "stitch-up".

The CA, which opposed the scheme, said the ruling paved the way for other insurers sitting on a total of £20bn of orphan assets to mount similar "smash and grab operations".

It had argued Axa was offering policyholders a poor deal because it is handing them only £225m of the £1.7bn, plus an up front cash payment averaging £400 each in return for giving up their right to any future distribution.

The £225m will be paid to policyholders in the form of bonuses that will be added to their policies while the £300m for the cash payments will come from shareholders' funds. It was originally planned that these payments would be made in February 2001, but this is now unlikely to happen until May or June.

Axa's barrister, David Richards QC, told the court the scheme had been backed by an independent actuary and had not been opposed by the financial services authority. Some 78% of policyholders have already accepted the deal. Retaining the bulk of the orphan assets - also known as inherited estate - will benefit all policyholders because it gives the company greater investment freedom and enables it to be cushioned from unpleasant shocks, he said.

But a group of 1,800 unhappy policyholders backed by the CA argued that they were entitled to a much larger slice of the total. They said orphan assets are policyholders' money, much of which has come from unclaimed policy proceeds and as a result of companies not paying adequate bonuses, and that the scheme is all about transferring money to shareholders.

About 455,000 policyholders have chosen to take the cash payments and back the plan. The judge said he would give full reasons for his decision at a later date.

After the case Axa chief executive Mark Wood said the verdict was a good result for policyholders but unless it hears in the next few days that there will not be an appeal, the payouts are likely to be delayed for a few months.

Ashley Holmes, the CA's head of legal affairs, said it would be considering whether to appeal. He said the verdict "shows the system has let down policyholders", and added: "You can bet your bottom dollar the industry is watching this closely, and we will see other deals like this coming forward over the next few months."

Calling on the chancellor to establish a public inquiry into all aspects of the life insurance and pensions industry, the organisation said Axa and Equitable Life "are a symptom of what is wrong with the with-profits industry, namely lack of corporate accountability, secrecy and failures of regulatory oversight".

It is estimated that UK life insurance companies are sitting on £20bn of orphan assets, with the Prudential thought to account for £6bn-£8bn of this, and CGNU £5bn.

webTitle: OFT to act on hidden banking charges

fields.headline: OFT to act on hidden banking charges
fields.standfirst:
Treasury halves big four's £1.25bn take on plastic and direct debits

Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Treasury halves big four's £1.25bn take on plastic and direct debits.
fields.body:
Hidden charges for buying goods on plastic cards and setting up direct debits, worth £1.25bn a year to the big four banks, are set to be slashed following new measures to regulate the payments system announced yesterday.

Banks at present charge retailers up to 3% for credit card transactions and 20p for accepting debit cards such as Switch and Delta, earning them around £750m a year. Small businesses also typically pay £1 for every cheque paid in or out and 70p for direct debits and standing orders.

But the Treasury said yesterday it is determined to halve these charges by setting up a new division within the office of fair trading which will closely monitor costs and prices and publicise those who overcharge. It will also throw open the payments system to entrants such as internet and telephone banks and prevent the existing banks from stifling competition.

Benefits to consumers are likely to be indirect - in the form of lower shop prices - although it is expected that OFT scrutiny will see excessive charges for overdrafts and returned cheques reduced.

The Treasury also stepped back from giving powers to the OFT to set cash machine charges, preferring to oblige banks to make their charges widely known and easily compared with other providers.

Delays in cheque clearing - where banks earn interest on money for three to four days before crediting accounts - is also expected to come under pressure from the OFT, as is the £13bn to £20bn that is held in small business accounts but which earns little or no interest.

"Payment systems are the lifeblood of the economy. En suring that they are competitive and workefficiently will bring benefits and better service to business and consumers," said OFT director-general John Vickers.

The proposals, which are unlikely to come into force until 2002, follow recommendations made by Don Cruickshank in his report, Competition in UK Banking.

But the Treasury and Mr Cruickshank moved quickly to stamp on suggestions that the measures are a softening of an original recommendation to set up a separate payments regulator, dubbed Paycom.

Mr Cruickshank said: "There have been many media queries suggesting that my recommendations have somehow been watered down, or rejected, because something called Paycom will not be created. In fact, I was eager to propose, and delighted that the chancellor has accepted, the idea that the consumer will be best served by arming the OFT with specific powers and resources to deal with competition problems in payment systems."

The major banks gave a low-key reception to the proposals. A Barclays spokeswoman said: "We are studying the proposals. It is sensible to use an existing regulator rather than go through the expense and time of setting up a new one."

Consumer groups expressed concern that the proposals do not go far enough. Stuart Cliffe, spokesman for the National Association of Bank Customers, said: "This falls short of what was proposed by Don Cruickshank.

"We are relieved that someone has responsibility for keeping a check on the industry, but it should have been a regulatory body with no other responsibilities, not the OFT, which already has plenty of other matters to worry about."

fields.headline: Matthias Goerne/Eric Schneider
fields.standfirst:
Wigmore Hall
London
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
Wigmore Hall
London
Rating: ****
fields.body:
Having shared a programme with Dorothea Röschmann two days previously, German baritone Matthias Goerne returned to the Wigmore Hall to claim the limelight for his own. Still in his early 30s, Goerne is perhaps the most exciting Lieder singer to have emerged during the last few years. His voice is extraordinary - smooth, pure and intoxicating - and this is bound up with an intense, compelling stage presence and absolute commitment to the music he sings. His programme consisted of songs by Mahler, all but two of them settings of the various folk verses and ballads contained in Des Knaben Wunderhorn.

Some of these are tragic, some flippant, some bleakly romantic. Goerne chose to up the intensity by performing together groups of songs with a similar feel, with no interjections of conflicting moods. The result was a remarkable recital. The warmth and resonance in Goerne's voice was apparent from his very first notes, and ample demonstrations of a formidable technical agility followed shortly afterwards. There are few people who can sing high notes so quietly and yet so evenly.

Indeed, one rarely can criticise performers for sounding too well prepared, but Goerne's technique seems so safe and secure that there is little he can do that will sound to the audience like a risk. It is the rough edges - even the barely perceptible ones - that go towards making a live performance more exciting than a recording, and Goerne's performances are almost too thoughtful, too polished.

Having said that, there were many points during the evening at which the audience was hanging on Goerne's every note - the last phrase of Urlicht (the song that Mahler included in his Second Symphony), the final Gute Nacht of the drummer-boy's song. A thrillingly strong crescendo in the penultimate verse of Der Schildwache Nachtlied was transformed in an instant into the enchantingly soft closing phrases. Though usually presenting a serious face, eyes staring or brow furrowed in concentration, Goerne switched from doom-laden lover to raconteur for five light-hearted settings. Lob des hohen Verstandes found him imitating cuckoos, donkeys and nightingales with equal earnestness.

Unfortunately, the pianist Eric Schneider didn't share his confidence and sounded nervous from the start. It's obvious that Goerne enjoys working with Schneider but, on the strength of this performance, he seems to have outclassed his accompanist. Many of these songs were originally written with full orchestra rather than keyboard in mind, but the piano reductions failed to sparkle and Mahler's wide palette of instrumental colour was left largely to the listener's imagination. Goerne still carried this recital off effortlessly, but left us wondering what he could accomplish with a pianist of a similarly high calibre.

webTitle: Theatre review: A Servant to Two Masters

fields.headline: A Servant to Two Masters
fields.standfirst:
New Ambassadors
London
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
New Ambassadors
London
Rating: ***
fields.body:
The alternative to pantomime is dished up in Lee Hall's deliciously enjoyable adaptation of Carlo Goldoni's 18th-century farce about the wily Truffaldino, who downsizes the servant economy and doubles his own pay by signing up to two different masters. But something curious has happened to Tim Supple's Royal Shakespeare Company production since it first played London at the Young Vic almost a year ago.

It is still sharp and funny, and Hall's easy, colloquial version makes the whole affair seem contemporary. It plays like a dream, allowing room for the actors to improvise and elaborate. But somehow you can now see all the artifice in it. At the Young Vic, audience and actors were engaged in a complicity of enjoyment, but at the New Ambassadors that has somewhat evaporated. The actors have to work much harder and the effort shows.

You could dismiss this as being the curse of the West End, but a more reasoned explanation is that it is about the complex alchemy of productions and spaces. At the Young Vic, the openness of the space matched the expansiveness of the production and performances - in particular Jason Watkins's athletic Truffaldino, whose two masters turn out, in best farcical tradition, to have been searching for each other throughout Venice. On a convetional West End stage it starts to look tricksy, even cute. You wonder why Truffaldino is turning cartwheels rather than trying to save his own skin and preventing everyone finding out about his ruse. Still, Truffaldino's disbelief that there can really be a pudding called Spotted Dick still brings down the house. And even with a cross-arch stage, Watkins knows how to work an audience.

This isn't the first time, and it won't be the last, that audiences at a show transferred to the West End wonder why it has arrived with such enthusiastic notices. But if my enthusiasm for Two Masters is now more measured than it was, it is still a far more enjoyable and worthwhile evening than an awful lot of West End pap.

It is also worth seeing for two really winning performances. The first is from Watkins, one of those hard-working actors who have been around an age doing unsung work and really deserve to be stars. The second is from Rachel Saunders whose cross-dressing Beatrice has all the sexy appeal of a panto principal boy and all the tragic desperation of a Juliet.

 Until February 3. Box office: 020-7369 1761.

fields.headline: Manchester's Pinero romp
fields.standfirst:
The Magistrate
Royal Exchange
Manchester
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
The Magistrate
Royal Exchange
Manchester
Rating: ****
fields.body:
As warming as a glass of the best malt wine, Arthur Wing Pinero's whimsical comedy is a convivial romp through the drawing rooms and drinking dens of Victorian London. Indeed, Pinero's socially conscious late 19th-century plays brought credibility to the farce as a genre in England, and he was soon championed by the other great dramatist of his era, George Bernard Shaw.

Gently exposing the hypocrisy behind the well-upholstered manners and morals of the upper middle-class, The Magistrate follows the misfortunes of the Posket family in a tale of much dissembling. Having deceived her second husband - Aeneas, the magistrate - about her age, Agatha Posket has had to corroborate her story by telling him that her son, Cis, from her previous marriage, is 14 when he is actually 19. And when this secret is threatened by the appearance of the boy's godfather, Colonel Lukyn, Agatha is drawn further into mischievous plotting.

Helen Atkinson Wood has great fun as the ostentatious and manipulative Mrs Posket, worrying her skirts with melodramatic gestures, or scheming with an affected determination. Dominic Hecht as the son who has inherited his mother's love of frolics is equally impressive. In breeches one moment and in gentleman's evening dress the next, he dashes hither and thither with a fruity petulance that can not be placated. He runs his poor step-father ragged, and Richard O'Callaghan gives a painstakingly funny performance as the magistrate trying to preserve the honourable institutions of family and law.

Designed by Robert Jones, the attractive sets switch from the quiet green decor of the drawing room to the strikingly dark and decadent red of the gentleman's club, and from there to the black-painted wooden austerity of the court offices. In between, there are well-worked street scenes across a black cobbled floor, and you really do get a sense of Victorian London in a play that name-checks many of the capital's streets and districts.

Greg Hersov's lavish production scours every pun and misunderstanding for laughs, and there are excellent performances from the supporting cast. Russell Dixon is very funny as the by turns ebullient and wittering Colonel Lukyn, and he develops an amusing rapport with Simon Treves as the broken-hearted Captain Vale, whose melancholy knows no bounds. Indeed, every member of the beautifully-costumed, 16-strong cast adds to the fun.

Although two and a half hours may be a little long for a top-hat-and-bonnet farce, it is the season of self-indulgence - so why not go see?

 Until January 27. Box office: 0161-833 9833.

fields.headline: Glamour and gutsiness - par for the Corrs
fields.standfirst:
The Corrs
Wembley Arena
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
The Corrs
Wembley Arena
Rating: ***
fields.body:
The Corrs may resemble an experiment in supermodel cloning, but it's refreshing to learn that they aren't always as perfectly lip-glossed and blow-dried as their publicity photos suggest. Andrea Corr, swishy pop glamourpuss, seemed positively flustered as she took the stage. She apologised shakily for her extreme nervousness, explaining at unnecessary length how she had been panicked by a problem with the sound equipment.

But after 10 years of performing together, the Corrs have developed a leathery hide of professionalism behind those horrifyingly perfect features, and normal service was swiftly resumed. And, for a band dismissed as frothy lightweights, they've added a sting in the tail and given their music a kick up the backside.

Much of this is down to Caroline Corr's thunderous performance on the drums, which brings extra steeliness even to an airy pop souffle such as So Young. Rolling Stones sticksman Charlie Watts is said to be a fan, and it's possible to detect something of his own rock-steady beat and unswerving timekeeping in her playing. The big difference is that Caroline hits her drums twice as hard, whipping up a ferocious head of steam in I Never Loved You Anyway, and battering the daylights out of Breathless.

Without this rhythmic backbone, beefed up with throaty guitar chords from brother Jim, the combo could easily lapse into bland frilliness, and indeed did so on stuff such as Listen to the Radio and the soap-operatic Queen of Hollywood. As for their rocked-up Irish jigs, they should be seized by the scruff of the neck and escorted off the premises. But the troupe really come into their own when they succumb to their love of 1970s soft-rock. They'll not find a better song to cover than Fleetwood Mac's Dreams, a perfect fit for their shimmering vocal harmonies wreathed in Celtic twilight. Running it close was All the Love in the World, sung by the three sisters ranged across the stage on stools, and tear-jerkingly evocative of Carole King and the Carpenters. Maybe the Corrs will turn out like Tina Turner - the longer they do it, the better it gets.

fields.bodyText: The Corrs may resemble an experiment in supermodel cloning, but it's refreshing to learn that they aren't always as perfectly lip-glossed and blow-dried as their publicity photos suggest. Andrea Corr, swishy pop glamourpuss, seemed positively flustered as she took the stage. She apologised shakily for her extreme nervousness, explaining at unnecessary length how she had been panicked by a problem with the sound equipment. But after 10 years of performing together, the Corrs have developed a leathery hide of professionalism behind those horrifyingly perfect features, and normal service was swiftly resumed. And, for a band dismissed as frothy lightweights, they've added a sting in the tail and given their music a kick up the backside. Much of this is down to Caroline Corr's thunderous performance on the drums, which brings extra steeliness even to an airy pop souffle such as So Young. Rolling Stones sticksman Charlie Watts is said to be a fan, and it's possible to detect something of his own rock-steady beat and unswerving timekeeping in her playing. The big difference is that Caroline hits her drums twice as hard, whipping up a ferocious head of steam in I Never Loved You Anyway, and battering the daylights out of Breathless. Without this rhythmic backbone, beefed up with throaty guitar chords from brother Jim, the combo could easily lapse into bland frilliness, and indeed did so on stuff such as Listen to the Radio and the soap-operatic Queen of Hollywood. As for their rocked-up Irish jigs, they should be seized by the scruff of the neck and escorted off the premises. But the troupe really come into their own when they succumb to their love of 1970s soft-rock. They'll not find a better song to cover than Fleetwood Mac's Dreams, a perfect fit for their shimmering vocal harmonies wreathed in Celtic twilight. Running it close was All the Love in the World, sung by the three sisters ranged across the stage on stools, and tear-jerkingly evocative of Carole King and the Carpenters. webTitle: Dance review: Magic rubs off for Edinburgh Aladdin

fields.headline: Magic rubs off for Edinburgh Aladdin
fields.standfirst:
Aladdin
Edinburgh Festival Theatre
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
Aladdin
Edinburgh Festival Theatre
Rating: ***
fields.body:
Opening in the darkest week of Edinburgh's year, Scottish Ballet's new production of Aladdin oozed oriental magic. It cuts away from the Disney treatment, body-swerves a camp Widow Twankey pantomime style and goes for a picture-book Chinatown look - full of dancing dragons and brilliant reds and golds.

Choreographer Robert Cohan heads an impressive collaborative line-up. Carl Davies, composer of film and television scores (The French Lieutenant's Woman, Pride and Prejudice) makes the music. Lez Brotherston, outfitter and set designer to Matthew Bourne's Swan Lake, frames the story in red and black. Colin Falconer dresses up the dance for everyone who likes a costume change.

Frames within frames, the set opens doors to the many scenes of the story. The village, the cave of jewels, the sultan's court, the princess's boudoir - all dovetail together in this neat and clean version. Deep black space projects the stained-glass colour of costumes and props. The mechanics of carpet flying and sliding scenery is as smooth as silk. The disappearing acts (such as the eye-popping death of the evil magician) and conjurings by illusionist Paul Kieve are wonderfully impossible. The company seems youthful, sure-footed and rejoice in a cheekily talented Aladdin from Jesus Pastor and Linda Packer's sweet-pea princess. So why does this lavish production feel flat?

Could it be that the music, with its splendidly carved filmic crescendos, is a tad on the big side for the body of the dance? Could it be that the length - though full of incidental action - requires some pruning? Could it be that, despite all the special effects, the magic lamp itself just does not work? The lamp, with its sleeping genie, is right at the heart of the story, and it should amaze us with power. It doesn't. The genie is a whiz of modern technology, dazzling us in green laser light, but he's two-dimensional, with no part to play.

The dance, too, lacks presence. Though a leading member of the contemporary dance revolution in this country, Cohan takes no risks and sticks to safe, familiar balletic routines. But there is one gem. After a chitter-chattering, somersaulting village scene, Aladdin drops down a clever trapdoor into the dark, starry depths of the treasure cave, and a whirl of shiny tutus and silverskin suits begins as the jewels dance. The orchestra rolls out a grand sound for the ballerinas, pitching the white, blue, red and green set pieces from romantic bells to tick-tock rhythm. With a waltzing homage to Tchaikovsky towards the end, it's the highlight of the evening.

Scottish Ballet's Aladdin is described in the programme as a new "classic". Surely that is something only time will tell.

 Until December 30. Box office: 0131-529 6000.
